Given Mr. Doe's age  sex  and lifestyle factors such as smoking and sedentary behaviour  as well as his medical history of hypertension  diabetes and hypercholesterolemia  he is at considerable risk for AAA. Early diagnosis and appropriate management can help prevent life-threatening complications such as aortic rupture.   Communication Plan  The management plan will be communicated to the patient and his family including the potential need for medication adjustments  lifestyle modifications and possibly  surgical intervention. They will be educated about the importance of regular follow-up visits and immediate medical attention if pain becomes sharp or severe suddenly.

Subject: Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain and lower back discomfort for the past few weeks. He is a retired construction worker and he lives with his wife only. Mr. Smith is a non-vegetarian and has a history of tobacco usage for around 50 years  around a packet of cigarettes daily; however  has successfully quit smoking 6 months ago. He also consumed alcohol socially. He denied using any illicit drugs.  Medical History:  Mr. Smith's medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol  diagnosed approximately ten years ago for which he is under medication. His blood pressure and cholesterol levels are moderately controlled. He has no known allergies and is not on any regular medications apart from his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering agents.  He has undergone an appendectomy at age 25  but no other surgical history exists. He reports a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 64 and his elder brother underwent an angioplasty at age 60.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Smith describes an episodic sensation of deep  gnawing pain in his lower abdomen that tends to radiate to his lower back. Initially  the discomfort was mild but has gradually become more noticeable and consistent  prompting him to seek medical consultation. He also reports recent unintentional weight loss but denies any change in bowel habits  chest pain  or palpitations.  Given his symptoms and prominent risk factors like age  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  and family history of cardiovascular disease  a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is suspected.   Further examination and medical imaging will be necessary in order to validate this suspicion  assess the size of the aneurysm  and make an appropriate plan for treatment given the presence and severity of Mr. Smith’s AAA.

Title: Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Name: Mr. James Robinson Gender: Male Age: 64 Address: 485 Barrydale Street  Brownwood  TX  78242 Occupation: Retired Mechanic Marital status: Married  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Robinson presented to the clinic with a complaint of intermittent  dull  gnawing abdominal pain and more recently a constant pain in his lower back region over the last week. He notes his pain seems to be non-positional and does not correlate with meals.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension - Diagnosed 15 years ago  treated with prescribed antihypertensive drugs. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with dietary modifications and Metformin. Recent HbA1c checked 3 months ago was 6.9%. 3. Hyperlipidemia – Diagnosed 10 years ago  treated with Statin therapy. 4. A history of 30 pack years of smoking  but he quit 5 years ago. 5. There is no history of any previous surgeries or known allergies.  Family History:  Father suffered a stroke in his late 60s and mother has hypertension.  Physical assessment:  On general examination the Patient is comfortable  alert  and oriented to person  place  and time. His blood pressure records as 145/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 78 bpm  temperature of 98.7 Fahrenheit  body mass index-28. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen  slightly above the umbilicus.   This available information might suggest the possibility of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). Further diagnostic procedures such as abdomen ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and stage the severity of the AAA. The patient’s medical management will be appropriately adjusted as per the findings.   Conclusion: Mr. Robinson is a 64-year-old male with a significant past medical history and classic symptoms highly indicative of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. Immediate care is needed to address and manage the potential AAA to prevent potentially life-threatening complications.

Title: Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  I. Demographic Information: Patient's Name: Smith  John Doe Age: 72 Years Old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Insurance: Medicare Location: Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania   II. Chief Complaint:   Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with the complaint of sudden and severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain began a few hours ago while he was at home and has gradually been increasing. He describes the pain as sharp  tearing and located in the center of his abdomen.   III. Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on antihypertensive and statin medication for the past ten years. He quit smoking 5 years ago but had a 20-year history of 1-pack-a-day cigarette use prior to quitting. He also has a family history of aneurysmal diseases - his brother had an aortic aneurysm five years ago. Mr. Smith admits to consuming alcohol moderately and has no history of drug use. He is not diabetic  doesn't have any known heart diseases  or a history of stroke.   IV. Physical Evaluation:   Physical examination found a pulsatile mass in his abdomen  with some tenderness upon palpation. His blood pressure was hypertensive at 160/95 mmHg  heart rate was 88 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation was 97% while breathing room air. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  In conclusion  the past history of smoking  family history of aneurysm  and current symptoms provide significant suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further radiological investigations (such as Abdominal Ultrasound  CT scan or MRI) are recommended to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the size and feasibility of surgical intervention.

Patient Presentation  Good day  everyone. Today we'll discuss Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents with moderate to severe abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back  a hallmark symptom of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).  He is a retired engineer and a smoker with a 25-year-history of consuming 1 pack per day. Doe lives in the suburbs with his wife and cat. He is an avid gardener and enjoys regular walks around his neighborhood. However  his activity has been declining due to increasing discomfort.  Doe has a significant medical history. He has been under treatment for Hypertension for the past 20 years and was diagnosed 5 years ago with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  for which he takes Metformin. He has been rather complacent about managing his blood sugar levels and monitoring his diet. His blood pressure readings have been consistently high in the last few doctor visits. He does not have notable family medical history of AAA. However  his father passed away due to complications related to heart disease.  Upon further examination  the doctor noted a pulsatile mass in his abdomen  a typical AAA sign. Considering his risk factors (age  gender  smoking history  hypertension  reputation for neglecting his diabetic condition)  Mr. Doe was scheduled for a diagnostic ultrasound which confirmed the existence of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm measuring approximately 5 cm in diameter.  Currently  we are developing a comprehensive care plan for Mr. Doe that includes both medical and surgical intervention alongside lifestyle changes to manage his AAA and prevent any catastrophic events such as a rupture. This includes quitting smoking and adopting a healthier diet and exercise regime to better manage his blood pressure and diabetes.  Further discussions will focus on the potential surgical intervention if the aneurysm advances or if any signs present that suggest a higher risk of rupture. The risk associated with surgery will need to be weighed against the potential benefits. Meanwhile  we will closely monitor Mr. Doe for changes in his symptoms or aneurysm size.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Caucasian Male   Introduction:  Patient J.D.  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in Dallas  Texas. He is retired and has a 35-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day  but quit 5 years ago. He lives with his wife and has 2 adult children.  Medical History:  J.D. has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been treated for these conditions for the past 10 years. His other medical conditions include osteoarthritis and a remote history of pulmonary tuberculosis treated 40 years ago. He has no known allergies. During the most recent visit  he came in complaining of intermittent abdominal pain  lower back pain  and mild unintentional weight loss over the past few months.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  his heart rate is 78 beats/min  blood pressure is 146/87 mmHg  temperature is 37.1°C  and respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. Rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Given his age  smoking history  and the palpable abdominal mass  abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was suspected. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a 5.6 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment:  Due to the size of the aneurysm and symptomatic nature  it was recommended that J.D. undergo electively surgical intervention in the form of an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).  Follow Up & Patient Counseling:  For long term management  he has been recommended diligent control of his blood pressure and regular follow-ups are required to monitor the status of the repair. He has also been advised on maintaining a balanced diet  regular exercise  and other lifestyle modifications to prevent further cardiovascular events. The importance of regular monitoring of his AAA and overall vascular health was discussed with him and his family.  Concluding Remarks:  While J.D.'s AAA was successfully identified and managed  his case highlights the importance of being aware of subtle symptoms and regular vascular screening in people with risk factors such as advanced age  smoking  and hypertension.

Title: A Case Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith is a 73-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the hospital with complaints of severe and sharp abdominal and back pain. His intense pain was sudden in onset. He comes from a suburban community  lives with his wife  and is a retired truck driver. He has a history of excessive smoking  consuming 2 packs of cigarettes a day for the past 45 years  though he claims to have quit 3 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally but denies using illicit drugs. He has three children – two sons and a daughter  all of whom are alive and well.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension that has been poorly controlled over the years. He has been on anti-hypertensive medications for the past 15 years  but admits to non-compliance with his medication regimen. He was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 10 years ago  for which he takes statin therapy inconsistently. He has a documented history of coronary artery disease and underwent a coronary angioplasty 7 years ago.  He does not have Diabetes Mellitus  Tuberculosis or any lung diseases. No familial history of cardiovascular disease or aneurysm was reported. He has no known drug allergies.   Social and Family History: As considered above  Mr. Smith has been a heavy smoker  though he quit 3 years back. He drinks alcohol but does not currently use illicit drugs. His father passed away due to lung cancer  and his mother died due to cerebrovascular accident. No significant familial history of aneurysm or cardiovascular disease exists. He lives with his wife and she is his primary caregiver.  Current Presentation: Mr. Smith’s current episode of severe abdominal and back pain  in light of his demographics  personal medical history including his long smoking history and poorly controlled hypertension  gives rise to suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Recent physical examination reveals an abdominal bruit  a pulsating abdominal mass  and tenderness on deep palpation of the abdomen. Further diagnostic testing needs to be confirmed.  This drafted case presentation has disclosed the demographic information  pertinent medical history  and present condition of Mr. Smith in relation to a potential diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male  Patient: Mr. X  Age: 75 years  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired (Former Electrician)  Epidemiological Data: Resides in a semi-urban area in South Florida.  Presentation: Mr. X presents with a two-day history of severe constant back and abdominal pain which was gradually escalating. He also experienced mild dizziness and was feeling generally unwell. He has a history of smoking and moderate alcohol use  which he quit five years ago. He denies any recent trauma or injury.  Past Medical History: 1. Observed hypertension for the past 15 years. 2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II - diagnosed ten years ago. 3. Hypercholesterolemia - diagnosed eight years ago. 4. Myocardial infarction recovery - 5 years ago. No subsequent episodes. 5. Retired electrician with over 40 years of documented asbestos exposure - high-risk factor for atherosclerosis  vascular damages.  Mr. X has been on medication for his hypertension and diabetes. He is currently on Lisinopril and Metformin. He regularly takes Atorvastatin for his cholesterol. He had completed cardiac rehabilitative therapy post his myocardial infarction.  Family History: Both parents died of cardiovascular complications in their late sixties. He has one elder brother who is presently managing similar complications related to hypertension and heart disease.   Social History: He is a widower for the last three years and lives alone  enjoying occasional visits from his children and grandchildren. He quit smoking and alcohol five years ago  post the cardiac event. He enjoys walks with his dog and indoor gardening.  Conclusion: Given the patient's history of hypertension  diabetes Mellitus Type II  hypercholesterolemia  smoking and asbestos exposure  and current symptoms  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected. His advanced age  family history  and condition keep him at high risk. Immediate imaging studies and vascular surgical consultation are being arranged for confirmatory diagnosis and subsequent management.

Title: Clinical Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information: Mr. Benjamin Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  a retired long-distance truck driver who lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia both of which have been managed through medication for the past 12 years. He has been a smoker for approximately 40 years with moderate to heavy consumption (one pack/day).   Reason for Visit: Mr. Smith presents to the ER with the chief complaint of sudden severe abdominal pain  described as sharp and constant  which started a couple of hours ago accompanied with nausea. There is no relief or exacerbation with position changes. He also reports a feeling of a pulsation within his abdomen and a minor unexplained weight loss in the last few months.  Physical Examination: Blood pressure is slightly elevated at rest (145/90 mmHg). He shows signs of tenderness on palpation in the mid-to-lower abdomen. He has a visible and palpable abdominal mass which is pulsatile. His abdomen also exhibits distension and rigidity.   Diagnostic Tools: An ultrasound of the abdomen is recommended  the most sensitive test for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. If confirmed  a CT scan or MRI will be used to glen more detail about the size and shape of the aneurysm.  Summary: Mr. Smith's presentation of sudden severe abdominal pain  a pulsatile abdominal mass  a history of hypertension  a long history of smoking  tends to suggest a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic imaging tests are required to confirm this diagnosis  and immediate intervention may be necessary given the high mortality rate associated with ruptured aortic aneurysms. As this is a life-threatening situation  decisions on the best approach to this condition should be done soon. If left unattended  the patient might further destabilize and develop shock. The management pathway might include either endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or open surgical repair.

Slide 1: Introduction  We are presenting the case of Mr. Alan Thompson  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  retired automobile mechanic  living in Ohio  who has been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Slide 2: Past Medical History  Mr. Thompson has been a smoker for the past 50 years  with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. In 1998  he had a myocardial infarction  which was managed with angioplasty and stent placement. He is currently on a regimen of Aspirin  Lipitor  and Lisinopril.  Slide 3: Latest Presentation  Upon his latest visit  Mr. Thompson complained of abdominal and back pain  particularly on the left side  which he had been experiencing for about a month. He described the pain as a deep  constant ache. No loss of appetite  weight changes  or changes in bladder or bowel habits were reported.  Slide 4: Physical Examination  On physical examination  Mr. Thompson appears to be in mild distress due to pain. Abdominal exam revealed a pulsatile mass in the middle and upper segments of the abdomen. No bruits were audible. There were no signs of distal ischemia. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 150/90 mmHg.  Slide 5: Diagnosis   A subsequent CT Angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of a 5.6 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. It started below the renal arteries and extended to the aortic bifurcation.  Slide 6: Management Plan  Considering the size of the aneurysm and Mr. Thompson's symptoms  surgical intervention was recommended. Mr. Thompson has been scheduled for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). He has also been advised to quit smoking  maintain a healthy diet  and control his blood pressure and cholesterol levels to prevent the growth of the aneurysm.  Slide 7: Conclusion  Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt diagnosis and appropriate management. In this case  a combination of patient’s history  physical examination  and imaging studies facilitated the timely diagnosis and treatment. Mr. Thompson’s case highlights the importance of maintaining a high level of suspicion for AAA in older males  especially those with a history of smoking  hypertension  and heart disease.

Title: Patient Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: Mr. Roger Davis  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented at our healthcare facility today with a chief complaint of consistent lower back and abdominal pain. Born and raised in Maryland  he is a retired army officer who lives alone. He is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. However  his dietary habits are not particularly healthy - red meat consumption is high and vegetable intake is poor. Mr. Davis does engage in light exercise (walking) three times a week. Additionally  he has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father passed away at 76 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Past Medical History: Mr. Davis has been regularly monitored for hypertension since he was 55 years old. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus at age 68  both of which have also been closely managed. He had an appendectomy at age 35 and an inguinal hernia repair at 50. There is no history of other cardiovascular diseases  pulmonary diseases  gastrointestinal disease  or neurological disorders. He has been receiving regular healthcare and adhering to diabetes and hypertension management guidelines. His medication regimen includes metformin  atenolol  and a statin. There is no known drug allergy.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Davis came to the facility complaining of an intense  persistent pain in the lower back and abdomen area  as well as occasional episodes of lightheadedness. He does not recall any inciting event or injury. The lower back pain radiated to the flanks and groin area  which started about a week ago. The pain is not associated with food intake  bowel movements  or position.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appeared in mild to moderate distress due to pain. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  heart rate of 80 bpm  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. The neurological examination was normal. A bruit was heard over the epigastric area. The abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the peri-umbilical region. No other significant abnormalities were seen.  Based on his family history  clinical symptoms  and physical examination findings  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected. The patient has been recommended for further imaging studies  including an abdominal ultrasound and CT scan  to confirm the diagnosis and determine the size and extent of the aneurysm. The vascular surgery team has been consulted for potential surgical intervention.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient.  Patient Information:   The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male named John Smith  retired  who lives with his spouse in the suburbs. He is a former heavy smoker  having smoked about a pack of cigarettes per day for nearly 45 years  but has reported to have stopped completely for the past six years. The patient also has a moderate intake of alcohol - about three to four standard drinks per week. His BMI is 27  indicating that he is in the overweight category.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known medical history of hypertension for which he is currently taking Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago and is on Atorvastatin. He has no known history of diabetes  but does have a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). He underwent a left total knee replacement surgery ten years ago due to osteoarthritis.  Family History:  Mr. Smith's father died of heart disease at the age of 72. His mother is living  and has well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. One of his two brothers died at an early age from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). His sister has no known cardiac history.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presented to the ER with a 48-hour history of mid-abdominal pain that he described as throbbing and relentless  but not sharp or changing with position. He reported occasionally feeling the pain in his lower back. He also stated that he felt light-headed and had nearly fainted several times. These new symptoms  in the context of his family history  suggested the potential for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Current Medications:  He takes Lisinopril 20 mg once a day for his hypertension and Atorvastatin 40 mg once daily for his hyperlipidemia. No known drug allergies.  Conclusion:  In summary  Mr. Smith's long history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  coupled with his smoking history and family history of AAA  place him at increased risk for developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Therefore  despite his asymptomatic condition  it is crucial that his care team continuously monitors him and includes routine screening for AAA in his primary care assessments.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Introduction:  This presentation introduces Mr. Randy Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents an incidental finding of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).  Demographic:  Mr. Smith is a retired electrician  hailing from Burlington  Vermont. He lives with his wife  and they have two adult children who live out of state. The patient is a non-smoker but admits to having a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith visited the clinic for a routine check-up. During the examination  an incidental finding of AAA was identified during abdominal palpation  despite the absence of any significant abdominal or lower back pain symptoms usually associated with AAA.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith's medical history reveals hypertension diagnosed eight years ago  for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril). He also has a history of high cholesterol levels controlled through statin therapy (Atorvastatin). While he has no personal history of AAA  it is noteworthy that his late father had a ruptured AAA at the age of 70.  Physical Examination:  On general examination  Mr. Smith is a well-oriented elderly gentleman  slightly overweight for his height. Vitals on presentation were stable. On abdominal exam  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the mid-abdominal region.   Investigations and Diagnosis:  An abdominal ultrasound was performed  confirming an infrarenal AAA with a size of 3.5 cm. According to guidelines  this is in the ""watchful waiting"" category.  Plan:  The plan is to continue monitoring Mr. Smith's AAA through serial ultrasounds every six months to keep an eye on any change in the size of the aneurysm. Mr. Smith is counseled to continue his hypertensive and cholesterol medications diligently.  This presentation of Mr. Smith's Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm gives us an insight into his current health status and a probable course of management. His case highlights the importance of early detection even in asymptomatic individuals  paving the path for timely intervention and reducing the risk of complications.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 68 year-old Caucasian male presented himself to the Emergency Department.  Chief Complaint: He mainly complained of severe waxing and waning pain in the back and his abdominal area.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a known history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40-year history of smoking. He quit smoking two years ago. He has never been diagnosed with any form of diabetes or cancer but has a history of atherosclerosis in his family. His father passed away due to a rupture of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure was 165/95 on both arms  pulse rate was 90 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 20 breaths a minute. He is afebrile with a temperature of 36.8 Celsius. Further  there was noted a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation of his abdomen. No bruit could be distinguished over any of the vessels. No neurological deficits were detected.  Investigations: An urgent CT scan confirmed a large unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring seven cm in its largest diameter.  Summary: Patient  John Doe  a hypertensive  dyslipidemic  68-year-old man  ex-smoker with a strong family history of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  presents with severe abdominal and back pain. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. CT findings are indicative of a large unruptured AAA. He represents a high risk and requires close monitoring and potential surgical intervention.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Geriatric Patient  Patient Introduction: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired from his job as a truck driver  residing in Brooklyn  New York. He is a non-smoker and abstains from alcohol. He lives with his wife and has two adult children.   Presenting Complaint: The patient reports experiencing an unusual  recurring pain in his lower back and abdomen over the past month. The pain is not associated with food intake  bowel movements  movement  or any other specific activity. He also reports some unexpected weight loss and occasional bouts of dizziness.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and elevated cholesterol levels for the past 10 years  both well-managed with medications (Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia). He was also diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 5 years ago which is currently managed with Metformin therapy. There is no history of any surgery or other significant diseases. He has no known drug allergies.   Family History: Patient's father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his mother died of stroke at 78. One of his brothers was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease in his 60s.  Differential Diagnosis: Considering the presented symptoms  age  background  and family history  the working diagnosis is an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). Other differential diagnoses include renal calculi  diverticulosis  and lumbar spondylosis.   Plan: The next step will be to confirm the diagnosis and assess the aneurysm size and risk of rupture. This will involve imaging studies such as ultrasound and CT angiography. If AAA is confirmed  treatment will be determined based on the size of the aneurysm and the patient's overall health and risk factors. Management may include observation  endovascular aneurysm repair  or open surgical repair. Coordination of care with cardiology  vascular surgeons  and the patient's primary care provider will be essential in ensuring optimal outcomes.   In addition  lifestyle modifications and better glycemic control will be emphasized to manage risk factors and associated comorbidities.

Slide 1: Introduction - Patient Information: Mr. Charles Robertson - Age: 66 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Slide 2: Chief Complaint - Progressive and severe pain in the middle and lower parts of his abdomen  sometimes radiating to his back.  - The pain began three days ago  intermittently  but today it seems constant.  Slide 3: Medical History - Mr. Robertson was diagnosed with high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels around 15 years ago.  - He is currently managing his conditions with prescribed medication.  Slide 4: Smoking and Alcohol Consumption - He has a significant history of smoking (45 pack years) and moderate alcohol consumption.  Slide 5: Lifestyle - He leads a moderately sedentary lifestyle due to his age and limited mobility.  Slide 6: Family History  - There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 70 and his older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 68.  Slide 7: Summary - With the ongoing  severe abdominal pain  his past medical history and high-risk behaviors  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is strongly suspected for Mr. Robertson.  - He needs immediate medical attention to confirm the diagnosis and to prevent potential life-threatening complications.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Presentation  Patient Information: Patient  Mr. John Anderson  is a 69-year-old Caucasian male  a retired engineer resided in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a married individual and has no children. The patient has a history of smoking and is a moderate consumer of alcohol. He is non-diabetic and has no known drug allergies.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Anderson presents with severe abdominal and lower back pain that has persisted for a period of two weeks. The pain is described as constant with occasional episodes of sharp shooting sensation. He reports no change in intensity or relief with rest. He also reports a noticeable pulsating sensation near his navel.  Compiled Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a known history of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia which have been managed with antihypertensive (Lisinopril) and statins. He also had a prior diagnosis of Peripheral artery disease and has had stent placements conducted five years ago. Other significant past medical history includes Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) due to his history of smoking. He is non-diabetic and has no significant surgical history except for the aforementioned stent placement.  Family History: His father died at the age of 74 from a heart attack while his mother passed away at the age of 77 from stroke. His older brother has a history of Coronary artery disease.  Possible Diagnosis: Due to the persistent abdominal and back pain coupled with his medical history  an immediate suspicion of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is raised. His history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  peripheral artery disease and especially tobacco usage increase his risk for developing AAA.  Conclusion:  Consequently  further diagnostic imaging using Ultrasound or CT scan will be necessary to confirm the presence and extent of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Intervention will be determined based on the size and rate of growth of the aneurysm  along with the patient's overall health status. Risk factor modification  surveillance  and possible surgical repair options will be discussed with the patient once the diagnosis is confirmed.

Title: Patient Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction: We present a case of a 69 year old Caucasian male with abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is a native of New York City and works as a taxi driver. He's a former smoker and is currently living alone since his wife's death three years ago.   Medical History: His medical background comprises of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia which were diagnosed 10 years ago. Both conditions have been managed with antihypertensive (Lisinopril) and statin (Simvastatin) medications.   The patient also has a history of long-term smoking of approximately 30 years  however  he quit about 5 years ago. His family's medical history includes a father who died of aortic aneurysm at the age of 71 and a brother diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.  Current Symptoms and Signs: He visited the outpatient department primarily for a scheduled follow-up visit for hypertension. He casually mentioned a vague  dull pain persisting intermittently in his lower back and abdomen for the past several weeks. Additionally  he reported feeling full quickly after eating a small amount of food. He denied any recent changes bowel or urinary habits  any unexplained weight loss  and any chest pain or shortness of breath. Physical exam revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Assessment: Given his age  risk factors including history of long-term smoking and positive family history  along with the symptoms and physical findings  he was suspected for abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic studies  including imaging and lab tests  have been recommended for confirmation and to decide upon the appropriate next steps.  This case highlights the importance of careful symptom history and physical examination in detecting serious conditions like abdominal aortic aneurysm  especially amongst high-risk populations.

Title: Patient Presentation - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient: Mr. John Smith  Age: 72 years old  Sex: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presentation: Our patient Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use who presents today with a sudden onset of severe lower back pain that started 2 hours ago.  Vital Signs: His blood pressure on arrival was 150/95 mm Hg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  temperature normal at 98.6 F  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 93% on room air.  History: Mr. Smith is a retired banker lives with his wife in the city. The patient has a history of high blood pressure controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He reports being a smoker with a 50 pack-years history. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 7 years ago and is being managed on Simvastatin. He reports no allergies to medications. His surgical history includes a right total hip arthroplasty 10 years prior.  Medical History: Mr. Smith’s general practitioner diagnosed him with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which were managed through diet  exercise  and medication. His hypertension has been poorly controlled over the years. He does not have diabetes mellitus or any other known endocrine issues.  Examination: He appeared distressed due to pain. On examination  he was found to have a pulsatile mass in his abdomen  slightly tender to palpation. No other significant findings were present during the examination.  Impression: With the presenting symptoms  clinical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  longstanding tobacco use  and physical examination findings  the leading presumption is a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. A CT scan is urgently needed to confirm the diagnosis and help us plan the subsequent line of management.   Medications: He is on Lisinopril 10mg daily for his hypertension and Simvastatin 20mg daily for his hyperlipidemia. He does not take any antiplatelets or anticoagulants.   Conclusion: We urgently need to evaluate Mr. Smith  as an abdominal aortic aneurysm is a serious and life-threatening condition. His history of hypertension  and persistent cigarette smoking increases his risk. If we confirm the diagnosis  it is essential to discuss the surgical intervention with vascular surgery  alongside optimizing the medical management of his other risk factors.

Slide 1: Introduction  The patient is Mr. James Thompson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He reports recently experienced abnormal sensations in his abdomen  sometimes with severe pain radiating to his back  reported rapid pulse rate and episodes of fainting. His primary concern is that the pain is usually brought on by physical exercise.  Slide 2 : Demographic Information   Mr. Thompson resides in New York City and has recently retired from his long-term position as a construction surveyor. Lives alone. His daughter lives nearby  visits him regularly. He has been a smoker for about 30 years. Also  reports regular alcohol use.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Patient's medical history reveals hypertension for which he takes a beta-blocker. He has smoked for 30 years and has made multiple unsuccessful attempts to quit. Also  he was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease two years ago. No history of diabetes or heart-related diseases. His family history includes a father who died from a stroke and a mother who died of breast cancer.  Slide 4: Recent Medical Exams  Recently  an abdominal exam showed a pulsatile abdominal mass and abdominal bruit  which can suggest an abdominal aortic aneurysm. This was confirmed through Ultrasonography  which showed a 6 cm diameter of the abdominal aorta.  Slide 5: Conclusion   Keeping in mind the size of the aneurysm  his other medical conditions  and his age  it seems surgery is the most appropriate option for Mr. Thompson. Further discussion is needed to decide between open repair and endovascular repair. It is also crucial that Mr. Thompson quits smoking and limits alcohol intake to prevent further vascular complications.

Slide 1: Patient Presentation  Our patient for discussion today is Mr. John Bolton  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  professionally retired  with a complaint of severe mid-abdominal pain that occasionally radiates to the lower back.  Slide 2: Demographics  Mr. Bolton was born and raised in Newcastle  England. He is married with two adult children. He has a long history of tobacco use  having been a smoker for over 45 years. He has a past history of occasional alcohol use. His family history is notable for heart disease and hypertension.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. Bolton's past medical history is notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral vascular disease. He had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 and has been on long term treatment with aspirin  atorvastatin  and an ACE inhibitor  lisinopril for the past 9 years.   Slide 4: Physical Examination  On physical examination  Mr. Bolton's pulse was 95/min  blood pressure was 160/90 mm of Hg  respiratory rate was 18/min  and temperature was 98.7°F. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass and a bruit over the mass on auscultation.  Slide 5: Lab Tests  Laboratory tests including complete blood count  electrolytes  and renal function tests were essentially within normal limits. However  his cholesterol levels were slightly elevated.  Slide 6: Imaging  An abdominal ultrasound was suggestive of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. This was further confirmed by a CT angiogram  which showed a 5.5 cm aneurysm of the infra-renal abdominal aorta.  Slide 7: Diagnosis  Given his history of smoking  family history of heart disease  and hypertension  along with his presenting symptoms  physical exam findings  and imaging results  Mr. Bolton was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Slide 8: Management Plan  In view of the size of the aneurysm and his symptoms  options for both endovascular repair (EVAR) and open surgical repair were discussed with him. After due consideration of the risks and benefits of both options  Mr. Bolton elected to proceed with EVAR. His medications were optimized preoperatively  and he was referred for smoking cessation counseling as well.   Slide 9: Follow Up  Post-operative follow up will be done to monitor Mr. Bolton’s recovery process to evaluate the success of the treatment and to monitor any potential complications. Mr. Bolton will also be counseled to make lifestyle changes to manage hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Furthermore  the importance of his cessation of smoking will be reiterated.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Presentation   Patient Information: Mr. John Allen  an 75-year-old African-American male  presented with complaints of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  back pain  and persistent leg pain. He has been living at Mountain View Retirement Home  San Francisco for the last three years with his wife. The patient has retired from his occupation as a lawyer. He is a lifetime non-smoker  but reports a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Medical History: Mr. Allen has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia since last 10 years and is compliant on his regimen of Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. He had a smoking history of 30 pack-years but quit 15 years ago. He successfully underwent angioplasty due to coronary artery disease 5 years ago and has been following up with Cardiology clinic regularly. Furthermore  he has non-insulin dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus and manages it with Metformin 1000mg BID. Family history is significant with a father who died of a myocardial infarction and a mother with stroke.   Presenting Complaint: He reported a mild  but persistent  abdominal discomfort particularly below his navel which prompted his visit today. He describes the discomfort as a deep  throbbing sensation that increases with coughing or rapid movements. It is not associated with food or bowel movements. He denies any recent changes in bowel habits  urinary symptoms  or weight loss. He also denies any chest pain or shortness of breath.  Examination Findings: Upon examination  there is a palpable  pulsatile mass in his abdomen. Labs reveal a slightly elevated white cell count. The rest of the complete blood count  renal function  and liver function tests are within normal limits.   Imaging: CT scan of the abdomen confirmed a 5.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no signs of rupture or dissection.  Impression: Mr. Allen's clinical findings and imaging confirm the diagnosis of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given the size  the risk of rupture is high  and he should be considered for surgical intervention. The patient will be referred to vascular surgery for further management.   Prognosis: With prompt surgical treatment  the prognosis for abdominal aortic aneurysm is generally good. However  there's a risk of complications  such as kidney damage  heart attack or aortic dissection  both due to the condition itself and the surgical intervention. While we hope for the best outcomes  Mr. Allen will have to be closely monitored moving forward.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents today with a complaint of consistent and intense abdominal pain. He describes the pain as a deep  gnawing sensation  particularly severe after meals  localized in the upper abdominal area. The pain is often accompanied by a pulsating feeling near his navel. He has also reported an unexplained weight loss over the last six months.  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension and high cholesterol  both well-controlled with medication. He has been a smoker for the past 45 years with a significant pack-year history. His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease  specifically  his father died from a ruptured aortic aneurysm at the age of 75. He does not have any history of diabetes  kidney disease  or other major illnesses. His medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for the management of his high cholesterol levels.  On physical examination  Mr. Smith's blood pressure was noted to be 135/86 mmHg  pulse 78 bpm  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and body temperature 37°C. He appeared mildly pale. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass  approximately 4 cm in diameter  in the mid to lower abdomen.  Considering the patient's age  smoking history  family history  and hypertension  he is at a potential high risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). These suspicions are further raised by his presentation of abdominal pain and a pulsatile mass on examination. We recommend urgent imaging  preferably by CT angiography  to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size of the potential aneurysm.  If confirmed  prompt vascular surgical intervention is essential for Mr. Smith  considering his pain manifestation suggests potential imminent rupture of the AAA. His long-term management should focus on strict blood pressure control and smoking cessation.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in Patient  I. Introduction Today  I will present the case of a patient diagnosed with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).  II. Demographic Information The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He resides in a suburban area and is a retired engineer. He has been married for over 40 years  has two adult children  and leads an active lifestyle that includes routine exercise and healthy eating habits.   III. Past Medical History The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia and smoking 1 pack/day for approximately 40 years but had quit smoking 6 years ago. He is on Atorvastatin 40 mg daily for his elevated cholesterol levels. No history of diabetes or hypertension. There is a significant family history; his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and a paternal uncle had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   IV. Chief Complaint The patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe pain in the lower back and abdomen  described as a tearing sensation. The pain was not associated with any food intake  movements  or bowel habits.  V. Diagnosis and Treatment A CT scan confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.6 cm. An urgent surgical consult was requested  considering the size of the AAA and the patient's intense pain suggesting imminent rupture. The patient was taken to the operating room for an emergent open repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm.   VI. Follow-up and Prognosis Postoperatively  he was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring. He has since been discharged and is currently recovering well  attending regular follow-ups with the vascular surgeon. His prognosis is quite promising  maintaining a healthy lifestyle and following a rigorous post-operative plan.  In conclusion  consistent follow-ups and preventive care will play a critical role in this patient’s overall health. His case highlights the significant importance of family history in diagnosing conditions like an AAA and how early diagnosis can significantly increase the chances of successful treatment.

Title: A Case Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Demographics:  Mr. John  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker currently residing in Buffalo  New York  presented in our outpatient department. He is a non-smoker and denied any illicit drug use. His family history is significant  with his father dying from a ruptured aneurysm.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr John presented with a several week history of abdominal and lower back discomfort that is relievable by rest. He describes this discomfort as a gnawing type of pain that is centrally located in his abdomen.  Past Medical History:  Mr. John's medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril 20 mg once daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg once daily) for the past five years. He has no history of diabetes mellitus  cardiac disease  or stroke. His surgical history is non-contributory with no known allergies.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. John was hemodynamically stable. Abdominal palpation revealed a pulsatile mass around the umbilical area. There was no bruit on auscultation.   Investigations:  As abdominal aortic aneurysm was suspected  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the abdomen was ordered. The results of the imaging confirmed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment:  Given the size of the aneurysm and Mr. John's age  he was referred to a vascular surgeon for further management  with endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) being considered.  Prognosis:  The risk of rupture of the aneurysm is high due to its size. However  if the patient goes through with the suggested EVAR procedure  the chance of survival and reduction of complications significantly increases.  Follow-up:  Mr. John is advised to maintain a low sodium and low cholesterol diet. As secondary prevention  he should continue his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications. Regular follow-ups with the primary care doctor and vascular surgeon every three months are recommended to monitor the aneurysm's size and manage his overall health condition.

Title: Case Presentation - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction:  Patient ID: Mr. Turner  72-year-old male   Presenting complaints:  Mr. Turner presents today complaining of a constant and severe abdominal pain and back pain  which began abruptly. The pain is not associated with meals or positional changes and has not been alleviated by over the counter medications.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Turner has a known history of hypertension which is treated with antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril). He also has a 20-year history of smoking (15 packs/year)  but quit about 10 years ago. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia  for which he takes rosuvastatin. There is no known history of diabetes mellitus. However  his younger brother died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm eight years ago.  Physical Examination:  Mr. Turner appears uncomfortable and is diaphoretic. His blood pressure is 170/85 mmHg  pulse 92 beats per minute  and he is afebrile. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area. There is no apparent external bleeding or signs of distress. All peripheral pulses are palpable. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Summary:  In conclusion  we present the case of Mr. Turner  a 72-year-old male with a sudden onset of abdominal and back pain  history of hypertension  smoking  hypercholesterolemia  and a familial history of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). His physical findings  especially the palpable pulsatile abdominal mass and hypertension  raise high suspicion for AAA. Further investigations and immediate surgical team consultations are essential for his management and possible repair of the suspected aneurysm.

Patient Presentation: The patient  Mr. Andrew Douglas  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a primary complaint of unexplained abdominal pain and lower back discomfort of moderate to severe intensity  persistent for the past few weeks. Besides  the patient also reports unintentional weight loss and mild shortness of breath. The pain is described as gnawing  deep  and not related to eating or defecation.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Douglas is a retired accountant with a history of hypertension controlled under medication for the past 10 years. He has been a pack-a-day smoker for the last 35 years  though he quit five years ago. He was also diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 8 years ago and is under treatment for the same. There is no history of diabetes  but he has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away from heart failure at the age of 75  and his older brother suffered a stroke at the age of 68. Moreover  Mr. Douglas underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) about five years ago. There is no history of previous surgeries or allergies.  On examination  he manifests a pulsatile and expanding mass in the abdomen. The assessment of peripheral pulses is normal. A bruit is heard over the mass upon auscultation. On the basis of the above findings and the patient’s age  ethnicity  history of smoking  hypertension  and expanded pulsatile abdominal mass  a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is highly suspected. Further investigations  including ultrasound  CT scan  and possibly MRI  are recommended to confirm the diagnosis and determine the management strategy  which may involve watchful waiting  endovascular repair  or open surgery depending on the risk stratification of the patient.   The above presentation is only indicative  and clinical decision-making should follow a comprehensive examination  discussion of risks and benefits with the patient  thorough examination of potential complications  and reference to the most current clinical guidelines.

Slide 1: Introduction Patient: Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Slide 2: Demographics Mr. Doe resides in a suburban area of New York City. He is a retired mechanical engineer  married with three adult children. He quit smoking 15 years ago but had a significant 30-year history of smoking prior to that.   Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. Doe has an extensive past medical history which includes: - Hypertension  controlled by medication for the last 20 years - Hyperlipidemia  controlled with statin therapy - Type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed by diet and metformin  - 3-vessel coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery done 10 years ago - Moderate chronic kidney disease  Slide 4: Presenting complaint Mr. Doe came to the ER with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain  described as sharp and continuous. The pain was localized in his abdomen and lower back.    Slide 5: Physical Examination Physical examination reveals a pulsating abdominal mass that is tender to touch. Mr. Doe's abdomen was rigid and distended on palpation. His vitals were stable.   Slide 6: Diagnostic Evaluation Ultrasound of the abdomen confirmed an AAA measuring 5.6 cm in diameter. Further investigations including CT angiography established the presence of an infrarenal AAA with signs of impending rupture.  Slide 7: Summary Mr. John Doe  due to his significant past medical history and current diagnosis of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  is recommended to have an immediate surgical intervention due to the risk of rupture.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Case Presentation  Patient Information: Our patient is Mr. John Roe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in Birmingham  AL. He has been a long-term smoker and has recently been experiencing unexplained dull pain in his back and abdominal areas.   Vital Signs:  On examination  his blood pressure was slightly elevated  recorded as 145/90 mmHg. His pulse rate is regular with a rate of 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute  and body temperature is 98.6F.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Roe presented with complaints of persistent abdominal and back pain  reduced appetite and noticeable weight loss over the past few months. He indicated that the pain was not related to food intake physical activity. He also reported a feeling of ""heart beating"" in his abdomen.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Roe has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and high blood pressure  well controlled with ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease about five years ago. His family history reveals that his father had an aortic aneurysm at the age of 74. He has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for over 40 years. There is no history of diabetes  high cholesterol  or coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. Examination of his chest suggested chronic changes associated with COPD. His lower extremity pulses were slightly diminished.  Investigations: Computed tomography (CT) performed confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). It showed an infrarenal AAA with a diameter of 5.6cm.  In view of his symptoms  age  medical history  family history  physical findings  and CT findings  AAA needs to be seriously considered  and surgical intervention may be required.   Plan: A multidisciplinary strategy involving cardiology  vascular surgery  and anesthesiology teams would be considered for his management. Despite the COPD  given the size of the aneurysm and his symptomatology  he would likely require surgical intervention to reduce the risk of rupture. He would also benefit from strict blood pressure control  smoking cessation guidance  and regular follow-up sonograms to monitor the aneurysm.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Presentation   Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 68 years  Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Race: Caucasian  Location: Rural Idaho  USA  Patient John Smith presented at the clinic complaining of persistent lower back pain and occasionally experiencing a pulsating sensation in his abdomen that has been progressing for the last six weeks. Mr. Smith is an active smoker  smoking about a pack of cigarettes a day for the last 40 years  and has a history of heavy alcohol usage until about a decade ago. His hypertension has been persistently uncontrolled over the past five years due to poor medication adherence. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago which is currently managed with oral hypoglycemic agents.  Family History: There is a familial history of cardiovascular diseases  with both his father and grandfather succumbing to myocardial infarctions in their late sixties. His elder brother was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 72 and underwent a successful repair.  Social History: Mr. Smith lives alone  his wife having passed away five years ago. He has two children who live in another state. He denies any drug use. He consumes a western diet with occasional indulgence in fast foods. He leads a sedentary lifestyle though does daily walks to the local grocery store.  Clinical Examination: Physical examination revealed a palpable pulsating mass in the mid-abdominal region slightly towards the left. BMI measurement indicates overweight status. Blood pressure was noted to be high at 170/95mmhg. Lower extremity pulses were normal with no evident signs of peripheral artery disease.  Investigations:  An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of an infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6cm in diameter. Further investigations like CT angiography and laboratory tests including complete blood count  kidney function tests  coagulation profile  and lipid profile have been ordered.   Medical History: - Hypertension  - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  - Heavy smoker - Occasional alcohol consumer   Conclusion:  Given the size of the aneurysm  high likelihood of rupture  and Mr. Smith’s age and cardiovascular risk factors  he was referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and treatment  possibly involving endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) or open surgical repair.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with the chief complaint of intermittent abdominal pain and lower back discomfort for the past two weeks. The pain is described as a dull ache that worsens after meals and during physical activity. He also reports experiencing episodes of lightheadedness and occasional indigestion. He denies experiencing fever  loss of appetite or weight  and changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Demographic Information:  The patient is retired and lives independently with his wife in a suburban setting. He is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago after a 30-year pack history. He typically consumes alcohol in moderation. He manages his daily activities without assistance and adheres to the dietary guidelines proposed by his general practitioner due to his hypertension. He reports no known allergies.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. There is also a history of intermittent claudication caused by peripheral artery disease. He has been taking low dose aspirin for cardiovascular prophylaxis and occasionally uses over-the-counter antacids for heartburn relief. His surgical history includes a cholecystectomy 20 years ago. The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  his father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his early seventies  and his older brother has coronary artery disease.  In conclusion  with the patient's history  the symptoms of abdominal and back pain in combination with his risk factors such as age  male sex  history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  peripheral arterial disease  and smoking point towards the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. A thorough examination  including abdominal physical examination and diagnostic investigations like an abdominal ultrasound  is recommended to confirm or rule out the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm and evaluate its potential risks.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information:   The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Albany  New York  USA. He is retired from his full-time job as an officer in the military. He's a lifelong non-smoker and has never abused alcohol or drugs.  Chief Complaint:   The patient reported to the Emergency Department complaining of deep and severe pain in his lower back and abdomen  potentially symptomatic of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  History of Present Illness:  The patient reports that the pain started abruptly two hours ago while he was resting at home  and it has been persistent since then. The pain is described as a pulsating feeling  similar to a heartbeat in the abdomen. Additionally  the patient also experienced a period of light-headedness and passing out temporarily.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension which is relatively well-controlled with Atenolol. He also has a history of high cholesterol  for which he is prescribed a statin. The patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm three years prior  which was small and had been under regular surveillance with his primary physician. However  he missed his last two check-ups due to concerns related to the COVID-19 pandemic. His father passed away due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  indicating a potential genetic predisposition.  Review of Systems:  Several systems are implicated by the patients' history and current symptom. These notably include the cardiovascular system given the nature of the suspected pathophysiology and his hypertension  and the digestive system  due to the localisation of the reported pain.  Physical Examination:   Upon a physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable  and the patient showed signs of mild distress due to pain. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Based on the above information  clinical suspicion for an enlarging or even potentially rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm is high  prompting urgent imaging evaluation along with surgical consultation.

Title: Patient Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Demographic Information: Patient Name: Robert Smith Gender: Male Age: 72 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Residence: Phoenix  Arizona  Chief Complaint: ""I've been having intermittent abdominal and lower back pain for a couple of weeks now.""  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith reports a several-week history of increasing abdominal pain that intermittently radiates to his back. The pain is described as a gnawing discomfort without specific exacerbating or alleviating factors. He denies any gastrointestinal symptoms but reports feeling fatigued more quickly than usual.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has an established diagnosis of hypertension managed by medication- amlodipine (5 mg daily) and losartan (50 mg daily). He is also a known smoker since his early 20s with a 40 pack-year history. He survived a myocardial infarction 8 years ago and underwent percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty following it. Mr. Smith also reports a history of peripheral artery disease that he manages with cilostazol (100 mg twice daily). He denies diagnoses of liver disease  kidney disease  or elevated cholesterol.   Family History: His father suffered a stroke in his late 70s and his mother died from complications related to breast cancer. His only sibling  a brother  died following an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 65.  Physical Examination: On abdominal examination  a pulsatile mass can be appreciated in the mid-abdominal region. He has diminished peripheral pulses in the lower extremities but no signs of limb ischemia.  Imaging and Laboratory Assessment: A subsequent abdominal ultrasonography confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a size of approximately 5.5cm. His complete blood count and electrolyte panel were within normal ranges. His creatinine is slightly elevated  indicating mild renal impairment  possibly related to his age and established hypertension.  Plan: Due to the size of the aneurysm and Mr. Smith’s past medical and familial history  surgical intervention is recommended. He is referred to a vascular surgeon for consultation and potential repair using either endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or open surgery. In the interim  his hypertension management needs to be optimized to decrease the risk of rupture. Smoking cessation consultancy is also initiated.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient: Mr. John Doe Age: 70 years Sex: Male Race: White Residence: Los Angeles  California  Presenting Issue:  Mr. Doe came in complaining of a sudden severe pain that started in the middle of his abdomen and radiated to his back. He described it as a sharp  tearing pain that made him nauseous. In addition to his primary complaint  he mentioned having a pulsating sensation in his abdomen for the past couple of months.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago but had a 30-pack year history prior to that. His medical history is significant for hypertension  which is currently being managed with medications. He also has a history of mild hyperlipidemia. Moreover  he mentioned that his late elder brother had an aneurysm repair in his late sixties. No history of diabetes mellitus. No history of renal disease or any other chronic medical condition. Closer examination revealed an abdominal aortic bruit.   Speculations:  Based on the patient's clinical presentation and family history  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is the prime suspicion. It is recommended that Mr. Doe undergo further tests  including an abdominal ultrasound and possibly a CT scan  to confirm the diagnosis and ascertain the size of the aneurysm.   Impressions:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) generally occurs in the elderly population  more commonly in men and smokers  a profile the patient fits into. Based on the presenting symptoms  especially the sudden severe pain in the abdomen radiating to the back  the suspicion of AAA is high  possibly indicating a leaking aneurysm. Since he has hypertension  which increases the risk for AAA  it strengthens the suspicion.  Plan:  Once the diagnosis is confirmed  management will depend on the size of the aorta and the presence of symptoms suggestive of rupture or impending rupture. In the presence of alarming symptoms or aneurysm size greater than 5.5 cm  a surgical consultation for aneurysm repair would be warranted. For smaller  asymptomatic aortic aneurysms  management typically involves regular surveillance and control of cardiovascular risk factors.

Title: Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   I. Patient Background  - Name: Mr. X - Age: 68 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Firefighter  - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Personal Habits: Former smoker  quit 8 years ago - Family History: Father deceased due to myocardial infarction at age 72.   II. Past Medical History   Mr. X has a history of hypertension since the age of 50  which has been managed with a combination of Lisinopril and Amlodipine. His last blood pressure reading taken a month ago was 140/85 mmHg. In addition  he has a diagnosis of hyperlipidemia which has been managed with statins. There is no history suggestive of diabetes mellitus  coronary artery disease  or peripheral vascular disease.  III. Presenting Complaint  Patient walked into the clinic with a complaint of a pulsatile feeling in his abdomen that he has been experiencing for the last 3 months. It has been mostly asymptomatic but he states that he feels a 'heartbeat' in his stomach and a vague discomfort. There are no associated symptoms such as abdominal pain  back pain  or any changes in bowel habits.  IV. Examination Findings  On physical exam  Mr. X is a well-nourished  well-developed man in no apparent distress. Notably  there is a pulsatile mass in the abdomen which is slightly painful on palpation. No bruits are heard on auscultation of the mass. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  These findings raise a suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm in Mr. X and we recommend an immediate abdominal ultrasound for the same. Further management would be decided based on the sonographic report.  V. Risk Factors  Given his age  gender  history of smoking  and hypertension  Mr. X falls under high risk for development of abdominal aortic aneurysm. It is important that he is educated about these risk factors  and regular monitoring is initiated.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Middle-Aged Male Patient   Patient Information: Mr. Henry Watson  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the hospital following a one-week history of distressing abdominal pain  lower back pain  and episodic nausea. Mr. Watson works as a lawyer and lives with his wife in the urban part of the city. His body mass index (BMI) is 28  indicating that he is in the 'overweight' category.   Past medical history: Mr. Watson has a 25-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes. Despite his prescribed antihypertensive drugs and oral hypoglycemic agents  he admits to poor medication compliance  erratic dietary habits  and minimal physical activity. He has been an active smoker for the past 40 years  with current consumption of 15 cigarettes per day.   The patient also has a relevant family history of aortic diseases; his father suffered from an aortic dissection at the age of 65  and his paternal grandfather died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient has a 10-year history of hyperlipidemia  managed with statin therapy.   Additional details about the patient’s medical history include an appendectomy 25 years ago and an infrequent alcohol consumption. His tetanus and flu vaccines are up to date.  In conclusion  this patient's presentation  together with his age  gender  uncontrolled hypertension  smoking habit  family history  and comorbid conditions like diabetes and hyperlipidemia places him at a high risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Therefore  further workup including Doppler ultrasound and possibly CT scan is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of AAA  determine its size  and assess the risk of rupture.

Patient Presentation:  Today we have a 72-year-old African American male presenting with a concern of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is currently residing in New York  NY  where he is retired from an office job. The patient is a former smoker  with a pack history of 30 years  but has quit smoking for the past 10 years. He has a Body Mass Index of 29 and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  In addition to a moderate amount of low back pain and a palpable mass in the abdomen  this patient has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain that is mainly in the mid- and lower- abdomen area. He also reported occasional feelings of lightheadedness  however there have been no episodes of syncope or loss of consciousness.   Past Medical History:  His medical history includes hypertension for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril) for the last 15 years. He also has a history of high cholesterol and has been taking statins (Atorvastatin) for the past 10 years. In addition to that  he has suffered from chronic back pain for many years  managed with physiotherapy and occasional use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. He does not have any history of diabetes or any known allergies.   He has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 78  and his mother died from a myocardial infarction at age 81.  In summary  given the history of chest pain  a family history of AAA  and his history of long-standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia  this patient has multiple risk factors that make him at risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic imaging  such as an abdominal ultrasound or CT scan  would help confirm the diagnosis and determine the size and growth rate of the aneurysm which will aid in developing an optimal management plan for the patient.

Subject: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction  I would like to present Mr. David Thompson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  residing at 1234 Main St.  Easton  PA. Mr. Thompson is a retired mechanical engineer who is actively involved in part-time consultancy. He presented himself to the hospital accompanied by his daughter with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain radiating to his lower back for the past few weeks.   Demographics Mr. Thompson speaks fluent English  graduated from Penn State University  and is a widower who lives alone. He has two kids  both of whom live close by and visit regularly. He has a history of smoking for the past 40 years with a 20 pack-years history  and consumes alcohol occasionally in moderate amounts. His family history reveals that his father died at 72 of a heart attack and his mother died at 79 with Alzheimer’s.   Past Medical History  Mr. Thompson's medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type-2 diabetes mellitus. These have been fairly controlled with medication - he takes antihypertensive (amlodipine)  lipid-lowering agents (atorvastatin)  and oral glycemic agents (glyburide). He is also on daily aspirin (81mg) therapy.  Presenting Complaint  He complained of pain in his middle and lower regions of the back  which he initially attributed to old age and physical strain. However  the persistence and occasional increase in the intensity of pain that radiates to his lower back led him to seek medical attention.  Physical Examination Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass and fullness in the mid and upper abdomen with an absence of peritoneal signs. There were no symptoms of shock  and vitals were stable at presentation moments with a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  pulse rate 78 bpm  and normal temperature.  Summary In conclusion  Mr. Thompson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type-2 diabetes mellitus presents with complaints of persistent abdominal and lower back pain. Physical examinations suggest probable abdominal aortic aneurysm. More detailed investigations like an abdominal ultrasound or CT angiography need to be carried out for a final diagnosis. His history of smoking and family history of cardiovascular disease further necessitates the need for screening for any associated cardiovascular conditions.

Slide 1: Introduction:  Today  we are presenting the case of a 68-year-old Caucasian male who has been recently diagnosed with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). The patient is an ex-smoker and former construction worker  currently retired. He is married with three adult children and lives with his wife.    Slide 2: Medical History:  The patient has a known medical history of hypertension for 30 years  for which he has been taking Losartan 50mg daily. Other significant history includes high cholesterol  managed with atorvastatin  and a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus that has been controlled with Glimepiride and regular insulin injections. The patient is an ex-smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 40-year pack-a-day history. He claims to drink alcohol only occasionally.   Slide 3: Presentation:  The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain which had started a couple of hours before. He also reported feeling lightheaded and faint.   Slide 4: Examination and Diagnostic Tests:  On physical examination  a pulsating abdominal mass was discovered. The patient appeared pale  sweaty and in distress. An ultrasound confirmed a 6.5 cm AAA. The impairment of renal function was noted with creatinine levels at 1.5 mg/dL  suggesting possible renal involvement. EKG showed no signs of myocardial ischemia.   Slide 5: Discussion:  Considering demographic details  medical history  presentation  and test results  the patient’s sudden onset severe abdominal and back pain  lightheadedness along with the pulsating abdominal mass are indicative of possible rupture or impending rupture of AAA. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial in these cases as ruptured AAA carries a high mortality rate. Appropriate surgical or endovascular repair will be considered after a careful risk-benefit analysis.   Slide 6: Conclusion:  In conclusion  AAA is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention and treatment. It is crucial to maintain high clinical suspicion  especially in older male patients with risk factors like smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  and diabetes. This can help in early diagnosis and management  thereby improving patient outcomes.

**Chief Complaint**: ""Sudden severe abdominal pain.""  **Presentation**: Mr. James Thompson is a 72-year-old African American male who presents today in the emergency room with complaints of severe  sudden onset of abdominal pain rampant to his back.
