He rates the pain a 10/10 on the pain scale  describing it as a constant  ripping sensation. He denies any recent trauma or injuries. He has never felt pain quite like this before. Over the past week  he has noticed a mild abdominal discomfort but didn't think much of it. Today  he also endorses mild dizziness  but no loss of consciousness  palpitations  shortness of breath  or chest pain.   **Past Medical History/Past Surgical History**: Patient has a past medical history known hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history. He denies any known heart disease or previous surgeries. No history of allergies; however  Mr. Thompson notes he might be slightly intolerant to codeine  as it seems to make him nauseous. He lives alone in a small one-story house and has retired from his work as a plumber.  **Medications**: He is on atorvastatin (Lipitor) 40mg and lisinopril (Zestril) 10mg. He takes his medications as prescribed but confesses missing doses occasionally.  **Family History**: Father died of ""heart problem "" but details are unknown. Mother passed away due to lung cancer. All 3 siblings alive and well; eldest brother diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes.  **Social History**: He continues to smoke half a pack per day despite his initial diagnosis of hypertension. He admits to drinking socially  reckoning it being around 4-5 beers weekly.  **Physical Examination**: On physical examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable  in moderate distress. No apparent respiratory suffering. Evidence of a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. No rebound or guarding. The rest of his physical exam  including cardiopulmonary examination  is normal.  **Summary**: Mr. Thompson's past medical history  presenting symptoms  and physical findings suggest an abdominal aortic aneurysm potentially undergoing rupture. The severe  sudden onset of abdominal pain relating to his back and the systemic hypotension suggests this diagnosis. Immediate further diagnostic testing with CT scan and consultation with vascular surgery is warranted to confirm our suspicions and proceed with appropriate course of action.

Slide 1: Patient Introduction   Patient Name: Mr. Jonathan Doe  Age: 68 Years Old  Gender: Male  Ethnic Background: Caucasian  Slide 2: Presenting Symptoms  Mr. Doe visited the emergency department complaining of persistent lower back and abdominal pain. The pain level was moderate and increasing over the past few days. He also reported episodes of fainting  nausea  and a rapid heart rate.  Slide 3: Medical History  Mr. Doe has a chronic history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are managed with medications. Additionally  he has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for approximately 40 years. He frequently consumes alcohol but reports no illicit drug use. Pathological history includes cerebral infarction five years ago.  Slide 4: Physical Examination  On examination  there was a palpable  pulsating mass in the abdomen. Abdominal bruit was also noted. Mr. Doe has a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg and his heart rate is 110 beats per minute  all further contributing to the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Slide 5: Additional Diagnostic Tests   Further diagnostic imaging studies are required to confirm the diagnosis  assessing the size and location of the aneurysm  and to inform treatment decisions. These may include ultrasound  computed tomography (CT) scan  or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Furthermore  serum laboratory tests will be conducted.  Slide 6: Conclusion  Mr. Doe's age  gender  history of smoking and hypertension  and current symptoms are all consistent with the hallmark features of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. After confirmatory tests  appropriate therapy options will be considered which range from watchful waiting and medication to surgical intervention based on the size and growth rate of the aneurysm  and his overall health status.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Case Presentation  Slide 1: Introduction  Patient Identification: Mr. J.H  a 72-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Acute-onset abdominal pain  which is gradually worsening.  Slide 2: Medical History  The patient is an ex-smoker with a 40 pack-year history and has been sober from alcohol for 10 years. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. Mr. J.H has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication; and a previous diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).  Slide 3: Pre-existing health conditions  The patient has been on medication for hypertension (Lisinopril) and hyperlipidemia (Atorvastatin) for the past ten years. He takes Salbutamol as needed for his COPD. He has no known drug allergies and is immunized according to age-appropriate protocols. He is a retired electrician  lives with his wife  and is supported by two adult children living nearby.  Slide 4: Clinical Findings   On examination  the patient seems in discomfort due to abdominal pain. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 165/95mmHg  pulse rate 90 beats/min  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area. There is no visible external hemorrhage  and peripheral pulses are present and symmetric.  Slide 5: Diagnosis  Based on the clinical findings and history  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is suspected. Immediate abdominal ultrasound demonstrates an aortic diameter of 5.5 cm confirming the diagnosis of AAA.  Slide 6: Next Steps  The emergency department physician initiates arrangements for a surgical consultation and potential operative intervention  considering the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms.  Slide 7: Conclusion   Abdominal aortic aneurysm noted in a 72-year-old male with significant cardiovascular risk factors demonstrates the importance of routine screening  particularly among those presenting with risk factors such as aged males  smokers  and those with a history of cardiovascular diseases.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  I. Demographic Information: Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Residence: Queens  New York Occupation: Retired School Teacher  II. Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department complaining of persistent and intense abdominal pain. The pain is described as central and slightly left-sided  which also spreads towards his back. He points it out as an intense  tearing pain that he has never experienced before.  III. Past Medical History: He has a history of long-time smoking  reported approximately 30 pack years  hypertension diagnosed 25 years ago  hyperlipidemia and has been under medication control. No known diagnosis of diabetes mellitus  no known allergies to any medication.  IV. Family History: Father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 72. Older brother has peripheral artery disease. Other siblings are healthy and no family history of kidney disease  stroke or aortic aneurysm.  V. Social History: Retired from teaching for 7 years. He lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. He is a former smoker and quit 2 years ago. No history of alcohol or drug abuse. He is a father of 3 children.  VI. Preliminary Diagnosis: Considering the patient's age  his persistent and intense abdominal pain radiating to the back  and history of long-term smoking and hypertension which are known risk factors  the patient is suspected to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Diagnostic evaluation  such as abdominal ultrasound  CT scan or MRI  alongside laboratory tests  will be conducted to confirm this preliminary diagnosis and to plan the appropriate course of treatment.    VII. Discussion: Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a life-threatening condition  which can be asymptomatic until it progresses to rupture  a situation exhibiting high mortality rate. Risk factors include smoking history  older age  and hypertension as seen in Mr. Doe. Early recognition and appropriate management can significantly improve the outcome. In this case  the interprofessional team will work to stabilize the patient  manage his pain and associated comorbid conditions  and discuss the need for surgical intervention in the light of his overall health state and risks associated with the intervention.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Slide 1:  Patient Demographics - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 68 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired engineer - Address: 123 Park Avenue  Houston  TX  Slide 2: Presenting Complaint Mr. John Doe presents with intermittent  severe abdominal pain and lower back pain of 6 months duration. He also reports unexplained weight loss and reported feeling an occasional pulsing sensation in his navel region.  Slide 3:  Clinical History The patient has a history of high blood pressure (hypertension) diagnosed 15 years ago. He has managed his condition with lifestyle changes and medication. He has a 20-year history of smoking but quit 8 years ago. Mr. Doe has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He has no known allergies.  Slide 4:  Family Medical History Mr. Doe has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms; his father died suddenly from a ruptured AAA at the age of 72.  Slide 5: Personal/Social History Mr. Doe is married  financially stable  and lives with his spouse. He is a non-smoker  does not use illicit drugs but consumes alcohol occasionally in moderate amounts. He does not exercise regularly and has a diet high in fats and cholesterol.  Slide 6:  Physical Examination  Mr. Doe is conscious and cooperative  appears to be in pain. He has a pulsatile abdominal mass perceptible on examination. Other findings are within normal ranges.  Slide 7: Investigations  An Abdominal Ultrasound was ordered  provides confirmatory evidence of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). Further diagnostic imaging such as CT and MRI scan proposed for determining the extent and rupture risk of AAA.   Slide 8: Preliminary Diagnosis  Given the history  clinical presentation  and preliminary investigations  Mr. Doe appears to have an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. A multi-disciplinary approach involving a vascular surgeon and cardiologist is advisable for further management.   Slide 9:  Treatment Plan & Prognosis  Early intervention in the form of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) might be necessary. Lifestyle modifications such as healthier diet and frequent moderate cardio exercises should be encouraged. Regular follow-ups are crucial to monitor the size of the aneurysm and potential rupture risks.   Slide 10:  Summary We are dealing with a 68-year-old male presenting with symptoms of an AAA. With a family history of AAA  history of hypertension  and past smoking habit  the patient falls within high-risk categories for developing AAA. Appropriate management and monitoring plans need to be instituted for this patient.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. This patient came to our attention due to the experience of sudden severe pain radiating through his lower back and abdomen  specifically in his middle and lower sections.  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  which has been managed with medication for the past ten years. He is also a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago but had a previous 30-year smoking history. There's a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 68  and his older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair at age 75. His only surgical history comprises an appendectomy when he was in his twenties.  He lives alone  drinks alcohol moderately  and follows a diet high in saturated fats. He is retired and leads a sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical activity.  In light of his prominent risk factors  including advanced age  male gender  history of hypertension  and familial disposition combined with his current clinical presentation  this patient poses a substantial likelihood for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic studies  including ultrasonography or potentially CT angiography if suitable  are recommended for the definitive diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Title: Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   I present Mr. John Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male who is currently residing in Seattle  Washington. His profession involves being a retired mechanic and thus  he hasn't reported any prior prolonged exposure to detrimental substances other than the occasional smoking before his retirement 7 years ago.  In terms of past medical history  Mr. Smith is a diagnosed hypertensive for the last 20 years and has been maintaining medication for it. He also has a history of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) owing to his history of smoking and his respiratory symptoms have been in control under medication. Previously he had high cholesterol  but it's been maintained within normal range through a combination of statin therapy and lifestyle modifications  including exercise and dietary changes.  Recently  he visited his GP reporting dull  constant  and severe pain concentrated in the central and lower region of the abdomen. He also presented complaints of low back pain accompanied by occasional episodes of light-headedness. His pulses in the lower extremities appear normal  but a pulsatile mass can be palpated in the central and lower abdomen suggesting an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).  Given Mr. Smith's age  his history of hypertension  and his smoking habits  his risk of developing an AAA is substantially high  and these symptoms are in coherence with the classic presentation of an unruptured AAA. Therefore  an urgent referral for radiological investigations and vascular consultation should be provided.   Early intervention can significantly reduce the risk of rupture  which can lead to life-threatening hemorrhage and resultant hypovolemic shock. This intervention is vital  noting Mr. Smith's COPD which could further complicate his prospects of surviving a possible rupture.

Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He is retired  is a non-smoker  and moderately consumes alcohol. Mr. Smith resides in a suburban neighborhood in Chicago  Illinois with his wife.   Presenting Symptoms and History:  Mr. Smith has been complaining of an ongoing  intense pain in his lower back and abdomen over the past week. He reported that the aching pain is distributed evenly across the abdomen but mainly concentrated in the center. He additionally mentioned feeling a pulse in his stomach  which is synchronizing with his heartbeat. No significant weight loss  changes in bowel movements or urination patterns have been noted.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has had hypertension for the past ten years and has been maintaining it with medication. He also has been diagnosed with high cholesterol  for which he takes statins. His last LDL cholesterol level checked in the clinic six months ago was 120mg/dl and his systolic/diastolic blood pressurization was 145/92 mm Hg. He also has a history of Type II Diabetes managed by oral hypoglycemic agents.  Family History:  He reports that his father suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and passed away during surgery aimed to repair the aneurysm. There is also a history of heart disease on the paternal side of his family.   Current Medications:  Mr. Smith's current medications include Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  Atorvastatin 20mg daily for hypercholesterolemia  and Metformin 500mg twice a day for diabetes.   In conclusion  considering Mr. Smith's history of hypertension  high cholesterol  diabetes  and a family history of AAA  these may have increased his risk for developing an AAA. The described consistent and intense abdominal pain needs an urgent attention. An abdominal ultrasound  CT scan or an MRI should be considered for proper diagnosis and immediate management. As AAA is a life-threatening condition  finding an appropriate intervention is paramount to prevent aneurysm rupture and improve patient's prognosis.

Slide 1: Introduction Our case involves a 72-year-old Caucasian male retired truck driver  Mr. Owen Jackson  who has presented with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Mr. Jackson is from the Texas and currently resides with his wife in Austin.   Slide 2: History of Present Illness Mr. Jackson reported discomfort in his abdomen gradually intensifying over the last few months. The discomfort is described as a deep  gnawing pain that does not appear to correlate with meals  activity or other factors. Recently  he’s noticed that he feels the pain more while he is lying down flat and it occasionally awakens him from sleep.   Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. Jackson has a medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and moderate tobacco use for the past 50 years. He had an appendectomy at age 25 and a right knee replacement five years back. His medications include a combination of amlodipine and atorvastatin. There’s a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father having succumbed to a myocardial infarction at age 65.   Slide 4: Examination Findings On examination  there is a palpable mass in the mid-abdominal region. His pulse rate is regular  with moderate hypertension evident. The auscultation of his chest suggests normal heart sounds without any murmur or rubs. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsating mass  and auscultation of the mass reveals a bruit.   Slide 5: Diagnosis The physical examination  symptoms  and medical history align with a potential diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Thereafter  an abdominal ultrasound was recommended  which confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal AAA.  Slide 6: Risk Factors The risk factors contributing to Mr. Jackson’s condition include his age (over 65 years old)  his sex (male)  his extensive history of smoking  and his history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Other factors include his sedentary lifestyle associated with his profession and a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Slide 7: Proposed Plan Given the size of the AAA and the patient's symptomatology  Mr. Jackson will be referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and treatment. The possible treatment course may include surgical repair like endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or open repair  depending on the surgeon's evaluation. Meanwhile  blood pressure and cholesterol control will be intensified  and he will be counseled for smoking cessation and healthier lifestyle habits.

Presentation Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a middle-aged Male - A Case Study  Introduction  Patient Mr. Michael Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired civil engineer  presented to the emergency department with chief complaints of severe  sudden-onset abdominal and back pain. He described the pain as a tearing sensation radiating to his back. He also reported experiencing mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History Mr. Johnson has a documented history of hypertension for the past ten years  smoking about one pack a day for 35 years  and a family history of cardiovascular disease  including his father passing from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He has hyperlipidemia and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  attributed to his long-term smoking habit. He is being managed with daily ACE inhibitors and statins. He also has mild obesity with a BMI of 30. The patient has no history of surgeries  no known allergies  and maintains a moderately active lifestyle.  Clinical Examination Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass accompanied by severe tenderness. His blood pressure was elevated (170/95 mmHg) and heart rate was mildly tachycardic. Pulmonary and neurological examinations were within normal limits.  This patient's age  sex  smoking history  family history of AAA  and hypertensive state significantly increase his susceptibility to AAA. His acute symptomatology combined with the palpable abdominal mass strongly suggested an AAA  prompting an immediate abdominal ultrasound.  Conclusion It is essential to maintain a high index of suspicion for AAA in patients  especially older males with a long-standing history of hypertension and smoking. Its diagnosis can be challenging due to its non-specific symptoms  but the immediate consequences of a missed or late diagnosis make it critical to consider AAA in the differential  leading to prompt diagnostic strategies and emergent interventions.

Title: Patient Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  I. Demographic Information: Patient is a 69-year-old Caucasian male. Occupation is retired  and he is currently residing in the suburban area of New Jersey. He lives with his wife and has a history of moderate cigarette use for 40 years. The patient has a BMI of 27  falls under the overweight range.  II. Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with central abdominal pain and back pain which he describes as a ""pulsating feeling"" in his abdomen. The pain has been of mild-moderate intensity for the past week but has markedly increased in the last 24 hours.  III. Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled on lisinopril. He also has a history of high cholesterol for which he takes rosuvastatin. Family history includes a father who died in his early 70s from heart disease and a mother with a history of stroke. No known history of AAA (Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm) in the family.   IV. Social History: The patient is a retired police officer  currently not working. He smokes approximately half a pack of cigarettes per day and has a drinking history of 1-2 alcoholic beverages per week. No reported illicit drug use. He is married and has two adult daughters in good health.  V. Review of Systems: The review of systems is significant for a decrease in appetite over the past week and some fatigue. Denies chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  leg pain  or neurological symptoms. Bowel and bladder functions are reportedly normal.  In conclusion  given the patient's age  long history of smoking  and presenting symptoms  there is a high index of suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The sudden increase in pain intensity might signify a risk of rupture  which would necessitate urgent surgical intervention. An emergency CT with contrast should be performed to confirm diagnosis  assess size and location  and determine if rupture has occurred.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Patient Presentation  Demographics: Patient Name: Mr. Alvin Rose Age: 72 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired civil engineer Marital Status: Married Habits: Lifelong non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially  history of sedentary lifestyle   Presenting Problem: Mr. Rose presents to the vascular surgery office with a 2-week history of progressive  non-radiating lower abdominal pain that is described as dull and persistent. Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   I. Patient Identification  Our patient  Mr. Smith  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who resides in the suburban area of Chicago  Illinois. He is retired and was previously employed as an engineer. Mr. Smith is non-Hispanic and married for over 40 years  and he has two adult children. He has a limited exercise regimen largely due to mobility constraints.  II. Chief Complaint  Mr. Smith presents today with complaints of sustained and intense abdominal pain  lower back discomfort  and feelings of abnormal fullness which has persisted for the past 48 hours. The pain seems to radiate to his back and does not seem to alleviate with regular over-the-counter pain medications.  III. Past Medical History  A review of Mr. Smith's medical history reveals hypertension and high cholesterol  which have been managed pharmaceutically for the past 15 years. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus five years ago and is under constant monitoring for the same. His medications include Ramipril for hypertension  Atorvastatin for high cholesterol  and Metformin for diabetes.  Mr. Smith underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 10 years ago due to ischemic heart disease. He also has a 20-year history of smoking  consuming a pack of cigarettes per day  although he quit smoking five years ago post his diabetes diagnosis. Mr. Smith mentions no known allergies.   IV. Family History  Mr. Smith's family history reveals that his father passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his mother died of a stroke at the age of 78. His younger brother  aged 65  has been recently diagnosed with peripheral artery disease. There is no familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysm.   V. Current Status  Diagnosis & Plan  Mr. Smith's complaints of severe abdominal pain  coupled with his past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  smoking history  and presence of vascular disease  raise a high index of suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. We have planned for an immediate abdominal ultrasound followed by a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis. Depending on the aneurysm's size and rate of growth  a treatment plan comprising either surgical intervention or continuous monitoring will be considered.  In summary  Mr. Smith's case needs urgent attention due to a fairly high possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  given his symptoms and medical history.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Good day everyone   I'd like to present a case of a 72-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. John Smith  who was recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient is from Anytown  Any State  and is a retired engineer.   Mr. Smith is a smoker with a 50pack-year history and consumes alcohol only on social occasions. Apart from his concerning smoking history  he has a noteworthy medical history that includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for the past 20 years  both conditions are controlled by medication. He has not had any previous surgeries.  The major symptoms leading to Mr. Smith's diagnosis included a sudden and severe onset of abdominal and back pain  along with symptoms of shock such as dizziness and profuse sweating. Upon admission  he was tachycardic and hypotensive. His meta-static workup was unremarkable  no other organ disorders were found  which led to an ultrasound where the AAA was found. The AAA was approximately 5.5cm in diameter and located below the renal arteries.  We are especially concerned about this case due to the considerable risk of rupture due to the size of the aneurysm  which is a major life-threatening complication of AAA. Hence  we are currently working closely with a team of vascular surgeons to discuss the suitable treatment method  either surgical open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair.  In conclusion  with AAA  we should be paying close attention to and act promptly on sudden severe abdominal or back pain in patients with a history of smoking  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia  especially in older patients. Immediate surgical consultation is warranted in patients with known AAA and abrupt onset of abdominal pain  as delay may have fatal consequences.   Thank you for your attention.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Presentation in an Elderly Male  Patient Background: Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  who presents with incidental finding of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). He is a lifelong resident of San Francisco and is currently retired after 40 years in a managerial position. He lives with his wife in a suburban area. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and consumes alcohol occasionally. He is generally independent in his activities of daily living.  Symptoms and Presenting Conditions: Mr. Smith initially attended the clinic for a routine physical examination. He admits of experiencing intermittent mild abdominal pain with associated lower back pain for the past few weeks  which he dismissed as indigestion or age-related. There has been no significant weight loss  loss of appetite  changes in bowel habit or any other symptoms to suggest malignancy.  Past Medical and Surgical History: Mr. Smith has a long-standing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been treated with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin). He experienced a myocardial infarction about 6 years ago and subsequently underwent angioplasty. Mr. Smith also has a medical history indicative of moderate Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and is an ex-smoker  having quit smoking ten years ago. He does not have any prior surgical history.   Physical Examination: On inspection  Mr. Smith is generally well-looking  normotensive with a BP of 130/80mmHg. Palpation reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid abdominal region that is slightly tender to touch. There are no visible signs of distention  visible pulsations  or skin changes over the abdomen. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Initial Investigations: Further investigations are planned to better visualize the AAA and include an abdominal ultrasound and CT angiogram for size  location  and morphology of the aneurysm.   In conclusion  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  COPD  and myocardial infarction  who presents with an incidental finding of AAA. His mild abdominal and back pain may be attributed to the aneurysm. The patient will be discussed in a multidisciplinary team setting to determine the best course of management based on his age  the size of the aneurysm  and co-morbid conditions. The team will also consider his quality of life and potential benefit from surgical intervention or surveillance.

Title: A Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  who presents with abdominal pain and back pain. He is a resident of Boise  Idaho  married with 3 children  and is a non-smoker but admits to a moderate history of alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History: The patient has a sorted history of cardiovascular diseases  including hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril  and a previously resolved myocardial infarction 8 years ago. He also has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years and been managing it with Metformin. Additionally  he has had elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol which is being managed with Atorvastatin. The patient has no known allergies. His family history is significant with his father dying from a stroke and his older sister undergoing surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Complaint: The patient has recently been experiencing sudden  severe  and persistent abdominal and back pain. He reports the pain as a dull ache located below the adam's apple that radiates to the mid-abdominal region. Along with this  he's been feeling fatigue and intermittent dizziness. He denies chest pain  palpitations  nausea  or vomiting.  Potential Diagnosis: Given the patient's age  gender  medical history  especially familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  and the typical symptoms of sudden  severe and persistent abdominal and back pain  a preliminary diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is considered.  Approach to Confirmation: To confirm the diagnosis  the patient will be initially evaluated with a physical examination followed by imaging studies including an abdominal ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) scan to visualize the aorta and determine the size and location of the aneurysm.   Following confirmation of the diagnosis  depending on the size and rate of growth of the aneurysm  treatment options could vary from watchful waiting and medication management to surgical intervention. This patient's cardiovascular risk factors will also need to be properly managed as part of an overall treatment plan to decrease the risk of aneurysm rupture.   Informed consent for diagnostic procedures and potential treatment interventions will be obtained after discussing the risk  benefits  and alternatives with the patient.  Conclusion: Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a potentially life-threatening condition if not diagnosed and managed promptly. Proper identification of risk factors  a suspicion based on symptoms  and accurate interpretation of diagnostic tests are key to a successful outcome. This case provides insight into the classic presentation of an individual who might be at risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Male  Patient Introduction: Presenting today is Mr. Richard  a Caucasian male  aged 70  who resides in Ohio. He has been a smoker for approximately 40 years  exercises infrequently and has a somewhat unhealthy diet  making him susceptible to various cardiovascular disorders.   Medical History: Mr. Richard has a known medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are under control through ongoing medication. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago and manages it with oral hypoglycemic agents and lifestyle modifications. Other past medical records show a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to long-standing smoking.  Presenting Symptoms: Today  he presents with complaints of abdominal pain and lower back pain of moderate intensity that has lasted for the last 48 hours. The pain has been constant  with episodes of sharp  severe pain. He has also mentioned a sensation of a pulse near his navel. No symptoms of bowel habits alteration  weight loss  vomiting  or urinary problems have been reported.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass has been palpated. No signs of renal or liver disease are evident during examination. The rest of the general and systemic examination was unremarkable.   Impression & Plan: The patient’s age  long-standing smoking history  the presence of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  COPD  and the described symptomatology all suggest the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. An urgent ultrasound scan of the abdomen is warranted to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the size and location of the aneurysm. If this is confirmed  an appropriate management plan including the possible need for surgical intervention will be undertaken. Immediate attention will be given to risk factor modification including further reinforcement of smoking cessation. Social support and resources for cessation will be discussed with the patient. Mr. Richard's case necessitates close follow-up and continuous support.

Presentation:  Today's patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented with complaints of intermittent  dull  and gnawing pain in the middle and lower abdomen and  sometimes  in the lower back. The pain is not associated with any particular activity and occurred about 3-4 times over the last month. There is no loss of consciousness  no chest pain  or shortness of breath. On further questioning  he noted some unintentional weight loss but denies nausea  vomiting  or any change in bowel habits.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  peripheral artery disease  a 40-pack-year smoking history (though he quit 15 years ago)  and a 6 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) identified on screening 2 years ago. He informs you that his brother had an AAA rupture at age 72. He has been in follow-up and has been compliant with his medications  including an ACE inhibitor for hypertension and atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.   Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. Neither renal bruit nor signs of limb ischemia are present. There is no evidence of an abdominal surgical scar.  This patient’s history of a known AAA and pulsatile abdominal mass seen on physical examination  as well as risk factors for AAA that include age over 65  male gender  smoking history  and a positive family history  reaffirms the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. As a safety measure  we are planning to confirm the aneurysm's current size using an abdominal ultrasound to decide if surgical intervention is necessary given the size and the associated pain symptoms.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Geriatric Patient  Demographic Information:  Patient's Name: Mr. David Walters  Age: 72 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired teacher  Marital Status: Widowed  Residence: Lives alone in New York City Insurance: Medicare   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Walters presented to the Emergency Department experiencing sudden and severe lower back pain  which he described as a pulsating sensation. He also reported feeling lightheaded and faint.  Medical History:  Mr. Walters has been managing his hypertension and high cholesterol for over twenty years  which are mainly controlled using medications. His other related medical history includes a smoking habit of 30 years  having given up 10 years ago  and moderate alcohol consumption.  Three years ago  he underwent an appendectomy after an acute appendicitis diagnosis. As per his family history  his father died due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 65  although Mr. Walters was unaware of the diagnosis  with a minimal understanding of the condition himself.  On his last GP visit  six months prior  and due to the family history  an elective ultrasound scan was done  where it showed an aneurysm of 3 cm at the abdominal aorta. He was then scheduled for annual monitoring.  Physical Examination:  On presenting to the department  his blood pressure was found to be moderately low at 100/60mmHg  and his heart rate was elevated at 98 beats per minute. Upon examining his abdomen  it was noted that a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable  indicating a possible aortic aneurysm.  Conclusion:  From the above data  his familial history  his smoking history  and his hypertension  it is highly suspected that Mr. Walters is suffering from an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  potentially at the point of rupture considering his symptoms. He would require immediate medical intervention including potential surgery  depending on the severity of the condition.

Slide 1:  Title: Patient Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 2: Title: Demographics - Patient: Mr. Robert Jones - Age: 68 - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired from a government job.  Slide 3: Title: Patient's Chief Complaint - Reports: Dull  aching lower back pain - Duration: On and off for the last two months but has become more frequent over the past week.   Slide 4: Title: Past medical history - Hypertension: Diagnosed twenty years ago  currently managed with Enalapril. - Smoker: 40 pack years  quit five years ago.  - Hypercholesterolemia: Diagnosed ten years ago  currently managed with Simvastatin. - Obese: BMI = 30.9 kg/m^2 - Prior surgeries: Left hip replacement 5 years ago.  Slide 5: Title: Investigations  Initial physical examination revealed: - Abdominal Aortic bruit - Systolic BP: 160 mmHg - Diastolic BP: 90 mmHg  Upon imaging workup: - Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) has revealed infrarenal aortic aneurysm of diameter 5.5 cm.   Slide 6: Title: Conclusion In conclusion  Mr. Jones presents a case of unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. His risk factors include a significant history of smoking  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and obesity. His symptoms have been progressive  and further investigation has revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Mr. Jones will require surgical intervention and ongoing management for his cardiovascular risk factors.    Slide 7: Title: Further Steps 1. Consultation and assessment by vascular surgeon 2. Pre-operative evaluation 3. Surgical or endovascular intervention 4. Post-operative monitoring and follow up 5. Optimization of cardiovascular risk factors management.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Case Presentation   Patient Profile Patient's Name: John Smith  Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Issue: Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with complaints of steady  gnawing pain in his abdomen that has persisted for the past week. He reports that the pain seems concentrated in the middle and lower part of his abdomen. Additionally  he mentions occasional lightheadedness  but no fainting episodes  vomiting  or changes in bowel movements.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 10 years ago  both of which are well-controlled with medication. He also underwent appendectomy at the age of 22. He mentions a history of smoking of 1 pack/day for 30 years  but quit 8 years ago. His father died of a heart attack at 62  and there is a family history of cardiovascular disease. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in fats and cholesterol.   Physical Examination: Vital signs are within normal limits. On palpation  there appears to be a pulsating mass in the mid-abdominal area. There is no rebound tenderness or rigidity. His peripheral pulses are palpable  equating bilaterally.  Based on the combination of patient's risk factors such as age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  high cholesterol  and family history of cardiovascular disease  along with the physical examination findings  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected.   Further diagnostic imaging (abdominal ultrasound or CT scan) is planned to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size and location of the aneurysm. A multidisciplinary approach  involving cardiology and vascular surgery  is crucial for the optimal management of Mr. Smith's condition.

Patient Presentation:  Good morning/afternoon   I would like to present the case of our patient  Mr. John Smith. He is a 69-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in Houston  Texas. Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  has been a lifelong smoker  and has a family history of cardiovascular disease. He is presently on medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His wife referred him to us when she observed an uncharacteristic paleness and occasional intense abdominal pain.   His past medical history includes the following:  1. Hypertension: Diagnosed eight years ago and has been on medication since then. He regularly has check-ups and his blood pressure levels are typically under control.  2. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed six years ago. He was instructed by his primary care physician to change his diet but struggled to comply. He has been on statins over the past four years.  3. Kidney Stones: He had kidney stones five years back but was successfully treated and has had no recurrence since then.   Upon examination  Mr. Smith was found to have a pulsatile abdominal mass upon physical examination. Detailed analysis including Abdominal Ultrasound and CT scan have confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. It measures around 5.5 cm in diameter. As Mr. Smith is also showcasing symptoms like intense abdominal pain and rapid pulse  I believe he is a high-risk patient who needs immediate attention.   Taking into consideration his age  vascular factors like hypertension and hyperlipidemia as well as his smoking history  his prognosis merits further discussion. Luckily  we identified the aneurysm before rupture. Aneurysm repair  endovascular or open depending on his fitness for surgery  would be the best course in his case to avoid life-threatening rupture.   A multi-disciplinary approach including advising lifestyle modifications  managing his chronic conditions and planning for prompt intervention to handle the aneurysm would be favorable in managing Mr. Smith’s condition.   Thank you for your attention. I welcome any questions or suggestions you might have regarding this case.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male  John  presents in the clinic with intermittent  mild to severe abdominal and back pain localized at the level of the navel  persisting for the last 2 months. He reports that the pain tends to worsen after meals but is not associated with any specific food intake. He also mentions feelings of fullness and an inexplicable weight loss of around 6 kg over the last month.   His past medical history reveals hypertension  ischemic heart disease  and emphysema - all managed with prescription medications. He is an ex-smoker  with a 40-pack-year smoking history. John has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father dying from myocardial infarction in his early 70s and his grandfather  from a cerebral stroke.  He does not have any allergies  and his immunizations are up-to-date. His current medications include aspirin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and salmeterol/fluticasone propionate for COPD.   On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the epigastrium. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient claims compliance with his medications but admits a sedentary lifestyle and an unhealthy diet high in sodium and saturated fats.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of a dull  persistent pain in his lower back and abdomen. Patient describes the pain as gnawing  steady  and has been gradually increasing over the past few weeks. On further questioning  patient mentions occasional episodes of feeling lightheaded. He is a retired construction worker and currently lives with his wife. He smokes around a pack of cigarette per day for nearly 50 years and drinks alcohol socially. His diet consists of high fat  processed food  but he is otherwise physically active.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension & hyperlipidemia which is usually controlled on medications. Additionally  he has had a past surgical history of gallbladder removal due to gallstones about 10 years ago. There are no known allergies. Family history is significant as the patient's father died suddenly at the age of 55 due to a presumed aortic dissection  though he was never diagnosed.   The patient has no other known diseases but admits inconsistent compliance with regular checkups and poor medication adherence. The patient has avoided regular medical care until now  due to a fear of doctors and hospitals. His last check-up was almost 2 years ago. He is currently on Lisinopril for his hypertension and Simvastatin for high cholesterol.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of persistent and increasing lower back and abdominal pain over the past two weeks. Patient describes the pain as deep and boring often reaching a severity of 8 on a scale of 10. His pain is not associated with meals or physical activities; however  it improves slightly when he changes his position.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 40-pack year smoking history  currently he is still smoking. His father died due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in his mid-sixties. There is no history of diabetes mellitus  coronary artery disease  or kidney diseases. He undergoes regular check-ups and all his previous abdominal exams were normal. He admits that he has not been compliant with his antihypertensive medications recently due to some personal stress.  He has no known drug allergies. His current medications include Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. On physical examination  there is a pulsatile mass noted in his abdomen which is tender on deep palpation. The rest of his examination is unremarkable. He is immediately referred for an abdominal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with a constant  severe  and sharp pain in his lower back/to abdomen and feeling of pulsation deep within his abdomen. He also reports lightheadedness  nausea  and a sudden onset of perspiration. He is a smoker with a 40 pack-year history  and his past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He denies any family history. On examination  he is noted an abdominal mass  which is tender  pulsatile and measures an approximate 5 cm in diameter. His vital signs are stable with slight hypertension evident. The rest of his examination is unremarkable. The patient is otherwise active and independent  with no signs of cognitive impairment.

A 68-year-old Caucasian man presents today with a complaint of mid-abdominal and lower back pain that has been gradually worsening over the past few days. The pain is described as a deep  steady ache  and rates it as a 6 out of 10. The patient denies experiencing any nausea  vomiting  change in appetite  change in bowel or bladder habits  and fever. He reports a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on treatment for the past 10 years. He has been a heavy smoker (one pack per day) for 45 years. He is also a retired mechanic. His father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in his 70s. The patient has no known allergies to medication.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain radiating through to his lower back. Pain is described as constant  does not change with position or movements and is rated as 10/10 in intensity. Patient also reports associated symptoms of lightheadedness  cold sweats and rapid heart beat. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or bowel bladder changes. He has no known drug allergies and has a 40 pack year history of smoking. Alcohol consumption is moderate while there is no history of illicit drug usage. His medical history reveals hypertension managed with Amlodipine and a hyperlipidemic disorder managed by Atorvastatin. There is a family history of aortic aneurysms with his father having passed away from a ruptured aneurysm in his mid-60s.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of pulsating abdominal pain that lasts for hours  along with low back pain. He rates his pain as an 8 out of 10 on the pain scale and reports that it feels like a deep  steady gnaw. The patient also reports experiencing feelings of fullness despite not having eaten much recently.  Past Medical History:  Upon reviewing the patient's medical history  it is discovered that he has been a smoker for the past 50 years  with an estimated 60 pack-years of smoking. His medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  heart disease  and peripheral vascular disease. His surgical history includes a coronary artery bypass graft surgery 10 years ago. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture. He is compliant with his prescribed medications  which include beta-blockers and statins. He denies any use of illicit substances or alcohol.   Vital signs on admission include B/P of 170/90 mmHg  his heart rate is 88bpm  respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute  oxygen level shows 97% on room air  and his body temperature is 37.1°C. His body mass index (BMI) is 28 kg/m^2  suggesting he is overweight. No changes are noticed on EKG or chest X-ray.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  an abdominal bruit is noted on auscultation  and a pulsatile mass is palpable on the abdomen. The patient  however  presents no signs of peripheral cyanosis or pallor.   Further diagnostic tests including doppler ultrasound and CT scan of abdomen reveal an aortic aneurysm measuring 5.7cm in diameter  confirming the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient is referred to a vascular surgeon for further management and possible endovascular surgery. The significance of immediate attention and treatment has been explained to the patient.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents today complaining of a consistent  dull discomfort in his lower back and abdomen for the past two weeks. He rates the discomfort as a 3 on a scale of 1 to 10  with 10 being the most severe. He notes that it seems to worsen after mealtimes  especially heavy meals  and alleviates with rest. He denies any changes in bowel patterns or any other symptoms.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a significant 45-year history of heavy smoking of approximately a pack a day. He quit smoking one year ago. Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  both of which are under control with medication and dietary modifications respectively. He also underwent CABG (coronary artery bypass graft) 5 years ago following the diagnosis of coronary artery disease.  Other Relevant Information:  There is a family history of cardiovascular disorders in the family  with his father dying of myocardial infarction at 60 years of age  and his youngest brother diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease. His maternal grandfather also suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Mr. Smith regularly takes Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes  along with Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension. He is also on Aspirin 81mg daily as a prophylactic against cardiovascular events.   Mr. Smith is a retired accountant  lives with his wife  and leads a sedentary lifestyle  consuming moderate levels of alcohol on weekends.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Brown  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today complaining of a constant  deep  gnawing pain in his lower abdominal region and back that has been ongoing for the last week. He also mentions feeling a noticeable pulsation near his navel. The pain has not improved with over-the-counter pain medications.   He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been taking Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He also has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. Both his father and older brother suffered from abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA).   He has not seen a doctor in several years and does not regularly monitor his blood pressure. His current blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg  and his heart rate is 88 beats per minute. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  difficulty eating  nausea  vomiting  fever  chills  or recent trauma.  Physical examination findings are significant for an easily palpable and pulsatile abdominal mass noted on palpation of the midline and lower abdomen. There is no evidence of lower limb ischemia  and peripheral pulses are intact.  Given his high-risk factors  symptoms  and physical exam findings  he is suspected of having an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further investigations  including abdominal ultrasound and CT angiography  are planned to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size and extent of the possible aneurism.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe  sharp pain in his lower back and abdominal area which he rates as 10 on a pain scale of 1 to 10. The pain started suddenly while he was at rest  and it has been constant for the past 3 hours. He additionally reports a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He denies any trauma  fever  urinary or bowel changes. He has no significant nausea  vomiting  or weight changes. He has a family history significant for cardiovascular disease - his father passed away from a heart attack at age 65 and his older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.  On further questioning  the patient admits to a past medical history of high blood pressure for which he takes Lisinopril 10mg once daily and hyperlipidemia which is managed by Atorvastatin 40mg. He also had a 45-pack year smoking history but quit ten years ago.  On examination  his blood pressure is 160/100mmHg. A bruit is audible on abdominal auscultation in the mid-epigastric area and a pulsatile mass is palpable on deep palpation in the umbilical area.  Given his presentation and history  he is suspected of having an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The emergency department initiates immediate management to prevent rupture and arrange further diagnostics including a CT Aortogram.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: The patient complains of intermittent throbbing abdominal pain for the past week and a sense of fullness in his stomach.  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing mid to lower abdominal discomfort for a week that he initially attributed to indigestion but the pain has gradually increased. He describes it as a dull ache which he feels mainly in his central abdomen but sometimes radiates to his back. Moreover  he complains of feeling full despite not eating much.  Past Medical History: The patient is a former smoker with a 40-pack year history of smoking. He quit smoking 10 years ago. He has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol  but he reports inconsistent adherence to his prescribed medications due to financial constraints. His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm and passed away from it at age 75.  Physical Examination: On examination  a palpable pulsatile mass about 3 cm in diameter is felt in the middle and upper part of his abdomen. His blood pressure on admission is 157/90 mm Hg  pulse rate is 82 beats per minute.  Lab tests: He was instructed to undergo Blood Routine Examination  Liver Function Test  Kidney Function Test and Lipid Profile.  Imaging: The doctor ordered an urgent abdominal ultrasound to be carried out along with a CT angiogram.  Assessment: Given his medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  the patient is highly suspected of having an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that began earlier this day. The pain  which he describes as ""tearing"" and ""sharp "" is primarily located in his abdomen and radiates to his back. The patient reports a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and smoking. He denies any recent trauma  alcohol or illicit drug use. The patient also informs that his father and grandfather both died in middle age from ""rupture of a large blood vessel."" He also has a 12-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and coronary artery disease  for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) eight years ago. His current medications include Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Hydrochlorothiazide. He has no known drug allergies  and his immunizations are up to date.

The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with a sudden onset of severe pain in the lower back and abdomen. He characterizes the pain as sharp and tearing  rating it as a 10/10 in severity. He also reports an associated feeling of faintness and rapid heartbeat. No associated nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel or bladder habits.   The patient is a known hypertensive and has a 50-pack year cigarette smoking history. His medical history also includes high cholesterol  coronary artery disease with a history of myocardial infarction 5 years ago  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He takes daily aspirin  a beta-blocker  and a statin.   Family history is significant for a brother who died from an aortic aneurysm. On examination  the patient is pale and diaphoretic. Palpation of the abdomen reveals an expansile pulsatile mass. He has diminished pulses in the lower extremities.   The history and examination findings are suggestive of rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Emergency evaluation and treatment are initiated.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of persistent abdominal pain and back pain over the past week. The pain is described as a gnawing  constant ache that is not usually relieved with over-the-counter pain medication. He also mentions that he has noticed a pulsating mass in his abdomen.   The patient has a past medical history of high blood pressure for which he has been prescribed medication. However  he admits that he has inconsistent medication compliance. He also has a long history of smoking  with a 40 pack year smoking history. His father had an aortic aneurysm  but he is not sure of any of the details. He denies having any allergies to medications.  On examination  he appears anxious and was noted to have a large pulsatile abdominal mass. The rest of his examination was unremarkable. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 80 bpm  respiratory rate of 18/min  and normal body temperature. His BMI is 26.3  indicating that he is overweight. These findings are concerning for an unstable abdominal aortic aneurysm  and the patient was immediately referred for emergent vascular surgery consultation.

Patient Presentation: A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset abdominal pain that began several hours ago. The pain is constant and radiates to his low back. He notes the pain is 10/10 in severity and unlike any pain he has experienced before. He also reports feeling lightheaded and notes episodes of nausea. No recent trauma or physical strain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension which has been managed with lisinopril for the past ten years. His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in his 70s. The patient is a former smoker who quit approximately 15 years ago but had a 30 pack-year smoking history before that. No personal history of aneurysms or surgery  no peripheral vascular or cerebrovascular disease.   Social History: The patient is retired  a non-drinker but consumes a high-fat diet as indicated by his BMI of 30  lives with his wife in a single-level home.   Family History: Aside from his father's sudden unexpected death from an abdominal aortic aneurysm  his mother died from breast cancer  and his two brothers are alive with one has diagnosed Type 2 diabetes.  Review of Systems: Review of systems is significant for weight loss over the past 6 months  which he attributes to a diminished appetite. The patient notes fatigue but no fevers  chills  night sweats. No recent travel or changes in bowel/bladder habits.

Patient Information: Mr. Patrick  72-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset severe lower abdominal pain  radiating to the back.  History of Present Illness: The patient reported to the ER with sharp  continuous lower abdominal pain and back pain for the last 2-3 hours. The pain is not associated with food intake or body movement. No history of trauma. He states the pain is unlike anything he has experienced before. He also feels fatigued and has a decreased appetite.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking. No previous surgeries. On medication for hypertension  notably including beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. There is no known history of allergies.  Family History: His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 65. His mother died of a stroke at age 77.  Social History: A retired navy officer  the patient has a long history of smoking (40-pack-year) but quit ten years back. Denies any alcohol or drug abuse.  Review of Systems: Positive for weight loss  fatigue  and decreased appetite. Negative for chest pain  cough  and shortness of breath  bowel or urinary changes.  Physical Examination: During the physical exam  the patient appeared in acute distress due to pain. Vital signs indicate systolic BP of 160  heart rate of 90  respiratory rate of 20  and fever grade 1. The abdomen is soft  not distended  but an abdominal bruit is audible  and a pulsatile mass palpable just above the navel.  Impression: Given the patient’s history  symptoms  and clinical observation  an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture is highly suspected. Further diagnostic tests such as ultrasonography and CT scan are being requested to confirm the diagnosis. Emergency surgical consultation is also warranted considering the patient’s level of pain and the risk of aneurysm rupture.   Recommendation: Given the strong suspicion of an active abdominal aortic aneurysm  emergency surgical intervention should be considered to avert life-threatening complications. Appropriate long-term plans should also address his risk factors such as hypertension and high cholesterol.

A 71-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset abdominal pain that started about 3 hours ago. The pain  mainly in the lower back  is constant in nature and 8 out of 10 in intensity. The patient describes it as a tearing sensation.   He smokes two packs of cigarettes per day and has been doing so for the past 45 years. He admits having a long-standing history of hypertension which is poorly controlled. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 5 years ago and also has a history of high cholesterol. His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm and died suddenly at the age of 65.   On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. His blood pressure is found to be elevated at 180/100 mmHg and pulse is somewhat rapid and irregular. His skin appears cold and clammy. He appears anxious and distressed due to the pain.   Given his past medical history  concurrent hypertension  smoking history  genetic predisposition and the examination findings  a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture is suspected. Immediate surgical consultation is sought.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset back and abdominal pain. The pain is sharp  continuous and severe  rated a 9 out of 10 intensity  and located in the center of his abdomen and radiating through to his back. He reports associated symptoms of lightheadedness and shortness of breath. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or any recent trauma. The patient appears pale  diaphoretic and appears to be in severe discomfort.  His past medical history is notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45 pack-year smoking history  though he quit smoking 5 years ago. He underwent a coronary artery bypass graft operation 10 years ago. Despite these comorbidities  the patient has been relatively active without any severe limitations in his daily activities.  Family history is remarkable for a father who died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in his early 70s. The patient resides with his wife  they have two grown children who are healthy. He is retired  having worked as an electrician for 40 years. Regular medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Simpson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset  severe lower back and abdominal pain. He describes his pain as tearing and constant for the past 3 hours. His wife  who accompanied him  mentions that he had two episodes of fainting at home which lasted for a couple of minutes. The patient's past medical history is significant for a 35-years history of uncontrolled hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and a 25-packs-per-year history of smoking. He also suffered a minor stroke 3 years ago. Currently  the patient is on medication: hydrochlorothiazide  lisinopril  and simvastatin. He had routinely ignored annual check-ups and was non-compliant to his medication use. No known drug allergies have been reported by him or his wife.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is noted to be 160/98 mmHg and pulse 110 beats/min. On inspection  the patient is in obvious distress  appearing diaphoretic and pale. Palpation revealed a tender  pulsatile mass in the midline of his abdomen. Upon auscultation  a bruit heard over his abdomen. Family history is positive for cardiovascular disease - as his father died of a sudden heart attack at the age of 56.  From his medical history  presenting symptoms  and physical examination  an emergency abdominal ultrasound was ordered revealing the presence of a large  6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. The case appears to be a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. An immediate surgical referral is made.

Patient Presentation:  A 73-year-old Caucasian male presents to the ER with a chief complaint of sudden onset  severe lower back pain spanning for the last few hours. The pain is described as a constant tearing sensation  which also radiates to his lower abdomen and groin area. He rates it as an 8 on a scale of 0-10 – ‘10’ being the worst imaginable pain. The patient also admits experiencing mild shortness of breath.   The patient has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a past smoking history of 40 pack-years  even though he quit smoking 10 years ago. There is no history of diabetes or ischemic heart disease. The patient mentions he was told about an ""abdominal aneurysm"" during a health check-up about a year back  but he did not follow up or receive any treatment for the same.   Family history is significant for his father having died of “a ruptured aneurysm” in his 70s. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpated in the abdomen. The rest of the physical examination details are currently under assessment.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents to the ER with sudden-onset  severe  tearing abdominal pain that radiates to the lower back. The pain is not associated with food intake  changes in bowel movements  or exertion. His medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. He denies recent trauma and has no known drug allergies. Family history is significant for a brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. On physical examination  the patient appears in moderate to severe distress  with pale and diaphoretic skin. His body mass index is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs include blood pressure of 180/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 98/min  respiratory rate of 20/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. There is decreased sensation to touch and pinprick in the lower extremities. There is no noted peripheral edema  and pulses are symmetric in the upper and lower extremities. The remainder of the examination  including musculoskeletal and lung examination  is unremarkable. A CT scan confirms the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6 cm in maximal diameter.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department with severe  sharp  and sudden-onset abdominal and back pain. The pain was constant and severe enough to limit his mobility. Additionally  he described a feeling of a 'pulsating sensation' in his abdomen. The patient confirmed mild shortness of breath but denied any chest pain  recent trauma  fever  or lower extremity weakness. His medical history was significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  long-standing smoking habit  and COPD. He underwent angioplasty for coronary artery disease 5 years ago. His family history revealed his father had died due to an aortic aneurysm. Upon physical examination  he appeared to be in acute distress with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 96 bpm. On palpation  a pulsatile abdominal mass was appreciated.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. John Smith  presents to the office with a chief complaint of discomfort in his lower back and abdominal region which he describes as a deep pain lasting for several hours. The pain is reported to be gradual onset and constant but not associated with meals  activity levels  or other exacerbating factors. He reports occasional mild episodes of similar pain over the past few months but never as severe as the current episode. He does not report any symptoms of nausea  vomiting  chest pain  fever or change in bowel habits. Further  he's been having infrequent episodes of light-headedness over the past couple weeks  however no fainting episodes have been reported.  Mr. Smith admits to a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He is a 30-pack year smoker  having smoked one pack per day for 30 years but reports no alcohol or illicit drug use. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases as his father died of myocardial infarction at 70 and older brother diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.   On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpated. On auscultation  a prominent bruit is appreciated over the mass. Given the history and presentation  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is highly suspected. An urgent referral for a CT angiogram to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size and structure of the potential aneurysm is made. The patient is also informed of the importance of cessation of smoking and maintaining the control of his blood pressure in managing AAA.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with intermittent  dull  lower abdominal pain that has been persisting for several weeks. The pain seems to be non-radiating but gradually increasing in intensity. He further describes an unfamiliar pulsating sensation in his abdomen  directly below his navel.   He is a retired engineer  a smoker with a 50-pack year history and admits to drinking alcohol moderately. His diet is poor in fiber  and he has a sedentary lifestyle. He has experienced unexplained weight loss over the past three months  but no change in bowel or bladder habits.  His past medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  for which he has been on antihypertensives and statins for the past ten years. He also had an episode of lower limb deep venous thrombosis five years ago which was managed successfully. There is a relevant familial history of aortic aneurysms  with his elder brother having one at the age of 75.  On physical examination  a notable abdominal aortic pulsation is evident  just below the renal arteries  with a bruit detectable on auscultation. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  with a heart rate of 90 beats per minute and respirations of 16 per minute.   Given Mr. Smith's features of abdominal pain  pulsating mass  significant smoking history  hypertension  family history of aortic aneurysm and the physical findings in the current clinical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm is being considered.  A referral for an abdominal ultrasound followed by a CT scan would be appropriate for definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Green  a 71-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a sudden onset of severe  persistent pain in the middle and lower parts of his abdomen and back. The pain began about 4 hours ago and has been gradually intensifying.   Past Medical History: He has a longstanding history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both of which have been managed through medication for the past fifteen years. Additionally  he has a 50-year history of heavy smoking  though he successfully quit approximately 5 years ago. Furthermore  he shares that his father and grandfather both suffered from aortic aneurysms.   On examination  a pulsing sensation in the abdomen is detected on palpation  and some tenderness is noted. His blood pressure is slightly elevated  and his pulse is fast but regular. His BMI is 28  indicating overweight.   A potential diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is considered  given his symptoms  gender  age  and significant family and personal medical histories. Immediate imaging is arranged to confirm the presence of AAA and determine its severity.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset lower abdominal and lower back pain that started about an hour ago. The pain is constant  9 out of 10 on the pain scale  and does not radiate to any specific area. The patient describes it as the worst pain he's ever experienced. Accompanying symptoms include mild nausea and shortness of breath. He denies vomiting  chest pain  or changes in bowel or urinary habits. He denies recent trauma or injury.   Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-year pack history of smoking. His medications include Lisinopril and Simvastatin. He has had no previous surgeries and does not have any known drug allergies.   On physical examination  he is in severe distress  pulse rate 105 beats/min  blood pressure 165/95 mmHg  respiratory rate 22 breaths/min and SpO2 94% on room air. His abdomen is rigid with a pulsatile mass palpated in the midline of the abdomen. His pulses are palpable in both lower limbs. No significant findings on chest and neurological examination.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden onset of severe  constant pain in his middle to lower back and abdomen. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation that started around 2 hours ago. He also states he feels faint  sweaty  and has thrown up twice before coming to the hospital. His past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlhemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He retired from his job in construction 5 years ago. No known drug allergies. His regular medications include Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. He lives with his wife and denies any alcohol or drug abuse. Family history is positive for cardiovascular disease  with his father dying of a heart attack at age 65. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpated. Further diagnostic imaging is suggested to confirm the possible presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  An 80-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with a complaint of sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdominal area which started a few hours ago. The patient describes the pain as a tearing sensation  localized around his navel  non-radiating but steadily worsening over time. He also mentions feeling light-headed and a mild shortness of breath  but denies any chest pain or any other symptoms.  He has a significant past medical history including a 40-pack-year smoking history  uncontrolled hypertension  and  high cholesterol levels. He also has a family history of peripheral vascular diseases. His father passed away due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient is on multiple medications including lisinopril for hypertension and atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. He is retired  lives with his wife  and admits that he is not compliant with his medication regime most of the time.  On physical examination  a palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass is noted just above the naval area  and the patient grimaces with palpation of this spot. There are no signs of peripheral edema  and basic neurological examination is unremarkable.  Given his presentation  risk factors  and physical findings  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is strongly suspected.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of sharp  severe abdominal pain that came on suddenly earlier today. The pain is constant  located in the middle and lower portion of the abdomen  without radiation. The patient describes the pain as a tearing  ripping sensation. His pain is associated with nausea and lightheadedness.  The patient reports a long history of a 45-pack-year smoking history and a 10-year history of hypertension which has been difficult to control.
