He also mentions that his father died suddenly from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 65. The patient denies recent trauma or any changes in bowel or bladder.   There is no history of previous surgeries. He currently only takes medication for hypertension including Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide. He admits that he is non-compliant with dietary and medication regimen.   He lives alone and admits to heavy alcohol consumption. His occupation involved long hours of driving a truck. He denies any known allergies to any food or medication. Physically  the patient appears pale  diaphoretic  and in acute distress. His vital signs are stable  but his pulse is slightly tachycardic. Upon palpation  the patient has abdominal tenderness and a pulsatile mass in the mid abdomen is appreciable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of severe chronic hypertension  25-year history of smoking one pack a day (quit 10 years ago)  and early-stage chronic kidney disease  who has come to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset severe  tearing stomach pain.  The patient states that the pain began this morning  is constant  and predominantly in the middle and lower abdominal and lower back area. He rates the pain as 10/10 in severity. The pain is not relieved or exacerbated by any position or activity. He also reports associated symptoms of light-headedness  nausea  and a significant decrease in the volume of urine output.  He denies any recent trauma  fever  chest pain  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits. He is currently taking anti-hypertensive medications  cholesterol-lowering agents  and aspirin as a part of his chronic illness management.  On physical examination  he appears uncomfortable with a pale complexion. His abdomino-pelvic region is tender to palpation with a pulsatile mass felt in the midline. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg and heart rate is 105 bpm.  Based on his medical history  the pain characteristics  and the finding of the physical examination  an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture is suspected and immediate imaging modalities were ordered to rule out this life-threatening condition.

Patient Information:   Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  heavy smoker for the past 50 years  presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up visit today.  Chief Complaint:  He reports a recent onset of intermittent  dull aching abdominal discomfort and low back pain that does not radiate.  History of Present Illness:   Symptoms started about 10 days ago and have been gradually worsening in intensity. Pain is not related to meals  bowel movements or physical activity. He has no associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  diarrhea or weight loss. No changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Past Medical History:  Known case of hypertension for the past 15 years  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for the past 10 years  and hyperlipidemia for the past 5 years. No previous surgeries or hospitalizations.  Family History:  Father died of myocardial infarction at the age 70. Mother had a stroke at age 78. One brother with diabetes mellitus type 2.   Social History:  Lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver. Formerly a heavy alcohol consumer  he stopped 10 years ago. Denied any illicit drug use.    Review of Systems:  No recent fever  chills  night sweats  changes in weight. Denies dyspnea  cough or chest pains. No genitourinary symptoms.  Physical Exam:  Vital signs stable. Abdominal exam showed a pulsatile  enlarged  non-tender abdominal mass. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations were normal.  Assessment:   A high index of suspicion is raised for an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) from the clinical presentation and background risk factors of Mr. Johnson  pending further investigation with imaging studies.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with constant and severe abdominal and back pain for the past six hours. The pain is described as 'tearing' and 'sharp' in nature and is radiating to his back and groin area. He rates his pain as a 9 on a scale of 1-10. Additionally  he complains of feeling faint and experiencing episodes of chilling sweats. His bowel movements have been normal but he reports having lost weight unintentionally in the past months.   His past medical history reveals a 20-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and a smoking history of 50 pack-years. He was a cigarette smoker from the age of 20  only quit 5 years ago. He has a past surgical history of a left hip replacement due to osteoarthritis. His father suffered from abdominal aortic aneurysm and died at the age of 76 due to rupture. His medication list currently includes Lisinopril for hypertension and a daily aspirin regimen for general cardiovascular prevention. He has no known drug allergies.   His primary care doctor referred him to the emergency department because he suspected an abdominal aortic aneurysm on palpation and sent him immediately due to the severity of the symptoms combined with his risk factors.   He lives with his wife and his three adult children visit them frequently. He is retired and enjoys gardening  but has recently had difficulty performing any exhausting activities due to his increasing fatigue.

The patient  Mr. Smith  is a 70-year-old white male who presents today for a check-up complaining of a few occasional episodes of abdominal and lower back pain about a 4/10 on the pain scale  lasting for 2-3 days at a time  and which seemed to significantly improve with rest. He also reports feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He denies any recent changes in bowel or urinary habits  fever  weight loss  or persistent vomiting.  Mr. Smith has a significant smoking history of 45 pack-years  despite having quit 5 years ago. He also has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes Losartan 100mg daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg daily  respectively. There is no known history of heart disease or stroke but he has a known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm in his paternal line.  In reviewing his vitals  he has a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 78 beats per minute  and BMI of 28 indicating overweight. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  He follows a sedentary lifestyle and admits to a diet high in saturated fats and simple sugars. He consumes alcohol moderately but does not use recreational drugs. He is now retired  used to work in a factory  and lives with his wife.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker presents with a complaint of an intermittent dull ache in the middle of his abdomen that has been persisting for the past couple of weeks. He states that the pain sometimes radiates to his lower back and describes it as ""a pulsating feeling"" in his abdomen. No significant changes in bowel or urinary habits have been noted.   His medical history includes 20-year history of hypertension fairly controlled with medication  type 2 diabetes managed with diet and metformin for the last 10 years  and 45 pack years history of smoking  only quit two years ago. He also reports that he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 5 years ago due to severe coronary artery disease.   Family history is positive for abdominal aortic aneurysm; his father died suddenly at the age of 75 from a burst abdominal aortic aneurysm. There is no known history of connective tissue disease in the family.  He is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. He denies any drug allergy. He is a moderate drinker and quit smoking two years ago.  Physical examination reveals a moderately overweight man with mild tenderness in his central and lower abdomen. An abdominal mass can be palpated in the midline that pulsates with the cardiac cycle. No bruits are heard over his abdomen. His lower extremities are warm with palpable pedal pulses bilaterally.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of consistent  sharp pain in his lower back and abdomen over the past 2 weeks. He admits that the pain seems to radiate towards his groin. He denies changes in bowel habits  weight loss  or loss of appetite. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are both poorly controlled despite being on medication for both conditions. He has been a smoker for 40 years  consuming about a pack a day. He had an MI (myocardial infarction) about 5 years back for which he received treatment. Reports no known allergies to food or medication. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  his father died from an aortic aneurysm. His diet is rather high in fats and carbohydrates and he has a sedentary lifestyle with little exercise. He appears uncomfortable but vital signs are stable at presentation. Abdominal palpation reveals an expansile mass. He agrees to undergo further diagnostic studies for possible abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and a 40-pack year smoking habit presents to the clinic with complaints of episodic  severe abdominal and lower back pain lasting for the last 2 weeks. The pain is described as a sharp  tearing sensation radiating to his lower back  not associated with any bowel or bladder changes. On examination  there is a palpable  pulsating mass in his abdomen just above the umbilicus. He reports unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds in the last month  but denies any changes in appetite  bowel habits  or night sweats. He reports no family history of any cardiovascular diseases but mentions that his father had an aneurysm in his ""stomach area"" which was surgically corrected. He is currently on medication for his hypertension and he quit smoking 2 years ago.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient named Mr. Smith presents to the emergency department with a complaint of severe hypersensitivity in his lower back and abdomen. He describes the pain as a constant  pulsatile sensation that's been going on for the past 12hrs. He also expresses feelings of loss of appetite and occasional discomfort and bloating. Mr. Smith is somewhat overweight with a BMI of 30.5.  He has a well-documented past medical history including hypertension diagnosed for 15 years under medication control  over 50 years of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day  and a family history of aneurysms (his father died of a ruptured AAA).   He does not drink alcohol and does not use illicit drugs. He lives with his wife and enjoys gardening  but admits to being less active because of the current discomfort. Upon physical examination  a prominent  pulsatile mass is noted near the umbilical area. Preliminary diagnosis from the presented manifestations is abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the office with complaints of intermittent  dull aching pain in his lower back and abdomen for the past two weeks. The pain radiates to his groin and buttocks occasionally and is not related to food intake or physical activity. He also mentions feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He has lost 8 lbs unexpectedly over the past month. He denies any vomiting  change in bowel habits  or urinary symptoms.   He has a 40-pack year smoking history but quit approximately five years ago. He continues to consume alcohol socially  particularly having 1-2 beers on the weekends. His diet predominantly consists of high fat and high salt foods  which has resulted in him being diagnosed with high blood pressure and high cholesterol for which he has been taking medications.   He has a past medical history of peripheral artery disease and coronary artery disease for which he had a stent placed 6 months ago. His father passed away from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and his mother died from a stroke.  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in his abdomen. The patient has a normal body mass index but appears chronically ill.  The symptoms and family history suggest a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic measures  including imaging studies like ultrasound or CT scan  would be required to confirm this suspicion.

Patient Presentation:  A 75-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe  sudden-onset abdominal and lower back pain that started approximately four hours ago. He describes the pain as tearing and radiating to the back. He also reports feeling slightly lightheaded. The rest of his review of systems is negative.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year history of smoking. He is on medication for his hypertension (Lisinopril) and cholesterol (Atorvastatin). He does not have known allergies aside from a mild reaction to shellfish. He does not consume alcohol and has not drank in over 20 years. The patient is a widower who lives independently  has two adult children  and is retired from a career as a construction worker. He has no prior surgical history and his family history includes a brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his late 60's.   Clinical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass with moderate abdominal tenderness on palpation. The patient's blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  heart rate is 98 bpm  temperature is 98.6 F  and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute with an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. His weight is 220 lbs and he is 5'9 tall.   This presentation  coupled with his risk factors like age  male sex  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and family history  suggests possible ruptured/infracting abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further investigations such as ultrasound or CT scan would be needed to confirm diagnosis.

A 66-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  moderate tobacco use (half pack a day)  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases  presents to the emergency room with a chief complaint of severe  sharp  and sudden-onset lower back pain. He describes the pain as radiating to his flanks and lower abdomen  rated as a 9/10 on the pain scale. Over the past couple of hours  he has also felt dizzy and has experienced bouts of vomiting  along with profuse sweating. He denies having any chest pain  dyspnea  or palpitations but admits to unintentional weight loss over the past few months. He is currently taking antihypertensive and statin medications  and has no known allergies. On further examination  he seems pallor and restless  and an abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area. Due to his symptoms  and the possibility of a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm  an urgent surgical consultation is arranged.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting in the emergency department with sudden  severe abdominal and back pain. The pain radiates to his groin area and is constant. He rates it an 8 on a scale of 10 and notes it started approximately 4 hours ago. He doesn't remember any specific event that could have led to the pain.   He also notices a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. On examination  a pulsating mass is palpable in the abdomen. He is slightly tachycardic and hypertensive but have no other signs of hemodynamic instability.   He has a past medical history of chronic smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has no history of previous surgeries or allergies. He was noncompliant with his medications related to his hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He mentions a history of heart disease in his family. His father died due to an aneurysm rupture when he was in his early 70s. He leads a sedentary lifestyle. His Body Mass Index is recorded to be 30 indicating obesity.   The severe abdominal pain combined with his medical history and family history is highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. However  radiographic imaging will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis. He is immediately referred to a vascular surgeon and started on medications to lower his blood pressure.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  persistent abdominal pain that began suddenly an hour ago. The pain is 8 out of 10  centered in his lower abdominal and back region. The patient describes the pain as ""tearing"" in nature. He denies any recent trauma. He admits to a feeling of faintness but denies actual syncope. He has had no prior episodes like this.  Past medical history is significant for longstanding hypertension  which is poorly controlled due to noncompliance. He has a 50-pack year smoking history. Furthermore  the patient indicates a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) as his father had an AAA rupture in his early 70s.  Vitals are stable  with a blood pressure of 156/96 and a pulse of 84. On physical examination  the abdomen is soft but there is a pulsatile abdominal mass present. The patient is referred for prompt imaging to confirm the diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian man who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  sharp  constant pain in his lower back and abdomen that began approximately 2 hours ago. The pain is non-radiating and is not associated with any trauma. It is relieved slightly when he lies flat and worsens if he moves. This is the first time he has ever experienced such a symptom.   He is a retired construction worker with a 50-pack-year history of tobacco use. His past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type-2 diabetes mellitus. There is no history of surgeries. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications. His father faced premature death due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. His blood pressure taken today is 160/95 mmHg and his pulse is 100 beats per minute.    On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in his abdomen. An abdominal ultrasound reveals an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is conscious  oriented with normal mentation. Respiratory and neurological examinations are unremarkable. Hematological and biochemical reports are awaited. His EKG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy but no acute myocardial changes. His chest X-ray is within normal limits.   Given his clinical presentation and risk profile  he is suspected to have an unstable abdominal aortic aneurysm and has been referred for a CT scan for further investigation and urgent vascular surgery consultation. He remains hemodynamically stable at this time. Repeat vital signs are stable. Pain is being managed with IV opioids.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Gregory Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a long-standing vague abdominal pain that has been gradually increasing in intensity. He describes it as a dull  throbbing pain located in the middle of his abdomen which occasionally radiates to his back. He reports an unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over the last 3 months along with reduced appetite. Mr. Smith denies any change in bowel habits  urinary disturbances  or vomiting. He has no known allergies  consumes alcohol occasionally  and has been a pack-a-day smoker for the past 50 years.  His medical history is significant for Hypertension controlled with Beta-blockers and Diuretics  Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which he uses inhalers and a history of Peripheral Artery Disease diagnosed 10 years ago. Recently his workup revealed a slightly raised serum creatinine level. His family history is remarkable for his father who died at 68 from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture.  He takes his medications regularly and has been compliant with his medical care. His vitals on examination were within normal limits but abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area. He underwent imaging studies which confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.7cm in diameter.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old African American male with past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and 40-pack year smoking history  presents to the clinic with a complaint of abdominal and back pain that has been gradually worsening over the past few weeks. The pain is described as a constant  pulsating type in the upper abdominal region that sometimes radiates to the back. There was no aggravating or relieving factors. He reports no nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel or bladder habits. He denies any recent trauma  fever  or any symptoms suggesting infection. On further questioning  Mr. Smith mentions experiencing a similar episode two months ago that resolved on its own. His family history is significant for dad diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has been non-compliant with many of his prescribed medications due to financial constraints and his current vital signs are stable except for an elevated blood pressure reading at 142/90 mmHg. His physical examination revealed bruit in the upper abdominal area and a palpable pulsatile mass in the central abdomen.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Patterson  a 72-year-old African American male presents to the emergency room with a complaint of sudden onset lower back and abdominal pain  which is severe and continuous. Patient reports a history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril and Statin respectively) for the past 15 years. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago but had a 30-pack year history prior to that. Mr. Patterson also reports a family history of cardiovascular disease – his father and elder brother both had myocardial infarctions.  He rates the pain as 9/10  localized in the central-lower region of the abdomen  radiating to his lower back. He admits to feeling light-headed and had one episode of syncope at home. There's no report of fever  trauma  dysuria  or haematuria. Bowel movements are normal  appetite reduced since the pain started.  On physical examination  a palpable pulsating mass was felt in the belly area  the umbilical region showing signs of tenderness. Vital signs are relatively stable but the patient has mild tachycardia.   The above presentation  along with his past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  smoking  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases  increases his risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation: A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the ED with sudden severe abdominal pain that started at rest. Pain is 10/10  tearing  and radiating to the back. The pain is associated with lightheadedness and syncope.   Past Medical History: The individual is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago but admits to a 30-pack-year history. He has known uncontrolled hypertension and atherosclerosis for which he is on aspirin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History:  His father passed away due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and mother due to coronary artery disease. His older brother also has an identified abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Social History:  The patient is retired from an executive position  lives with his wife  is physically active  abstains from alcohol  and follows a healthy diet.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent gnawing abdominal pain and lower back pain for the last few weeks. The pain intensifies after eating and at times is associated with nausea  but he has had no episodes of vomiting. He also reports an unexplained weight loss of about 7 pounds over the past month.  He gives a history of medical diagnoses of hypertension for 30 years and high cholesterol for 20 years. His medications include Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  but he admits non-compliance with these medications due to forgetfulness. He is a former smoker with a history of 40 pack years but quit 5 years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol  mostly during social gatherings. His father apparently died from a ""ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm"" which makes him scared.   The patient had been relatively independent  active and worked as a truck driver until retirement. His regular exercise is limited  consisting primarily of daily walking his dog. His diet mainly consists of home-cooked meals prepared by his wife. He's allergic to Penicillin which causes him a rash.   His vital signs revealed high blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg. The rest of his physical exam was generally unremarkable  except for a pulsatile  non-tender mass palpable at his mid-abdominal region. He is afebrile  with HR 88 bpm and SpO2 reads 98%. His BMI is 29.  Based on this presentation  further investigation is suggested to evaluate the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  considering his age  gender  history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and family history. The presence of continuous abdominal and lower back pain associated with weight loss further substantiate this suspicion.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe  constant lower back and abdominal pain that began 4 hours prior to arrival. The pain intensity is described as a 10 out of 10. The patient states that the pain is ""the worst I've ever had"" and feels like a ""tearing"" sensation. He denies having any naseau  vomiting  chest pain  shortness of breath  or change in bowel or urinary habits. He does feel slightly lightheaded but does not feel like he is going to faint.  The patient has a known history of hypertension  30-pack year history of smoking and high cholesterol. His father passed away at 65 from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.  Physical examination reveals a mildly distended abdomen with severe tenderness to palpation and a pulsatile abdominal mass is felt. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is 98 bpm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. His extremities are cool to touch but with palpable pulses.  A bedside ultrasound done by the physician reveals an approximately 7 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient is immediately referred for a CT angiogram to assess the extent of the aneurysm and surgical opinion is sought for consideration of emergent repair. His blood work results confirm a mild state of shock likely due to the suspected ruptured aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  a retired bank manager  who was referred to the ER by his primary care physician with symptomatic abdominal pain. He reports experiencing a sudden onset  sharp  constant  and severe pain located in the mid-abdominal area that radiates to his lower back for the last 6 hours. The pain was not influenced by either food or body position  and there were no accompanying symptoms such as vomiting or changes in bowel habits.   Smith denies any previous similar episodes. He has a significant smoking history of 35 years and drinks alcohol socially. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia  which have been well-controlled with antihypertensives and statins respectively. He does not have any known drug allergies. His surgical history is unremarkable and he has no family history of aneurysms.  On further examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable  and he showed signs of being in significant pain. His blood pressure is elevated at 165/85mmHg and he exhibits a normal pulse rate of 78 beats per minute.   The patient reports no history of traumatic injury and the pain was not precipitated by any known event. Given his age  history of smoking  and hypertension  his physician ordered an urgent abdominal ultrasound suspecting a potential abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset severe lower abdominal pain that started only a few hours ago. He describes the pain as sharp and constant. Pertinent history reveals a 35-year history of hypertension  well-controlled with Lisinopril and Amlodipine. As a former smoker  he quit smoking 10 years ago but has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He reports having lost significant weight within the last three months without actively trying. On physical examination  he is tachycardic with a palpable  pulsatile mass in the lower abdomen. He denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. His family history is significant for his father dying of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 75.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Holland is a 75-year-old white male presenting with a complaint of severe  sudden-onset abdominal and lower back pain that began a few hours ago. The pain is constant  sharp  and radiates to the lower part of his back. The severity is noted to be 9 on a scale of 10. He describes feelings of faintness and lightheadedness  but denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. The pain was not related to any physical activity  and rest does not seem to alleviate the discomfort. No bowel or bladder changes are reported. He admits to a loss of appetite but denies any nausea  vomiting or weight loss.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He also has a 40-pack year history of smoking but stopped smoking 10 years ago. He doesn't drink alcohol and exercises regularly. No known allergies. Dawn on his paternal side died due to an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is detected on deep palpation. The skin over the area is not warm and there are no visible veins. His blood pressure is on the lower side at 90/60 mmHg with a heart rate of 100 bpm and regular. Rest of his physical examination is reportedly normal.  The severity and sudden onset of Mr. Holland's symptoms  in correlation with his risk factors and family history  are worrisome for a possible ruptured or impending rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate further evaluation is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  A 73-year-old Caucasian male presents to the ER with a chief complaint of sudden  severe abdominal pain that began about an hour ago. Pain is described as constant  sharp  and located in the middle of the abdomen with radiating towards the back. No nausea or vomiting is associated with the pain. The patient also reports an uncharacteristic decrease in appetite and unintentional weight loss over the past couple of months reports no bowel or bladder changes.  Demographic Information: Gender: Male Age: 73 years old Race: Caucasian Residential Status: Lives by himself in a suburban area Occupation: Retired construction worker  Relevant Past Medical History: 1. 40-pack year smoking history  quit 10 years ago 2. Hypertension for the past 20 years  controlled with medication 3. Hyperlipidemia  Physical Exam Highlights: • Pallor observed • Vital signs: BP: 165/100 mmHg  HR: 85 bpm  RR: 24/min  Temp: 36.9 ˚C  • Abdominal examination showed an abdominal mass with palpable pulsation • Lower extremity examination revealed diminished pulses  Based on the clinical presentation  severe pain and the physical examination revealing an abdominal mass with a palpable pulse  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected. Emergency imaging has been ordered to confirm this suspicion.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with a gradual onset of lower abdominal pain  radiating to his back  over the past 3 days. The pain is steady  severe  and not relieved by any position or activity. He also reports feeling nauseous without any hints of vomiting or diaphoresis and recent unexplained weight loss of approximately 8 lbs over the last month. Checking his records  he has well-controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50 pack-year history of smoking. He has no known history of connective tissue diseases or any family history of aortic aneurysms. Upon physical examination  pulsating abdominal mass is palpable below the naval area. His blood pressure in both arms is slightly high  around 160/95 mmHg. He has no obvious mental confusion or limb weakness.

Patient Presentation:   A 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired veteran  presented to the ER complaining of severe  intermittent abdominal pain over the past 24 hours radiating to his lower back. He described the pain as 'tearing' and rated it as 8/10 on the pain scale. He also complained of mild nausea  but denied any vomiting  changes in bowel movements or urinary symptoms.   His past medical history included hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history  but quit 6 years ago. He had a history of intermittent claudication primarily on exertion. He was on Lisinopril and Atorvastatin from the past 10 years. He had no known drug allergies.   In his family history  his father died following a massive abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 75.   His blood pressure was found to be 160/90 mmHg  and pulse rate was 90 beats per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in his mid-abdominal area. The overlying skin appeared normal with no visible inflammation or swelling.   Impression: Patient’s age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  family history coupled with his symptoms and physical exam raise a high suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Expedited imaging assessment planned.   This is a succinct example of a patient presentation with a potential abdominal aortic aneurysm  presenting to the ER  and includes significant patient details and relevant past medical history.

A 72-year-old male patient  Caucasian  presents at the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden-onset acute pain in the middle of the abdomen and lower part of his back. The pain is constant with no palpabled pulsatile mass.  The patient is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  while his alcohol intake is within recommended limits. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  with both conditions requiring daily medication. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at a similar age.   The patient also has a known  small infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm which has been under surveillance with no significant changes observed in the preceding years. Recently the patient also had progressive worsening of symptoms of claudication during his regular walks which was new for him.   The patient lives with his wife  is retired  and has a moderately active and independent lifestyle. He reports adherence to his medication regimen and regular follow-up with his healthcare provider.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe and sudden onset of pain in his lower back and abdomen. He tends to be hypertensive and has a known hisotry of smoking  about a pack per day for 50 years. He has a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and peripheral arterial disease (PAD). His grandfather died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Upon examination  he is noted to be diaphoretic and distressingly groaning due to the pain. Despite taking medication  his blood pressure readings are at 180/100 mmHg and his heart rate at 115 bpm. The physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass felt in the abdomen.  The patient states that he has lost considerable weight over the last few months  although this wasn't intentional. He also mentions feeling fatigue and mild shortness of breath during routine activities. There is a notable absence of rectal bleeding  hematuria  or melena. He has not reported any other symptoms related to clotting problems or issues with his cardiovascular system.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  constant  and tearing lower back pain that began suddenly about an hour ago. He describes it as the worst pain he has ever experienced. The pain intensity decreases slightly after about half an hour  but he still feels discomfort. Besides  he reports mild abdominal pain and a feeling of fullness. He denies having a fever  chills  vomit  hematemesis  or bowel and urinary changes. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs  but he admits to having smoked a pack a day for 35 years  having quit 5 years ago.   His past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He had been previously admitted to the hospital due to pneumonia. He currently takes Losartan  Simvastatin  and Tiotropium. His mother died of a stroke  and his father had a myocardial infarction at an early age. He worked as a truck driver and is a retired military veteran. He is married and has three children. He enjoys woodworking and gardening in his spare time. His BMI is within the normal range. His blood pressure on presentation is significantly elevated.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen that began half an hour ago. The pain is not relieved by any position and is described as a tearing sensation. He also reports feeling lightheaded and has vomited twice since the pain started. On examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in his abdomen. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg on the left arm and 105/65 mmHg on the right arm. He has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and has been a smoker for 40 years. There is a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms as his father died of a ruptured aneurysm at the age of 75.

Patient Presentation: A 73-year-old male named John  retired maritime captain  Caucasian ethnicity  presents to the emergency department complaining of severe and unrelenting abdominal and back pain that started abruptly four hours ago. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation  radiating through to his back and uniformly affecting his entire abdomen. Accompanied by weakness and dizziness  John did not experience any trauma or intense physical activity prior to the commencement of symptoms.  Demographic Details: John lives with his wife  is a 10 cigarettes per day smoker with a 40-pack year history. He consumes moderate alcohol and admits to a poor diet high in fatty and processed foods. He does not work out but regularly takes walks along the pier. John reports a personal history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-year history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 10 years back.   Relevant Past Medical History: John has been taking Amlodipine 5mg  Atorvastatin 40mg  and Metformin 500mg BID for several years now to manage his hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes respectively. Despite complying with medications  he admits to erratic blood pressure and blood glucose levels. John has not undergone any major surgeries or hospitalizations in the past. He reports a paternal history of heart disease; his father died of a heart attack at the age of 67.  John’s clinical picture is suggestive of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). His age  male sex  smoking history  and chronic hypertension further hint towards this diagnosis. Moreover  his report of severe  sudden onset pain  particularly with description of a tearing sensation radiating to his back  is characteristic of a ruptured AAA. His underlying uncontrolled diabetes and peripheral artery disease heighten the risk of adverse cardiovascular events  including AAA. Given this critical condition  it is imperative to confirm the diagnosis and proceed with emergency treatment promptly.

Demographics:  Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint:  He reports sudden severe abdominal pain that began approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. He describes the pain as a ripping sensation  located in the center of his abdomen and radiating to his back.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith reports that he has never experienced such severe pain before. He denies any nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits. The patient adds that he has not been able to pass urine over the last couple of hours  and also states he feels faint and his feet feel cold.  Past Medical History: He has a 45-year history of smoking  with an estimated 40 pack-years. He suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are controlled with medication. He has no known allergies. There is a history of coronary artery disease in his family  with his father dying of a heart attack at age 60.  Upon examination  Mr. Smith appears distressed and in pain. He is sweaty and pale. His pulse is 120 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is appreciated.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  presents with a constant  throbbing abdominal pain over the past 48 hours  radiating to his lower back. He states the pain as 7/10 in intensity  not associated with food intake  that has been progressively getting worse.   He has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-year pack history of smoking although he quit smoking 10 years ago. The patient has been relatively compliant with his medication. He has a surgical history of cholecystectomy 5 years ago. He reports no drug allergies. His familial history indicates his father faced a similar issue in his late 70's.   On examination  the patient's vital signs are: BP = 160/90 mmHg  Pulse = 70bpm  Temperature = 98.6°F  and RR = 18 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. No signs of acute distress are observed. His heart rate and rhythm are normal  and he presents no symptoms of shock.   Upon asking further  the patient complains of occasional claudication and admits to a recent unintentional weight loss of about 5 pounds over the past month. All of which increase the clinical suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:    A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that has lasted for 3 hours. The pain is located in the lower mid-abdomen and radiates to his lower back. He rates the pain as 9/10 on a pain scale  and it is sharp in nature. Accompanying symptoms include nausea  vomiting and lightheadedness  but he denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness.   Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 72 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Marital Status: Married with two adult children Residence: Lives with spouse in their own house Insurance: Medicare   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history  quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications (Lisinopril 10mg daily and Simvastatin 40mg daily)  and a history of 2 remote myocardial infarctions (MI)  with the most recent episode 8 years ago. He underwent coronary bypass surgery following his last MI.   Family History:  He has a family history significant for cardiovascular disease: his father died of a heart attack at the age of 67 and his elder brother had a stroke at the age of 60. His mother died of breast cancer and his sister is alive and well.   Social History:  He leads a sedentary lifestyle due to frequent fatigue but denies any illicit drug use. He is concerned about his current condition due to his history of heart disease. His wife is present  visibly worried  and confirms the patient's account.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset abdominal and lower back pain that started approximately 2 hours ago. The pain is non-radiating  constant  and he rates it as an 8 on a scale of 10.  The patient describes the pain as 'tearing' and 'sharp'. He also reports episodes of mild syncope  nausea  and shortness of breath  but no fever  weight loss  or changes in bowel habits. The patient appears anxious and diaphoretic.   Past Medical History:  Patient is a former smoker with 40 pack-years  quit 5 years ago. His medical history is significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. He had a myocardial infarction 7 years prior and has been on Aspirin and Atorvastatin since then. His family history is notable for an older brother who died suddenly of a 'ruptured vessel in his abdomen'. There are no known drug allergies. He lives alone  is retired  and his diet is relatively high in cholesterol and fat. He is moderately active but has noticed recent onset of claudication while walking his dog in the last 6 months. His only medication is a daily low-dose aspirin and statin. His surgical history is unremarkable. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset abdominal and lower back pain. The pain is described as sharp and severe  localized around the navel  and radiating to the back. The patient reports the pain began abruptly  and has been worsening over the past few hours. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 158/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respirations of 22 per min  temperature of 98.2 F  and an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. On physical exam  the patient appears uncomfortable  and there is noted abdominal distension with a palpable pulsatile mass identified in the periumbilical area.  The patient's past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45 pack-year history of smoking. He has no surgical history. He is currently on losartan for blood pressure management and atorvastatin for cholesterol control. He consumes moderate alcohol and quit smoking 6 months ago. His father died at age 72 from what he suspects was an ""abdominal blood clot""  though an official confirmation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his father is missing.  Given the patient's age  past medical history  history of significant smoking  presence of hypertension  the acute presentation of severe abdominal and back pain  and the physical examination findings  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected. Urgent imaging and surgical consultation are warranted.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Mitchell  a 72-year-old male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of persistent and severe abdominal and back pain for the past 6 hours. The pain was unrelieved by over-the-counter pain medication and was accompanied by feelings of light-headedness and nausea.   Demographics:   Mr. Mitchell is a Caucasian male  lives with his wife of 50 years in the same town. He is a retired engineer and spends his time in gardening  reading  and socializing with friends. He had served in the military and is a lifetime smoker  averaging one pack per day for more than 50 years.  Relevant Past Medical History:   Mr. Mitchell has a known history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both under control with medications prescribed by his primary care physician. He also has a history of peripheral artery disease diagnosed 3 years back. His father died of a stroke at an early age (56 years) and his elder brother passed away due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm at the age of 65. There is no history of diabetes mellitus  but he has been treated for diverticulitis twice in the past 5 years. He underwent a colonoscopy a year ago with no significant findings. Currently  Mr. Mitchell takes daily doses of amlodipine and simvastatin. He has no known drug allergies.   This presentation  along with his severe  persistent pain and the feel of a pulsating mass in his abdomen during the physical examination  led the medical team to suspect an abdominal aortic aneurysm. A subsequent ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden-onset abdominal and lower back pain that began a couple of hours ago. The pain is described as a deep  constant ache that rates as a 9 on the scale of 1-10 and it is not relieved by any positional changes. The patient also reports feeling faint and having experienced a near syncopal episode at home  along with persistent nausea and lack of appetite. There has been no recent trauma or fall.  The patient has a known history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm which was diagnosed incidentally during a CT scan for kidney stones two years ago. The aneurysm  at that time  was small and was being monitored by regular ultrasound scans. His past medical history also includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year history of smoking. His medications include amlodipine  atorvastatin  and low-dose aspirin. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease as his father died of a myocardial infarction  and his brother had a stroke.  On physical examination  the patient appears distressed and pale. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg  pulse 110 beats/min  temperatures 37.1°C  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and generalized tenderness. The extremities are cold  especially the lower extremities.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 69-year-old retired Caucasian male visiting the clinic for a follow-up on his symptoms of mild backache and vague abdominal pain that he reported last week. He reports the symptoms as mild yet persistent  particularly when he is up and moving around.  His past medical history is significant showing that he has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and high cholesterol  for which he has been on medicine for the past 15 years. He is also a long-term smoker  with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for 43 years. He quit smoking two years ago due to a diagnosis of moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). There is also a family history of cardiovascular diseases as his father passed away from a heart attack at age 72 and his older brother had a stroke at age 75.  On physical examination  it is noted that he is obese with a BMI of 32 and there is a pulsatile mass that can be felt in the middle and upper part of the abdomen. The patient reports it does not hurt but does feel ""unusual"". He also has a blood pressure of 146/92 mmHg.  Based on his risk factors and clinical presentation  the doctor is highly suspicious of abdominal aortic aneurysm. The physician orders an abdominal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  intense and constant abdominal and back pain that started six hours ago. The pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity  with no aggravating or relieving factors. He describes it as a tearing sensation and states it is unlike any pain he has ever experienced. He also reports feeling faint and notes a rapid heartbeat. On examination  there is a noticeable pulsatile mass in his abdomen.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known past history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history. He underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 5 years ago due to coronary artery disease. There is also a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  his father having died from a ruptured AAA. While he admitted to having had periodical follow-ups for his cardiovascular condition  he has yet to undergo any screening for AAA. No known drug allergies. He is on daily medication including aspirin  beta-blockers  and statins.   The patient's typical signs and symptoms  together with a known risk profile of being male  over 65  with a history of smoking  cardiovascular disease and a family history of AAA  point towards a likely diagnosis of AAA. Urgent diagnostic imaging is required for confirmation.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  sudden onset abdominal pain. The pain is described as constant and sharp  radiating to his back. Associated symptoms include nausea and increased frequency of urination.  The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  a 40 pack-year smoking history  and a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with his father having died from a ruptured AAA. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications.  Upon physical examination  he appears diaphoretic and in distress. Vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg and a pulse of 105 bpm. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen while auscultation yields a bruit over the mass.  The patient admits to delaying medical follow-up and prophylactic screenings for AAA due to fear and denial. An immediate CT angiography is scheduled to confirm the suspected diagnosis of an AAA  with surgical consultation and intervention planned.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Charles Stevenson  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with complaints of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen and a consistent  dull pain in his lower back both of which started about 3 weeks ago. He also mentions episodes of fatigue and some unintentional weight loss over the last couple of months.   Demographic Details:   Mr. Stevenson is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife in the local area. He is a former 45 packs-year smoker  having quit smoking 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally  around 1-2 drinks per week. He is uninsured but previously attended annual check-ups regularly until five years ago.  Relevant Past Medical History:  He has a documented history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels for which he takes daily medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at age 70. He informs us that he is non-compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive medication. He has no previous history of surgeries or other relevant conditions.   Based on this presentation  the differential diagnosis would include an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further investigations through physical examination  ultrasound  and if necessary  a CT scan  would be warranted to confirm the diagnosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and heavy tobacco use presented to the Emergency Department with a complaint of severe lower back pain that began three hours prior. He describes the pain as sudden onset  tearing  and radiating to the lower abdomen. The pain is 8 out of 10 in severity and constant. He adds that he also feels a pulse in his abdomen. He denies any recent trauma  fever  urinary or bowel incontinence  change in bowel habits  or weight loss  but he has been feeling light-headed today. Physical examination reveals a mildly distended abdomen with a palpable pulsatile mass approximately 4 cm in diameter in the epigastric region. The patient's blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate 94 bpm  and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. His remaining vital signs are within normal limits.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. B is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents with intense  persistent pain in the abdomen and lower back. The pain is described as a deep  piercing pain that began suddenly two hours ago and has been gradually increasing in intensity  rated 8/10. He describes it as the worst abdominal pain he's ever felt. His vitals include a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 90 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus and he has been a smoker for the past 50 years. He was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease five years ago. His father passed away from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in his early 70s. The patient is currently taking metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in his abdomen. High suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm due to history  risk factors  and exam findings. Recommended immediate surgical consultation and CT scan to confirm the diagnosis of suspected ruptured or leaking abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent abdominal and back pain localized in the middle and upper part of the abdomen  and experiencing a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He is a retired truck driver  smoker for past 40 years  moderate alcohol drinker and has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He also mentions unintentional weight loss of 5 pounds in the last month but denies any changes in bowel or bladder function. He lives alone without supportive care at home. The patient denies any allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the office with complaints of vague abdominal pain for the past few weeks. He describes a pulsating sensation in his stomach area  but no other gastro-intestinal symptoms such as changes in bowel habits  weight loss  or nausea/vomiting. He has experienced intermittent lower back pain as well  which he initially attributed to his long history of degenerative disc disease.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Jones has a significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year history of smoking  though he quit smoking ten years ago. He also has peripheral artery disease diagnosed a few years ago. He reports no known allergies and currently uses Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Aspirin for his medical conditions.   He underwent a back surgery nearly ten years ago for his chronic lower back pain  which he reports was only partially successful. He denies any previous diagnosis or family history of aneurysms. His last physical examination was a year ago  and no abnormalities were noted at that time. He reports that he has been non-compliant with recent scheduled follow-ups or consultations due to the ongoing COVID pandemic.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the office with intermittent mid-abdominal pain that is not associated with meals or activities  and that radiates slightly to his back. He reports that the pain has been occurring for a few weeks and seems to have increased in intensity over the last couple of days. He further reports feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. There is no nausea  vomiting  fever  constipation  or diarrhea. He denies any changes in his bowel or bladder habits.   His vitals on presentation are: BP 154/92 mmHg  HR 78 bpm  RR 16 rpm  and T 98.6 F. Physical examination reveals a slightly distended abdomen with pulsatile and palpable aortic mass about 3 cm in diameter. Rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.  Past medical history is notable for hypertension and a 45-pack year smoking history. He has no history of any surgeries  no allergies  and doesn’t drink alcohol. His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 60. His medications include amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension.

Patient presentation:   Mr. R  a 70-year-old  Caucasian male  retired school teacher  presents in the ER with sudden onset of severe  sharp pain in his lower back and abdomen  which he describes as ""Tearing"" in nature. He also mentions feeling dizzy and sweaty. He reports no accompanying chest pain  shortness of breath  or nausea.  Demographics: Lives alone in a suburban community  widowed  with 3 adult offspring who live independently. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol in moderation. He reports being physically active  with a history of regular daily walks.   Past medical history: The patient has a known history of hypertension  for which he is on medication (Lisinopril 10mg/daily). His cholesterol level is reported to be in the borderline high range in his last routine check-up 6 months ago. He is aware of a abdominal aortic aneurysm detected 4 years ago via a screening ultrasound  measuring 3.5 cm at the time which has been monitored for changes annually. He also suffered from claudication resulting in a bypass surgery in the left leg two years back.   He has been on a low-dose Aspirin regimen for prophylaxis against heart disease due to a family history (his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 73). Also  he has arthritis for which he takes over-the-counter NSAIDs occasionally.   He is allergic to Penicillin  which causes a skin rash. His surgical history is significant for gallbladder removal (cholecystectomy) 10 years ago. His immunizations are up to date. There is no history of drug or alcohol abuse and he has not had any blood transfusions. He denies any recent travel or exposure to infectious diseases.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe  sharp  and constant pain in the middle and lower sections of his abdomen and back. Pain started suddenly during a routine walk in his neighborhood. The pain is rated as an 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. Denies any other associated symptoms like chest pain  shortness of breath  vomiting  or loss of consciousness. Pertinent positives on review of symptoms include weight loss of 10 pounds over the past six months and feeling of a pulsation below the sternum. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass noticed.  The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history. He states compliance with taking Lisinopril 10 mg and Atorvastatin 20 mg daily. He admits occasional alcohol consumption but denies any recreational drug use. He worked as a mechanic before retirement and lives alone since his wife passed away three years back. His father died from a ""burst artery"" in his abdomen at the age of 70. The patient admits woeful neglect of regular medical check-ups over the years. The adopted sedentary lifestyle in recent years especially increased after his wife’s passing. His past surgical history is relatively unremarkable except for an appendectomy in his mid-twenties.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old white male who presents with a gradual onset of abdominal pain for the past few days. The pain is described as a constant  dull ache near the navel area that radiates to his lower back. He states it does not get better or worse with food intake or bowel movement. He rates the pain as moderate (5/10). The patient reports feeling lightheaded when standing up quickly. He notes no issues with bladder or bowel control  no loss of appetite  and no recent changes in bowel habits.  His past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both effectively controlled with medications. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. His surgical history includes a right hip replacement 10 years ago. The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 67.   The patient has been compliant with his prescribed medications; Losartan 50mg daily for hypertension and Simvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia. He denies any use of over-the-counter medications or herbal supplements.  On general examination  he appears in evident discomfort but not acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits except for a mildly elevated blood pressure (145/90 mmHg). Abdominal examination reveals a palpable  pulsatile mass. Other systemic examinations are unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Watson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department with a sudden severe sharp  tearing  stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the abdomen and down to the groin. Mr. Watson also describes a pulsating sensation in the abdomen.   He has a medical history significant for untreated hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and recent unexplained weight loss. His social history reveals that he is a former smoker and has been consuming alcohol regularly. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with his father and grandfather both having died of myocardial infarctions in their 70s.  On physical examination  Mr. Watson appeared clammy with vital signs showing hypertension and tachycardia. Abdominal examination found a palpable  pulsatile mass in the mid-epigastric area. Other examination findings were unremarkable.  Mr. Watson lives with his wife and is a retired bank employee. He runs errands and walks his dog for physical activity. His diet is reported to be balanced with small portions of meal. He is adherent with all his medications. He is up to date with his routine check-ups  and other health maintenance indices are at goal.   The abdominal pain  pulsatile mass  history of hypertension  and family history of cardiovascular diseases lead to strong suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. An urgent aortic ultrasound and subsequent CT angiography were ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Profile: Gender: Male Age: 71 years Occupation: Retired Navy officer  Presenting complaints: Mr. Smith presents with an intermittent  yet severe  constant gnawing abdominal pain that radiates to his back over the last few days. He also complains of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He noticed an unintentional weight loss over the last month but denies any changes in bowel movements or urinary habits.  Past medical history: Mr. Smith has a documented medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  which he has quit around a decade ago. There are no records of any previous surgeries.   Personal history: He served in the Navy for 30 years and currently lives with his wife. He has two adult children. Mr. Smith is socially active and does not consume alcohol.  Family history: His father died at the age of 72 due to 'heart problems ' while his mother died at 88 without any cardiovascular disease. His younger brother  currently aged 68  successfully underwent repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm two years ago.   Early observations: Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass that is tender to the touch. There is a systolic bruit heard over the mass. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/95mm Hg  and heart rate is at a regular pace of 78 bpm. Given his family history and symptoms  there is a high suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is immediately referred for further imaging tests for a definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with severe  abrupt onset of pain in his lower back and abdominal region that began several hours ago. Pain is characterized as a sharp  tearing sensation that radiates to his groins and lower extremities. He is profusely sweating and expresses a feeling of unease.   He has a past medical history consistent with chronic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for approximately 45 years  but quit smoking ten years ago.  On physical examination: he is pale  maintains a resting blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg and a pulse rate of 100 bpm. His abdomen is remarkably pulsatile with a palpable mass. Lower extremity pulses are weak but present. His EKG shows no signs of myocardial infarction.  The patient's symptoms alongside his personal medical history contribute to a high suspicion of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian man presented to the emergency department with sudden severe abdominal and back pain. The pain was described as tearing and radiating to his back. The patient also reported episodes of lightheadedness.  Detailed History:  The patient has had intermittent abdominal discomfort for a while now  which he attributed to indigestion. He mentioned recent unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over the last six months but no other changes in his eating habits or evaluated by any specialist. The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years.   Social History:  The patient is retired and lives with his wife. He denies any alcohol or illicit substance use.   Family History:  The patient's father died of a stroke in his 70s  and his mother passed away from breast cancer around the same age.   Physical Examination:  Vital signs on arrival to the emergency room revealed blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Examination reveals an obviously distressed  pale and diaphoretic elderly man. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable  pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region that was tender to touch. No bruits were heard on auscultation. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Plan:  Given the patient’s history  the nature of the pain  and the physical examination findings  an emergent CT scan was ordered to rule out the suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). It was also decided to start pain management and cardiovascular stabilization while awaiting the imaging results.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40 pack-year smoking history who presents today with complaints of sudden onset  severe abdominal pain radiating to his lower back for the last three hours. He describes the pain as an intense  throbbing sensation. He is also experiencing light-headedness and feels uncharacteristically fatigued. He denies any symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  fever  or bowel changes. He has been compliant with his medications which include atenolol and atorvastatin. There have been no recent changes to his medications or lifestyle. He reports a family history of aneurysms: his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. No known allergy to any medications. He is retired  lives with his wife  and does not drink alcohol. He quit smoking ten years ago.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith who presents at the emergency department with severe  sudden onset abdominal pain and lower back discomfort that began just an hour ago. The pain is centralized in his lower abdomen and is described as a tearing sensation.  He has been slightly lightheaded and noticed his heart racing. Vital signs are stable.  Mr. Smith has a history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication for the past ten years. He is a former smoker  having quit smoking five years ago after a 40-year pack-a-day history. Notably  he has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms as his father passed due to the rupturing of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Physical examination reveals a significant pulsatile mass in his mid-abdomen along with mild distension and tenderness. Lower extremities are warm with good pulses. The rest of his physical exam  including cardiorespiratory exam  is relatively unremarkable.  Considering his symptoms  history  family predisposition and the physical examination findings  a suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm is raised  and relevant investigations are ordered.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden severe abdominal and lower back pain that started approximately 2 hours ago. He states that the pain is 9/10 on the pain scale and describes it as a continuous  throbbing sensation that seems to be radiating to his groin and right thigh. He also reports mild nausea but denies having any vomiting. The patient appears pale and is sweating profusely.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking 5 years ago. He had a mild heart attack 7 years ago but did not require any surgical intervention. Records show he is currently on a daily regimen of aspirin  a statin  and an ACE inhibitor. He has no known allergies and strictly takes his medications.   In his family history  his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 77. His older brother deceased from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at 69. The patient denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. His last visit to the doctor for a regular check-up was approximately 8 months ago  but no abdominal ultrasound was done at that time. High suspicion arises for an abdominal aortic aneurysm based on his symptoms and medical and familial background.

A 68-year-old Caucasian man presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain which began two hours ago. The pain is described as sharp and constant. He also reports feeling lightheaded and sweaty but denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or bowel habit alteration.  There's a positive history of smoking  two packs daily for 40 years. He has a known past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and peripheral artery disease  managed with regular medications including atorvastatin  lisinopril  and aspirin. He has no known allergic reactions to any medications. There is a family history of aortic aneurysms as his father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is retired and lives with his wife and reports consumptions of alcohol only during social occasions.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Davis is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  constant lower back and abdominal pain which began suddenly three hours before. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation  rating it 9 out of 10 in severity. He denies any nausea  vomiting  loss of consciousness  chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other associated symptoms but notes that he has been feeling lightheaded since the pain started.   Mr. Davis has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45 pack-year history of smoking  which he quit 10 years ago. He does not have any history of heart diseases  diabetes or any other chronic disease. He currently takes atenolol and simvastatin daily. He denies any known allergies.   On examination  his blood pressure is 98/56 mmHg and a pulsatile abdominal mass is noted on the physical examination. His heart rate is regular but rapid at 102 beats per minute. Abdominal auscultation reveals a bruit over the area of the mass.   He has a family history of aortic aneurysms; his father died suddenly at the age of 73  where cause of death was determined to be a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Specifically with his past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia along with his history of smoking and a positive family history  he is at a high risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Considering the severe sudden onset of lower back and abdominal pain along with the presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass  a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is highly suspected.  His condition is emergent and he needs immediate surgical consultation and admission to intensive care for further management.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department complaining of uncontrolled severe back and abdominal pain that initiated a few hours earlier. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation that is constant and does not radiate. The patient rates his pain at 10 on a scale of 10.   Past Medical History:  He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-year pack history of smoking. He has been poorly compliant with his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications. The patient has no known allergies. He has had no previous surgical interventions. The family history is relevant for his father  who passed away from ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Social History:  The patient is retired  lives with his wife  consumes alcohol occasionally  and smokes a pack of cigarettes daily.   Physical Examination:  The patient appeared distressed due to pain. He was sweating profusely and had a pallor. Vitals were significant for blood pressure: 95/60 mmHg  pulse: 110 bpm  and respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute. The abdomen was tender in the mid and lower quadrants  pulsatile mass palpable. There were no signs of lower limb ischemia.   Investigations:  Complete blood counts and biochemistry were within the normal range except for a slight elevation in creatinine (1.5 mg/dl). The ECG showed sinus tachycardia with no acute ST or T wave changes. A performed urgent CT scan with IV contrast confirmed the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm  which appeared to be in imminent risk of rupture.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a long-standing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  former smoker with about 30 pack-years of smoking. He presents to the emergency department with sudden  severe pain in his lower abdomen and back that began about an hour ago. The pain is described as constant  sharp  and radiates to the groin area. Patient reports feeling light-headed and has vomited once. He has a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father passing away due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Besides taking medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  he does not have any allergies to medication. His BMI is 29  indicating overweight. Physical examination revealed marked abdominal pulsation with tenderness. No evident injury marks on the abdomen. Vital signs: BP 90/60 mmHg  HR 104 beats/min.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Lawrence King is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented in the emergency department with a complaint of a constant severe abdominal pain felt in the central and upper part of his abdomen. The pain also radiates down towards his lower back and he describes it as the most severe pain of his life  occurring abruptly within the past three hours. He believes that the pain is not associated with food intake or bowel movements.   Mr. King has a significant history of high blood pressure  hyperlipidemia  and has been a 20 pack-year smoker  though quit 5 years ago. He has a family history of aneurysmal diseases as his older brother experienced a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 78. His only medications are a statin and ACE inhibitors for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Upon initial investigation  his blood pressure was slightly elevated to 148/90 mmHg and pulse was 100 beats per minute. His abdomen was tender on palpation.   The sudden onset of severe pain  history of hypertension  smoking and family history of aneurysmal diseases makes you suspect an abdominal aortic aneurysm in Mr. King. The patient was ordered for immediate abdominal ultrasound.

Patient Presentation: A 70-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset  severe  constant lower back and abdominal pain for the past 3 hours. He describes the pain as tearing and radiating to his lower back. The patient also reports feeling light-headed and is sweating profusely.
