A 62-year-old Hispanic male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with acute lower back pain  suggestive of a potentially rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with a past medical history significant for hypertension  moderate tobacco use  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency room with sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain is 10/10 in severity  characterized as a tearing sensation  and has been gradually worsening over the last few hours. He also reports associated symptoms of nausea and a feeling of faintness. Further examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and examination of extremities displays signs of decreased distal pulses. Patient's vitals showed mildly elevated blood pressure and tachycardia. He has no known allergies and is currently on medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia management. Previous abdominal ultrasound  taken two years ago for an unrelated complaint  showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic diameter of 3.4 cm. Based on the sudden onset of severe pain and the clinical presentation  suspect a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a history of 55 pack years of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic with complaints of a pulsatile abdominal mass that he noticed while bathing. He has noticed gradual lower back pain over the past few weeks as well  which he had initially attributed to aging and arthritis. He denies syncope  dizziness or recent weight loss. He has no familial history of connective tissue disorders but his father had an abdominal aorta aneurysm. He is a retired police officer and denied any illicit drug use. He has no known drug allergies. His current medications include lisinopril for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus presents with lower abdominal and back pain that is sudden in onset  severe and without any relief. The pain is constant  radiates to his back and is not associated with food intake or position change. He admits to feeling anxious with a sense of impending doom. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel or urinary habits. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the abdomen without any superficial signs of inflammation and hyperactive bowel sounds without tenderness or rebound. The rest of the systemic examination is unremarkable. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year history. His father passed away from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture. He is on atenolol  atorvastatin  and metformin regularly.

A 70-year-old  Caucasian male  with a medical history notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 50 pack-years of cigarette smoking  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe abdominal and lower back pain. The pain is described as ""tearing"" and radiating to his back. Physical examination further reveals an appreciable pulsatile abdominal mass. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg  pulse 90 bpm  temperature 98.6 F  and respiratory rate 20/min. The patient also reports associated symptoms like nausea and restlessness. His concern about his condition and the severe pain he is experiencing indicates a potential complication of his known abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40 pack-year smoking habit  presents with severe sharp and tearing abdominal and lower back pain that suddenly started 2 hours ago. The pain does not radiate to any specific region. He also reports mild nausea with no vomit  no changes in bowel movements  and no urinary symptoms. He has a family history of notice with his father having undergone an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. On examination  the patient has a pulsating abdominal mass and his blood pressure is found to be elevated at 160/90 mmHg. He denies any preceding trauma or heavy lifting. The patient appears diaphoretic and in significant discomfort.

Patient is a 70-year-old Hispanic male with a history of chronic hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with sudden onset  severe  tearing abdominal pain more on the lower back. The pain is constant  radiates to the back and lower extremities  and has lasted for approximately three hours. The patient denies symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting or changes in bowel and bladder habits. On examination  there is a palpable  pulsating mass in the central abdomen and a bruit is auscultated over the mass. The patient's blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and pulse rate is 90 bpm.   Possible risk factors in this patient's past medical history include chronic hypertension  which can cause increased pressure on the arterial wall and lead to aneurysm formation. Hyperlipidemia can also contribute to artherosclerotic changes and weakening of the arterial wall structure. The sudden onset  severe abdominal pain radiating to the back is highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The palpable  pulsating abdominal mass on examination appears to confirm this suspicion. This is deemed a serious  life-threatening condition as it can lead to aortic rupture which can cause internal bleeding and shock.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and a 60 pack-year smoking history presents with sudden onset  severe abdominal and back pain. He also reports feeling a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. Furthermore  he has had recent unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite. He is on medication for hypertension and takes a daily aspirin  but is otherwise in generally good condition. Upon physical examination  the patient appears pale and anxious  with a large palpable  pulsatile mass in the abdomen and hypotension. There is no history of trauma or recent surgical interventions. A previous abdominal ultrasound 2 years ago did not show aortic abnormalities. This clinical picture suggests an abdominal aortic aneurysm that may possibly be ruptured.

Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and a 45-year pack-a-day smoking history  who presented with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and lower back pain that started early this morning. Mr. Smith described the pain as a ripping sensation that didn't improve with changes in bodily position or over-the-counter pain relievers. Over the past week  he also mentioned feeling a pulsating mass in his abdomen which he initially dismissed. He denies having bowel or urinary changes  nausea and vomiting  but does note feeling lightheaded particularly when standing. His father died at an early age from rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He lives with his wife and consumes alcohol moderately. He does not perform any regular exercises.

A 73-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 45 pack-year smoking history  presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain radiating to the back. He additionally notes feeling light-headed. Examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and hypotension. Patient is afebrile  and remaining vital signs were stable barring slightly increased heart rate at 110 bpm. His pain is 10/10 in severity and not relieved by any measures so far.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  smoker  with a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels. He presents with a sudden onset of severe lower back and abdominal pain  which he describes as tearing in nature. The pain began 2 hours ago and has persisted since  with no relief. Also reports a sense of fullness in his abdomen and back. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is noted and the patient also seems to be in hypovolemic shock (tachycardia and hypotension). No history of similar complaints or surgeries. No known allergies. The clinical picture is highly suggestive of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Mr. Miller  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of occasional back pain and abdominal discomfort for the past 4 weeks. He has a significant history of hypertension  moderately controlled with medication  and a 40-pack-year history of smoking  where he quit 10 years ago. On examination  the patient is found to have pulsatile  expansile mass in the umbilical region that is not tender on palpation. An audible bruit is noted over the mass. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. No signs of shock or systemic inflammation are evident. His blood pressure and pulse rate are within normal limits for his age. He has a history of peripheral artery disease. There is no family history of aortic aneurysms. His BMI is 26 and he lives a sedentary lifestyle. The severity of his back pain and abdominal discomfort occasionally affects his appetite and sleep.

Mr. Perez is a 70-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of hypertension (well-controlled with medication)  high cholesterol  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He presents complaining of constant  severe lower back and abdominal pain that started suddenly two days ago. The pain does not radiate and is not associated with nausea  vomiting or any changes in bowel or bladder habits. He denies any recent trauma or injuries. He does however  report mild intermittent claudication on exertion lately. On examination  there's a palpable pulsatile mass in the abdomen and a diffusely tender abdomen. His vital signs are stable. His family history is significant for a brother who died suddenly at age 60 with a post-mortem diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presents with a sudden onset of severe  constant  and gnawing pain in his lower back and abdomen  which is breaking through his chronic back pain medications. He also reports a feeling of fullness in his abdomen  associated with nausea and vomiting. He also exhibits symptoms of tachycardia and hypotension. No history of trauma is reported. His family history reveals that his father died from an ""abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture"". Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. No signs of limb ischemia are noted. Given his history  presentation  demographics  and risk factors (hypertension  smoking  male gender  advanced age  family history)  the patient may potentially be experiencing an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a relevant past medical history of smoking (40 pack-years) and uncontrolled hypertension. Mr. X presents with a sudden onset of severe  tearing lower abdominal and back pain. He reports that he has never experienced this type of pain. Over the past few hours  the pain refused to subside and generally increased upon movement. He also reports that he feels light-headed and occasionally experiences bouts of nausea. On physical examination  he exhibits hypotension and a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient's symptoms  together with his medical history and physical examination findings  are strongly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.

A 70-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking habit presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe abdominal pain  and back pain. The pain is unrelenting and is not reduced by changes in position or activities. He also reports feeling light-headed with palpitations on few occasions. On examination  he appears anxious and pale  with a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation  and an audible bruit can be detected. Initial vitals show an elevated pulse rate and a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. He denies any functions of bowel or bladder changes  no fever  no cough or shortness of breath. History of similar symptoms is not reported by the patient or the family. No history of surgical interventions in the past.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and long-term tobacco use presents with sudden onset severe abdominal and lower back pain. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" and radiating from the back to the legs. He also reports feeling lightheaded and faint. Physical examination identifies abdominal pulsations associated with tenderness. There was a note of previously unnoticed  significant weight loss. His heart rate is tachycardic  blood pressure is low  and signs of peripheral hypoperfusion are noticed on examination. There is no apparent history of surgery or trauma. The patient is a retired construction worker and lives with his wife. He drinks alcohol occasionally but has a 50-pack year history of smoking. His father reportedly had an aortic aneurysm. The patient is concerned as the pain is unlike anything he has experienced before.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels  history of smoking  and no previous surgeries  presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset  severe  constant pain in the back and lower abdomen. The pain is non-radiating  non-colicky in nature. He also complains of light-headedness  a sudden increase in heart rate  and decrease in physical strength on the left side. He denies nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel or bladder habits. Family history includes his father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Physical examination reveals distended abdomen and a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region. The patient also has pallor and his blood pressure is on the lower side. There is no sign of trauma or any other apparent cause of the pain. His peripheral pulses on the left side are decreased. The above symptoms and findings raise a high suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is Mr. John  a 68-year-old Caucasian male arrives at the ER presenting with a sudden and severe pain in the lower back and abdomen. He further elaborates this pain as severe and constant  rating it as an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10. These symptoms were accompanied by extreme pallor  profuse sweating and near syncope. His medical history reveals hypertension and hyperlipidemia; he is an ex-smoker  who quit 10 years ago after a 30-year history of tobacco usage. Notably  he has a known history of small abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rated 3.4 cm in diameter from an abdominal ultrasound done two years ago  for which he was kept on a 6-monthly surveillance program. He has missed his last follow-up appointment  which was due six months ago. However  he denies any familial history of AAA.  On physical examination  he has hypotension with a BP of 90/60 mmHg  pulse rate 110 bpm and he appears distressed. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile  tender  spherical mass in the epigastric area. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

A 69-year-old male with a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and a 45-year smoking history  presents with a sudden  severe abdominal and lower back pain with a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. He endorses an unintentional weight loss of 10 lbs. over the last 6 months  occasional constipation  and decreased appetite. The patient denies nausea  vomiting  or changes in urination or stool pattern. Physical exam reveals a sizable pulsatile mass in the abdomen and mild abdominal tenderness. Blood pressure is slightly elevated at 148/90 mmHg  and patient appears clammy and anxious. There is no history of aortic aneurysm in his family.

Problem Representation:  A 69-year-old Caucasian male smoker  with a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  presents with a sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain that started three hours ago and radiates to his lower back and groins. He also complains of tenderness in the abdominal area. No history of fever  weight loss  or change in bowel or urinary habits. He also experiences mild shortness of breath. He does not have a known familial history of cardiovascular disease or connective tissue disorders. Family history does reveal that his father had an aortic aneurysm. He denies the use of recreational drugs. He has a social history of consuming alcohol occasionally. His daily medications include lisinopril  metoprolol  and atorvastatin. Vitals reveal a blood pressure of 164/92 mmHg  pulse rate of 102 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 36.9°C. Physical examination demonstrates a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. His extremities are warm  without cyanosis  clubbing  or peripheral edema. Additionally  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. Further evaluation like labs  CT scans  and aneurysm measurement are needed for a diagnosis and further treatment plan.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male  former smoker with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol and coronary artery disease  presents with a sudden onset of severe  constant and tearing lower abdominal pain radiating to the back. The patient reports a loss of appetite and recent unexplained weight loss. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower extremity weakness. There is no known family history of aneurysms. He had undergone a coronary angioplasty 5 years ago. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is found on palpation. He also has a slightly lowered blood pressure and his cardiovascular examination revealed bruits over the abdominal region. His EKG does not show any ischemic changes.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-per-year history of smoking. He presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset  severe  and constant pain in the middle and lower abdomen that started 3 hours ago. He also reports a faint pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He denies any gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea  vomiting  constipation  or diarrhea.  He reports feeling dizziness and occasional palpitations  but no chest pain or shortness of breath. His pain has not been relieved with over-the-counter pain medication. He lives alone and has been in his usual state of good health until this incident.  On examination  he is mildly diaphoretic  uncomfortable  and has a tender  distended abdomen with a palpable pulsatile mass. His pulse is 100 beats per minute  blood pressure is 165/85 mm Hg  respirations are regular at 18 breaths per minute  and his oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Labs reveal a hemoglobin of 13 g/dL (normal range: 13-18 g/dL) and slightly elevated creatinine of 1.6 mg/dL (normal range: 0.6-1.3 mg/dL)  suggesting moderate renal impairment.   Mr. Smith's symptoms and medical history make an abdominal aortic aneurysm likely. Further diagnostic imaging is needed to confirm.

The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year smoking history  presenting with significant abdominal and back pain that began suddenly 3 hours ago. The pain is described as tearing and radiating to the back. Physical exam reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient also reports an episode of syncope and shortness of breath. No history of similar episodes or previous diagnosis of aneurysm. Family history  however  reveals a sibling who had an aortic aneurysm. The patient is hemodynamically stable at this time.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 50-pack-year smoking habit presents with sudden severe  tearing abdominal and lower back pain. He describes the pain as constant and not relieved by changing position. He also reports feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. Additionally  he mentions recent unintended weight loss and a decrease in appetite. He denies any bowel disturbances or changes in urination. On physical exam  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. He is hemodynamically stable but appears anxious and distressed.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40 pack-year history of smoking  who presents with sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. He describes the pain as constant and ""ripping"" that has become progressively worse over a course of four hours. He also reports associated symptoms of nausea and lightheadedness. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. He has no history of abdominal surgeries or injuries. The patient's latest vitals include blood pressure of 180/98 mmHg  heart rate of 100 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.7°F  and an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. On auscultation  a bruit is appreciated over the abdominal mass. No signs of peritonitis or lower limb ischaemia are present. His last lipid profile and renal function tests were within normal limits six months ago. He is compliant with his antihypertensive and statin therapy. Liver enzymes  renal function tests  complete blood count  and coagulation profile have been ordered. On reviewing family history  he mentions that his brother underwent surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm five years ago.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history presents with sudden onset  severe abdominal and lower back pain. He indicates that the pain is 10/10 and is unlike any pain he has ever experienced. The pain is constant and does not radiate or change with repositioning. He also reports feeling light-headed and nauseous. On examination  he exhibits a pulsating mass in the abdomen  hypertension with orthostatic hypotension  and diaphoresis. His lab tests show elevated d-dimer levels. There are no signs of trauma  and he denies any recent heavy lifting or strenuous physical activity. He denies any changes in bowel or bladder habits or weight loss. He does have a family history of aortic aneurysms with his father and elder brother both having emergency surgeries for ruptured aortic aneurysms.

A 67-year-old retired male  ex-smoker with a 10-year history of hypertension and high cholesterol  presents with a 3-day history of severe  tearing abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. He also reports feeling lightheaded and has lost his appetite over the past several days. He has no known drug allergies. Family history is significant for father with a ruptured aortic aneurysm at 70 years of age. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and mild tenderness in the peri-umbilical area. His blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg  pulse rate 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 per minute and body temperature 37.0 °C. Rest of the physical examination  including neurological evaluation  is within normal limits. His last lipid panel  6 months ago  showed mixed hyperlipidemia.

Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  45 pack-year history of smoking  and a familial history of cardiovascular disease. He presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  non-radiating abdominal and lower back pain  which started approximately two hours ago. On examination  he appears diaphoretic and a pulsatile mass is palpated in the mid-abdominal area. His blood pressure is marginally low with readings 105/60 mmHg  and his heart rate is slightly increased at 98 beats per minute. He denies any other recent trauma or illness. He reports no recent changes in bowel or bladder control  and no nausea or vomiting. The differential diagnosis at this point most prominently includes an abdominal aortic aneurysm possibly at imminent risk of rupture.

Mr. Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of severe hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 35-year history of smoking (quit 10 years ago)  now presenting with sudden onset of severe lower abdominal and back pain. The pain is sharp  continuous and was not initiated by any known triggers. The patient also reports general feelings of unwell  nausea  and faintness. He denies any trauma  recent illness  changes in bowel or urinary habits  fever or chills. The family history is significant for father who had a fatal abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 78. Physical Exam found a pulsatile abdominal mass accompanied by high blood pressure. BMI calculated as 28 with an active lifestyle  but poor diet history. He reports no known drug allergies  and his current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. Current condition raises significant concerns for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and 50-pack year smoking habit  who presents with acute onset of severe abdominal pain. The pain is described as a sharp  constant  and radiating to the back. The patient also reports feeling a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. There is no associated nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits. There is no history of previous abdominal surgery. The patient has experienced weight loss and poor appetite in the last few months. He is currently taking antihypertensive and statin medications. Past medical history also includes peripheral artery disease. His family history is notable for a brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable  and the patient appears in distress due to pain.

Demographic Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Problem: He presents with sudden and severe abdominal and lower back pain accompanied by episodes of fainting.  Medical History: The patient has a known case of hypertension and atherosclerosis. He also has an extensive smoking history of over 30 years.  Symptoms: Along with the severe pain in the abdomen and lower back  the patient is also experiencing weakness and dizziness  cold and sweaty skin  and a rapid  yet faint  pulse. His abdomen appears distended and is tender to the touch. His lower extremities are experiencing decreased circulation  evidenced by a lowered skin temperature  sluggish capillary refill  and noticeably weakened pulses below the site of pain compared to the upper extremities. There is no record of previous similar episodes.

Demographic Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a history of smoking  hypertension  and high cholesterol. He is on medication for both hypertension and high cholesterol but has been inconsistent in taking his medicines regularly.   Presenting Symptoms: Over the past two weeks  he has been experiencing occasional abdominal pain and a sense of fullness. The abdominal pain is located mainly in his lower abdomen  and middle back which he describes as a ""throbbing"" sensation. His sleeping pattern has been disturbed due to this discomfort  and he has also reported a sudden loss of appetite.  Physical Examination: On examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the mid-abdominal region  which raised suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further investigations are required for a definitive diagnosis and to rule out any potential complications such as rupture.   Patient is being counselled about the potential risks and benefits of endovascular treatment versus surgical management of the suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm. His blood pressure and cholesterol management would need to be optimized. He is also being encouraged to quit smoking.

A 68-year-old male patient with a 30-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with constant  severe lower-back and abdominal pain over the past 6 hours. He reports an associated feeling of light-headedness and shortness of breath. He has been compliant with his hypertension and hyperlipidemia medications. He is an ex-smoker with a 20-pack-year history  quit smoking 10 years ago. He does not consume alcohol. His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at an old age. On examination  there's presence of pulsatile abdominal mass. There are no signs of peripheral ischemia and his pulses are palpable bilaterally in his lower extremities. He appears pale and anxious.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 45-pack year smoking history presented with dull  persistent lower back pain for the past several days. He describes the pain as aches radiating to the hips. He does not recall any specific injury or triggering event for the onset of pain. The pain is not accompanied by fever  chest pain  vomiting  or changes in bowel or bladder function. The patient's blood pressure on presentation is slightly elevated (150/95 mmHg)  and he has a pulsatile mass palpable on his abdomen. The patient also reports unintentional weight loss over the past month  but denied having any other symptoms such as abdominal pain or discomfort.

Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 50-pack year smoking history. He presents to the ER complaining of sudden onset severe  constant  and sharp pain in his back and lower abdomen for the past few hours. The pain began while he was at rest and he describes it as the worst pain he has ever experienced. It is not radiating and is not associated with nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel or bladder function. He also reports feeling lightheaded when he stands up. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and his blood pressure is reading low. The clinical suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm is high based on his risk factors and presenting symptoms.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking  presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset back pain and lightheadedness. The patient also reports a history of intermittent abdominal pain along with unexplained weight loss for the past few weeks. The pain is continuous  does not radiate  and is not relieved by any particular body position. He denies fever  chills  chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or bowel and bladder changes. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. Initial vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension  suggesting possible rupture of the aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with sudden  severe pain in the lower abdomen and back  along with a noticeable pulse near his navel. His medical history is significant for smoking  hypertension  and high cholesterol levels. Patient has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The pain is severe and constant  without any relieving factors. He also complains of feeling cold  clammy  and light-headedness.

Patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male with a longstanding history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with midline lower abdominal and back pain. He reports a 2-day history of intense  constant dull ache in his stomach area that radiates to the lower back. He denies nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits  although he describes a recent unexplained weight loss. The patient has been a heavy smoker for the past 50 years with a 40 pack-year history of tobacco use. His father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 77. His pulse is regular but he has marked abdominal pulsation. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. There is no prior history of such pain  nor has the patient any known allergies. His medications include amlodipine for hypertension  simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. The patient is particularly concerned due to his family history and his own lifestyle as potential risk factors. Based on his age  male sex  family history  significant smoking history  hypertension and the presence of an abdominal pulsation accompanied by pain  there is a high suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for poorly controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with sudden severe lower back pain of 1-hour duration. The pain is non-radiating and is associated with a feeling of fullness and pulsations in his abdomen. On examination  there is evidence of a tender  pulsatile abdominal mass. His vital signs are relatively stable but he reports feeling lightheaded when moving quickly.

A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and smoking presents with intermittent severe abdominal and lower back pain over the past two weeks. He also has noted a pulsatile abdominal mass. He denies bowel or bladder changes  but notes unintentional weight loss. He has no history of surgical interventions. He has tried over-the-counter pain medications without sufficient relief. His father died from an aneurysm rupture but details are unknown. His vitals are stable currently and he doesn't have any known allergies.

A 68-year-old male patient  with past medical history significant for hypertension and high cholesterol for over 15 years  and current smoker with a 30-pack-year history of smoking  presents to the ED complaining of severe  sudden onset of lower back and abdominal pain. Additionally  he reports feeling light-headed and has observed an increase in his pulse rate lately. He has not experienced any changes in his bowel or urinary habits. First degree male relatives have had an abdominal aortic aneurysm in the past. On physical examination  there is a notable pulsatile abdominal mass. His vital signs show a slight tachycardia. His pain score is a 7/10 and is not relieved by any analgesics.

A 72-year-old  Caucasian male  retired engineer  presents with severe  persistent  and localized abdominal pain for the past several hours. He has a 25-year history of heavy smoking (more than 30 cigarettes per day)  uncontrolled hypertension even with antihypertensive therapy  and hypercholesterolemia. Additional historical information includes a diagnosis of peripheral artery disease 3 years ago. The patient denies fever  nausea  or vomiting. He has no known allergies. On physical examination  a painful  pulsatile abdominal mass is palpated in the midline just above the umbilicus. His blood pressure is 170/95 mmHg; heart rate is 90 beats per minute. Distant heart sounds are heard on cardiac auscultation  and diminished pulses are noted in the lower extremities. There is no history of thoracic aortic aneurysm in his family. His past surgical history is unremarkable. The patient's symptoms with relevant medical and family history suggest a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of heavy smoking  uncontrolled hypertension  and high cholesterol  presents with an acute onset of severe  sharp  and tearing abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back and right thigh. The pain is 8/10 in intensity with no associated relieving or aggravating factors. The patient also mentions feeling a pulsating mass in his abdomen  persistent for several days. He reports associated symptoms of dizziness  nausea  and clammy skin. Denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. Physical examination notes a pulsatile abdominal mass with marked tenderness to palpation. An urgent abdominal ultrasound is ordered to further evaluate the suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient has no known allergy. His family history is significant with his father dying in his early 60s due to a ruptured aneurysm. His medications at home include Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  however  he admits to nonadherence to his medications.

Patient Profile: A 70-year-old  Caucasian male with a history of cigarette smoking (two packs/day for over 40 years)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.  Medical History: The patient's hypertension and hyperlipidemia are managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. Family history includes a father who died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient quit smoking 2 years ago.  Presenting Complaint and Symptoms: The patient presents with a complaint of sudden  severe lower back and abdominal pain  consistent with a ruptured AAA. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. The patient also complains of mild shortness of breath and profuse sweat. Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg  heart rate 85 bpm  and SpO2 of 95% in room air.   Problem Representation: In this 70-year old male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  long-term smoking  and a significant family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm who is now presenting with sudden  severe lower back and abdominal pain together with a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass  the clinical concern is a potentially life-threatening ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male  current smoker with a 40-pack per year history and a relevant medical record of hypertension  presents with complaints of severe  sudden onset abdominal and back pain. He has been on regular medication for hypertension. He denies having any fever  nausea  vomiting  change in bowel or bladder habits. It should be noted that he also has a family history of aortic aneurysms. He appeared diaphoretic on physical examination  had a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation  and showed signs of moderate distress.

Mr. Smith is a 78-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  who has presented with complaints of ongoing dull  constant abdominal pain for the past week that radiates towards his lower back. He also mentions associated symptoms of occasional lightheadedness but denies any chest pain  nausea or vomiting. He has a family history of aneurysmal disease with his father having suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. On physical exam  he has a pulsatile mass noted in his abdomen. No bruits are heard over the mass. His cardiovascular exam revealed no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulses are symmetrically strong in all extremities. His BP is 140/85 mmHg  HR is 78 bpm. He is afebrile and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Stevens is a 70-year-old Caucasian man with a significant past medical history of long-standing  untreated hypertension and a 30-year pack history of smoking  who presents with a sudden onset  severe abdominal pain that's radiating to his back. The pain started approximately 2 hours ago and has been steadily increasing in intensity. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" in nature and is more severe than any he has ever experienced before. On further history  he reports recent unintended weight loss  decreased appetite  and occasional dizziness. He has ensured regular check-ups and has no history of other cardiovascular diseases or surgeries. His father also had surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm at a similar age.  Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. Vital signs are significant for high blood pressure (170/100 mmHg)  tachycardia with a heart rate of 112 beats per minute  and normal respiratory rate and temperature. All peripheral pulses are palpable and symmetrical. The rest of the examination is normal. Given his risk factors (age  smoking  hypertension)  symptoms (abdominal/back pain)  and examination findings  an acute abdominal aortic aneurysm is considered.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40-pack year smoking history. He presents with severe  sudden onset lower back pain radiating to the abdomen  along with a pulsatile abdominal mass that he never noticed before. His vital signs reveal a mild tachycardia and normal blood pressure. His physical exam is significant for a palpable  pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. He denies having any chest pain  shortness of breath  bowel irregularities  or urinary complaints. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Demographic Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the last 10 years. He is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago and has no known family history of aortic disease. He has a prior history of coronary artery disease for which stent placement was done 5 years back.  Presenting Problem: The patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that started 2 hours before arrival. He described the pain as constant  sharp and radiating to his lower back. Patient also reported feeling lightheaded in episodes and had one episode of vomiting  but no other gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient denied any fevers  chills  chest pain  cough  or urinary symptoms.  Initial Assessment: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. Blood pressure was found to be lower than baseline. The rest of the systemic examination was within normal limits.   Conclusion: Based on the clinical history and examination  there is a high suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in this patient  which requires immediate surgical consultation and imaging for confirmation.

Patient is a 72-year-old male  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-year smoking history - who presents with severe  abrupt abdominal pain. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation  which started in his stomach area and radiated to his back. He states the pain started about 1 hour ago and has been progressively increasing in intensity. He also reports dizziness  feeling light-headed and sweaty. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass  and a decreased blood pressure of 95/55mmHg. Also  lower extremity pulse examination demonstrates asymmetry. No significant family history of vascular diseases.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year smoking habit presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  tearing mid-abdominal pain radiating to the back. The pain was not associated with food intake or physical activity. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or changes in bowel habits. Additionally  he reveals that he has been experiencing mild  intermittent abdominal discomfort for several months  which he attributed to gastritis and did not seek medical attention. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpated above the navel  and there is tenderness on deep palpation of the abdomen. The patient appears anxious and sweaty. His vital signs on presentation are: Temperature 98.6°F  Blood pressure 180/90 mmHg  Heart rate 100 beats per minute  Respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation 96% on room air.

Demographic Information:  Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking and hypertension.  Medical History:  He has been a smoker for over 40 years although he quit 5 years ago. His blood pressure has been managed on medication for the past 10 years  with intermittent compliance. He has no history of heart disease  diabetes  or high cholesterol. There is a family history of major cardiovascular diseases  specifically his father died of an aortic aneurysm at the age of 72.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Johnson presents today with complaints of a gradually increasing  severe recurrent pain in the abdomen and lower back for the past two weeks. He also describes a sense of fullness in his abdomen. He describes the pain as sharp and constant  which is not relieved by any position or medication. He denies any radiation of the pain  associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or changes in bowel or bladder habits. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents with sudden  severe  and persistent pain in the lower abdominal and back area. He describes the pain as sharp and reports feeling a pulsating sensation around the navel. He rates the pain as an 8 on a scale of 1-10. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history. He has had no prior imaging of the aorta. His family bears a history of aortic aneurysms. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in his abdomen. The rest of the physical examination does not reveal any additional abnormal findings  and his cardiovascular examination is normal. His vitals upon presentation include blood pressure of 168/102 mmHg  a heart rate of 96 beats per minute  and a pain rating of 8 out of 10. There are no past surgical procedures. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. However  he reports nonadherence to the regimen due to financial constraints. He reports no known drug allergies. He doesn't drink alcohol  but has been a smoker for about 45 years.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45 pack-year smoking history  presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass which he noticed incidentally while showering. He also reports a 2-month history of non-radiating  dull abdominal pain. His symptoms are associated with a recent unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds and reduced appetite  but denies any associated GI symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits. Patient has no known allergies and family history is non-contributory. On examination  there is a prominent  pulsatile abdominal mass present in the peri-umbilical region. No overlying skin changes or signs of inflammation. Labs on presentation show normal renal function  mild leukocytosis  and mildly elevated CRP.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male.   Medical History: The patient has a known history of high blood pressure and atherosclerosis. He is an ex-smoker and used to smoke 1 pack/day for the past 30 years. He is moderate drinker and no history of illicit drug use. Over the past year  he has been struggling with high levels of stress due to loss of his beloved wife.  Presenting Complaints: For the past week  the patient has been experiencing acute  severe pain in the middle or lower abdominal region. He also feels tenderness if he touches the site. The pain radiates intermittently to his lower back and/or groin. He admits that the pain is so severe that he has difficulty standing or walking. The patient reports feelings of dizziness  has high pulse rate around 110/min and his blood pressure readings are high and fluctuated.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  the patient’s abdomen is rigid and tender to touch. Notably  a pulsating mass can be detected in the middle and upper part of his abdomen.  Assessment: The symptoms and medical history are most likely to indicate a rupture of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). His hypertension and atherosclerosis  along with his history of smoking  all contribute to this risk. Given the severity of his symptoms  this is a medical emergency.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 45-year pack history of smoking presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset lower back and abdominal pain. The pain is described as tearing  reaching maximum intensity within seconds. He denies any recent trauma  fevers  chest pain  shortness of breath  or any changes in bowel or bladder habits. He also reports feeling a pulsing sensation in his abdomen. He has no known allergies and his current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Physical examination reveals a tender  pulsatile abdominal mass. The remainder of the exam - including chest and extremities - is unremarkable. His BP is 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 88 beats/minute  and his BMI is 28.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a relevant medical history of hypertension and a 30year history of smoking presents with severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain. The pain seems to radiate to his lower back and he also reported about an hour-long episode of lightheadedness  nausea  and near-syncope. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile and palpable abdominal mass  and the patient appeared pale and sweaty. No known family history of vascular diseases or connective tissue disorders. The presenting symptoms  combined with his history of hypertension and long-term smoking  raise high suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 55-pack year smoking history. He presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset tearing abdominal pain radiating to his back  along with hypotension. The patient has also reported an occasional pulsating feeling in his abdomen for the last couple of months. The family history is significant for his father who passed away due to abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture. On physical exam  the patient appears diaphoretic and distressed. Upon palpation  a pulsatile abdominal mass can be felt. This presentation is consistent with a suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 40 pack-year smoking history  presenting with sudden-onset severe abdominal and back pain. He also reports feeling slightly faint. The pain radiates to the lower back and is not associated with any meals  bowel movements or physical activity. Patient denies symptoms of fever  recent trauma  or preceding chest pain.  Physical examination reveals an abdominal bruit and a pulsatile abdominal mass. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg  pulse rate is 90 bpm  and there are no signs of overt hemorrhagic shock. The patient is alert but appears to be in distress due to the pain. Neurologic  respiratory  and cardiovascular examination findings are unremarkable. No evidence of peripheral arterial disease is noted.    He has a known history of a smaller AAA that was less than 5 cm in diameter and was being monitored by his PCP. However  based on his sudden pain and hemodynamic stability  there is concern for possible rupture. He has no history of other cardiovascular disease  and his family history for AAA is unknown. His only medication is amlodipine for hypertension which he has been non-compliant with. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug usage. He has been smoking 2 packs of cigarettes a day for the past 20 years and has failed multiple attempts to quit smoking.   This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with a likely rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  with a known history of hypertension and long-term tobacco use presents with an acute onset of severe abdominal and back pain. The pain is described as constant and is located in the middle of the abdomen radiating through to his back. Examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the midline abdomen  tender to palpation and the patient appears sweaty and pale. Additionally  his pulse is high at 110 beats per minute  and systolic blood pressure is marginally low at 100 mm Hg. He denies experiencing any recent trauma or falls. Previous medical records indicate no prior abdominal aortic interventions or surgeries. His social history is notable for 40 pack-years of cigarette smoking and moderate alcohol use. The patient endorses a history of hypertension controlled with medication  yet denies any known history of cardiovascular disease  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. There is no known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm or sudden death related to it.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient with a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year history of smoking presents with worsening mid-abdominal pain radiating to the back over the last 3 days. The pain is described as sharp and continuous with no associated alleviating or aggravating factors. The patient also reports a sensation of a ""pulse"" or ""heartbeat"" in the abdomen. He denies any history of recent trauma  fever  changes in bowel habits  or urinary symptoms. He has not had any past surgeries. His medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. He does not have any known allergies. On physical examination  the patient shows a palpable  pulsatile epigastric mass. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. The remainder of the examination  including neurologic exam  is unremarkable.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history  presenting with an acute onset of intense  tearing lower back pain. He reports feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen accompanied by nausea and syncope. Vitals reveal elevated blood pressure at 160/90 mmHg and decreased pulses in lower extremities. Physical examination demonstrates a prominent pulsatile abdominal mass. Patient denies any previous similar episodes  changes in bowel or urinary habits or any recent illnesses. There are no known drug allergies or family history of cardiovascular disease. Remainder of the review of systems is non-contributory.

Chief Complaint: 72-year-old Caucasian male with history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset back and abdominal pain.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports that the pain is severe  8/10 in intensity  and located in the lower back and abdominal region. The pain has been persistent for several hours  worsening despite oral analgesics. Pain is not associated with meals or exertional activities. Patient also reports feelings of faintness and a recent unintended weight loss  but denies changes in bowel movements  urinary symptoms  fever  or vomiting.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use (30-pack-year history). No previous surgeries  and no history of diabetes  heart diseases  or stroke.   Family History: Deceased father had a history of peripheral artery disease  mother with hypertension.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  the patient's vitals indicate hypotension (BP 85/55 mmHg) and tachycardia (HR 112 bpm). Abdominal examination reveals a palpable pulsatile mass approximately 5 cm in diameter in the mid- to lower-abdomen which is tender to touch. No signs of abdominal distension  guarding or rebound tenderness are present. Bowel sounds are present and normal. Vascular examination shows no peripheral edema or signs of deep venous thrombosis.  Assessment: The patient's presentation of severe  sudden onset abdominal and back pain  noted hypotension  and tachycardia combined with palpable abdominal mass suggests a highly probable ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient's history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking use further support this potential diagnosis. Emergent surgical consultation is required.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and 45 years of smoking presents with severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain and tenderness  coupled with back pain. He describes it as a tearing pain that radiates to the back. He also reports feeling light-headed and experiencing a rapid heartbeat. On physical examination  he displays a pulsatile abdominal mass and extreme tenderness on palpation. The patient's body habitus is cachectic. He is alert and oriented. His blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mm Hg  pulse 110 bpm  and respirations 24 breaths per minute. His past surgical history is notable for a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide  aspirin  and amlodipine. He denies any use of alcohol or drugs but admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. There is no known family history of any cardiovascular disease. There is also a moderate risk of rupture given his presenting symptoms.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with history of hypertension  smoking  and high cholesterol presented with sudden  severe pain in the back and lower abdomen  with a pulsating sensation around the abdominal region. The patient describes the pain as ""tearing""  and it radiates down to his legs. He also features symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  and lightheadedness. The patient's family history is notable for a brother who had an aortic aneurysm. There are no known drug allergies or previous surgical procedures. Patient is currently on medication for hypertension and cholesterol control.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe abdominal pain  History of Present Illness: The patient reports a sudden onset of severe  sharp  and constant abdominal pain  which started this morning and has continued to worsen. The pain is localized in the lower abdomen and is not related to food intake  bowel movements  or physical exertion.  Past Medical History: The patient has known hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes medications (amlodipine and atorvastatin). He is also a former smoker (30 packs/year for 40 years)  having quit 10 years ago.   Family History: The patient’s father died from a stroke at the age of 75. The patient's mother died from breast cancer at the age of 80.  Review of Systems: Aside from the severe abdominal pain  the patient also reports feeling light-headed and has been experiencing occasional shortness of breath  recent unintentional weight loss  decreased appetite  but denies any chest pain  vomiting  diarrhea  blood in stool  or fever.  Physical Examination: On examination  patient is anxious and diaphoretic. His blood pressure is 158/96 mm Hg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Abdominal exam reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. No lower extremity edema  and pulses are palpable bilaterally in the lower extremities.   Assessment: The combination of severe abdominal pain  a pulsatile abdominal mass in a patient with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and a history of smoking raises a high suspicion for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Plan: Urgent consultation with vascular surgery and immediate imaging with CT angiography to confirm diagnosis.

Patient is an 75-year-old Caucasian male with a relevant medical history of a long-standing smoking habit and high blood pressure. He presents with a sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain that is continuous and not related to meals or bowel movements. Pain is also reported to be radiating to his back. He additionally mentions feeling abnormally full after eating a small amount of food  accompanied by some degree of weight loss in the past few months. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. There has been no previous history of abdominal surgeries. There is known family history of aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history presents complaining of severe acute-onset abdominal pain  radiating to his back  for the past two hours. He further describes the pain as a tearing sensation  rates it as 10/10 in severity  and denies any associated nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel habits  urinary complaints or loss of consciousness. His vitals show persistent arterial hypertension  and on physical examination  he has a pulsatile abdominal mass accompanied by tenderness. No signs of peripheral neurovascular deficits are noticed. Given his risk factors  the acute onset of severe pain  and physical exam findings  a working diagnosis of a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is suggested.

Patient Demographics: A 75-year-old Caucasian male  ex-smoker and frequent drinker  presents to the ER.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a previous history of hypertension and high cholesterol. The patient mentions that his father died due to an aortic aneurysm before the age of 70.  Presenting Symptoms: On presentation  he reports experiencing an abrupt onset of severe  tearing pain in the middle of his abdomen that radiated to his back. He further mentions feeling light-headed and dizzy accompanied with nausea.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  he appears restless and anxious. He is slightly hypertensive with BP 150/90 mm Hg and tachycardia with pulse rate of 110 bpm. Abdominal exam reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and abdominal tenderness.  Summary: The uniquely severe pain  presence of pulsatile abdominal mass and his known risk factors (age  hypertension  family history) are highly indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a prior medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-pack year history of smoking presents with intermittent  vague  lower abdominal discomfort for the past 2 weeks. On examination  a pulsatile mass is felt in the mid-lower abdomen. Further evaluation with an ultrasound reveals a 5 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. He denies any associated symptoms such as radiating back pain  changes in bowel behavior  lower extremity weakness  or any significant weight loss. His vital signs are stable with blood pressure consistency in the hypertensive range. His lipid profile reveals elevated cholesterol levels.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 50-pack year smoking habit  presents with complaints of a sudden onset of severe  sharp  and constant lower back and abdominal pain that began earlier in the day. He also reports feeling light-headed and a little short of breath. He has no fever  nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel habits or urinary symptoms. He also denies chest pain  palpitations or dyspnea. His abdominal examination reveals an expansile pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area. There is no abdominal tenderness or guarding. His cardiovascular exam shows tachycardia with normal S1 and S2  and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. His extremities show no edema  and peripheral pulses are palpable bilaterally.

A 70-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset of severe  tearing lower back pain radiating to his abdomen. The patient reports he has no history of abdominal issues and denies experiencing any gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea vomiting or changes in his bowels. He has never smoked  has a family history clear of similar symptoms  and lives an active lifestyle. On presentation  patient is noted to be slightly diaphoretic with moderate distress due to pain. His abdomen is nontender and soft but there is a palpable pulsatile mass in the middle and lower part of his abdomen  indicating potential rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Jones  a 74-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with persistent back and abdominal pain over the past two days. He has a smoking history of 30 pack-years but quit 5 years ago. He has a known diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is under medication. He has no family history of cardiovascular or connective tissue disorders. On presentation  he appears in mild distress due to pain  but vital signs are stable. Pertinent physical exam findings include a tender  pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region. The patient also reports having unexplained recent weight loss. He has not noticed blood in his stool and has no history of liver disease or cancer. There are no urinary symptoms or signs of intestinal obstruction. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower extremity swelling.

A 73-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 40-pack year history of smoking  presents with sudden onset  severe abdominal pain that radiates to his back. The pain was noted to begin abruptly  reaching maximum intensity almost immediately. It is described as a tearing sensation  constant  and not relieved by any position or medications. There are no associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  diarrhoea  fever  or urinary symptoms. His vitals reveal a pulse rate of 110 per minute and blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows a pulsatile mass with his abdomen being distended and tender to palpation.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-a-year smoking habit  presents to the ER with sudden  severe abdominal and back pain which he describes as tearing and radiating to his groin and legs. He is also experiencing nausea  clamminess  and rapid heart rate. Upon examination  a pulsating mass can be felt in his abdomen  coupled with profound hypotension. The patient's symptoms and risk factors align with a suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-pack year smoking history who presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain. The pain is constant  located in the lower back and abdomen  and has increased in severity over the last few hours. Patient also feels light-headed and has been experiencing an unsteady gait. No associated nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits. Exam reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdomen and tenderness on palpation. His vitals indicate tachycardia and hypotension.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with significant medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 20-year pack smoking with occasional alcohol intake. Patient presents with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain which he describes as a continuous and sharp pain with a rating of 8 out of 10 on pain scale. The pain is primarily located at mid-abdomen and lower back  and does not radiate to groin or buttocks. He denied any changes in bowel moments or urinary symptoms  though reported lightheadedness and a vague feeling of weakness. On physical examination  he was found to have a pulsating mass palpable in the abdomen  around the navel. No gastrointestinal or urinary symptoms are reported. His last general physical examination was 2 years ago and he hadn't participated in any health screening program since. Family history uncovers that his father had suffered from aortic aneurysm and died at 76 years of age.

Mr. Ivan Kovacs is an 81 year-old Caucasian male  a former smoker with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and peripheral artery disease  presents with sudden severe abdominal and back pain for the last two hours. He denies prior episodes  nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel or bladder function. He appears diaphoretic and anxious. Family history is significant for aortic aneurysm. On examination  he is hypertensive and his pulse is rapid and weak. Abdominal palpation reveals a pulsatile mass that's approximately 5 cm in diameter. The pain does not radiate and is not alleviated by positional changes. Thus  the initial impression is of a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and heavy smoking for 30 years  presents with intermittent  dull aching pain and a pulsating sensation in the mid-abdominal region for the past 2 weeks. The pain occasionally radiates to his lower back. The patient also reports unexplained weight loss and decreased appetite over the same period. He denies any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  rectal bleeding  or changes in bowel habits. The patient has no prior surgical history. His father passed away due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Physical examination reveals a palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass. There are no signs of limb ischemia. Blood pressure is controlled and lipid profile is slightly elevated.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history notable for smoking  hypertension  and high cholesterol who presents with complaints of intense abdominal pain that can be described as a tearing sensation  extending to his lower back area. The pain is sudden in onset and he mentions feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He is experiencing mild nausea and light-headedness. Detailed familial history has revealed that his father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. The patient's blood pressure is moderately reduced and pulse rate is slightly elevated. His BMI is under the obese range.

Demographic Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: Known history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and smoking. The patient has no known allergies  carries a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and has a positive family history of both cardiovascular disease and abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in a first-degree relative.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient has been experiencing episodes of periodic abdominal and back pain for the past four weeks. The pain  initially mild and intermittent has progressively become severe and persistent  and is described as deep  throbbing  and not related to physical activity or food intake.   On physical examination: The presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass was noted. He also reports recent unexplained weight loss. No bowel or bladder changes were reported.

A 72-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and previous smoking presents with consistent mid-abdominal pain and lower back pain for the past 24 hours. He describes the pain as dull and continuous. He also reports recent unexplained weight loss and fatigue. He denies any changes in bowel or bladder habits. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass is detected in the mid-abdominal region. His blood pressure is slightly increased  and mild tenderness in the abdomen is noted on palpation.

Mr. Johnson  a 66-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and a 30-year pack history of smoking presents with a two-day history of severe  constant  and sharp abdominal pain. The pain does not radiate to any particular region but is more pronounced in the lower abdomen and back. He rates it 9/10 in severity and denies any alleviating or exacerbating factors. He reports associated nausea  a one-time episode of vomiting  significant unexpected recent weight loss but no changes in his bowels or bladder habits. He has no known allergies  consumes alcohol occasionally  and quit smoking ten years ago. His medications include amlodipine for hypertension and a daily aspirin. He denies any family history of similar problem  cancer or cardiovascular diseases. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile  expansile mass in his abdomen. His abdomen is tender with an increased pain on palpation over the mass. He appears pale and vital signs indicate hypotension and increased heart rate.

A 72 year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 50-pack/year smoking habit  presents with a recent-onset of severe  constant  abrupt lower back pain  radiating to his groin and legs. He also describes a pulsating feeling in the abdomen along with early satiety and unintentional weight loss. On physical examination  he exhibits abdominal tenderness and an audible bruit over his abdomen was noted. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and 40 pack-years of tobacco usage presents with a 2-day history of mid-abdominal pain. The pain is characteristically constant  severe  and radiates to his lower back. He also reports associated symptoms of lightheadedness and mild shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass in mid abdomen that is pulsatile  tender and around 5 cm in diameter. He is hemodynamically stable but appears in moderate distress due to pain. There is no family history of known abdominal aortic aneurysms.

A 68-year-old male  former smoker  with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain  localized to the lower belly and radiating to the back. The patient also notes feeling faint with occasional episodes of dizziness. On examination  a pulsating mid-abdominal mass is palpated. He has no allergy and is currently on Gliclazide and Lisinopril. There's no family history of aneurysms. His vital signs on presentation were: blood pressure: 145/90mmHg  pulse: 105/min  oxygen saturation: 96% on room air and temperature 36.5 °C. The tenderness is increased on deep palpation and percussion over the area of the abdominal mass. A bruit can be heard on auscultation.

Demographics: 75-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: History of long-term smoking (60-pack years)  well-controlled hypertension  and a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). No other significant past medical conditions.   Presenting Complaints: The patient came in with complaints of sudden onset abdominal pain  which he describes as “tearing” that started around 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to the lower back and is not associated with meals  bowel movements  or urination. It is his first experience of such a pain. He also complains of unexplained weight loss over the last few months and feeling a pulsating mass in the abdomen. No fever  nausea  vomiting  hematuria  chest pain  or fainting episodes. He seems slightly uncomfortable and anxious due to this unusual pain.   Physical Examination: Vital signs - BP: 150/90 mmHg  HR: 100 bpm  RR: 18 breaths/min  Temp: 98.6°F. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen  and tenderness is noted on deep palpation. Peripheral pulses are present and equal; no signs of limb ischemia are noted.  Relevant Findings: The above demographic factors  risk factors  presentation  and physical findings are characteristic of a progressively enlarging abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  which is a life-threatening emergency due to increased risk of rupture.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  known smoker with a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension  dyslipidemia  and familial predisposition for abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). He presents with a sudden-onset severe abdominal pain and mild lower back pain  which he describes as ""tearing"" in nature. The pain radiates to the back and is not associated with food intake  bowel habits  urination  or any specific triggers. He also complains of mild nausea but denies any associated vomiting  change in appetite  or noticeable weight changes. He denies any previous similar episodes. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable But no signs of hypotension or shock are present. End-organ damage is absent: no changes in mental status  kidney function  or distal pulses. His vitals are stable with mildly elevated BP. He has never undergone screening for AAA  despite his risk factors. Considering his history and symptoms  he may have a symptomatic or possibly ruptured AAA.

Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history. He presents today with a concerning symptom of acute-onset mid-abdominal and lower back pain that is not colicky  accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The pain was sudden and is gradually worsening. On physical examination  he has a pulsatile abdominal mass present in the midline of abdomen. His peripheral pulses are palpable and symmetrical. His blood pressure is elevated at 160/100 mmHg. There is also slight tenderness on deep palpation around the mid-abdominal region. He reports unintentional weight loss in the last month and reduced appetite. The clinical findings are suggestive of an advanced abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents with a sudden  severe abdominal pain radiating to his back. He reports the pain as constant  and a 10/10 on the severity scale. The pain was sudden in onset and has gradually become more severe. There are no associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  or weight loss. He smokes 2 packs of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. He denies any recent fever  trauma  or change in bowel habits. Patient has never had an abdominal surgery. Family history reveals his father had an aneurysm repair in his sixth decade. Physical exam shows a pulsatile abdominal mass; no tear or rupture evidence.

A 65-year-old male named Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden  severe  persistent pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain was characterized as ""ripping"" and radiated to his back. He also disclosed that he felt faint  and had experienced episodes of dizziness and shortness of breath. His medical history revealed hypertension consistently managed with medication. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His family history includes a brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. His blood pressure was 160/90 mm Hg  pulse rate was 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute. His BMI was within normal range.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  smoking  and peripheral vascular disease presents with acute onset  severe pain in his lower back and abdominal area accompanied by light headedness and a feeling of ""passing out"". The patient also reports noticing a pulsatile mass in their abdomen. He has never had such a severe abdominal pain before. There is no history of any surgery. The pain is not associated with food intake or bowel movement. Family history includes deaths due to stroke in his father and an aneurysm in his uncle.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with a sudden onset of severe abdominal and lower back pain. The pain is described as a sharp  tearing sensation that radiated to the back and groin. Patient also reports mild shortness of breath and an elevated heart rate with a feeling of a pulse in his abdomen. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking but no family history of aortic aneurysm or other vascular disease. On physical examination  the patient appears in distress with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 100 beats per minute. Abdominal exam reveals a pulsating mass in the central abdomen. Diagnostic imaging confirms an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6cm in diameter.

Problem Representation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of heavy smoking  hypertension  and high cholesterol  currently managed on beta-blockers and statins  presents with constant  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen over the past 36 hours. This is the first occurrence of such symptoms and reports no alleviating or aggravating factors. He also reports a feeling of fullness in his abdomen and a pulsating sensation. He denies any recent trauma  weight loss  changes in bowel or bladder habits  or fever. On exam  there is a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass. His vital signs are stable  although his blood pressure is at the high end of his normal range. His remaining physical exam is unremarkable. Diagnosis with imaging is required but the clinical suspicion is high for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
