Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  diagnosed with hypertension and high cholesterol levels. He has been a smoker for 50 years and currently smokes one pack per day. He has a history of peripheral artery disease and is also moderately obese. There is a family history of aortic disease. He presents with sudden onset  severe abdominal pain that radiates to the back  along with tenderness in the abdominal region. Pain is not related to meals and there are no alleviating or aggravating factors. Furthermore  he complains of unexplained weight loss over the last six months but no change in appetite. There is no history of nausea  vomiting  fever  or changes in bowel or bladder habits. physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. No signs of other organ involvement.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of chronic smoking (40 pack-years) and hypertension presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that radiates to his back. The patient also reports associated nausea  vomiting  and mild shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass with tenderness to palpation in the mid and lower abdomen  and mild hypotension. The patient has a known history of atherosclerosis but denies any history of familial aortic aneurysm disorders. He has no known drug allergies and is currently on Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. There is no history of recent trauma or surgical intervention. The patient’s family history is notable only for father that passed away due to myocardial infarction. His social history reveals he is retired and lives with his wife and he quit smoking 2 years prior.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male retired construction worker presents with a newly recognized pulsatile abdominal mass and associated intermittent dull and throbbing abdominal pain. He reports having noticed the mass a few weeks ago and states that the pain seemed to worsen over this period. He also mentions a history of smoking (30 pack-years)  hypertension currently treated with lisinopril  and a family history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with his father having been diagnosed at 70. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is felt on palpation. No other relevant symptoms such as weight loss  fevers  or changes in bowel or urinary patterns are reported. No previous surgeries or traumatic incidents are noted. The patient's blood pressure is elevated (155/98 mmHg) and heart rate is within the normal range.

Demographics: Mr. Thompson  a 72-year-old retired firefighter  smoker for 40 years  with a BMI of 25.  Medical History: He has a known history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and peripheral arterial disease diagnosed three years ago. He has been on anti-hypertensives and statins for the same.  Presentation: He presented to the emergency room with a sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen  rated as 9/10  described as tearing in nature and radiating to his back and groin. The pain was associated with feelings of lightheadedness and shortness of breath. Physical exam revealed a pulsatile mass about 5cm in diameter in the abdomen  slightly tender to touch. His blood pressure was 140/90mmHg and his pulse rate was 82 bpm. Mr. Thompson's anxious and pale appearance has further intensified the clinical suspicions of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking  high blood pressure  and hyperlipidemia presents with abdominal discomfort  persistent back pain  and occasional palpitations. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. On physical examination; a pulsatile  palpable abdominal mass was noted. His blood pressure was noted to be high (155/90 mmHg). He reported unintentional weight loss over the past 4 months. The preliminary diagnosis is Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).

Patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history for hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40-year history of smoking. He presents with complaints of intense  sudden abdominal pain radiating to his back for the past 6 hours  accompanied by cold  sweaty feet and shortness of breath. Patient has been feeling light-headed  has vomited twice since the onset of pain. Patient was in normal health until the sudden onset of symptomatic complaints. His pain has been consistent and did not alleviate with any change in position or movement. No known drug allergies. Currently on medication for blood pressure and cholesterol management.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile:   A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen that started a few hours ago. The pain is not radiating anywhere and is accompanied by a lightheadedness and a feeling of unease. The patient has a history of smoking  but quit about 10 years ago. He is a retired accountant and lives with his wife. They have two adult children and four grandchildren.   Relevant Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels for which he takes medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin). The patient also has a previous history of peripheral artery disease and is on baby Aspirin. The patient was diagnosed with early-stage COPD last year due to his smoking history. He is not diabetic  and there is no reported history of cancer or kidney diseases.   Family History:  The patient's father had cardiovascular disease and died from a stroke. His mother had Alzheimer's. He also has an older brother who was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  which was successfully repaired years ago.   Current medications:   - Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension - Atorvastatin 20mg daily for high cholesterol levels - Aspirin 81mg daily for peripheral artery disease - Inhalers for COPD (Albuterol as needed and Symbicort 160/4.5mcg bid)  Evaluation and Problem Identification:  Given the patient's history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels  peripheral artery disease  elderly age  and familial history of AAA  the clinician considered a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The acute onset of severe and persistent lower back and abdominal pain further supports this hypothesis. The low blood pressure and the feeling of unease could suggest shock or internal bleeding. An urgent abdominal ultrasound is required to confirm the diagnosis.   Plan:  - Commence ABC's of life support - Emergency ultrasound - Consultation with vascular surgery - MRI if condition allows - Blood tests: Complete blood count  renal function  coagulation profile  blood type and crossmatch - IV fluids and pain management (consider opioid analgesia) - Blood pressure and heart rate monitoring - Surgery if AAA is confirmed (endovascular repair vs. open repair depending on the patient's health and the size and location of the aneurysm).   Differential Diagnoses:  - Renal Colic (due to the location of pain) - Myocardial infarction (given the history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels) - Gastro-intestinal problems like acute appendicitis  diverticulitis or pancreatitis

Patient Representation:  1. Demographics Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who is retired. He is a former smoker (quit 20 years ago)  has a regular alcohol intake within recommended guidelines  and has a body mass index of 27 kg/m2. He lives with his wife. He has 3 adult children and 8 grandchildren. Prior to his retirement  he worked in an office setting.   2. Presenting Information The patient presents with complaints of back pain that has been consistent for two months. The pain intensity fluctuates  and does not seem to be associated with meals or physical activity. He also reports unintentional weight loss  occasional abdominal pain  and a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. The patient also mentions an incident of lightheadedness about a week ago.  3. Past Medical History He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago and manages it with oral hypoglycemic agents. He has had no prior surgeries or known allergies  and his immunizations are up-to-date.  4. Family History There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died from a myocardial infarction in his early 70s  and his brother underwent a coronary artery bypass in his late 60s. He has one maternal uncle who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  5. Social History He denied current tobacco use but mentioned he quit smoking 20 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially  usually not more than two standard drinks a day. He does not use illicit drugs.  Based on history  symptoms  and family history  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected and further investigation is needed.    6. Medications - Metformin 500mg twice daily (for T2DM). - Lisinopril 10mg daily (for hypertension) - Atorvastatin 40mg at bedtime (for high cholesterol).  7. Review of Systems Everything is otherwise normal  with no other reported abnormalities or complaints.  8. Physical Examination The patient appears comfortable  an abdominal bruit is heard on auscultation and there's a palpable mass in the abdominal area. No masses or enlargement of lymph nodes is appreciated anywhere else on the body. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  This should allow for adequate representation of a typical patient presenting with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile:  Gender: Male Age: 70 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired construction worker Location: Rural Midwestern United States  Presenting Problem: The patient comes in complaining of a sudden onset of severe and persistent abdominal pain. He describes the pain as a deep  intense throbbing sensation that has not been relieved with over-the-counter pain medications. The patient also reports lightheadedness  rapid heartbeat  and clammy skin.  History of Present Illness: The patient has noticed occasional mild abdominal discomfort over the past few months  which he attributed to aging or indigestion. However  the pain has dramatically increased in severity within the last 24 hours.  Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension  which has been managed with antihypertensive medication. His medical history also includes high cholesterol and a 40-year history of cigarette smoking. He discontinued smoking 5 years ago. The patient had an episode of myocardial infarction about 8 years back. His family history reveals that his father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at age 75.  Medications: The patient is currently on Atenolol 50 mg once daily and Atorvastatin 40 mg once daily for his hypertension and high cholesterol  respectively.   Allergies: The patient reports no known drug allergies.  Social History: The patient lives with his wife and has a supportive community including two adult children who live within the town. He was a long-term smoker but quit 5 years ago. He acknowledges that he has a sedentary lifestyle and his diet could be better. He drinks alcohol socially  averaging about three drinks per week.  Physical Examination: The patient appears distressed  is in obvious abdominal pain  with pallor and sweating. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Impression: Considering the patient's age  gender  medical history  family history  physical examination findings of a pulsatile abdominal mass with sudden severe abdominal pain  lightheadedness and rapid heartbeat  the clinical suspicion is strong for the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Urgent imaging studies  including an abdominal ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) scan  are needed to confirm the diagnosis  determine the size and location of the aneurysm  and guide further management.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient  living in an urban setting  is a retired teacher with a low to moderate socioeconomic status.  Chief Complaint: The patient has been experiencing intermittent abdominal and lower back pain for a few weeks.  Representative Symptoms:  Recurrent  severe abdominal pain  a pulsating sensation in the abdomen  and persistent back pain. Incidental findings upon physical examination may include a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Demographic Characterization: The patient has a history of smoking having quit fifteen years ago  drinks alcohol socially  and leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases including an uncle who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His diet is moderately balanced but he admits to indulging in high cholesterol and high sodium foods more often than recommended.  Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient has controlled hypertension for which he is on medication  hypercholesterolemia and had an ischemic stroke two years ago. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease a year ago.  Social History:  The patient enjoys playing chess  reading novels  and has an active social life attending community group meet-ups. He is a widower and lives with his adult son who recently moved in due to unemployment.  Medication History: The patient takes antihypertensives  a statin for his hypercholesterolemia  and antiplatelet therapy post-stroke.  Patient-Specific Factors:  The patient shows good adherence to medication and healthcare advice  although his lifestyle is primarily sedentary. He demonstrates resilience and has a supportive social network  which could potentially aid in recovery and management. However  he has multiple cardiovascular risk factors including age  male gender  hypertensive and hyperlipidaemic disease  and history of smoking  which increase his susceptibility to an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Conclusion:  An abdominal aortic aneurysm is likely  given the patient's persistent abdominal and back pain  pulsatile abdominal mass  along with demographic and lifestyle factors. Immediate steps should be taken to confirm the diagnosis through appropriate imaging tests  taking into consideration his multiple cardiovascular risks. Upon confirmation  a treatment plan should be laid out which includes suitable surgical or endovascular procedure and long-term management of risk factors and comorbidities.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Mr. Jones is a 72-year-old Caucasian male.  Demographics: - He is a retired construction worker  married with 3 children and 8 grandchildren.  - He is a lifelong resident of an urban setting. - He lives with his wife in their own home and is entirely self-sufficient. - His annual income is stable  coming from his pension and social security.  Past Medical History: - Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension well-controlled with medication (lisinopril 20mg daily). - He smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years but quit 10 years ago. - He is also diagnosed with moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is on inhaled bronchodilators. - Mr. Jones's father died at the age of 68 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  prompting a concern for familial tendencies. - He follows a moderate diet and exercise regimen.  Presenting Issue: - Mr. Jones presents with a complaint of lower back and abdominal pain which he describes as a throbbing feeling that is constant but not severe. - The pain has been on-going for the past two months  gradually increasing in intensity.  Clinical Findings: - Physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. - Ultrasound confirms the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.2 cm in diameter.  In this case  the significant risk factors for Mr. Jones’s situation include advanced age  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  COPD  and a family history of AAA. Considering the size of the aneurysm (5.2 cm in diameter) and the patient’s current symptoms  he is at a high risk for the rupture of the AAA. Surgical intervention might be necessitated as the next course of action for his management.

Problem Representation:   Mr. X is a 70-year-old male Caucasian patient  a retired police officer residing in a suburban setting. He is a non-vegetarian  smoker and has been consuming moderate amounts of alcohol for around 40 years. He is presented with complaints of persistent localized abdominal and back pain over the past 72 hours which is increasing in intensity. The patient describes the pain as a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  similar to heartbeat. No other symptoms like fever  biliary symptoms  or gastrointestinal symptoms reported.  He has significant past medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He has no personal history of coronary artery disease or stroke  though his father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and his mother suffered from stroke. His last preventive health screening comprising blood tests  colonoscopy and routine physical check-up was done 11 months ago  results of which were within normal limits. It is noted that he missed his annual ultrasound screening of the abdominal aorta because of his personal circumstances.  His current medication list includes: Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  Atorvastatin 20mg daily for high cholesterol  multivitamins  and occasional OTC analgesics for related pain management. He is not on any anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy and has no known substance allergies. He lives with his wife  three loose dogs  and is fairly active in his community. He attends his local church and is an active member in his neighborhood advocacy group. His wife states that he has been more fatigued over the past week and has shown decreased appetite.  Given his age  sex  genetic composition  smoking history  hypertension  high cholesterol  presence of chronic abdominal and back pain  and family history  he is suspected to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He will require further investigations for confirmation and management.

Patient Profile:  Demographics: - Name: John Doe - Age: 70 years old  - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired (Previous: Construction Worker) - Residence: Lives alone in a single-story house in suburban area - Insurance: Medicare  Medical History: - Smoking History: 30 pack years (quit 10 years ago) - Alcohol Usage: Moderate drinker (2-3 times per week) - Drug Usage: None - Relevant Family History: Father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at age 65 and maternal grandfather died from AAA rupture at age 75 - Cardiovascular History: Non-insulin dependent type 2 diabetes  high blood pressure - Previous Surgeries: Appendectomy (age 25)  Total Knee replacement (age 60) - Current Medications: Metformin for Diabetes  Lisinopril for Hypertension  Presenting Problem:  - John Doe presented to the clinic with dull  throbbing mid-abdominal pain that he has had intermittently over the past month. His primary care physician referred him after she noted pulsations in abdomen during a routine physical checkup.  - Pain description: Moderate  5/10 on pain scale  constant  non-radiating  dull ache - Associated symptoms: He also reported feeling fatigue and weight loss in recent weeks but no associated fever  nausea or changes in bowel habits.  - Risk Factors: John Doe's age  gender  family history of AAA  smoking  and history of high blood pressure and diabetes make him at high risk for Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.  Concern:   Potential Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Given John Doe's risk factors  symptoms  and primary care physician's discovery of abdominal pulsations  it is necessary to evaluate for the possibility of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  which left untreated  may rupture and lead to life threatening internal bleeding.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male. Professionally  he is a retired mechanic. He is a smoker with a 40-pack-year history. He also reports a moderate consumption of alcohol  with an average of four alcoholic beverages per week. He is moderately active and lives with his wife in a suburban environment.   Presenting Problem:  The patient has presented to the hospital with complaints of constant  severe abdominal pain that began suddenly. The pain is felt mostly near the navel area. He also reported feeling a pulse in his abdomen and has a history of unexplained weight loss.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol  for which he is on amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. He has been treated for peripheral artery disease in the past. His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  and on the maternal side of the family  there is a history of coronary artery disease.  The patient's vital signs on presentation to the hospital include: Blood pressure: 160/95 mmHg  Pulse: 98 bpm  Oxygen saturation: 97% on room air  Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute  and Temperature: 36.7°C.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  a palpable pulsatile mass was noted in the patient's abdomen. No signs of shock or rupture were evident at the time of presentation.  This combination of demographic features  personal and familial past medical history  symptom presentation  and physical examination findings raises a high level of suspect for the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Further diagnostic tests such as abdominal ultrasound or CT angiogram may be ordered to confirm the diagnosis and determine the size and location of the aneurysm  so that appropriate treatment options can be discussed and implemented.

Patient Profile:  Gender: Male Age: 68 years old Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanic Residence: Suburban area  Presenting Issue:  The patient presents with persistent  sharp abdominal pain expanding to the back along with tenderness in the abdominal region. He also reports a pulsating sensation near the belly button area.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years and has been regularly taking anti-hypertensive medication.  2. Smoking: He is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history. He quit 5 years back.  3. Cardiovascular disease: The patient had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago with subsequent coronary angioplasty.  4. High cholesterol: The patient was diagnosed with high cholesterol 8 years ago and is on statin therapy.  5. Family History: The patient's father died at the age of 60 from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.  6. Previous surgeries: Carpal tunnel release surgery and appendectomy more than 20 years ago.  Current Medications:  1. Antihypertensive Medications (Lisinopril) 2. Statins (Atorvastatin) 3. Aspirin - for previous heart disease  Investigation to be done:  Due to the typical presentation of symptoms and risk factors  an Ultrasound or CT scan is recommended for confirmation of abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Given the age  gender  history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  elevated cholesterol levels  and family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  the patient fits the high-risk category for abdominal aortic aneurysm. Therefore  consultation with a vascular surgeon is suggested for further evaluation and management.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male retired construction worker who currently lives alone is presenting complaint of intermittent  vague abdominal pain for the past several months.  Vital Signs and General Appearance: Vital signs are stable  although the patient appears to be slightly diaphoretic and anxious.   Medical History: The patient has a long history of smoking and is known to have high blood pressure which is poorly controlled. He also has a significant history of high cholesterol  atherosclerosis and peripheral artery disease.  Social History: The patient admits to having been a heavy smoker for more than 50 years  although he quit around five years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and has a diet high in saturated fats and lacking in fruits and vegetables. His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Physical Examination: Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass  a classic sign of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. No bruit is heard over the mass. Lower extremity pulses are diminished.  Laboratory Tests/Imaging: An Ultrasonography is conducted which confirms the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Problem List: 1. Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm 2. Hypertension (poorly controlled) 3. Hypercholesterolemia 4. Atherosclerosis 5. Peripheral Artery Disease 6. History of heavy smoking (quit 5 years ago) 7. High fat diet 8. Family history of AAA  Plan: 1. Immediate vascular surgery consultation considering the size of aneurysm and potential risk of rupture.  2. Tight control of blood pressure and cholesterol to slow aneurysm growth would be managed by primary care provider and cardiologist. 3. Promoting lifestyle changes like diet modifications to reduce cholesterol levels and continued abstinence from smoking. 4. Regular surveillance and follow-up.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired construction worker and currently lives alone. He is a smoker with a 40-year smoking history  consuming 1 pack per day. He has a 20-year history of poorly controlled hypertension. He is moderately obese with a BMI of 32. He has limited physical activity and follows an unhealthy diet.  Past Medical History: The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension which has not been well-controlled  with frequent readings above 160/90 mmHg. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 15 years ago and was prescribed statin therapy  however  his adherence to the medication has been inconsistent. Additionally  he has type 2 diabetes mellitus with suboptimally controlled blood sugar levels. He has a history of intermittent claudication and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease from prolonged smoking. No history of renal disease  liver disease  or gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient has no history of any surgeries in the past.  Presenting Problem: The patient has been experiencing episodic abdominal pain and back pain for the past two months. The pain is persistent and is not relieved with over the counter analgesics. He denies any changes in bowel habits or urinary symptoms. The patient also reports feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen.  On examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the abdomen. From these symptoms and findings  abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected.  This relationship between the clinical characteristics  habits and past medical history of the patient increases his risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The combination of advanced age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension and atherosclerotic disease provides high risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain.  Patient Profile: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a corporate job leading a sedentary lifestyle and lives with his wife in an urban area. The patient is a former smoker with a 40-year pack history  socially drinks on occasion  and is on a diet with frequent consumption of red meat and fatty foods.   Past Medical History: His family history consists of his father passing away due to ischemic heart disease and his mother from stroke. He has been suffering from hypertension and high cholesterol for ten years and has been on long-term medication. He had a myocardial infarction 7 years ago  followed by a successful angioplasty.   Surgical History: No prior surgical history but regular check-ups due to his past myocardial infarction.  Social History: The patient is a former smoker who quit about five years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol occasionally and does not exercise regularly.  Current Condition: The patient presents with a severe  sudden onset of abdominal pain that has been persisting for the last few hours. The pain seems to be radiating into his back and lower regions. Upon physical examination  the doctor found a pulsating mass in the mid-abdominal region. He mentioned feelings of dizziness and occasional lightheadedness.  Medications: The patient is currently taking calcium channel blockers and statins for his hypertension and high cholesterol.  Provisional diagnosis: Given his history and the presence of a pulsating abdominal mass  the patient is suspected of having an abdominal aortic aneurysm. An ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) scan are recommended for further investigation and confirmation of the diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  who presents with a sudden onset of severe lower back pain and reports a history of hypotension. Additionally  he reveals a past medical history significant for hypertension  smoking (40 pack-years)  and coronary artery disease. He underwent a previous surgical procedure for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 7 years prior.   Family history is notable for cardiovascular disease  as his father died at 68 years due to myocardial infarction  and his older brother has a diagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysm.   On examination  he has a pulsatile abdominal mass. His BMI is 29  blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg  heart rate is 105 bpm  and O2 sat 96% on room air.   Overall  the patient's advanced age  sex  smoking history  hypertensive history  and family history significantly suggest a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm which may have ruptured  given his symptoms and physical findings. An urgent surgical consultation is recommended.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  - Gender: Male - Age: 68 years-old - Race: Caucasian - Occupational status: Retired engineer - Marital status: Widowed; with 3 adult children - Health behaviors: Smoker (30 pack years); drinks alcohol moderately; limited physical activity  Presenting Symptoms: - Pain in the abdomen (mid-to-lower) and back  mostly constant but occasionally can be throbbing - Palpable abdominal mass  Past Medical History: - History of hypertension (controlled with medications) - History of hyperlipidemia (managed through diet and medication) - Mild obesity with BMI of 32 - Sibling deceased due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm   Physical Examination: - Mildly distended abdomen  non-tender  pulsatile abdominal mass palpable - Normal bowel sounds  no signs of gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction - Peripheral pulses palpable bilaterally but significantly decreased at the level of the feet   Investigations: - Abdominal ultrasonography suggested an aneurysm in the abdominal aorta - CT Angiogram confirmed a saccular abdominal aortic aneurysm with anterior wall thickness of 7.3 cm  with no evidence of rupture or leak  Treatment: - Patient has been referred to a vascular surgeon for further management. Possible options include Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR) or Open Aneurysm Repair  depending upon the general health and other factors relevant to the patient. - Smoking cessation and risk factor modification encouraged.   Follow up: - Regular six-month follow-up with vascular surgery post-AAA repair surgery - Lifelong follow-up with primary care physician for management of cardiovascular risk factors and general health - Lifestyle modifications advised  including regular physical activity  a healthy diet  and strict no-smoking policy.   This problem representation provides a concise overview of the patient  their relevant medical history  and current clinical situation. It allows for an understanding of the problem at hand and its context  helping to guide further management and care.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Peterson is a 73-year-old Caucasian male brought to the emergency room due to a sudden onset of abdominal pain. It was described as severe  intermittent  and radiating to his back. The patient also noted feelings of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. Other relevant symptoms include a decreased appetite  weight loss  and fainting spells.  The patient's lifestyle revolves around his 40 years of history as a heavy smoker  averaging about 2 packs a day. He consumes alcohol only on social occasions  and his diet mostly includes high-fat content owing to his preference for fast food. He does not engage in regular physical exercises.  Mr. Peterson's past medical history shows several risk factors such as hypertension and high blood cholesterol levels  both of which he is on medication for. He has undergone angioplasty for coronary artery disease 3 years ago. He also has peripheral artery disease and suffered from a transient ischemic attack (TIA) last year.  In addition to the family history of cardiovascular disease (His father had fatal aortic aneurysm rupture  and his brother suffers from coronary arterial disease)  recent examinations identified calcification in the abdominal aorta. Furthermore  he has a history of obesity and was diagnosed with prediabetes. Given these findings  Mr. Peterson's overall clinical picture increases his risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm.   There are no known drug allergies. He is on antihypertensive medication  statins for cholesterol  and antiplatelet for coronary and peripheral arterial disease.   Lastly  his social history reveals a retired firefighter  widowed with three grown-up children. He lives alone  and his children visit him periodically. His financial situation is stable and has a health insurance cover for his medical needs. He has no history of domestic abuse  child abuse  or any legal problems. His cognition  despite his age  is intact with no complaints of memory issues reported. He also denies having any substance abuse or taking any illicit drugs.

Problem Representation:  Subject: A 69-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief complaint:  Sudden pain in the lower back and abdomen that is severe  throbbing  and constant. No history of physical trauma.  Demographics and personal history: The patient is a former construction worker who retired five years ago. He lives with his wife of 45 years in a rural area. The patient has a 30-pack year smoking history but quit seven years ago. He maintains a diet high in red meat and saturated fats and has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal exercise. He reports moderate alcohol use and denies illicit drug use. There's no family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Past medical history:  1) Chronic hypertension for the past 15 years  controlled with beta-blockers. 2) Diagnosed with high cholesterol three years ago but non-compliant with statins. 3) No history of kidney disease  lung disease  or peripheral artery disease. 4) Overweight with BMI of 29.  Physical examination: 1) Blood pressure is elevated at 155/95. 2) Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass around the umbilicus with a bruit heard over it. 3) Lower extremity pulses were normal. 4) No edema  abdominal bruit  or discoloration of lower extremities were found.  Possible interpretation:  The former smoker  hypertensive  high-cholesterol  and overweight patient presents with severe abdominal and back pain and a palpable abdominal mass  indicative of a possible ruptured or fast expanding abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The absence of physical trauma and history of these risk factors necessitate rapid imaging diagnostics to confirm AAA and rule out other causes like kidney stones  pancreatitis  or diverticulitis. If AAA is confirmed  immediate surgical consultation would be advised.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:   Mr. John is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who lives in an urban area. He is married with 3 adult children. His wife is his primary caregiver. He is a retired banker and has medical insurance which includes coverage for prescription medications. His BMI is 27  indicating he is overweight and has a modestly high risk of cardiovascular disease. He doesn't smoke and drinks alcohol moderately.  Presenting Problem:   John presents with occasional mild abdominal and lower back pain that he rates as a 4 out of 10 for severity. He has noticed the pain off and on for a month.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he has been taking medications (beta blockers and statins) for 20 years. John has no known allergies to medications. John has had fluctuating blood pressure readings in the past five years  owing to non-compliance with medications and lifestyle modifications. He has experienced two previous minor cardiac events  with mild angina about ten years ago and a minor stroke event 3 years ago that required no hospitalization. He did not pursue cardiac rehab or physical therapy for these incidents.   Family History:  John's mother died at 65 years due to a myocardial infarction (heart attack)  and his father died at 72 years due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. John has a younger brother who had a stent placed two years ago for coronary artery disease.  Conclusion (Impression/Diagnosis):  John is a 70-year-old overweight male who drinks alcohol moderately  has a consistent history of hypertension and high cholesterol  a family history of cardiovascular disease and abdominal aortic aneurysm. John's current intermittent abdominal and lower back pain are potentially concerning and suggestive of an undiagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysm  particularly given his father's history. An abdominal ultrasound is recommended to investigate this further.

Given the patient's advanced age  history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  diabetes  smoking as well as the suspicious physical findings  a preliminary diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is made.

Problem Representation:  Mr. X is a 70-year-old male former smoker  with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and peripheral vascular disease. He has never been diagnosed with coronary artery disease or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has no history of surgeries or known allergies. There is a significant family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father suffering from a myocardial infarction and his brother diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Recently  he has been complaining of intermittent abdominal pain  along with lower back pain for the past weeks. The pain is severe  tearing in nature  and radiates to his back and lower extremities. Accompanying symptoms include weakness  dizziness  and transient episodes of loss of consciousness. There is also a report of unexplained weight loss and diminished appetite over the past months. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  gastrointestinal symptoms  or urinary symptoms.  Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass that is mildly tender on deep palpation. Vitals are stable with mildly elevated blood pressure reading of 145/90 mm of Hg. Lower extremity pulses are diminished bilaterally. The complete blood count  liver function tests  kidney function tests  and coagulation profile results were within the normal range. An ultrasound confirms the presence of an aneurysm in the abdominal aorta  measuring a diameter of 5.5 cm.  Given his age  risk factors  clinical symptoms  findings on physical examination  and results of the ultrasound  Mr. X most likely has an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Considering the size of the aneurysm and presence of symptoms  immediate intervention is required to prevent rupture and life-threatening complications.

He suffered from a minor stroke 5 years ago  from which he fully recovered.   Family History: No significant family history noted for any genetic or hereditary condition. Review of Systems: The patient has noticed a decrease in appetite but no significant weight loss. He denies any changes in bowel habits  urinary symptoms  chest pain  or shortness of breath. This demographic report enables the healthcare provider to focus on abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) as a most likely diffential  considering the patient's presenting symptoms of occasional back pain  the pulsating sensation in the abdomen  together with the several risk factors identified during the medical history review.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with consistent dull to intense abdominal pain (more pronounced in the center and lower regions of the torso) that often travels to the back.  Past Medical History:   1. Hypertension for the past 20 years  managed with medication (beta-blockers). 2. History of smoking about 1 pack of cigarettes per day for almost 40 years. He quit smoking approximately four years ago. 3. He has been diagnosed with hyperlipoproteinemia type II (familial hypercholesterolemia)  for which he takes lipid-lowering medications. 4. Known with mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). 5. Previous history of atherosclerosis  resulting in a Percutaneous Coronary Intervention of the left anterior descending artery 5 years ago.  Family History: Both father and older brother died in their early 70s of abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Present Clinical Signs:  1. Obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 30 kg/m2. 2. Frequent shortness of breath associated with activities of daily living. 3. Routine blood tests show elevated levels of cholesterol  despite treatment.  Physical Exam:  1. The abdominal exam reveals a palpable and pulsatile mass app. 4 cm in diameter at the level of the navel. 2. Blood pressure remains elevated at 155/90 despite medication. 3. Cardiovascular exam: heart rate is regular with no murmurs. 4. Lungs: sparse wheezing heard bilaterally  no crackles. 5. Lower extremities: symmetric and mild pitting edema is present with no signs of skin color changes  ulcers  or other signs of venous insufficiency.     Urgent Diagnostic Tests: After noting the abdominal mass on physical examination  the physician orders an ultrasound of the abdominal aorta  which confirms the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6 cm in diameter.  Social History: Retired engineer  widowed  has one son who lives out of state. Drinks occasionally (2 drinks per week)  quit smoking four years ago. His daily activities are limited due to COPD and recent abdominal pain.  Summary: This is a 70-year-old male with a significant predisposition to cardiovascular disease  involving hypertension  hyperlipoproteinemia  COPD  obesity  smoking history  and family history  presenting with symptoms and confirmatory ultrasound suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Early diagnosis and proper management are critical considering his risk factors.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian (White) Occupation: Retired Living condition: Lives alone Location: Rural Midwest Smoker: Yes  has been smoking for 40 years  Relevant Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Patient has been diagnosed with high blood pressure 10 years ago and has been on medication since then.  2. High Cholesterol: Patient was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels 8 years ago and is on medication  but has reported variable compliance with diet and medication regime.  3. Peripheral Vascular Disease: Patient was diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease 6 years ago  for which he was prescribed aspirin and counseled on smoking cessation.  4. Coronary Artery Disease: Patient had myocardial infarction 5 years ago  was hospitalized  and has been on maintenance medication since then.   5. Diabetes: Patient has been managing Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 7 years with oral medications and diet control but has variable glucose control.  Presenting Complaint:  John presents with occasional episodes of sudden  severe pain concentrated in the back and abdominal area. It’s usually not provoked by any specific activity  but the intensity increases when he undertakes extensive physical activity. On probing  John also indirectly reports a reduction in appetite and unintended weight loss.  Family History:  John's father passed away from stroke at the age of 70. His paternal grandfather passed away due to a ruptured aneurysm  specific type unknown. John also has a younger brother who suffered an infarction at the age of 50.  Considering John Doe's risk factors including advanced age  male sex  history of smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  peripheral vascular disease  coronary artery disease  uncontrolled diabetes  as well as familial predisposition  an assessment for abdominal aortic aneurysm should be considered.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Characterization: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired with a 20-year history of smoking  and occasional alcohol consumption. The patient lives in a urban setting with his wife and has two adult children.  Presenting Problem: The patient presented due to an abrupt  severe pain in the lower back and abdomen that is not relieved by changing position  over-the-counter pain medicine  or bowel movement. The patient also reported feeling a slight pulse in his abdomen. The pain was first noticed 1 day ago and has progressively become worse.   Relevant Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: The patient has a 15-year diagnosis of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril 20mg daily.  2. Lumbar Pain: The patient occasionally suffers from lumbar pain which he relates to an old work injury. Usually the pain is relieved by NSAIDs and rest. He rates the current pain episode as way severe than usual  and without any relation to physical strain.   3. Hypercholesterolemia: In 2012  the patient was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels. He's been on Atorvastatin 10mg daily since then.  4. Smoking: The patient has a 20-pack year history of smoking. Although attempts have been made to leave the habit  the patient continues smoking  albeit less frequently.  5. Family History: The patient's father died of a heart attack at 70 and his mother died from complications due to diabetes at 75.   Overall:  This is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a longstanding history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  smoking  and family history of cardiovascular disease  presenting with an abrupt severe lower back and abdominal pain  with a palpable pulse in his abdomen. This clinical picture raises the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Problem Representation:   A 68-year-old male presents with complaints of persistent and dull pain in the abdominal region and lower back that's not related to any physical activity. The pain has been intermittent over the last two weeks. The patient also reports a pulsating sensation in the abdomen. There's no associated nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel movement. A physical examination reveals an expansive pulsatile mass in the central abdomen. He has a known history of hypertension  smoking  and cardiovascular disease. His pulse is regular and blood pressure is controlled under medication. Lower limb pulses are palpable. Family history includes a brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Given the patient's symptoms and history  the preliminary diagnosis is an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate vascular surgery consultation and further diagnostic procedures (like an abdominal ultrasound or CT scan) are advisable to confirm the diagnosis and provide appropriate treatment.  Complete Demographic Characterization:  - Age: 68 years old - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Profession: Retired Engineer - Lifestyle: Former smoker - Marital Status: Married with 3 children - Family Medical History: Brother with a history of AAA.  - Residence: Lives in the city in a moderate-income neighborhood - Insurance: Medicare  Relevant Past Medical History:  - Hypertension - on medication (10 years) - Cardiovascular diseases - controlled under medication - Packs/year history of smoking - Quit 5 years ago - No history of diabetes or kidney disease - No history of known food or drug allergies - Received annual health check-ups regularly.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: John Doe is a 70-year-old Caucasian male.   Chief Complaint:  John presents with a constant  severe abdominal and back pain that has progressively worsened over the last few hours.  Vital Statistics: Weight: 200 lbs  Height: 6 ft  Lifestyle: John is a retired engineer  who is quite socially active. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and has been doing so for the last 40 years. Though his alcohol intake is limited to occasional social drinking.  Family History: John's father had a history of peripheral artery disease and had died of a heart attack in his late 70s.  Past Medical History: John suffers from Type II diabetes and hypertension  both of which are moderately controlled with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. He also had a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from his years of smoking.  Medications: John takes Metformin for type II diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and an inhaler for COPD.  Clinical Presentation: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass in the abdomen could be felt. John's blood pressure was elevated  and he appeared distressed because of the pain. His abdominal and back pain appear to be severe and constant  unlike the intermittent claudication he had complained of in previous visits.  Suspected Diagnosis: John’s current symptoms alongside the physical examination findings  his age  persistent smoking habit  and history of hypertension and type II diabetes  point towards a high suspicion of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).   The diagnosis must be confirmed with suitable imaging studies and immediate management should be initiated considering his severe pain and the pulsatile mass noted on examination which raise a concern about the risk of impending rupture of the aneurysm.

Problem:  Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of abdominal and back pain that has been slowly worsening over the past week  discomfort in his belly  along with nausea and general fatigue. He relates these symptoms to his primary care physician who immediately refers him to a vascular surgeon  suspecting an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Patient's Demographic Details: - Age: 70 years old - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired - Marital status: Married - Education level: College graduate - Living situation: Lives at home with spouse  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was an active smoker for 25 years but quit 15 years ago. He has a known history of hypertension and atherosclerosis which he manages with antihypertensive medication and statins. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease as his father died from a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. The patient also has a history of mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His last abdominal ultrasound was 3 years ago. In terms of surgeries  he underwent a hernia repair 10 years ago. Other relevant facts include a fairly sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in red meat and fats.  Social History: He drinks alcohol occasionally and quit smoking 15 years ago. Recent stressors could be related to his retirement and some anxiety as his wife was diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's disease.   This AAA suspect problem representation provides a comprehensive view of the patient  considering his age  lifestyle  family history  and individual medical history. Tailored management  including further examination  imaging studies  and possibly surgical intervention  should be initiated promptly to prevent potential rupture of the aneurysm.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Demographics: 72-year-old Caucasian male with BMI 27.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient is presenting with a gradual onset of constant lower back and abdominal pain over the past week. Pain intensity is moderate but worsens while lying flat or during physical movement.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for past 15 years  for which he's been taking antihypertensive medications. There's also a history of hyperlipidemia managed with medication  and a 40 pack-year smoking history  but he has quit smoking ten years ago. No family history of aneurysms. He had myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Social History: Lives with wife in a suburban setup  had retired from his job as a lawyer  and has a moderate alcohol intake.  Physical examination: Physical examination reveals a positive abdominal pulsating mass and bruit. No signs of peripheral vascular disease were found.   Tests: Blood pressure: 165/90 mmHg  Blood cholesterol: 250 mg/dL  Abdominal ultrasound: saccular bulge of aorta measuring 6 cm in diameter.  Problem Summary:  The patient is a 72-year-old male presenting with symptoms suggestive of abdominal aortic aneurysm. The pain in the lower back and abdomen could be due to aneurysm pressing on nearby organs. Due to the size of 6 cm of the aneurysm in the abdominal aorta  the risk for rupture is increased. Given his high blood pressure  hyperlipidemia  advanced age  and previous smoking history  the patient's overall cardiovascular risk is high.   Chronic hypertension may have contributed to aneurysm development due to strain on arterial walls. Moreover  hyperlipidemia and history of smoking are also known factors for aneurysm development. Hence  these need to be aggressively managed to prevent further complications. The patient should also be evaluated for potential surgical intervention considering the size of the aneurysm.

Problem Representation:  Mr. J  a 72-year-old male presents with a complaint of intermittent  dull aching lower abdominal pain and occasional episodes of lightheadedness over the last two weeks. The pain is not related to meals or movement. It radiates to his back and is not associated with any bowel or bladder changes. His family history is significant with his father having an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) surgery in his late 70s. Mr. J is a retired engineer  married  with a significant history of cigarette smoking for the past 50 years (30 pack-year history). He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. His past medical history is relevant with hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has not had any prior surgeries or hospitalization. He has never been screened for AAA.  His medications include Atorvastatin 20 mg daily and Lisinopril 10 mg daily. He is allergic to aspirin  where it caused him to have an anaphylactic reaction. His vitals on record include: Blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  temperature 98.7°F (37.1°C)  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air.  Physical examination is unremarkable except for a palpable mass in his abdomen that pulses with the heartbeat  and high-pitched systolic bruit over the mass.  These signs are suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Investigations will be needed to confirm the diagnosis and ascertain the size and presence of any potential complications related to the aneurysm. As he is a high-risk patient due to his age  history of smoking and familial history  an immediate evaluation will be required to prevent any fatal ruptures.

Patient Profile: Name: Jane Doe Gender: Female Age: 72 Years Old Marital Status: Widowed Occupation: Retired Accountant Residential Location: Suburban Area Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: 1. High Cholesterol Level: Diagnosed with high LDL cholesterol levels 8 years ago. Prescribed Medicine: Atorvastatin 20mg daily. 3. Recent Medical History: Presenting Complaint: Complaints of consistent  severe pain in the middle and lower part of the abdomen for the past 2 weeks. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson  a white male of European descent  is 72-year-old retired army officer. His main complaint is a sudden  strong pain radiating from his abdomen to his back and groin  which has been getting progressively worse. He does not report any obvious trauma or injuries as a cause for the discomfort. Mr. Johnson confesses to have been a moderately frequent smoker during his military service and having quit smoking ten years ago. He also admits that his diet is relatively high in fats and sugars  leading to weight gain in recent years.  Medical History: Mr. Johnson's past medical history includes hypertension  diagnosed ten years ago  for which he takes daily medication  and high cholesterol levels  also controlled with medication. There was no evidence of diabetes mellitus  however  his body mass index (BMI) was computed to be 27 (overweight).   Family History:  Mr. Johnson's family history is relevant as his father died due to a stroke at the age of 75 and an older brother has undergone surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 66  and a cousin was identified to have thoracic aneurysm. No family history was reported for diabetes or any rheumatologic diseases.   Recent Observations and Investigations: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the abdomen  more prominent than typically found in people of similar age and build. His blood pressure readings were found to be elevated  although this could be a response to pain. Ultrasonography confirmed the presence of a large aneurysm in the lower part of the aorta.  In conclusion  the presented case is a typical demographic profile and history for a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm  with risk factors including advanced age  male sex  a familial history of arterial aneurysms  hypertension  high cholesterol level  previous smoking  and being overweight.

Patient Representaion  Identification:  Mr. Walters  a 78-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints suggestive of abdominal aortic aneurysm. Other notable concerns include a background of peripheral artery disease (PAD) diagnosed three years ago and a mild stroke which occurred five years ago. He does not have a history of diabetes  but he does show mildly elevated cholesterol levels from time to time. No familial history of aneurysms. His daily activity includes going for walks  reading books  and gardening. He has adequate familial support from his wife and two children who live nearby. Overview:  Given Mr. Walters' age  history of hypertension and smoking  peripheral artery disease  and the presenting complaint of abdominal and back pain with a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  it is strongly indicative of a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm. This would require confirmatory diagnostic imaging and appropriate medical or surgical intervention  as clinical warranted. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 72-year-old male  caucasian  former smoker with a 30-pack year smoking history  retired construction worker living independently with spouse with a daily alcohol intake of moderate amount.   Symptomatarium: The patient presents with abdominal and lower back pain that is constant and dull in nature. He reports that this pain has been gradually worsening over the past several days. The pain is generally above the navel and radiates to his back. The patient also reports experiencing a sensation of a pulse in his abdomen.  Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension that is managed with daily medication (Amlodipine). Additionally  the patient has been diagnosed with Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) 10 years ago for which he is on long term aspirin therapy. The patient also reports a family history of aneurysms with his father passing away due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in his late sixties. He underwent chest radiographs last year as a part of his annual evaluation which showed a suggestion of aortic calcification.   Lifestyle Factors: The patient has a history of heavy smoking for the past 35 years  though he quit smoking 5 years ago. He also has a moderate alcohol consumption of about1-2 drinks per day. His occupational history includes a career in construction  which may have exposed him to heavy lifting. He exercises occasionally and reports poor diet habits with a fondness for high-fat foods.   Clinical Indicators: On physical examination  the patient is found to have a palpable abdominal mass that pulses with his heartbeat. His blood pressure is elevated  despite being on medication. Laboratory tests show moderately impaired renal function and mildly elevated inflammatory markers. An abdominal ultrasound has been scheduled.   The above description indicates that the patient presents a typical case of abdominal aortic aneurysm with key risk factors such as old age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  and family history of the disease. An immediate evaluation including an abdominal ultrasound is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size and risk of rupture.

Patient Profile:  Name: Joseph Smith Age: 70 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Living status: Living with spouse Smoking status: Ex-smoker  quit 15 years ago Alcohol status: Moderate drinker  Past Medical History: 1. High cholesterol - Diagnosed 12 years ago  on statins 4. History of smoking for 30 years  quit 15 years ago  Presenting Problem: Patient presents to the hospital for a regular check-up. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the mid to upper abdominal area. The patient reports occasional abdominal discomfort  but assumed it was related to gastritis. No nausea  vomiting  severe sharp/stabbing pains  syncope  changes in urinary or bowel habits. He also reports fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Another significant finding included a difference in blood pressure between the patient’s arms and legs.  Given the medical history of the patient  the physical examination  and presentation  suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) emerges. This is further supported by the hypertension  high cholesterol  and extensive history of smoking - all of which are known risk factors for AAA. Further diagnostic testing (e.g. ultrasound  CT scan) is required to confirm the presence of AAA and assess its extent. The presence of symptoms such as fatigue and SOB may suggest an impact on the patient’s cardio-pulmonary function. Additionally  this elderly patient’s co-morbidities including diabetes and hypertension further complicate the clinical scenario.

Patient Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  is a current smoker with a 40-pack-year history living in the rural Midwest. He consumes alcoholic beverages moderately  usually drinking beer two to three times a week.  Presenting Symptoms: He presents with occasional  mild  lower abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back  which over time has been slowly worsening.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a documented history of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril. His BMI is 28.1  indicating that he is overweight. He also has high cholesterol and is on Atorvastatin. His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in his mid-70s  and thus he has a familial predisposition to aneurysms.   One remarkable detail is that he pursued medical attention only for the shortness of breath he started experiencing last week  attributing his abdominal/back pain to his old age.   Lifestyle: Mr. Smith lives with his wife in their farmhouse and leads a semi-active lifestyle  managing their small farm. Primarily  he has been ignoring his health and avoiding routine medical check-ups.  Problem List: 1. Current smoker with significant pack year history of 40. 2. Hypertension. 3. High cholesterol levels. 4. Overweight (BMI of 28.1). 5. Family history of AAA. 6. Mild to moderate pain in the lower abdomen  radiating to the back. 7. Recently developed shortness of breath. 8. Avoidance of regular health check-ups.   Summary Mr. Smith is an older male with major risk factors for AAA such as a smoking history  hypertension  high BMI  and familial predisposition. This  in combination his described symptoms  strongly suggest the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Problem Representation:   Chief Complaint:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male complaining of severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain.   Demographics: The patient is retired with a sheltered  mostly sedentary lifestyle living in an urban town. He has a history of moderate alcohol use  daily use of tobacco in the past  and irregular dietary habits with a preference for processed and fatty foods.   Past Medical History (PMH): The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension and high LDL cholesterol levels. He has a past history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and treated successfully  but remains with a borderline HBA1C.   Family History (FH): The patient’s family history is positive for cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away from a stroke in his late 70s and his elder brother died of a myocardial infarction in his early 60s.   Social History (SH): The patient is married  has 2 adult children  is a retired engineer  and lives with his wife. He has a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years back.   Current Medications: - Lisinopril 20 mg OD for hypertension - Atorvastatin 40 mg overnight for high LDL cholesterol level - Metformin 500 mg BD for type II diabetes - Low-dose aspirin 81 mg OD as a prophylactic antiplatelet agent  Relevant Clinical Findings: - Physical Examination: Pulse rate: 110/min; BP: 150/90mmHg; RR: 22/min  Tenderness in the abdominal region upon palpation - Lab Results: Increased serum creatinine  LDL cholesterol on higher side  Elevated D-dimer - Imaging: CT scan showed enlarged diameter of the abdominal aorta  Working Diagnosis: A 72-year-old male with significant cardiovascular risk factors presented with sudden  severe abdominal pain. Based on the clinical findings and imaging  a working diagnosis of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is made. The patient’s advanced age  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  familial history of cardiovascular disease  and diabetes pose significant risk factors for AAA. Prompt surgical intervention  Tobacco cessation counseling  and aggressive management of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia are indicated in this case.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  former smoker with a 30 pack-year history  who presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of mild to moderate but persistent abdominal and back pain. He also reports a sense of fullness in his abdominal area and occasional pulsating sensations.   Demographics: - Age: 70 years - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired office worker - Residence: Lives with his wife in the suburb  Past Medical History (PMH):  - Hypertension for 10 years  controlled with medication (Lisinopril) - High cholesterol levels  controlled with medication (Statin) - Quit smoking 10 years ago  smoked 1.5 packs per day for 20 years (30 pack-year smoking history) - No known drug allergies  Family History (FH): - Brother died of a heart attack at age 72 - Father died at the age of 78  cause unknown  but he had a history of ""heart problems""  Social History (SH): - Reports occasional alcohol intake; 1-2 glasses of wine/week - Quit smoking 10 years ago - No use of illicit drugs - Lives with his wife; both are retired and mainly stay indoors due to COVID-19 restrictions  Medications:  - Lisinopril 10mg daily - Atorvastatin 20mg daily  The patient's history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and significant smoking history contribute to his high risk for developing an atherosclerotic disease like an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The reported abdominal fullness  back pain  and occasional pulsating sensations may be indicators suggestive of an enlarging abdominal aortic aneurysm. Early identification and intervention is crucial to prevent life-threatening complications such as rupture.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  Mr. A.B is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  relatively sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Issue:  He presents to the clinic with a complaint of a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  which has progressively increased over the last months. He does not complain of any acute abdominal pain or back pain but has mentioned episodes of lightheadedness. There's no history of loss of consciousness  chest pain or shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  Mr. A.B has a significant 20-year history of hypertension and has been diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia for the last ten years  both of them under pharmacological control. He also has a 40 pack-year smoking history  but quit smoking about 5 years ago. He has no known allergies. There has been no previous surgery or hospital admissions in his history.  Family History: His father died at the age of 75 with 'heart problems'  but no further details are known. He also has a brother who underwent surgery for an aneurysm in his stomach  i.e.  abdomen aortic aneurysm at around the same age.    Social History: He lives with his wife  is a non-alcoholic  quit smoking 5 years back. He does not indulge in any form of regular exercise. His diet is high in saturated fat  with little to no inclusion of fruits or vegetables.  This 72-year-old male patient with a significant smoking history along with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  presenting with pulsating abdomen and lightheadedness  could potentially be suffering from an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm also makes him at increased risk. Note that often patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms present with no symptoms  and it is found incidentally  so the symptom of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen serves as a significant finding.

Problem Representation:  Patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  who presents with a 2-day history of a pulsing  sharp and severe lower abdominal pain. Associated symptoms include lightheadedness  cold  clammy skin  and rapid heartbeat. He has a history of smoking from age 20 until 65 (approximately 45 pack-years) and a high-fat diet with limited physical exercise. The patient has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and hypercholesterolemia  and has been noncompliant with his prescribed antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. His family history is significant for abdominal aortic aneurysms (father died at the age of 78 due to aortic aneurysm rupture). On physical examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. Palpation of abdomen reveals a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen  just below the xiphoid process.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension diagnosed 8 years ago  noncompliant with antihypertensive medication. 2. Hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 5 years ago  noncompliant with statins. 3. Tobacco use disorder: heavy smoker from age 20 until 65. 4. Unhealthy diet: patient follows a high-fat diet  regular intake of fast food  low intake of fiber  fruits and vegetables. 5. Limited physical activity: sedentary lifestyle due to former job as a truck driver. 6. Family history significant for abdominal aortic aneurysms.  The patient’s age  previous smoking history  high blood pressure  hypercholesterolemia  unhealthy diet  lack of physical exercise  together with the family history of aortic aneurysms all contribute to a high suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm in this patient. His presenting complaint of pulsing  severe abdominal pain  associated with symptoms suggestive of shock (lightheadedness  rapid heart rate  cold  clammy skin)  could indicate a rupture of the aneurysm  which is a medical emergency requiring surgical intervention.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 70 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Residential Location: Urban area Smoking History: Smoked 1 pack/day for 40 years before quitting 10 years ago. Alcohol Use: Moderate  occasional glass of wine for dinner. Diet: Balanced  follows Mediterranean diet pattern. Activity Level: Moderate  walks daily for exercise.  Presenting Problem:  The patient presents with a 6-month history of intermittent  dull abdominal pain  and a recent episode of severe back pain. He reports feeling full even when he has not eaten much. He complains of occasional constipation and unexplained weight loss.  Past Medical History:  He has a known history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol  which are managed by medications including an ACE inhibitor and a Statin respectively. Patient also has a history of Peripheral artery disease and a previous myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He has been on an antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin) post-MI. Family history significant for a brother who died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Relevant Tests/Examinations:  The physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. The diagnosis is confirmed with an abdominal ultrasound which reveals a 5.5cm diameter abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Problem Representation:  70-year old male  long history of cardiovascular disease (Hypertension  Hypercholesterolemia  Peripheral artery disease  and previous MI)  ex-smoker  with a family history of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  now presents with intermittent abdominal and back pain associated with a feeling of fullness  constipation  and weight loss. He has a palpable abdominal mass confirmed by ultrasound to be a 5.5cm abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe Age: 71 Years  Gender: Male Ethnicity: White  Residence: Urban setting Occupational history: Retired Army Officer Family History: Father died of stroke  mother died of heart disease Lifestyle: Ex-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption  physically active  Complaint:   Recent onset of persistent abdominal and back pain  occasionally described as a pulsating sensation in the abdomen  unexplained weight loss and persistent fatigue.
