Patient Profile: Patient ID: P-001234 Name: John Doe Gender: Male Age: 67 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional drinker  lives alone  Location: Suburban-Area  East Coast Insurance: Medicare  Presenting Complaint: The patient has reported moderate to severe abdominal pain that is persistent and sporadic in nature. He describes it as a throbbing pain in the abdomen.   Relevant Family History: 1) Father had hypertension  2) Mother died of a stroke 3) Brother was diagnosed with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)   Relevant Past Medical History: 1) Diagnosis of hypertension  controlled with medication  2) Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 9 years ago  under control through diet and Metformin. 3) Previous history of hyperlipidemia managed through statins. 4) Patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 7 years ago 5) History of occasional bouts of gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD)  Relevant History of Present Illness: Pain onset: 3 days ago Pain Duration: Lasts around 5 to 15 minutes  Pain Intensity: Moderate to severe (7/10 on the pain scale) Pain Description: Throbbing and intense  Social History: The patient is a widower with two adult children who live out of state. He lives alone with a pet dog. The patient is a retired engineer and spends time on hobbies such as gardening and playing chess. He does not smoke but consumes alcohol occasionally. No recent travel history or major changes in diet.   Physical Examination: Patient is conscious  alert and oriented to time  person  and place. There is tender palpation noted in the lower abdominal area.   Conclusion: The demographic information combined with his medical history  current symptoms  physical examination  history of cardiac disease  and a family history of AAA suggest the potential for an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. The risk is also elevated due to his age  hypertension  and history of atherosclerosis. Further diagnostic investigations  such as abdominal ultrasound or CT scan  should be performed to confirm.

Problem Representation  Patient Demographics: Mr. X is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He is divorced  retired  and lives alone in the city. He has a history of moderate alcohol consumption and quit smoking about 5 years ago after a 40-year habit.  Past Medical History: His past medical history is significant for hypertension (HTN)  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease (PAD). He has experienced intermittent  mild claudication on exertion for which he takes Aspirin daily. Mr. X has been on antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril and Amlodipine) for over 15 years and takes a statin (Atorvastatin) for hyperlipidemia. He is also on a multivitamin supplement. He was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) about a year ago during an investigation for unrelated symptoms.  Review of Systems: Mr. X has been in relatively stable health for the past year  with episodic abdominal discomfort  which he attributes to his AAA. He has not experienced any chest pains  palpitations  or shortness of breath. Mr. X has no complaints of change in bowel habits  weight loss  or night sweats. He occasionally experiences mild lower extremity swelling but denies any numbness or tingling. His recent blood work was mostly within normal limits  with his cholesterol borderline high.  Social History: Mr. X is independent with his activities of daily living. He has no known drug allergies. He has a supportive network of friends in his neighborhood and is visited by his children and grandchildren occasionally. He used to work in the construction field before retiring. He quit cigarette smoking 5 years ago but still drinks alcohol moderately.  Family History: His mother had hypertension and his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  In addition to the primary care physician  Mr. X has regular check-ups with a cardiologist for his hypertension and AAA.   Summary: Mr. X  a 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  peripheral artery disease  and an AAA  presents for his routine check-up. He remains a moderate risk for cardiovascular events given his smoking history  lipid numbers  and AAA. His primary complaints are occasional abdominal discomfort and lower extremity swelling.

Problem Representation:  Demographics:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a managerial job  married with two adult kids  and is a resident of the Midwest. He has been an active smoker with about 40-pack year smoking history and reports moderate weekly alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaint: The patient has been feeling unexplained  vague lower abdominal and back pain intermittently for the last few months  but the pain has slightly increased in the last few days. He also notes unintentional weight loss over the last six months.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels that he controls with medication and diet. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting fifteen years ago. His father died at the age of 65 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and his older brother had an elective repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 70.  Other Relevant History: The patient is a former marathon runner but has put on significant weight over the last 20 years. He denies any history of diabetes  stroke  or kidney disease. The patient is compliant with his annual medical evaluations and laboratory checks  but he has missed his last two appointments due to the COVID-19 pandemic. He has no known drug allergies.   Social History: The patient has been smoking for the past 45 years  averaging a pack a day  and drinks alcohol socially  approximately six drinks per week. He has been retired for a few years and spends his time gardening and taking care of his grandchildren. He eats a balanced diet  but confesses to indulging in fast food and desserts more often since his retirement.  Medication: The patient is currently on an ACE inhibitor (lisinopril) for hypertension and a statin (atorvastatin) for hyperlipidemia.  Considerations: Given the patient's age  gender  family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm and personal history of smoking  hypertension and hyperlipidemia  the patient is at significant risk of developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His recent symptoms of abdominal and back pain could further suggest the presence of an aneurysm. Therefore  a thorough physical examination and appropriate imaging should be performed to investigate this possibility and determine if immediate clinical intervention is required.

Patient Problem Representation:  Demographics:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male. He is a long-term smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history. He is retired  a veteran  and lives with his wife. His BMI is 28 and he is otherwise relatively active  engaging in light exercises such as walking daily.  Presenting concern: The patient presents today with occasional abdominal and back pain that has been bothering him for the past few weeks. He describes the pain as a dull ache rather than a sharp pain and notes that it seems to be worse when he lies down. He denies any changes in bowel habits  hematochezia  melena  or weight loss.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: He was diagnosed approximately ten years ago and is on Amlodipine which has been able to control his blood pressure. He sees his primary care physician every 3-6 months for blood pressure checks. 2. Hypercholesterolemia: Diagnosed concurrently with his hypertension  he is on simvastatin  which controls his cholesterol.  Family History:  The patient’s father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosed at the age of 76. Reflecting on it  he believes his father had similar symptoms before his diagnosis was made. Otherwise  his family history is unremarkable.  Social History:  He is a heavy smoker  having smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for about 40 years. He is a social drinker  having 2 beers most days after work. He admits to being a 'meat and potatoes' kind of guy and he does not eat many fruits or vegetables. He does not exercise beyond his daily walks. He worked in construction before his retirement. He denies any illicit drug use.  Review of Systems: Negative except for occasional abdominal pain  intermittent back pain  and recurrent mild dyspepsia.  Objective findings: On general physical examination  he is afebrile with a BP of 145/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 76/min  respiratory rate of 18/min  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable  pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. Rest of the examination is normal.  Possible Diagnosis: Considering his age  smoking history  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  family history  symptoms  and physical findings a working diagnosis of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) can be suspected. Further confirmatory diagnostics such as ultrasound or CT scan of the abdomen may be warranted.

Patient Profile:   Mr. William  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  is currently residing in a suburban community with his wife. He is retired  is a former smoker having quit 10 years ago after a 40-year pack history. He occasionally consumes alcohol  averaging one to two glasses of wine per week. He's of average height and weight with a BMI within the normal range.  Presenting Complaint:   The patient made a visit to his family doctor  reporting a pulsating sensation around the abdominal area that he first noticed a couple of weeks ago.   Medical History:  His personal medical history is significant for hypertension under control with medication  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 Diabetes mellitus controlled through diet and medication. No prior surgeries reported. He doesn't report any allergies. Family medical history includes a brother who passed away from aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 60.  Evaluation:  The physical exam  in general  does not produce any abnormal results other than a palpable mass in the abdomen and a soft systolic murmur. His vital signs upon arrival are stable. The patient is alert  oriented and his neurological assessment is normal.   To confirm the suspicions  he's referred for an ultrasound - aortic duplex. The ultrasound confirms the presence of the abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with a diameter of 4.5 cm. Blood test results indicate normal complete blood count but elevated blood sugar levels.  Current Medication:  - Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension - Metformin 500mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes - Atorvastatin 10mg daily for hyperlipidemia  Conclusion:  The patient is asymptomatic AAA  and the diameter is less than the threshold for surgery (5.5cm). Because of his personal and familial history and risk factors - male  age  high blood pressure  smoker and Type 2 diabetes  he is closely monitored for any changes in the size of the AAA. He will continue his current medications and advised on strict glycemic control. Regular ultrasounds at intervals depending on any change in symptoms is planned. He is educated about the symptoms of a potentially rupturing aneurysm and instructed to seek immediate medical attention if he experiences intense back or abdominal pain.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. John Smith  Age: 72 years old  Sex: Male  Occupational History: Retired engineer  Social History: Non-smoker; drinks socially  Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Smith presents a complaint of persistent  dull abdominal pain over the last two weeks. The pain is felt more in the center of the abdomen and Mr. Smith reports a feeling of fullness. He has also reported occasional lower back pain.   Past Medical History:   1. Diagnosed with high blood pressure and has been on antihypertensive medication for the past ten years. 2. History of hyperlipidemia and has been prescribed statin medication for this. 3. No surgical history. 4. A family history of cardiovascular diseases: His father had coronary artery disease and his elder brother died from a stroke. 5. Experienced occasional episodes of claudication for which he never sought medical attention.  Physical Examination:   On examination  there was a pulsating mass in the abdomen and a bruit was heard on auscultation of the abdomen.  Diagnostic Evaluation:  An abdominal ultrasound showed an aortic diameter of 5.5 cm confirming the suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Problem List:  1. Abdominal pain  2. Lower back pain 3. Pulsating abdominal mass 4. Hypertension 5. Hyperlipidemia 6. Family history of cardiovascular diseases 7. Current diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)   This problem list represents a typical presentation of a patient with an abdominal aortic aneurysm and related issues that need to be managed or further evaluated.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year old Caucasian male  retired military officer who has a 50-year history of heavy smoking and moderate alcohol use. Weighing 220 pounds with a height of 5 foot 11 inches  his BMI is within the overweight range.   Presenting Complaint: The patient visited the ER complaining of severe  sharp  and persistent pain in the lower back and abdomen.  Past Medical History: Significant history includes hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago which is controlled by medication. He was diagnosed with high cholesterol 8 years ago and manages it by statins. The patient had an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago. No history is noted for diabetes mellitus  asthma or cancer. There is no significant surgical history. His father died of stroke at the age of 68 and his mother died of aneurysm at 75.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  an abdominal mass was palpable in the periumbilical region that was pulsatile. He had high blood pressure (160/100) and the rest of his vitals including the temperature  pulse rate  and respiratory rate were normal. No peripheral oedema was present.   Given this case presentation  the likely problem representation would be: “a 72-year-old male with a significant smoking history and hypertension  presenting with sudden-onset  persistent lower back and abdominal pain suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.” This conclusion would prompt immediate medical intervention given the high risk of rupture and significant mortality associated with untreated abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile:  - Demographics: A 70-year-old Caucasian male.  - Occupation: Retired civil engineer.  - Family history: Father died due to heart disease at the age of 66. Mother died of natural causes at the age of 72. He is the oldest of four siblings  one of whom had an early heart attack at 55.  - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  drinks socially but within healthy limits.  - Clinical History: Has a 10-year history of high blood pressure since his sixties which is controlled by medications. There's a five-year history of high cholesterol and 2 years ago he was diagnosed as pre-Diabetic.  Medical presentation:  Presents with acute  severe lower back and abdominal pain  described as tearing or ripping  that started suddenly about 3 hours ago while he was in his garden. Reports feeling lightheaded and sweaty but denied chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath  though admits to mild nausea. Patient noticed his abdomen was slightly distended and his family forced him to come to the emergency because they noted his pallor.  Relevant Past Medical History:  - Diagnosis of hypertension around 10 years ago. Patient has been taking lisinopril 20mg daily since the diagnosis.  - Patient diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia about 5 years ago  and he has been on statin treatment (atorvastatin 20mg daily) since then.  - Pre-diabetes diagnosed 2 years ago  managing with diet and metformin 500mg twice daily.  - No known history of any previous surgeries or major illnesses.  - Patient is allergic to Penicillin  triggers rashes and itchiness.  - Has occasional lower back pain  attributed in part to age and in part to a mild disc herniation diagnosed several years ago. He usually manages it with over-the-counter NSAIDs.

Problem:  Mr. James  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents with recent complaints of a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  intermittent severe abdominal pain and lower back pain over the past two weeks. He mentions feeling a sensation of fullness and states these symptoms are unlike the usual indigestion problems he's had in the past.   Past Medical History:  Mr. James has a long history of hypertension and has had bouts of low-level intermittent claudication  primarily following activities such as walking. He has been a smoker for the past 50 years. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father suffered a stroke at the age of 65 and his older brother underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 70. His cholesterol levels  lipid profile have been recorded on the higher side of the normal range over the past few years. In addition  he has a history of Myocardial Infarction  10 years ago. He also mentions episodes of erectile dysfunction.   Current Medications:  His current medication regimen includes beta-blockers ('Metoprolol') for hypertension  'Lipitor' for his cholesterol  Nitroglycerin for angina pectoris  and 'Plavix' for the prevention of stroke. He is currently not on any anticoagulation drugs  is not diabetic  and his kidneys function normally.  Lifestyle Factors:  Mr. James retired from a high-stress job about seven years ago and lives with his wife. He has a 50 pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol socially. His diet is high in red meat and fats. His exercise is limited to casual walks post-dinner.

Patient Profile: Name: John Stevens Age: 75 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Residence: Urban area  Presenting Issue: The patient presents with severe intermittent abdominal pain and lower back pain that has been persisting for the past two weeks. He describes the pain as dull and does not improve with rest or change in position.  Demographics: John is a Caucasian male  aged 75  retired  living with his wife. He has a history of moderate alcohol consumption and was a pack-a-day smoker until he quit 10 years ago. He also reports having a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement. His diet consists of high-fat food and he is overweight with a Body Mass Index of 28. His older brother passed away from an abdominal aortic aneurysm at 77 years old.  Past Medical History: John has a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels which are currently managed with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). He had a heart stent placed two years ago after experiencing chest pains and was subsequently diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease. Six years ago  he was treated for Peripheral Artery Disease leading to intermittent claudication. He also has a history of stress and generalized anxiety disorder for which he undergoes therapy and takes Escitalopram.  Social History: He quit smoking a decade ago after 40 years of tobacco use. He consumes alcohol in moderation  roughly 4-5 drinks per week. John is retired so does not engage in any significant physical activity as part of his daily routine.  Family History: Notably  his older brother had a fatal abdominal aortic aneurysm event at the age of 77. His father succumbed to a heart attack at the age of 70 and his mother passed away because of a stroke at 80. Additionally  there is a family history of high blood pressure  heart disease  and high cholesterol levels.   Current Medication: - Atorvastatin (20mg) once daily  - Lisinopril (10mg) once daily - Aspirin (81mg) once daily - Escitalopram (10mg) once daily  This patient's high-risk factors include advanced age  male sex  history of smoking  obesity  diet  peripheral and coronary artery disease  uncontrolled hypertension  and significant family history of aneurysms and cardiovascular diseases. These indicate a high risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm and suggest the need for further diagnostic workup.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who has presented with symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is a retired engineer and is currently living with his wife. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit 20 years ago. He has a high calorie diet and low physical activity. His BMI is 30  indicating obesity. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  his father having suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm as well.  Past Medical History:  The patient has had a long-standing medical history of hypertension for the past 25 years  for which he is on amlodipine. He also has a background of high cholesterol  managed with statins. His previous medical records suggest poor control over these conditions. In addition  he has also been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage 3  secondary to long term hypertension. He has no known allergies. There is no history of diabetes  lung disease or cancer.  Clinical Status:   Currently  the patient has been experiencing unfamiliar abdominal pain  describing it as a pulsating feeling in the abdomen  most noticeable when he is lying down. The pain is not associated with eating  bowel movements  or urination. There is no change in bowel habits  urinary habits  or appetite. The patient also mentions intermittent lower back pain. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  dyspnea or syncope.   The patient’s symptoms  particularly the age  gender  the nature of abdominal pain  his significant smoking history  long-standing uncontrolled hypertension  high cholesterol  family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm and presence of chronic kidney disease risk factors align with those of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. A high index of suspicion is needed and further investigations should be arranged promptly to confirm the diagnosis and manage the condition.

Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 73-year-old Caucasian individual  retired and lives with his wife. He’s a former smoker and has been abstinent for twenty years  though has a 40 pack-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially and has daily exercise through walking. He has family history of cardiovascular disease.  Presenting Problem: Mr. Johnson presented with abdominal and back pain that he described as sharp and persistent. The back pain radiates to his flank  and he has mild dyspnea. He denies any associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or bloody stools. He also denied urinary symptoms.  Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which have been well-managed with medication. He also had a minor MI five years ago and had two stents placed at that time.   Recent Physical Findings: Mr. Johnson's vital signs are stable. Examination of the abdomen revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Findings: An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  which measured 5.5 cm. The patient has minimal plaque burden.  Impression: Mr. Johnson fits the typical demographic for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) sufferer  being an elderly male with a history of smoking and with hypertension  and having atherosclerotic disease. Given the fact that his aneurysm is larger than 5.5 cm  he is already presenting with symptoms  and he has a significant history of cardiovascular disorder  he is at substantial risk. Prompt intervention is suggested to lower the risk of rupture and serious consequences.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Mr. Jones  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Intermittent sharp abdominal and lower back pain for the past one week  Present Illness: Has observed loss of appetite; reports feeling light-headed on occasions   Relevant Past Medical History: - Positive history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 10 years  poorly compliant with anti-hypertensive medications - 30 pack-year history of smoking (stopped 5 years ago) - Diagnosed with high cholesterol levels about 7 years ago - Underwent a stent placement procedure for coronary artery disease 5 years back - An episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) with full recovery about 2 years ago - Family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm in his father  who expired due to aneurysm rupture  Social History: Retired accountant; lives with his wife; moderate alcohol consumption (2 standard drinks per day)  Recent Medications: Losartan  aspirin  atorvastatin  Allergies: No known drug allergies  Physical Examination: Patient looks in discomfort  vital signs show slightly elevated blood pressure  abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass  Patient's Concerns: Concerned about worsening abdominal pain  Diagnostic Hypothesis: Given the patient's age  gender  history of smoking and hypertension  history of vascular disease  family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  and the presenting symptoms including the physical exam findings  there is a strong suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Representation:  Demographics: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 66 years  - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired mechanic - Residency: Urban dwelling  lives alone  Medical History: - Hypertension: Diagnosed 15 years ago  managed with antihypertensive medication. - Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with lifestyle changes and occasionally medication. - Smoker: 40 pack years - Alcohol: Moderate drinker - No known drug allergies - No history of surgeries  Family History: - Father died of myocardial infarction at age 68 - Mother died of stroke at age 79 - One brother alive  diagnosed with abdominal aortic aneurysm at 62 - No family history of malignancies or inherited disease.  Current Presentation: - Presented with a few weeks history of abdominal discomfort and lower back pain. - Reports a feeling of a ""pulsating"" sensation in the abdomen. - No report of syncope  nausea  vomiting  recent weight loss or urinary symptoms. - Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Test Results and Investigations: - Abdominal ultrasound confirms an abdominal aortic aneurysm with maximal dimension of 5.5 cm. - No signs of imminent rupture  however size does classify as large aneurysm. - Electrocardiogram (ECG) normal. - Blood test results indicate slightly raised cholesterol levels and normal kidney function.   Clinical Summary: 66-year-old male with a significant history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with several weeks of lower back pain and unsettled abdomen. A diagnosis has been established of abdominal aortic aneurysm through physical examination and ultrasound  classifying as large at 5.5 cm. The patient's management plan now ought to be discussed comprehensively. Based on the size of the aneurysm and the patient's high-risk factors (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history)  surgical intervention may be necessary.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 72 years Gender: Male Country: United States Marital Status: Married Occupation: Retired construction worker  Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) with a size of approximately 5.5 cm discovered incidentally during a routine check-up for abdominal pain and indigestion. He has had a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the last 30 years  for which he takes medication regularly. His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 74.  The patient has also had severe atherosclerosis  diagnosed 10 years ago and has undergone percutaneous angioplasty and stent placement in his right coronary artery five years ago.   He was a heavy smoker for around 40 years but quit smoking a decade ago. He has a sedentary lifestyle and his diet is rich in red meat. Despite repeated advice  he has been non-compliant with lifestyle modification and dietary changes advised for his co-existing medical conditions.  He has no history of diabetes  pulmonary disease or cerebrovascular disease. He is allergic to penicillin.  Social History: He is a retired construction worker  living with his wife. He is reliant on his monthly pension for his expenses. He has two children who live abroad and visit him once or twice a year. He drinks alcohol occasionally and has a history of smoking  which he quit 10 years back.   Conclusion: John Doe  a 72-year-old retired construction worker  presents an abdominal aortic aneurysm  with a high risk of rupture due to its size and his history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  atherosclerosis  and smoking. His chronic conditions  poor lifestyle habits coupled with a familial history of AAA  put him at substantial risk. Proper management strategies  including possible surgical intervention  need to be implemented promptly to prevent complications and improve his prognosis.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Caucasian male; retired army officer  current smoker with a 40 pack-year history.   Presenting Problem: The patient presents with intermittent  non-radiating abdominal and lower back pain for the past two months. The pain doesn't appear to be related to food intake or physical activity. He has occasionally experienced episodes of sudden  severe pain in the abdomen and back that subsides on its own. No associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  constipation  diarrhea  chest pain or shortness of breath are reported.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. There is no history of diabetes mellitus  myocardial infarction  cerebrovascular accidents  or any malignant diseases. Family history is remarkable  with his father dying of rupture abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is currently taking medication for hypertension (Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide) and hyperlipidemia (Atorvastatin).  Social History: The patient lives with his wife  drinks alcohol moderately with an occasional binge but denies any illicit drug use. He retired 8 years back and now does voluntary work at a local community center.  The patient’s presentation alongside his risk factors (smoking  age  male  Caucasian  family history of AAA  hypertension  peripheral artery disease  hyperlipidemia) and his clinical symptoms strongly suggest the likelihood of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. An appropriate imaging study (abdominal ultrasound  CT scan) should be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  I. Demographics: A 75-year-old male  II. History of Present Illness:  The patient has been experiencing a sudden and severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. Pain is sharp and continuous. It started suddenly with no precipitating factors. The pain is so severe that the patient has difficulty in walking and sometimes collapses due to the severity. When asked to locate the pain  he places his hands in the middle of his abdomen.  III. Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a heavy smoker with a smoking history of 50 pack-years. There is no history of diabetes or any heart disease  but the patient had been diagnosed with peripheral vascular diseases about five years ago. His father had an aortic aneurysm which was surgically managed.  IV. Relevant Medication History: The patient is on a regular antihypertensive medication  including ACE inhibitors and thiazides. For his hyperlipidemia  he is taking statins. He has not been on any anticoagulant or antiplatelets.   V. Social History: He lives alone since his wife passed way ten years ago. He persists in smoking despite repeated advice to quit. He drinks alcohol occasionally.  VI. Review of Systems: Abdomen: Severe abdominal pain. Cardiovascular: Hypertension  hyperlipidemia  peripheral vascular disease. Other systems are non-contributory.  VII. Physical Examination Summary: Vitals: Blood pressure: 160/90 mmHg. Pulse: 110/minute. Temperature: Normal. Abdomen: A pulsatile mass is noted in the abdomen. Cardiovascular examination: Normal heart sounds. No murmurs. Peripheral pulses are palpable but weak. Remaining systemic examination is unremarkable.   VIII. Impressions and Plan: Given the patient's presentation with sudden onset severe abdominal pain  a known history of peripheral vascular disease  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  heavy smoking  and family history of aortic aneurysm  there is a high index of suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An urgent CT angiogram should be planned to diagnose the condition. If confirmed  an urgent surgical consultation for repair would be warranted  with smoking cessation assistance and blood pressure management.  This document summarizes the demographic information  clinical symptoms  and history of a typical patient likely to present with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. It also outlines the typical physical exam findings and suggested next steps in evaluation and treatment.

Problem Representation:   A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with mid-abdominal and lower back pain for the past several hours. The pain is characterized as sharp and pulsating  rating it 8 out of 10  which has progressively gotten worse. Thankfully  there has been no fainting or loss of consciousness.  The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which he takes Amlodipine 5mg daily. He was a smoker for 30 years (2 packs per day) but quit smoking 8 years ago. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. Regarding his family  he has two older brothers that had abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Patient has a history of lower back pain diagnosed as sciatica and treated with physical therapy and the occasional use of NSAIDs  but never had this level of severe pain. There's no report of trauma or recent heavy lifting.   Upon inspection  there were no visible abnormalities at rest  but the patient expressed severe discomfort when the abdomen was palpated. Furthermore  a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdomen was noticeable.  The patient's vital signs currently show a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and an O2 saturation of 95% on room air.   This is a high-risk patient with familial predisposition who presents with severe  persistent abdominal and back pain and a pulsatile mass  criteria suited for suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate imaging studies and surgical evaluation need to be considered.

Problem representation:  Mr. S is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanical engineer  former smoker with 45 pack years history  but quit smoking 15 years ago. He presents with intermittent abdominal and back pain that has been present for the last couple of weeks. He describes the pain as a pulsating discomfort  centered around the navel. He reports instances of light headedness but denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting or bowel irregularities.   In his past medical history  he has well-managed hypertension (on Lisinopril 20 mg daily)  and mild hyperlipidemia for which he takes Atorvastatin 10 mg at bedtime. He has no history of diabetes  lung or liver disease. His surgical history is notable only for an appendectomy around 30 years ago. His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 75.  On physical examination  he is afebrile with blood pressure of 136/88 mmHg and pulse rate of 78 beats/min. An approximately 5 cm pulsatile abdominal mass could be palpated in his periumbilical area. Bowel sounds are normal  and there is no sign of peritoneal irritation.  Given the family history  physical presentation  and past medical history  the patient is suspected to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Imaging studies will be ordered to confirm the diagnosis. If an abdominal aortic aneurysm is confirmed  the size and rate of growth will determine the treatment plan  which could include anything from watchful waiting to surgical repair.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who lives in a suburban neighborhood with his wife. PROBLEM: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  PATIENT DEMOGRAPHIC PROFILE:  - Sex: Male - Age: 70 years old - Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Construction Worker  - Social History: Smoked cigarettes 1 pack/day for 35 years  stopped smoking 10 years ago; occasional alcohol use  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - High Blood Pressure (hypertension) - High Cholesterol (hypercholesterolemia) - Previous Tobacco Use - Family History: Brother had AAA at age 65 - Previous Smoking-related Pulmonary Disease  - Peripheral Arterial Disease - History of Heart Disease (previous myocardial infarction at age 58) - Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Knee Replacement Surgery 15 years ago  PRESENTING PROBLEMS: - Recent palpitations - Occasional abdominal discomfort  - Unintentional weight loss  RELEVANT FINDINGS: - Physical exam reveals a palpable  pulsatile mass in the mid-epigastric area - Abdominal Ultrasound confirmed a AAA measuring 5.5 cm in diameter  MANAGEMENT PLAN: - Immediate surgical consultation due to high risk of rupture - Aggressive management of blood pressure - Continuation of cholesterol-lowering medications - Strict glycemic control for type II DM - Smoking cessation support (although patient quit 10 years ago) - Follow up appointments with primary care physician and relevant specialists as necessary.

Demographic Information:  Mr. Peter Hanson is a 72-year-old retired Caucasian male. He lives in a suburban area with his wife of 48 years. He is a non-vegetarian with occasional indulgence of fast-food and he has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28 which is indicative of his overweight. As per his medical reports  his hypertension and high cholesterol have been inadequately controlled. He was treated previously for angina  5 years ago.   Family History: There is a relevant family history of cardiovascular disease (CVD). His father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 70.  Presenting Complaints:  For the past few months  Mr. Hanson has been experiencing sporadic episodes of abdominal pain  particularly after having meals  that radiates to his lower back. Based on available medical and family history  population demographics  and presenting symptoms  there is a suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in Mr. Hanson. He belongs to a demographic group (older  male  smoker) that is typically at a higher risk for AAA  making this a plausible diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient profile:  - John  a 70-year-old  Caucasian male who is a long-time smoker  presents himself to the hospital.  - Currently lives in an urban setting with his wife  retired  has 3 children  and 5 grandchildren. - Past medical history includes hypertension for the last 20 years  moderately controlled with medication. - Chronic Kidney Disease (Stage 3) for 10 years. - Has hyperlipidemia for 18 years  managed with lifestyle modifications and medication.  Problem:  - Over the past few weeks  John has experienced intermittent episodes of abdominal pain and a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. - Symptoms also include occasional low back pain and unintentional weight loss.  - On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated. - On the basis of the symptoms and physical findings  an initial diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm was suspected.  Medical Management:  - John was immediately referred for an abdominal ultrasound  which confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. - The aneurysm measures 5.6 cm in diameter. - Due to the size of the aneurysm and the associated risks of rupture  John will likely need to undergo surgical repair  specifically an endovascular aortic repair procedure. - The risks associated with the surgery were explained to John and his wife  primarily the chances of Mirizzi's syndrome and myocardial infarction due to his hypertension and smoking history. - He was also urged to quit smoking and to consistently take his blood pressure and lipid-lowering medication. - Follow-ups and monitoring of his aneurysm and overall health were also advised.  Highlights:   - Age  gender  and the smoking habit combined with his longstanding hypertension and hyperlipidemia make John a high-risk individual for the development of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. - John's chronic kidney disease may also influence his treatment options and potential for recovery from the surgery. - The pulsatile abdominal mass and unexplained back pain are key clinical features  which clue into the diagnosis of this condition. - The relatively large size of the aneurysm means that surgical intervention will be required to prevent the aneurysm from rupturing  which could result in life-threatening internal bleeding. - Frequent medical follow-up and maintaining healthy lifestyle adjustments are going to be crucial for his prognosis post-surgery.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reports intermittent episodes of moderate to severe abdominal pain and lower back pain over the past few weeks.   History of Presenting Complaint: Patient describes the abdominal pain as a deep  pulsating sensation that's persistent most of the day. The pain seems to radiate to his lower back and sometimes to the groin. He sometimes notices a feeling of fullness in the abdomen. There's no relation to food consumption or physical activity.  Past Medical History: History of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril) and hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin. He has a 35-pack year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. His father passed away secondary to a ruptured aortic aneurysm in his 60s. No history of diabetes mellitus or ischemic heart disease.   Social History:  He is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and is independent with his activities of daily living. He doesn't consume alcohol and is a non-drinker.  Clinical Assessment:  Physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the abdomen upon palpation. His blood pressure is controlled and the rest of the vital signs are within normal limits. The initial impression based on his complaints  family  personal and medical histories suggest the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.     Investigation Plan: A possible abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) would necessitate further diagnostic evaluations such as ultrasounds  computed tomography (CT)  or a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size and location of the aneurysm. Routine blood tests would also be recommended to help understand the overall health of the patient.   Management Plan:  The management plan would be determined by the size and growth rate of the aneurysm. Small or slow-growing AAA's usually require careful monitoring and management of blood pressure and cholesterol levels. Large or fast-growing AAA's may need surgical intervention to prevent rupture. The patient will require lifestyle modifications including a healthy diet to control his blood pressure and cholesterol levels. Consider referral for smoking cessation if the patient resumes smoking.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 70 years old Gender: Male Job: Retired engineer Residence: Urban setting Ethnicity: Caucasian Blood Group: B positive Marital Status: Married  Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with a 3.8 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) on routine cardiovascular check-up. He reports occasional mild abdominal discomfort  but minimal other relevant symptoms. The aneurysm appears fusiform in shape on ultrasound.   Patient has a significant past medical history of: - Chronic hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  - Moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  diagnosed 8 years ago with irregular compliance to medication  - Smoker for 50 years  20 cigarettes/day (50 pack years)  - Hyperlipidemia  diagnosed 7 years ago  - History of angina pectoris  diagnosed 4 years ago.  Family History:  Mother died at 71 due to stroke; Father had a history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm and died at the age of 72 due to its rupture. No siblings. One son  healthy.  Lifestyle: Poor diet high in salt and fats and sedentary lifestyle. Recent attempt at introducing light exercise with walking in the park.  Current Medications:  1. Amlodipine 10mg for hypertension 2. Salbutamol inhaler for COPD 3. Atorvastatin 20mg for hyperlipidemia 4. Aspirin 75mg for angina pectoris  The above medications are provided as once daily. Patient's compliance to medication regime is not optimal  with frequent missed dosages.   Allergies: Penicillin.  Social Exposures: No significant social exposures - Patient lives with wife. No pets. No recent travel history. Minimal alcohol use with consumption of occasional glass of wine.   Given his significant family history and risk factors of smoking  age  and chronic hypertension  this puts him at high risk for continued expansion of the AAA.   This discovery dictates close supervision and further management  including possible intervention if the aneurysm expands to ≥5 cm. The primary goal will be to manage cardiovascular risk factors in hope to avert aneurysmal rupture.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Gender: Male  - Age: 70 years old - Occupation: Retired  ex-smoker for last 15 years after smoking for about 30 years - BMI: 32 (Obese)  Medical History: - Hypertension: Diagnosed 20 years ago  under management with medications - Hyperlipidemia: Treated with statins for the past 10 years - Family history: Father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 78  Presenting Chief Complaints: - Episodic abdominal pain  - Lower back pain  - Noticeable pulsation in the abdomen  Physical Examination: - Abdominal palpitation reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass 4cm in diameter. - No visible signs of peripheral vascular disease.  Probable Diagnosis: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Rationale: Given the age  gender  history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history  obesity and the physical examination findings of abdominal/back pain with palpable abdominal mass  the suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm is high.   Investigation Plan: - Ultrasonography/computed tomography angiography to confirm the presence  location  and size of the aneurysm.  Management Plan: - If the AAA is small (less than 5.5cm) and asymptomatic  it could be managed conservatively - regular monitoring of the AAA size  controlling blood pressure  and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. - If the AAA is large (greater than 5.5cm)  symptomatic  or growing rapidly  surgical intervention may be recommended  either via open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). - Address modifiable risk factors – continuation of hypertension and hyperlipidemia management  advising against smoking  and guiding on weight management.

Therefore  urgent evaluation and management should be carried out.

The patient admits to a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement with few activities apart from watching TV and doing a bit of gardening. Problem Representation:  Patient: John Doe  Demography: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  hailing from a semi-urban region. He has a history of smoking about a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years  although he quit 7 years ago. He has a typical diet  with a fondness for meats and minimal intake of fruits and vegetables. His BMI is 28. He does light exercises  such as walking  and avoids heavy physical activity due to age-related joint stiffness.   Past Medical History: Has been on antihypertensive medication for 18 years for managing chronic hypertension and he is compliant with his medication regimen. He was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) 10 years ago. He underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and stenting 8 years ago for the significant occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD). He is presently maintained on dual antiplatelet therapy for CAD.  Family History: The patient's father died of stroke at 79 and his mother died of colon cancer at 75. His older sister  74  is currently living with type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Current History: Reports a sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain (described as a tearing sensation)  he also has been experiencing progressive abdominal bloating and discomfort for the past few months. However  this acute pain has been constant and severe for the past few hours.   Physical Examination: On examination  he appears distressed with the pain. His blood pressure is elevated (160/92 mm Hg) with a pulse rate of 86 beats/min. Palpation reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area.   Current Impression: Considering the heavy tobacco use history  the chronic burden of hypertension and coronary artery disease  and the acute onset of abdominal and back pain with a pulsatile mass on examination  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture is suspicious and should be immediately ruled out.  Immediate Management: A prompt referral for abdominal ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis  followed by CT angiography if needed  is vital. General surgery/emergency medicine consultation might be needed for probable surgical repair depending on the size and symptoms of the aneurysm. Also  pain control and blood pressure management should be optimized urgently.    This problem representation could vary depending on specific patient characteristics and clinical findings.

Past Medical History:      - Hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril 10 mg daily     - Hyperlipidemia  controlled with Atorvastatin 20mg daily     - History of coronary artery disease with myocardial infarction 5 years ago  treated with coronary artery bypass grafting.  5. Past Surgical History:    - Underwent left knee replacement surgery 2 years ago    - Coronary artery bypass grafting 5 years ago  6. Review of Systems:    - Constant  severe lower back and abdominal pain    - Mild shortness of breath    - No chest pain    - No fever    - No cough or recent weight loss  7. Current Medications:    - Lisinopril 10 mg daily    - Atorvastatin 20mg daily    - Low-dose aspirin daily    - Occasional use of over-the-counter antacids   8. Allergies: Penicillins  9. Physical Examination:    - Appears pale and diaphoretic    - Blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  heart rate 98 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6 F    - Abdomen: Severe tenderness to palpation in the umbilical region and lower back  no rebound tenderness or signs of peritonitis  pulsatile mass palpated in the mid-abdomen  10. Recent Lab Results:    - Normal complete blood count    - Mildly elevated creatinine    - Increased C-reactive protein    - Normal liver function tests    - Cholesterol within normal limits on current therapy  Based on demographic data  history  and physical examination  the patient's painful and palpable abdominal mass raises concern for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The history of smoking along with his history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia contribute to the risk of AAA.                                    Next steps would include confirmatory imaging to determine the size and location of the aneurysm which might range from ultrasonography to computed tomographic angiography depending on the clinical scenario and availability. Emergency consultation with a vascular surgeon should be considered given his sudden onset of severe pain which could suggest impending or ongoing rupture.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint:  Recent intermittent abdominal pain and lower back pain over several weeks.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Patient has been diagnosed hypertensive for the past 15 years and is currently under medication. 2. Smoking: The patient smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit smoking five years ago. 3. Heart Disease: The patient underwent a coronary artery bypass graft 10 years ago. 4. High Cholesterol: Has a history of high cholesterol. 5. Diabetes: Patient also has a type 2 diabetes history. 6. Family History: He has a family history of cardiovascular disease including an elder brother who died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.   Physical Assessment Findings:  On examination  the patient is comfortable and not in acute distress; His cardiovascular system review revealed a healthy heart rate and rhythm  but a significant abdominal aortic pulsation is palpable on physical examination.   Investigation Findings:  An abdominal ultrasound test revealed an enlarged aorta with a maximum diameter of 6 cm indicating an aneurysm.   Problem Representation Summary:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male; long-standing controlled hypertension  former smoker with a significant past history of heart disease  high cholesterol  and type 2 diabetes; presents with several weeks of intermittent abdominal and lower back pain. He has a notable family history of cardiovascular disease and abdominal aortic aneurysm. On physical examination  an abdominal aortic pulsation was palpated. The patient's abdominal ultrasound has revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm of 6 cm diameter in size.

Problem Representation:  Mr. J.K.  a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 40 pack-year smoking history  presents with an asymptomatic pulsatile abdominal mass. He has had no recent weight loss  change in appetite  no fever or chills  and has not observed any blood in his stool. Other than a bit of indigestion  he denies any abdominal pain. He recalls a brother who died suddenly from a ""ruptured blood vessel in the stomach"" in his early 70s. He is currently retired  drinks socially  and denies use of illicit drugs.  Upon physical exam  he was found to have a palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass and a systolic bruit was heard over the mass. His blood pressure was slightly elevated but within acceptable range given his long-standing history of hypertension.   His medical history is relevant for atherosclerosis  with past medical history of coronary artery disease for which he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement five years ago. He is currently on Aspirin  a statin  and an antihypertensive medication.  The patient was sent for an ultrasound of the abdomen which showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.6 cm.   Diagnosis is an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) likely secondary to atherosclerotic disease. Further evaluation and management are indicated due to the high risk of rupture.

Patient Profile:  Name: Jim Doe Age: 70 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer Race: Caucasian  Residency: Cincinnati  Ohio  Complaint:  The patient has presented with persistent back pain and a feeling of heaviness in the lower abdomen for the past two weeks. He has also reported experiencing occasional bouts of nausea.  Demographics & Lifestyle:  The patient is a retiree and is a former habitual smoker with a history of 40 pack years. He quit smoking 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially and exercises approximately 3 times per week. His diet is fairly balanced  but he does take medications for chronic conditions.  Family History:  The patient's father died of a heart attack at the age of 72. His mother died due to a stroke at 78.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension for which he takes prescribed medication. He also has a known history of high cholesterol and has been controlling it through statin therapy. He underwent surgical resection for Stage II colon cancer 6 years ago and has been in remission since.  Medications:  He is on a daily dose of Lisinopril 5mg for hypertension and Atorvastatin 20mg for high cholesterol.  Relevance:  The history of longstanding hypertension  high cholesterol  and a history of heavy smoking places the patient at risk for vascular conditions including abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The described symptoms like persistent back pain and a feeling of heaviness may correlate with this clinical picture. The male gender  age over 65  and family history of cardiac problems further increases this risk.

Patient Profile Gender: Male Demographic: Caucasian Age: 78 years old Weight: 85 kgs Height: 5'10"" Location: Urban  Social History: The patient retired two decades ago from a manual labor job and lives by himself. He is a former smoker with a 40-year pack history  who quit 15 years ago. He drinks alcohol moderately  usually 1-2 drinks per day. The patient maintains a relatively sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activities.  Family History: Father passed away at the age of 83 from a myocardial infarction. Mother passed away at the age of 90 from natural causes. He has an older brother with peripheral vascular disease and a younger sister with no significant medical issues.   Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago  which is controlled with medication (amlodipine 5 mg daily). 2. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 15 years ago  currently managed using statin therapy (Atorvastatin 20 mg daily). 3. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed with T2DM 10 years ago and is currently managed with Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.  Current Problem: The patient has recently presented to the emergency department with a sudden  severe pain in the lower abdomen and back. This has not occurred before  and the pain was not associated with foods or movements. The patient reported feeling lightheaded  and pulse was rapid at the time. Based on the clinical picture and quickly performed ultrasound  the patient was diagnosed with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient also presented with slightly lower extremity edema and a pulsating mass in the upper middle abdominal area.   Impression: The patient's age  gender  hypertension  smoking history  and familial history suggest a high risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms. The sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain coupled with hemodynamic instability is characteristic of a ruptured aneurysm  a life-threatening condition requiring immediate surgical intervention. The presence of lower extremity edema further indicates compromised vascular perfusion  likely secondary to the ruptured AAA.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 76-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the emergency department.  Presenting Complaint: Sudden onset of severe  sharp mid-abdominal pain radiating to the back and pain in the legs lasting for four hours. He also reports feeling lightheaded and faint.  Past Medical History: Previously diagnosed with hypertension; on medication (Beta-blockers). Non-smoker but exhibited heavy smoking habits up until a decade ago. No known allergies. History of cardiovascular disease on the paternal side of the family. A regular annual screening with normal cholesterol levels. Last colonoscopy five years ago showed non-specific colitis; follow-up was without pathological findings. He had a hernia repair in his 50s and appendectomy during childhood.   Social History: He lives alone; his wife died three years ago. He has two adult daughters living in the same city. Retired from an administrative job. No known alcohol or illicit drug use.   Relevant Exam Findings: Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. On auscultation  bruits may be heard over the mass. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. The patient is hemodynamically stable but looks pale and appears distressed due to pain. Blood pressure is a bit high whereas the pulse is low.   Considered Diagnosis: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) due to age  gender  prior history of smoking  presentation of symptoms  and physical examination. The patient's hypertension  as well as the familial predisposition  add to his risk.   Note: Lab tests  including Full Blood Count  Coagulation Profile  Renal Function Test  Liver Function Tests  and inflammatory markers  as well as imaging (CT angiography)  would help in confirming the diagnosis and evaluation for possible intervention.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Smith Age: 69 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Profession: Retired engineer  Presenting Problem: Mr. Smith presents with unexplained  severe abdominal and lower back pain that has been intermittent for the past few weeks. He reports a feeling of fullness in his abdomen and has also recently noticed a pulsing sensation in this region. Occasionally  he has been dealing with episodes of lightheadedness and fainting.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension since his 50s  managed with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and lifestyle modifications. - Moderate smoker for 40 years but quit 15 years ago. - History of coronary artery disease for the last ten years  managed with statins. - Had a brief episode of deep vein thrombosis in his 60s.  Family History: Both of Mr. Smith's parents had heart disease. His father died of a heart attack at age 75  and his mother died of stroke at 82. His older brother has an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Social History: Mr. Smith is a widower living alone in his own home. His two adult children live nearby and visit regularly. As a retired engineer  he has led a rather sedentary lifestyle post-retirement  but he does go for a walk every day. He quit smoking fifteen years ago  he doesn't consume alcohol and follows a healthy diet.   Physical Examination: Mr. Smith’s vitals indicate slightly elevated blood pressure. The doctor notes a pulsatile mass in the abdomen upon palpitation.  Given Mr. Smith's symptoms  coupled with his personal and family medical history  his physician suspects an abdominal aortic aneurysm and orders subsequent imaging tests to confirm this.

Patient Profile:   - Name: John Doe - Age: 70 - Sex: Male  - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Residence: Urban   Medical History:   - Hypertension for 15 years managed by medication - 20 pack years of smoking history (quit 10 years ago) - No known allergies to medications - Diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 5 years ago  on medication (statin) - Family history of cardiovascular diseases: Father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 68  mother had a stroke at the age of 72 - Appendectomy 30 years ago - No history of diabetes or any lung disease - Free from any chronic autoimmune or inflammatory disease   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe has been experiencing the following   - Gradual onset of pain in the abdomen and back over the past few weeks  - The pain is dull and constant in nature  not related to any food intake or physical activities - Mr. Doe also reported feeling ""a pulsating sensation"" in the abdomen.   Vitals:   - Blood Pressure: 160/85 mmHg  - Pulse: 82 bpm  - Temperature: 98.6 F  - Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths/minute - Oxygen saturation: 97%   Given the demographic profile  medical history  and presenting complaints and vitals  we suspect an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). Further examinations like Ultrasound or CT would likely ensue to confirm the diagnosis.   Note: AAA is often undetected and can be fatal if it ruptures. It occurs most commonly in men aged over 60 and those with a family history of AAA. Other risk factors include smoking and cardiovascular diseases  which are present in Mr. Doe.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  with a history of smoking  presents with abdominal pain and a pulsating sensation in the stomach area. He lives alone and has occasional alcohol intake. He is physically inactive and generally feels fatigued most of the time.  Medical History: - Active smoker for about 50 years. - Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) diagnosed 10 years ago  on intensive therapy  and requires home oxygen. - Hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  poorly controlled  on antihypertensive medication. - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed seven years ago  on statin therapy with inconsistent medication adherence. - History of mild renal insufficiency. - Has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). His father died of a ruptured AAA. - He has had no surgeries or allergies. - Recently had unexplained significant weight loss.  Examinations: On examination  he appears anxious and pale. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg and his pulse rate is irregular at 85 bpm. There is a palpable and pulsatile mass in the patient’s mid to lower abdomen. His peripheral pulses are intact. On abdominal auscultation  a bruit over the mass was noticed.  Abdominal ultrasonography revealed an infrarenal AAA of 5.5 cm in maximum diameter.   Problem List: 1. Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (5.5 cm diameter) with symptoms of abdominal pain and a pulsating sensation in the stomach. 2. Uncontrolled hypertension. 3. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease. 4. Hyperlipidemia with inconsistent adherence to statin therapy. 5. History of heavy smoking. 6. Mild renal insufficiency. 7. Unexplained significant weight loss.  8. High-risk family history of AAA  with father's fatal rupture.   Psychosocial Issues: 1. Poor compliance to medications. 2. Potential lack of social support from living alone.   Prognosis: The patient's overall prognosis is complicated by his age and complicated medical history. Owing to the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  the risk of rupture is high. This  along with the patient's COPD and hypertension  elevates the risk of perioperative mortality and morbidity. Therefore  careful surgical planning and risk management are required.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  • Sex: Male • Age: 68 years old • Race: Caucasian  Patient Presentation:  The patient presents with a sudden  severe  and persistent pain in his lower back and abdomen  which he describes as a tearing sensation. The pain has gradually radiated to his groin and buttocks over the span of few hours. It also includes tachycardia (heightened heart rate)  hypotension (low blood pressure)  and a pulsatile abdominal mass  which could be palpated during physical examination. The patient reports no recent history of trauma or injury.  Demographics & Lifestyle  The patient is retired  lives alone  and is relatively sedentary. He is a former smoker  with a pack-year history of 30 years  and experiences moderation in alcohol intake.  Relevant Medical & Surgical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension  which has been managed with anti-hypertensive medications for the past 10 years. Furthermore  the patient's lipid profile results had indicated high levels of LDL cholesterol  which has resulted in a diagnosis of hyperlipidaemia. He has previously undergone surgery for appendicitis when he was in his early thirties.  Family History:  The patient's father died at the age of 50 due to a rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Additionally  two of his paternal uncles underwent surgery for an aortic aneurysm.  Problem Statement:  In view of the patient’s age  gender  smoking history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of aortic aneurysm  as well as the symptoms of severe and persistent pain in the lower back and abdomen  pulsatile abdominal mass and hemodynamic instability  this is a case of a suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Without prompt diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention  potentially through endovascular aortic repair  this patient's survival could be at a significant risk.

Patient Representation:  Patient Initials: J.T.  Demographic Information: Male  72 years old  Caucasian  married  retired teacher.  Reason for visit: Complains of constant  deep  gnawing abdominal pain for the past week.   Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: The patient has been suffering from hypertension for the last 22 years. He takes a daily dose of lisinopril (20mg).   2. High Cholesterol: His latest lipid panel  taken six months ago  showed high levels of LDL and total cholesterol. He is on atorvastatin (40mg daily).  3. Smoking History: Patient smoked one pack of cigarettes a day for the last 30 years  but quit 5 years ago.  4. Previous Surgery: Underwent appendectomy when he was 27.  5. Family History: Father died due to a heart attack at 62  mother died from stroke at 70.  6. Alcohol: The patient drinks socially  approximately 2-4 drinks a week.  One week ago  the patient began noticing a constant  deep and gnawing pain in his lower abdomen. The pain seems to be centralized to the middle of the abdomen and does not radiate. It doesn't seem to get worse or better with food  position or physical activity. He rates the pain as 6/10. He also reports mild episodes of dizziness for the same period. The patient's current medications are lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 40mg daily for high cholesterol. He has no known drug allergies.

Patient Representation:  Demographic Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named John  who resides in Brooklyn  NY living with his wife. He is a retired truck driver and has three adult children. He is a former heavy smoker with a 40-pack per year history but quit smoking 10 years ago. He rarely drinks alcohol and consumes a diet moderately high in fat.  Presenting Problem: John has come to the emergency department at the local hospital with the chief complaint of severe  sudden-onset lower-back and abdominal pain  which he rates as 10 out of 10 on the pain scale. He reports the pain came on suddenly while finishing his daily morning walk.  Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia (both factors that contribute to atherosclerosis)  and a history of claudication with exercise for which he has been seeing the local vascular surgeon. His medication list includes amlodipine for hypertension  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and an 81 mg aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease. He has a family history of cardiovascular problems with his father dying from a myocardial infarction in his 70s and his brother having a history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Past Surgical History: John's past surgical history is relatively unremarkable. His only surgery was a cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) 15 years ago following a diagnosis of gallstones.   Psychosocial History: John is a lifelong resident of Brooklyn  NY where he worked as a truck driver until retirement at 65. He has been married for over 40 years and has a supportive network of family and friends. John is a non-practicing Roman Catholic. He does not have any history of drug use and seldom consumes alcohol.   Potential Problem: Given his sudden severe abdominal and back pain  history of claudication  significant family history  and risk factors of age  male gender  smoking history  and hyperlipidemia  there is a high index of suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) - a potentially life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical attention. An AAA might be enlarging or leaking which can lead to a fatal rupture if not treated promptly. The pain he experienced could be a sign that the aneurysm is about to rupture.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  residing in the suburban area. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack year history and quit 15 years ago. He has no known drug allergies.   Chief Complaint:  He presents with intermittent abdominal and lower back pain which he has been experiencing for the past couple of months.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history of moderate hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well-controlled with medications (Lisinopril 10mg daily  Simvastatin 20mg daily). He was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and hyperlipidemia about 7 years ago.   Family History:  He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - his father had a myocardial infarction at 65  and a maternal uncle died from a ruptured aortic aneurysm.  Review of Systems:  He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  changes in bowel or bladder function  or any neurological symptoms. He also denies any recent weight loss or night sweats.  Sexual/Reproductive History: The patient has been married for 50 years  has had no other sexual partners.  Travel  Social and Environment History: His alcohol consumption is approximately 3-4 standard drinks per week and he does not use any illicit drugs. He denies any recent travel or changes in dietary habits.  Medications: He takes 10mg Lisinopril daily for hypertension and 20mg Simvastatin daily for hyperlipidemia.  Physical Findings on Examination: Initial vital signs are stable. On physical exam  he has a pulsatile abdominal mass that is slightly tender to palpation. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy or peripheral edema.  Pathogenic Factors: History of smoking predisposes the patient to atherosclerosis and consequently aortic aneurysm. Age and male gender also contribute to a higher risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms. Furthermore  the patient’s family history makes him genetically predisposed to cardiovascular diseases  including aortic aneurysm.   Hence  the aforementioned cues and patient history point towards a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic testing including abdominal ultrasound or CT angiogram is recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

Case Report: Large Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Male  I. Demographic Information Patient Initials: JB  Age: 68  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer  II. Reason for Reporting: A 68-year-old man presented to the emergency department with complaints of intense abdominal pain. He has been diagnosed with a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  III. Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  each of which has been controlled for the past 10 years with lifestyle modifications (dietary changes and exercise) and oral medications. He quit smoking 15 years ago  but had a 30-pack year history. His father died of an aneurysm  type unknown  at the age of 55.  IV. Physical Exam Findings: Upon physical examination  his Blood Pressure was measured at 154/98 mm Hg and his heart rate was 102 beats per minute. He reported severe  constant pain in his lower back that radiated to his groin  making his legs feel weak. His abdomen was soft but with a palpable pulsating mass in the mid-epigastric region. There was tenderness on palpation in the region as well.  V. Diagnostic Tests & Results: The patient underwent abdominal ultrasonography  which indicated the existence of a 7.0 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. Additionally  an abdominal CT scan was performed to confirm the diagnosis and plan for surgical intervention. The CT scan corroborated the findings from the ultrasound and also revealed a small amount of free fluid in the abdomen  suggesting imminent rupture. Hematological and biochemical investigations were otherwise normal.  VI. Clinical Course: Due to an imminent risk of rupture  the patient was quickly prepared for emergency endovascular aortic repair (EVAR)  rather than open repair due to his overall health and comorbidity status  and as per the consensus with the patient and his family. He underwent successful surgery  with stent placement and was kept under close monitoring. Post-surgery  he showed significant improvement and was discharged ten days later. He was referred for follow-up visits and monitoring at intervals of 1  3  6  and 12 months post-discharge.   VII. Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and intervention in managing large abdominal aortic aneurysms to prevent life-threatening outcomes. It manifests the role of unspecific symptoms in potential vascular catastrophes and guides the requirement of good medical history for risk strata identification and timely intervention. The patient's family history of aneurysms and his lifestyle conditions made him vulnerable to AAA. Though faced with the problem at a severe stage  timely and appropriate diagnosis and surgical management helped the patient turn toward a regular lifestyle post-discharge.   N.B: This report has been anonymized to maintain the patient's privacy.

Report Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old Caucasian Male  Patient Information: The presented case involves a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired salesman residing in the urban region of New York. We respect patient privacy  so the patient will be referred to as Mr. X throughout the report.   Medical History: Mr. X is a former smoker with a history of hypertensive and hyperlipidemia conditions. He quit smoking ten years ago after a 30-year smoking history. There is no family history of heart disease or aneurysms. He has been prescribed angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (for hypertension) and statins (for hyperlipidemia). Mr. X is not diabetes and does not suffer from any other known disorders.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. X sought medical advice due to persistent abdominal and lower back discomfort  which arose over the previous two weeks. Moreover  he felt a throbbing sensation in his abdominal region  which intensified gradually.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a pulsating abdominal mass was detected  and a bruit was heard upon auscultation. Mr. X's blood pressure measured 160/95 mmHg  and his BMI was within normal range. Blood tests revealed elevated levels of cholesterol and triglycerides.  Diagnostic Assessment: Following the initial assessment  Mr. X underwent ultrasonography  revealing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further evaluation by computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed a 5.7 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no signs of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. X was immediately referred to vascular surgery. He underwent elective open surgical repair  and the postoperative course was uneventful. The excised aneurysm was sent for histopathological evaluation.   Follow-up and Outcomes: Due to the successful surgery  there was significant symptom reduction. Mr. X was discharged with ongoing drug therapy to treat his hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Regular follow-ups  including ultrasound examinations every six months  have been proposed to ensure no recurrence or development of new aneurysms. Two weeks after surgery  Mr. X reported a significant decrease in abdominal pain.  Patient Perspective: Mr. X expressed relief  having undergone successful surgery. He recognized the seriousness of his condition and understood the need for regular follow-up consultations and lifestyle modifications for maintaining his health.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and any accompanying images.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the significance of regular follow-up and monitoring of high-risk patients with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  as well as those people with a history of smoking. The case also illustrates the subtlety with which an abdominal aortic aneurysm can present  reinforcing the importance for physicians to consider this potentially fatal condition in patients presenting with abdominal or back pain.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Caucasian Male  Patient Profile The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history relevant for Type II Diabetes mellitus  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease.
