He has a history of smoking - two packs of cigarettes per day for 40 years before quitting ten years ago. The patient also has a history of mild alcohol intake. He is currently on medications including Metformin  Lisinopril  Simvastatin  and Aspirin. He lives with his wife  has three grown children  and he is a retired carpenter.  Presenting Complaint  The patient presented in the Emergency Department with a chief complaint of severe abdominal pain  radiating to his back and lasting for several hours. The pain was sudden  severe and constant. The patient mentioned he has been feeling abdominal fullness for few days but thought it might be due to indigestion. He also reports feeling dizzy and sweaty but denied chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  loss of consciousness  nausea  or vomiting.   Clinical Findings On physical examination  the patient was afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Abdomen was non-tender  distended with a notable pulsatile mass in the middle and lower part of his abdomen. Following initial examination  an emergency abdominal ultrasound was performed which showed a 6 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. Subsequently  a CT angiogram was obtained for detailed anatomy review which confirmed the diagnosis of a 6.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no sign of rupture and no renal artery involvement.   Discussion The patient was diagnosed with a large abdominal aortic aneurysm. This is a life-threatening condition  requiring immediate surgical intervention. Given the patient's past medical history and smoking history  he falls into the common demographic for an aneurysm which is typically seen in Caucasian men  over the age of 60 with cardiovascular and pulmonary issues or those who have a history of smoking.   Treatment Following discussion with the vascular surgeon and anesthesiologist  and considering the size of the aneurysm and its impending rupture  an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was performed.   Conclusion The operation was successful without complications and the patient's post-operative period was uneventful. He was discharged from the hospital in stable condition with follow-up visits arranged with the vascular surgery outpatient clinic. This case emphasizes the importance of considering abdominal aortic aneurysm in the differential diagnosis in older patients with abdominal pain  especially in those with risk factors such as hypertension  smoking and hyperlipidemia.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-Year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is an asymptomatic  potentially fatal condition that commonly affects older adults. This report presents the case of a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with AAA.  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  living in the midwestern United States. He is a retired truck driver who spent a significant portion of his career driving long distances  leading a sedentary lifestyle. He is a current smoker with a 40-pack per year history and consumes moderate amounts of alcohol regularly. He is obese (BMI  31 kg/m2) and has a family history of vascular diseases. The patient lives with his wife and has a regular but not varied diet.  Clinical Findings:  The patient reported to the outpatient department with mild abdominal discomfort that had been persisting for two weeks. The pain was non-radiating and constant  rather than intermittent  with no associated symptoms such as fever  chills  nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits. There was no history of black tarry stools or hematemesis suggestive of gastrointestinal bleeding.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Physical Examination of the abdomen revealed a palpable  pulsatile mass. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring 5.5cm in maximum anterior-posterior diameter which suggested an impending rupture. Laboratory test results unveiled mildly elevated serum cholesterol  triglyceride levels  and C-reactive protein.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient underwent an urgent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) procedure  which was uneventful. His postoperative period was marked by a brief hospital stay in the surgical intensive care unit. He received appropriate postoperative care  including analgesics for pain management  and antibiotics to minimize infection risk.   Follow up and outcomes:  Upon sequential follow-ups  it was observed that the patient was recovering well. He was free of abdominal pain and other associated symptoms. Repeat abdominal ultrasound after three months revealed no leakage or expansion of the repaired aneurysm.   The patient has been further counseled on the importance of lifestyle modification which includes quitting smoking  adopting a balanced diet to control his weight and lipids level. He was also encouraged to engage in moderate-intensity physical activities like walking or swimming.   Discussion: This case underscores the significance of early detection and immediate intervention in AAA  especially among high-risk populations to improve the prognosis. Patient education for lifestyle modification could play a vital role in preventing the expansion or rupture of AAA.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief with the resolution of abdominal discomfort and was determined to adhere to the lifestyle modifications suggested. The patient also understood the importance of routine follow-ups to monitor his recovery.

Title: Acute Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 67-Year-Old Male with a Medical History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Introduction:  This case presents Mr. L  a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  who was referred to the emergency department due to sudden onset of severe lower back and abdominal pain.  Demographic Information:  Mr. L is a retired engineer who lives with his wife in rural Pennsylvania. He has a 35-year history of smoking  drinking alcohol occasionally  and no known drug allergies. His regular medications include amlodipine for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He has no history of surgeries or prior hospitalizations. His family history is notable  with his father having died of a heart attack at the age of 70 and his mother of stroke at age of 80.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  Mr. L was visibly in distress  sweating profusely with a notably distended abdomen. His vital signs revealed a beating heart rate of 110 beats/min  blood pressure 160/90mmHg  respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  and an oxygen saturation of 95% while breathing ambient air. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsating mass in the mid-abdomen region and a systolic bruit. Lower limb pulses were symmetrical  and there was no sign of limb ischemia.  Diagnostic Assessment:  With suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  we performed an urgent computed tomography (CT) scan. It confirmed an infrarenal aortic aneurysm of 7.5 cm in diameter. Furthermore  evidence of a mural thrombus was seen without signs of active rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention:  After discussing the CT findings and available treatment options with Mr. L and his family  he was immediately prepped for emergency open repair surgery. During the surgery  the aneurysm was exposed through a trans-peritoneal approach and a prosthetic (Dacron) graft was successfully placed. The postoperative period was uneventful and he was discharged home a week later on appropriate medications.  Follow-Up & Outcomes:  At a six months follow-up  Mr. L was doing well and had managed to quit smoking. An ultrasound at that time showed no signs of aneurysm recurrence.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering AAA in any elder patient with hypertension history presenting with severe abdominal or back pain. Also  it stresses the crucial role of CT imaging in the prompt diagnosis and management of potentially life-threatening AAA. Furthermore  this report underscores the value of post-surgery lifestyle modification counseling in minimizing future cardiovascular risks.  Authors: [Author's Name] and team  Date:  [date]

Patient Introduction:   Mr. A is a 68-year-old Caucasian male from the rural suburbs. He is a retired farmer with a medical history of hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and a 45 pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking 5 years ago upon a diagnosis of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). He stands 5'10"" tall and weighs 85kgs  putting his BMI at 26.6  considered overweight. He drinks occasionally  and denies any history of illicit drug use.  Chief Complaint and History of Present Illness:  He presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of progressively worsening and persistent abdominal and lower back pain for the last two weeks. He also reported occasional dizziness and a feeling of ""fullness"" in the abdomen  particularly after meals. He denied any chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  changes in bowel or bladder habits  unexplained weight loss  or fever.  Family History:  Reportedly  his father had a history of cardiovascular disease and died of a myocardial infarction. His mother had diabetes  and a younger sister survived breast cancer. There has been no known history of peripheral vascular disease or aneurysms in the family.   Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  Mr. A's vital signs were within normal limits. He appeared mildly discomforted due to pain. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile and tender mass in the peri-umbilical area  more noticeable on deep palpation. The rest of the physical examination  including the cardiovascular  respiratory  and musculoskeletal systems  was unremarkable.  Investigations:  Lab results indicated a slight anemia (Hb 11.2 g/dL) and mildly raised inflammatory markers (CRP 20 mg/L). Liver and kidney function tests were within normal parameters.   An abdominal ultrasound showed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. The findings were confirmed by a contrast-enhanced CT angiogram of the abdomen and pelvis showing an saccular aortic aneurysm with mild mural thrombus  without any signs of rupture or dissection.  Management:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  he was counselled for urgent surgical intervention. He underwent an elective open surgical repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm  with placement of a Dacron graft  performed by the vascular surgery team. The procedure went smoothly  without any complications.  Follow Up:  Postoperatively  he was monitored in the Intensive Care Unit initially and then moved to the ward. His postoperative recovery was uneventful  and follow-up ultrasound at one week and then at one month showed no complications. He was advised to attend regular follow-ups and was referred to a smoking cessation and cardiac rehabilitation program.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing the aortic aneurysm symptoms and the crucial role of primary care providers in the timely referral for surgical intervention. Given the patient's risk factors  including age  hypertension  and a significant smoking history  an abdominal ultrasound or CT scan should be considered if they present with persistent abdominal or back pain  particularly if a pulsatile abdominal mass is detected on examination.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: The patient is a Caucasian male  aged 70 years  from the urban region of San Francisco. He is married with two children and is a retired mechanical engineer living with his wife. He has a social history of moderate alcohol consumption and is a former smoker  having ceased smoking 15 years ago.   Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are well-managed with medication. There is family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father had a myocardial infarction and his mother had a stroke. He has no known allergies and is currently under a combination of antihypertensive  lipid-lowering and antidiabetic medications.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that had awakened him from sleep. The pain was described as a sharp tearing sensation  radiating to the back. The patient also noted mild shortness of breath but denied symptoms of chest pain  palpitations  syncope  nausea  vomiting  or lower limb weakness.   Examination & Investigation: Upon examination  the patient was found to be alert and oriented but appeared in significant distress due to pain. Vital signs were notable for tachycardia with a heart rate of 102 beats per minute and blood pressure of 170/85 mmHg. There was a palpable abdominal mass with systolic pulsation. No bruits were discernable.   An immediate contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan was ordered  which revealed a 7.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with evidence of rupturing.   Management: The patient was immediately admitted to the intensive care unit for monitoring and preparation for emergency surgical repair. Given the rupture risk and patient's distressing pain  endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was promptly executed after hemodynamic stabilization.   Post-operation  the patient was stable. He was discharged on post-op day 7 with prescriptions for pain medication and follow-up appointments with the vascular surgery team.  Follow-up: At three-month follow-up  a repeat CT scan demonstrated successful aneurysm exclusion and no endoleak. The patient was advised to continue regularly monitoring and follow-up sinography for his aneurysm.  This case underscores the importance of immediate assessment and management of abdominal aortic aneurysm to avoid life-threatening complications. It also emphasizes the role of effective long-term surveillance post-repair to identify any complications at the earliest. Future directions include an emphasis on smoking cessation and atherosclerotic risk factor reduction  consistent with guidelines for aneurysm management.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)   Patient: Male  68 years old  Caucasian  retired teacher  resides in New Orleans  Louisiana with his spouse.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient was referred to our vascular clinic for a routine checkup  following incidental detection of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) on a lumbar spine MRI performed for chronic back pain evaluation. He complained of no other symptoms and appeared generally well.  Clinical History:  The patient’s medical history is noteworthy for hypertension  diagnosed eight years ago  and for which he has been on treatment (Amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide) with fair control. He also has a ten-year history of type-2 diabetes mellitus  managed with oral hypoglycemic agents (metformin). There is no history of heart disease or stroke. The patient has not had any previous surgeries.   He has quit smoking four years ago  after a 40-year long smoking history and denies alcohol abuse. He is a known case of hyperlipidemia for the past five years and is on statin therapy.  Clinical Examination:  Physical examination of the abdomen revealed a pulsatile mass just above the umbilicus. No bruits were heard on auscultation over the mass. The rest of the body examination was unremarkable.  Investigation:  Confirmatory diagnosis was made by abdominal ultrasonography which revealed an infra-renal AAA  measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. No sign of impending rupture was noticed. Subsequent CT angiogram provided similar results  while also ruling out the potential for aneurysm extension into the iliac vessels.  Management and Discussion:  The patient was counseled about the risks and benefits of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and open surgery for AAA. Considering the patient's age  comorbidities and the size of the aneurysm  he was scheduled for an elective EVAR. The procedure was uneventful and the patient was discharged on postoperative day three.  Regular follow-up will be crucial for our patient to monitor for potential complications including endoleak  graft migration  aneurysm enlargement  or rupture. Moreover  the patient needs to adhere to his ongoing treatment for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes  as these comorbidities can adversely affect the prognosis.  The case emphasizes the importance of routine health checks and imaging  which can lead to the incidental diagnosis of potentially critical conditions like AAA  particularly in population groups at higher risk  such as older  male patients with a history of smoking  hypertension and atherosclerosis.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Patient Description: The patient  Mr. X  is an 80-year-old Caucasian male residing in New York. He has been a habitual smoker for over 60 years and has a record of moderate alcohol consumption. His occupation  pre-retirement  was a long-time construction worker.  Medical History: Mr. X has a significant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been taking angiotensin receptor blockers and statins  respectively  for the past ten years. He also has a history of ischemic heart disease and underwent stent placement 5 years back. There hasn't been any significant surgical history apart from the stent procedure. He doesn't have any known allergies.  Presenting Problem: Mr. X presented to the emergency department with severe on-going abdominal and lower back pain  which started about 2 hours ago  along with signs of acute distress. No prior episode of such pain was mentioned during the medical history recording. He was pale  clammy  with cold extremities and showing signs of shock.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  his blood pressure was 85/50 mmHg with a pulse rate of 105 beats per minute. A pulsatile abdominal mass was felt on palpation  accompanied by tenderness. Labs revealed a decreased hematocrit and mild hyperkalemia.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation  severe pain  hypotension  and presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass  the preliminary diagnosis was a suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This suspicion was confirmed by an urgent CT angiogram which revealed a large infrarenal AAA with evidence of rupture.  Treatment Course: Mr. X was expeditiously transferred to the operating room after initial resuscitation with crystalloid fluids. An emergency open aortic repair was successfully performed to exclude the aneurysm.  Outcome: The patient made a steady recovery in the intensive care unit post-operatively. He was discharged after 14 days without any marked postoperative complications.  Prognosis: He was advised to continue his antihypertensive and statin medication  quit smoking and limit alcohol consumption. He was scheduled for regular follow-ups  as patients with a history of AAA have an increased risk of developing thoracic aortic aneurysms.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of immediate recognition and rapid resuscitation before definitive surgical repair for ruptured AAA cases. Despite the high mortality rate  early diagnosis and prompt treatment could result in favorable patient outcomes and survival as successful in Mr. X's case.  The report serves as a noteworthy reminder for regular AAA screenings in older  smoking males with cardiovascular risks  given their higher propensity for developing this condition. Close monitoring of the patient post-treatment is also crucial due to the potential for other vascular aneurysms.

Patient Information:   Mr. R.D.  a Caucasian male  aged 68 years  residing in Houston  Texas.  Case History:   Mr. R.D. consulted the Cardiovascular Outpatient Clinic complaining about persistent abdominal and back pain. He is a retired bank executive and non-smoker but has a history of hypertension for 15 years. He also reported having episodes of dull  intermittent abdominal discomfort  mostly located in the lower abdomen that occurs predominantly during physical exertion in the past few months. Family history was significant for premature cardiovascular disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at 52 years of age and his brother underwent an open surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 59.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient was found to be overweight  with a body mass index (BMI) of 29 kg/m2. Abdominal palpation revealed a pulsatile mass in the supraumbilical area. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An abdominal ultrasound was performed  which confirmed the presence of a fusiform AAA with a maximum diameter of 5.4 cm extending from the renal arteries to the aortic bifurcation. No signs of rupture or leak were seen. EKG showed no anomalies  and cardiac tests returned normal results. Laboratory tests  including full blood count  renal function  and lipids were within normal limits.  Treatment:  Given the size of the aneurysm  its rapid enlargement  and the patient's family history  it was decided to opt for surgical intervention. An elective open surgery for AAA repair was performed successfully without any complications.  Follow Up:  After the surgery  he was observed in the hospital for several days and then instructed to attend regular follow-ups. Restoration of natural flow of the blood by graft repair was confirmed by the postoperative ultrasound. He was prescribed beta-blockers for hypertension and was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle.  Conclusion:  This case portrays the significant role of early detection and management of AAA  especially in individuals with a strong family history of cardiovascular disease. It emphasizes the necessity of regular follow-up and medical management in preventing fatal complications such as rupture and large blood loss. Along with surgical interventions  addressing modifiable risk factors like hypertension and obesity is crucial.

Title: Management of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male with Chronic Conditions: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 79-year-old Caucasian male  a retired factory worker  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. He described a sudden and extreme pain sensation originating in his midsection and spreading across his lower back. Additional symptoms include nausea and significant fatigue. The patient lives with his wife and is regularly mobile. He is a non-smoker and only drinks alcohol socially.  Medical History:  His medical history was significant with a diagnosis of stage-I kidney disease five years prior  managed by diet and ACE inhibitors. He also has Type II diabetes (10 years)  controlled with Metformin  and hypertension (15 years)  managed by Lisinopril. The patient has moderate obesity (BMI: 30.5) and a family history of cardiovascular disease (father died from myocardial infarction  brother has peripheral artery disease). The patient is otherwise regularly monitored and remains medication compliant.  Clinical Findings: During evaluation  the patient appeared in distress. Vital signs demonstrated a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and SpO2 of 94% on room air. Initial physical examination revealed a tender  pulsatile abdominal mass and a palpable thrill. Auscultation of the abdomen also detected a bruit over the mass. An ultrasound confirmed the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Diagnostic Assessment: Further diagnostic imaging of the abdomen through computed tomography angiography (CTA) showed a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with a small area of hyperdensity indicating possible impending rupture. Given the patient’s presentation and risk factors  the decision was made to proceed to immediate surgical repair.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient underwent successful open repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm with a Dacron tube graft. His postoperative course was uneventful  and he was discharged on postoperative day six with instructions for wound care and follow-up visits.  Follow-up and Outcomes: At a follow-up one month later  the patient was recovering well  with no symptoms related to the repaired aneurysm. His wound was healing appropriately  and graft placement was confirmed to be uneventful by imaging. The patient was counseled again on weight management and cardiovascular risks with his current comorbidities.  Learning Points: This case highlights the importance of considering AAA in elders presenting with severe abdominal or back pain  especially with a history of hypertension  kidney disease  and familial predisposition. Prompt diagnosis and treatment in suspected AAA can prevent fatal consequences. Comprehensive postoperative care  along with lifestyle and risk factor modifications play pivotal role in mitigating future cardiovascular events.

Title: Emergency Management of a Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Information: Mr. T is a 76-year-old male presented to the emergency room (ER) with a history of an abrupt onset of severe abdominal and back pain  described as “tearing.”   Medical History: He has a past medical history of hypertension  coronary artery disease  and peripheral arterial disease  for which he was on pharmacological management including aspirin  statins and beta-blockers. He has been a regular smoker for the past 55 years  and he also has a 20-years history of high alcohol intake. He had no known allergies. His family history revealed that his father died from the rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient had a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg with a heart rate of 110 bpm. He appeared pale  diaphoretic and distressed. His abdomen was distended and pulsatile. Further examination confirmed the presence of a large palpable abdominal mass. Rectal examination revealed melaena.  Diagnostic Assessments & Therapeutic Interventions: Lab results were significant for hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL  INR 1.4  and a serum lactate of 4.0mmol/L. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was immediately done  which confirmed a 7.5 cm ruptured infrarenal AAA with surrounding hematoma. Owing to the patient’s unstable condition  he was emergently transferred to the operating room for a repair of the AAA. Open surgical repair was performed  and the patient tolerated the procedure well.  Follow up and Outcome:  Post-op  the patient was closely monitored in the surgical ICU with regular measurement of his hemodynamics and hemoglobin levels. He required transfusion of packed RBCs. His recovery was uneventful until post-op day 3 when he developed a fever. Investigations revealed a urinary tract infection which was managed successfully with antibiotics. The patient was discharged home on post-operative day 14 after a period of inpatient rehabilitation. He was advised to quit smoking and drinking. A follow-up appointment was scheduled for a month later  where his recovery was satisfactory.  Patient Perspectives: Mr. T expressed his relief on surviving the life-threatening AAA and agreed to actively work on his lifestyle modifications.  Informed Consent: The patient gave his informed consent for this case to be published.  Takeaway Lessons: The high mortality rate associated with ruptured AAA places significant importance on early detection and intervention. This case highlights the importance of late-night surgery  good post-operative ICU care  and the role of lifestyle modifications in preventing recurrence.  Learning Points: 1. A high index of suspicion for AAA is required in elderly patients presenting with severe abdominal or back pain  particularly if they have a history of hypertension  coronary artery disease  or peripheral arterial disease. 2. Given the high risk of AAA in first-degree relatives  proactive screening can be lifesaving. 3. Lifestyle modifications  such as smoking cessation and reduction of alcohol intake  are important in the management of patients with  or at risk for  AAA.

Case Report on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old male  Caucasian with a BMI of 28. He is a retired mechanic and is a current smoker with a 50 pack-year history. Alcohol consumption is noted to be moderate. His mother suffered from strokes  and his father died of sudden cardiac arrest. The patient has two sons  both healthy.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Medications include a statin  an oral antihypertensive  and inhaled steroids for his COPD.   Presenting Complaint: The patient arrived at a hospital reporting severe and sudden onset of pain in the lower back and abdomen  accompanied by a feeling of fullness in the abdomen. The patient described the pain as a ripping sensation  initially rated as a 10 on a severity scale of 1 to 10.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination showed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. His vital measurements were stable but blood pressure was slightly elevated at 150/90 mm Hg and pulse rate was approximately 80 beats per minute. Lab results indicated an elevated white cell count and increased D-dimer levels  suggesting an inflammatory process.   Diagnostic Assessment: A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  indicating rupture risk.   Treatment Plan: Given the size of the aneurysm and presenting symptoms  the decision was made to proceed with surgical intervention. The patient underwent elective open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair  which went smoothly with no intraoperative complications.   Postoperative Course: Postoperatively  the patient was transferred to the ICU. His recovery period was remarkable with no complications. He was discharged on the 10th postoperative day with prescriptions for analgesics  a continuation of his previous antihypertensive therapy  and lipid-lowering medications.   Patient Education & Follow-Up: The patient was advised to quit smoking and to modify his diet to help manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia. A long-term follow-up plan was formulated that included regular visits to a vascular surgeon and a cardiologist with periodic monitoring of his aneurysm via ultrasound.  This case undeniably showcases the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment of abdominal aortic aneurysms to prevent life-threatening complications like rupture. Comprehensive patient education on lifestyle modification along with long-term medical supervision are essential for successful outcomes.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old Male with a History of Hypertension  Case Description: Our patient is a 65-year-old African-American male who presented to the emergency department with a complaint of severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that had begun approximately four hours prior to arrival. The pain was described as a constant sharp pain radiating to his lower back. The patient also reported a sensation of ""pulsating"" in his abdomen. There was no history of trauma or any triggering event associated with the onset of pain. On further questioning  the patient admitted to a history of untreated hypertension  a past smoker having smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for 20 years and stopped 10 years ago  and a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father dying at the age of 70 from a ""ruptured aorta"".  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient was found to be in distress  sweating  and slightly pale. His blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg  heart rate was 110 beats per minute  and his respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute. On palpation of the abdomen  a pulsatile mass was detected in the midline of the abdomen just above the umbilicus. There was marked tenderness along the course of the aorta.  Investigations: An urgent CT angiography was performed  which confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.9 cm in maximum diameter. There was no evidence of leak or rupture noted.  Management and Follow-up: The patient was admitted to the vascular surgery service and underwent an urgent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  without any perioperative complications. He was started on antihypertensive medication. His hospital course was uneventful and he was discharged after five days. The patient was scheduled for regular follow-ups with our outpatient vascular surgery service.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the dramatic presentation of a potentially life-threatening condition in a patient with a history of untreated hypertension and smoking. It further underscores the importance of regular screenings for abdominal aortic aneurysms in high-risk populations to ensure an early diagnosis and prevent catastrophic complications. Regular follow-ups in such patients are critical for the timely identification of aneurysm expansion and the evaluation for potential intervention. It also emphasizes the necessity of a multi-disciplinary approach in managing AAA  involving emergency physicians  radiologists  and vascular surgeons. Regular check-up and medication adherence were encouraged to this patient to manage his hypertension.

Patient Information:  Mr. K was a 72-year-old Caucasian man living with his wife in a suburban area. He had a history of hypertension for the past 10 years but was otherwise generally healthy  with no documented allergies. Mr. K had a 30 pack-years history of smoking but had quit 15 years prior to presentation.  Clinical Findings:  Mr. K presented at the outpatient clinic stating he had been experiencing vague lower abdominal pain over the past few weeks. The pain was mainly centrally located  constant  and described as a dull ache. He denied any changes to his bowel habits  but he reported occasional loss of appetite. There was no history of weight loss  no symptoms suggestive of upper or lower gastrointestinal bleed  and no urological symptoms.  Diagnosis  Treatment  and Outcomes:  Physical examination showed a pulsatile mass in his central lower abdomen. Abdominal ultrasound revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The aneurysm was 6 cm in diameter approximately 2 cm below the renal arteries. A CT angiogram confirmed the presence  location  and size of the aneurysm  revealing that there was no leak or rupture of the aneurysm. Mr. K was. Therefore  referred to a vascular surgeon for further management.  The vascular surgical team recommended an elective open surgical repair of the aneurysm due to its size and the patient's symptoms. He underwent a successful aortic aneurysm repair. His postoperative recovery was uneventful  with no immediate complications. Mr. K was discharged on the 10th postoperative day with instructions for regular follow-up.  Six weeks postoperatively  the patient reported resolution of his abdominal symptoms. A follow-up ultrasound showed no evidence of an aneurysm. He remained healthy and symptom-free at his six-month and one-year follow-up appointments.   In summary  this case report highlights the successful diagnosis and management of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in a patient presenting with vague lower abdominal pain. The case underscores the importance of considering the differential diagnosis of abdominal pain in elderly patients  especially those with known risk factors such as hypertension and a history of smoking.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 74-Year-Old Male  Patient Profile: The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male presenting with vague  moderate  non-radiating abdominal discomfort. He is a former smoker with a smoking history of 28 pack-years but successfully completed a smoking cessation program 12 years ago. There is no significant familial history of any cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and has been stabilized on medication. He was also diagnosed with mixed hyperlipidemia and is on a Statins regime. He has no history of diabetes mellitus  ischemic heart disease  valvular heart disease  chronic pulmonary disease  or any familial connective tissue disorders. He underwent an appendectomy in his 20s; no other surgical history is notable.  Clinical Presentation: The patient complains of discomfort in the abdominal region  which has persisted for several weeks. No other symptoms such as fever  nausea  weight loss  lumbar pains  or changes in bowel movements were reported. On examination  he is apyrexic  with a blood pressure of 138/84 mmHg and heart rate of 86 beats/minute. Abdominal palpation induces mild discomfort and reveals a prominent  pulsatile mass about 4 cms in diameter.  Investigations: Extensive laboratory testing  including full blood count  liver function tests  renal profile  electrolytes  cholesterol levels  and coagulation profile  were all largely within normal limits. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan displayed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.2 cm with no signs suggestive of rupture or dissection.  Management: The patient was assessed to be fit for open surgical repair with no contraindication on preoperative evaluation  and thus he was scheduled for elective open aortic aneurysm repair. The aneurysm repair was successful  with no perioperative complications. His postoperative recovery was uneventful  and he was discharged on post-op day 6.  Follow-up:  On subsequent follow-up visits  the patient reported resolution of abdominal discomfort. Abdominal ultrasound at 6 months demonstrated a stable postoperative state without any aneurysm-related abnormalities. His medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia were continued.  Summary: This case indicates that even with moderate  vague symptoms  an abdominal aortic aneurysm can be a differential diagnosis  particularly in elderly males with a history of smoking and hypertension. Early diagnosis and prompt intervention can significantly improve the prognosis of patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  Mr. Jones  a white male aged 68  presented to the emergency department. He resides in Raleigh  North Carolina  and works as a retired banker. Mr. Jones is a nonsmoker but has a history of moderate alcohol intake. He is married with two adult children.  Chief Complaint:   Mr. Jones reported suffering from intermittent and increasing lower abdominal pain over the past few weeks. The pain escalated in the past two days  prompting his visit to the Emergency Department.  History of Present Illness:   The patient describes the pain as a severe  sharp sensation  occasionally radiating to the lower back. The pain does not appear to be related to meals or any specific activities. Over the past week  he reported losing his appetite and noticed notable weight loss. Furthermore  he has complained of recent fatigue and constipation.  Past Medical History:  The patient suffers from hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both controlled with medication over the past 10 years. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago  which was managed successfully with angioplasty. There was no history of surgery or known allergies; however  his elder brother died due to aneurysm rupture two years ago.  Physical Examination:  His vitals on arrival were: blood pressure: 180/95 mmHg  pulse: 88 beats per minute  respiration: 16 breaths per minute  temperature: 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation: 97% on room air. The physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass that was tender to deep palpation. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  The laboratory tests reveal no abnormalities except for mildly elevated C-reactive protein and lipid profile indicating high cholesterol. Abdominal ultrasonography confirmed the presence of a 5.6 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm  prioritizing the patient for urgent surgical intervention.  Clinical Discussion:  Considering the patient's age  male sex  family history  and cardiovascular risk factors  he is considered high risk. The size of the aneurysm and associated symptoms indicate a significant risk of rupture. The patient will therefore undergo an endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) procedure in an urgent setting  considering his heightened blood pressure and medical history.   Patient Outcome:  Mr. Jones consented to the surgery and it was successful  with no noted complications. Post-operative imaging showed a well-seated endograft with no sign of endoleak. He will need routine monitoring with imaging for his aortic health condition. He is also advised to moderate his alcohol intake and strongly recommended to go on a low-fat diet and engage in regular exercise to manage his comorbid conditions and prevent possible recurrence.

Patient Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. J.H.  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department complaining of severe abdominal and lower back pain along with feelings of light-headedness.  Clinical findings: On presentation  the patient was sweaty and visibly in distress. His vital signs were stable  albeit tachycardic with a heart rate of 108 bpm. His blood pressure was 140/90mmHg. The physical exam revealed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen that was tender on palpation.  Past Medical History: Mr. J.H. is a smoker with a 40 pack-year history. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia but has been generally noncompliant with his antihypertensive medications and statins. His surgical history includes an inguinal hernia repair 10 years ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father died of a myocardial infarction in his 60s and his brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair at the age of 65.  Diagnostic assessment: A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis was ordered  which revealed a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No evidence of rupture  but some signs of imminent rupture were noted  such as increased diameter  uncontrolled hypertension  and symptoms correlated with AAA.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was emergently taken to the operating room for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) given the size of the aneurysm and signs of imminent rupture.   Follow up and outcomes:  The surgical intervention was successful and without complications. The patient was monitored in the hospital for five days post-operation and then discharged home. Follow-up imaging six months after the procedure demonstrated a successfully excluded AAA with no evidence of endoleak. The patient's abdominal and back pain completely resolved and he reported a significant improvement in his overall health.  Patient Perspective: Mr. J.H. expressed relief and gratitude following his surgery. He acknowledged his inconsistent medication management and committed to a healthier lifestyle  including smoking cessation intervention.  Informed consent: Informed written consent was obtained from the patient for the surgical procedure and for the publication of this case report.   This case illustrates the importance of early suspicion and diagnosis of AAA  especially in the presence of risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  old age  family history  in conjunction with the corresponding clinical features.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Male  Patient Information  A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient was presented to the emergency department primarily complaining of increasing and severe abdominal pain centered around his naval area  with a secondary symptom of back pain. The patient  a retired contractor  has a known history of hypertension and moderate smoking for about the past 40 years. He has no known drug allergies and his only medication is hydrochlorothiazide 25mg for hypertension. Moreover  the patient has been noncompliant with the prescribed antihypertensive medication due to the side effects of frequent urination as described by the patient. His family history is significant as his father died at the age of 72 due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm.  Clinical Findings  On primary survey  the patient appeared pale and was sweating profoundly. Initial vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a pulse rate of 100bpm. The patient's physical examination showed a pulsatile mass about 3 cm in size in the middle and upper part of his abdomen. An ultrasound confirmed the suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). A computed tomography (CT) scan was performed immediately which revealed a 5.8 cm infrarenal AAA with evidence of bleeding around the aorta  which indicated an impending rupture.  Diagnostic Assessment  Blood tests presented a hemoglobin level of 11.8 g/dL and a hematocrit of 34% which were lower than his typical range  suggesting a bleed. His renal function tests were within normal limits. An electrocardiogram was performed which showed no acute cardiac ischemia.  Therapeutic Intervention  Prompt discussions were performed regarding the possible risks  benefits  and alternatives for surgery  after which the patient gave his consent to undergo an emergent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). The patient was stabilized with IV fluids and blood products  followed by successful implantation of an aortic stent graft.  Follow-up and Outcomes  Post-procedure  the patient was moved to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for close monitoring. His blood pressure steadily increased to 130/80 mmHg within the next 48 hours and his hemoglobin and hematocrit also improved. He was discharged after a week with oral medications and follow-up instructions. Currently  he is undergoing regular checkups and his latest CT scan a month later showed a successful graft with no endoleaks.  Conclusion  Catastrophic consequences may be seen in patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm especially those with risk factors like a history of hypertension  smoking and a positive family history  thus timely diagnosis and prompt intervention can prove to be life-saving. This case also emphasizes the importance of patient education and compliance to their medication routine.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an 84-Year-old Male with a Past History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Patient Information:   The patient is an 84-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of abrupt  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. His past medical history includes chronic hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. The patient lives alone  has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  and is a former smoker  who quit smoking 20 years ago with an estimated 30 pack-year history.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 110 bpm  and his body temperature was 37.5C. He was visibly distressed and mentioned the pain started suddenly a few hours ago. There were no bowel or bladder disturbances  lower limb ischemia  or recent weight loss reported.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Laboratory reports showed a mild increase in white blood cell counts but otherwise unremarkable. His chest radiograph was normal. An urgent abdominal ultrasound detected a 7.4 cm infra-renal aortic aneurysm with signs of impending rupture  confirmed with a subsequent CT Aortogram. No other significant aortic  iliac  or renal aneurysms were detected.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was rushed for an emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Using a femoral approach  a stent-graft was successfully placed covering the aneurysm. Post procedure  the intensive care unit monitored the patient. Pain was controlled with intravenous analgesia and he was hemodynamically stable.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient was discharged home on the 5th postoperative day. He was prescribed antiplatelet and antihypertensive medication. Six-week and six-month follow-ups revealed a successful stent-graft placement without any leak or dislodgement. His pain fully relieved  and he continues his routine activities.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief at his successful surgery and has been compliant with his treatment regimen. He has been encouraged to maintain regular check-ups to monitor his cardiovascular health.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the urgency of diagnosing and treating abdominal aortic aneurysm  particularly amongst elderly patients with a significant history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The adoption of less invasive procedures such as Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) offers a lower risk alternative  especially among high-risk patients. This case also underscores the importance of postoperative surveillance in guaranteeing patient recovery and stent-graft effectiveness.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:   Mr. Jones is a 72-year-old African American male  married  retired mechanical engineer  with a ten-year history of hypertension. He is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol drinker. He worked in his field for over 40 years with possible exposure to asbestos. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases including his father who died of myocardial infarction and a paternal uncle who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Clinical Presentation:  Mr. Jones presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset  sharp  and continuous lower back pain of 5 hours duration. The pain was 8 out of 10 in severity and radiated to both lower extremities. He also reported a pulsating sensation in his abdominal area  but denied any recent trauma  nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his vitals were stable: blood pressure 155/90 mmHg  pulse rate: 82/min  respiratory rate: 24/min  body temperature: 98.6°F. Abdominal examination revealed a tender  pulsating mass located in the central and upper area of the abdomen. All peripheral pulses were equally palpable bilaterally.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the clinical presentation and physical examination signs  an emergent abdomen and pelvic CT scan was ordered which confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.5cm.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient underwent emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  given the size and symptomatic presentation of his AAA. He tolerated the procedure well and his postoperative course in the ICU was uneventful.  Follow Up:  Mr. Jones was discharged after 1-week post-surgery with scheduled vascular surgeon appointments for the next 6 months  and annual surveillance thereafter. We also recommended lifestyle modifications including daily moderate exercise  low salt diet  and regular monitoring of blood pressure.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of a thorough examination for early detection of abdominal aortic aneurysms. As with Mr. Jones  many cases may be detected during evaluation for unrelated issues or during routine physical examination. This may lead to early and timely intervention  potentially saving lives. Due to Mr. Jones's family history of AAA and his occupational exposure to asbestos—both risk factors for development of AAA—it would be prudent to have alerted his primary care physician for earlier surveillance.

Patient Information: Mr. M  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented with intermittent  dull abdominal pain radiating to his lower back. The patient has a history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for 45 years (90-pack/year)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He denies ever having diabetes or cardiovascular problems. He lives alone and is a retired factory worker.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient had mild hypertension (150/90 mmHg). He was afebrile with a heart rate of 82 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Abdominal exam revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region. There were no signs of peripheral arterial disease. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: Due to examination findings  an abdominal ultrasound (US) was ordered. The US revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.5 cm in diameter  with intraluminal thrombus. Blood work showed elevated lipids and slightly reduced hemoglobin; however  no signs of infection or kidney impairment were evident.  Therapeutic Intervention: Following the diagnosis  he was referred to a vascular surgeon. After considering the patient’s age  symptomatology  aneurysm size  and overall health status (including smoking status and controlled hypertension)  the patient was deemed suitable for an elective open repair surgery. The patient consented to the procedure once the risks and benefits were properly explained to him.  Follow Up: The patient underwent successful open aortic repair. He was monitored in the intensive care unit post-operatively and subsequently transferred to the regular floor on post-operative day 2. His post-operative recovery was smooth with good pain control and initiation of ambulation on the first post-operative day. The patient was discharged from the hospital on post-operative day 7  and a follow-up appointment was arranged with the vascular surgery team in six weeks.  Patient Perspective: The patient was relieved to have survived the operation without any major complications. He recognized the importance of cessation of his smoking habits and was motivated to take part in a smoking cessation program.  Clinical Pearls: This case underscores the importance of meticulous physical examination and appropriate referral to a vascular surgeon upon suspicion of AAA. The condition heavily associates with smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  emphasizing the necessity for early detection  lifestyle modification  and elective repair option to mitigate mortality risks.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Male with a History of Hypertension and Smoking  Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented with lower back pain of moderate severity  unaccompanied by any other symptoms. He comes from a low-income community and mentioned that his access to regular healthcare services has been limited over the years.   Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a 20-year history of uncontrolled hypertension. He has been taking antihypertensive medication intermittently due to financial constraints and has lack of regular follow-ups. He also has a significant 40-pack year smoking history and quit around five years ago. He has no known history of diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  or any other cardiovascular diseases. There was no familial history of aortic aneurysm. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 78 beats per minute  and body mass index (BMI) was 24.5 kg/m2. Abdominal palpation revealed a pulsatile mass in the upper middle region of the abdomen. His lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally  and cardiovascular exam showed regular heart sounds with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lower extremity pulses were palpable bilaterally. He had no neurological deficits.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Subsequent ultrasound and CT confirmed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no evident rupture. His complete blood count  coagulation profile  renal  hepatic  and lipid profiles were within the normal range.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Due to the size of the aneurysm  the patient was referred to a vascular surgeon who recommended an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure. The patient underwent successful EVAR without any complications.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Mr. Doe was discharged from the hospital after three days of observation. At the six-month follow-up visit  a CT scan demonstrated that the stent graft was in good position without any signs of endoleak or aneurysm expansion.  Patient Perspective:  Mr. Doe reported significant improvement in his overall health status  with no occurrence of back pain after the procedure. He showed a deep understanding of his continuing need for monitoring and addressing his hypertension and the importance of regular medical follow-ups.  Informed Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images. A copy of the written consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal on request.   Concluding Remarks:  This case highlights the importance of early detection and intervention of abdominal aortic aneurysm  particularly in high-risk patients with long-standing hypertension and a significant smoking history. It also underlines the impact of socioeconomic factors on disease management and patient compliance to medical care.

Title: An Case Report of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Caucasian Male  Patient Information: The patient is Mr. Fred Jones  an 80-year-old Caucasian male born and raised in Kansas  United States.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with severe  sudden-onset abdominal and back pain that had started approximately two hours prior to his arrival at the ED.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Jones described the pain as a sharp  stabbing sensation  rated at 8 on a 1-to-10 pain scale. The pain was relentless  unremitting  and did not radiate to any specific region. He also reported feeling faint and feverish  although he denied any associated nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or urinary symptoms.  Past Medical History: The patient's medical history is significant for controlled hypertension for which he has been on Hydrochlorothiazide for the past 10 years  and a 50-pack year history of smoking  but stopped smoking 15 years ago. Other than these  Mr. Jones has been generally healthy most of his adult life  with no surgeries or significant illnesses except for occasional episodes of bronchitis.   Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared distressed  pale  and diaphoretic. His vital signs were as follows: heart rate 110 bpm  blood pressure 85/55 mmHg  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and temperature 98.6 F. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the central area of the abdomen.  Investigations: Suspecting an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  an emergency abdominal ultrasound was performed  revealing an abdominal aorta of 7.5 cm  indicative of a large AAA. This was confirmed with an emergency CT scan that also revealed an imminent rupture.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was immediately transferred to the vascular surgical team for an emergent open surgical repair. The surgery was successful  and the patient was moved to the intensive care unit for post-surgical monitoring. Mr. Jones was discharged 10 days after the surgery in stable condition and was scheduled for follow-up medical consultations.  Key Learning Point: The case underscores the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for AAA in elderly patients with risk factors such as smoking history  hypertension  male sex  and sudden onset of abdominal pain. Early diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention can significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with AAA.

Patient Information  Mr. Santos  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  was living in New York and having a routine life  working as an accountant at a local firm before retirement. He is a non-smoker and was a moderate consumer of alcohol up until 2 years back  which he gave up upon advice from his attending physician. His family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases  his father and grandfather both having passed away from heart-related conditions.  Presenting Issue  Mr. Santos presented to the emergency department with an intense  sharp pain in the middle of the abdomen that radiates to the lower back region. The pain appeared suddenly and he reported it as the most severe he's ever experienced. He also reported an intermittent feeling of fullness in the abdomen and slight shortness of breath.  Clinical Findings  Clinical examination and ultrasound revealed an abdominal mass which was pulsating. A CT scan confirmed the existence of a 5.5 cm infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Apart from mild hypertension  Mr. Santos was hitherto unaware of any significant health problem.  Past Medical History  Mr. Santos's past medical history includes controlled hypertension  for which he's been on medication for the past 5 years. He was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 8 years back and is under medication. He has no known allergies. His weight is within a healthy range with a BMI 24 mirroring his controlled diet and moderate physical activity.  Therapeutic Intervention  Given the size of the aneurysm and the severe  sudden onset pain  emergent surgical intervention in the form of open repair was undertaken. A graft was successfully placed across the aneurysm. Hospital stay was uneventful.  Follow-up  Upon discharge  Mr. Santos was advised to continue his medication for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Regular follow-ups and scans were suggested to monitor the graft and any potential development of new aneurysms. Lifestyle changes were recommended including maintaining a healthy diet  regular exercises  controlling blood pressure  and cholesterol levels. Staying informed about the signs of an AAA rupture was emphasized  and the patient was urged to seek immediate emergency care if such symptoms occurred in the future.  Conclusion  AAA does not show any symptoms often until rupture. Given Mr. Santos's family history of cardiovascular disorders  routine screenings may have unveiled the developing aneurysm earlier. This case underlines the importance of reaching out to symptomatic individuals  especially those with familial predisposition and educating them about the condition. Condition awareness  routine screenings  immediate response to symptoms  and regular follow-ups post-treatment  play significant roles in managing abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Title: Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 64-Year-Old Male  Introduction:   Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is often a silent and potentially fatal condition characterized by a dilated segment of the aorta in the abdomen most often secondary to atherosclerosis. Here  we report a case of a AAA in a 64-year-old man.   Case Presentation:   The patient  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with intermittent  sudden-onset  severe sharp pain in the lower abdomen and back that had begun 24 hours prior. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and rated it as 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. The patient had a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking (30 pack years).   Physical examination recorded blood pressure at 120/80 mmHg  heart rate of 88/min  respiratory rate of 18/min and temperature of 36.8 degrees Celsius. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass  but there were no signs of peritonitis. There was no distension  bowel sounds were normoactive  and there were no signs of digital clubbing  cyanosis  or edema.   Investigations:   Laboratory tests showed normal complete blood count and creatinine but raised D-dimers (800 ng/mL). Electrocardiography indicated normal sinus rhythm. An ultrasound showed a 7 cm infrarenal AAA without evidence of rupture but with intramural thrombus.  Management and Follow-up:   The patient was immediately transported to the operating room  where an emergent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) was performed successfully without complications. Following surgery  he was started on beta-blockers  statins  and antiplatelet therapy. The patient remained stable postoperatively and was discharged after one week.   At the three-month follow-up  a CT scan showed the aneurysm's successful exclusion and no endoleak. The patient reported a significant decrease in abdominal pain and improvement in his general condition.  Discussion:   This case report underscores the necessity of maintaining a high level of suspicion for AAA even in patients with non-specific abdominal and lower back pain  especially in the presence of risk factors such as age  male gender  smoking  and a history of hypertension. Our patient was properly and promptly managed due to early diagnosis  potentially averting a catastrophic rupture.  Conclusion:  AAA should not be overlooked in differential diagnoses in patients with risk factors particularly due to its high mortality rate in case of rupture. Early detection  via a simple screening tool like ultrasound for high-risk patients  should be promoted.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient   Patient Profile: The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  who lives independently. He was admitted to the hospital due to complaints of intense abdominal pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and coronary artery disease. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 10 years ago. No history of diabetes or other metabolic disorders. There is no known history of allergies or adverse drug reactions. He is a former smoker  though he quit 20 years ago  and reports minimal alcohol use.  Presenting Complaints: The patient was brought into the emergency room reporting severe abdominal pain radiating to his back and lower limb  which had been ongoing for the past 3-4 hours. The pain was described as sharp  constant  and progressively increasing in severity.   Physical Examination: Primary examination showed a distressed elderly male with tenderness in the abdomen  primarily in the periumbilical area. Clinically  the patient was haemodynamically unstable with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. No bruits were audible over the abdomen.   Imaging Studies: An urgent ultrasound was ordered  and it revealed a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with evidence of rupture leading to periaortic hematoma.   Management: The patient was immediately given intravenous access  and aggressive fluid resuscitation was started. He was cross-matched for 6 units of blood. The vascular surgeon was consulted  and an emergency laparotomy and repair of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm were performed.   Postoperative Course: Postoperatively  the patient was taken to the Intensive Care Unit. He was managed with pain relief  antibiotics and intravenous fluids initially. Blood pressure and heart rate improved postoperatively. The patient was extubated on the second postoperative day and walked on the third day.  Follow-up: On the seventh day  he was discharged from the hospital. The patient was put on a regimen of anti-hypertensives and statins. He was advised regular follow-ups to monitor his recovery and potential complications.   Conclusion: This case report underlines the importance of early diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention in managing a patient with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm which can be life-threatening if left untreated. It also draws attention to the increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysms in patients with cardiovascular ailments and emphasizes the need for a clinical vigilance in elderly patients presenting with unexplained abdominal pain.   (Keywords: Abdominal aortic aneurysm  Aneurysm rupture  Hypertension  Coronary artery disease  Elderly  Case report)

Patient's Initials: R.S.  Date: November 1  2022  Demographics:  Age: 75 years old Sex: Male Race/Socioeconomic Status: Caucasian/Middle class Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaints: The patient initially presented with mild to moderate pain in the lower back and stomach area that he reported as a pulsing feeling. The pain occurs intermittently  spanning over a few weeks. The patient also mentioned episodes of sudden severe sharp pain in the same region that had started only in the past 2-3 days.   Past Medical History: The patient has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes a day  quit smoking five years ago. Past medical history includes hypertension controlled with lisinopril  hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin  body mass index (BMI) of 29 (indicating overweight)  and a family history of AAA (abdominal aortic aneurysm) and stroke in his father.  Physical Examination: On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was noticed. Vital signs were stable except for a mildly elevated blood pressure read of 145/90 mmHg. The patient appeared in mild distress due to discomfort in his stomach area.  Investigations: Ultrasound of abdomen confirmed an AAA  revealing a 5.6 cm aneurysm in the infra-renal aorta. An ECG was performed which showed normal sinus rhythm. Further laboratory investigations revealed raised inflammatory markers with C-reactive protein at 10mg/L and normal renal function tests.  Diagnosis: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  based on the above findings and supported by imaging.  Plan: Although there was no imminent sign of rupture  given the size and his symptomatic presentation  vascular surgery was immediately consulted for potential repair. The patient was admitted to the vascular surgery unit for monitoring and to prepare for an open or endovascular aneurysm repair per the surgeon's decision. We also adjusted the patient's hypertension medication and pain management to increase comfort and reduce risk factors.  This case reflects the importance of considering AAA in older patients  especially those with a history of smoking and hypertension  presenting with nonspecific abdominal or back pain. Early diagnosis and apt management are crucial due to the high mortality rate associated with ruptured AAA.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 62-year-old Male Patient with History of Hypertension  Case Description:  Patient Information: A 62-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department (ED) of our hospital with sudden onset  severe abdominal pain radiating to the back.  Clinical findings: The patient described his pain as tearing and was sweating profusely on arrival. His blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg and pulse rate 110 bpm. His abdominal examination revealed marked tenderness and a palpable pulsatile mass.  Prior Medical History: The patient's medical records indicated high blood pressure (hypertension) for approximately 10 years  fairly controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He was also a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago. He had no known allergies and no family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Diagnostic Assessment: Due to the physical examination and past history  an emergent ultrasound was performed  which revealed a large 7 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. An emergent computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the findings and indicated that the aneurysm had ruptured.  Therapeutic Intervention: The on-call vascular surgeon was immediately notified and the patient underwent emergent open surgical repair of the ruptured AAA. The intraoperative period was complicated by significant blood loss  requiring multiple units of packed red blood cells.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Postoperatively  the patient's blood pressure improved to 120/80 mmHg and his pain was considerably diminished. His postoperative course was complicated by an episode of pneumonia  which was treated with antibiotics. After a prolonged hospitalization of 21 days  the patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up after 6 weeks showed a healing surgical wound and improved overall health.  Reflection: This case underlines the importance of considering ruptured AAA in older patients with a history of hypertension who present with severe abdominal pain. Early recognition and rapid vascular surgical intervention is critical to reduce the high mortality associated with rupture.  Patient Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Long-standing Undetected Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 62-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction:   Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) refers to the localized enlargement of the abdominal aorta exceeding the normal diameter by more than 50 percent. It is generally asymptomatic until it ruptures  leading to high mortality rates.  Case Presentation:   A 62-year-old Caucasian man presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain. The patient was a life-long smoker and a known sufferer of hypertension  high cholesterol levels and obesity. He also had a family history of AAA  where his father had died of a ruptured AAA.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the patient showed signs of severe pain and discomfort. His blood pressure was noted as 160/100 mmHg and his heart rate was 95 beats per minute. There was marked pulsatile mass in the epigastric region. Significant tenderness had been observed in the bilateral renal angle area. Initial laboratory test results showed a high C-reactive protein  slightly elevated white blood cell count and abnormal coagulation profiles.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  An urgent abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a large AAA measuring 7 cm in maximum diameter. A CT angiography was also done which revealed a large infrarenal AAA with signs of impending rupture.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was urgently transferred to the vascular surgical unit and underwent an emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Post-surgery  the patient’s blood pressure and heart rate were continuously monitored. A follow-up CT angiography was conducted after three days  revealing no endoleak and confirming the success of the intervention.  Follow-up and Outcome:  On follow-up four weeks later  the patient reported resolution of the abdominal pain. He had stopped smoking and had been on regular follow-ups with a cardiologist to manage his hypertension and high cholesterol levels. The cardiovascular team stressed on lifestyle modification which includes a healthy balanced diet  regular exercises  and weight management.   Take-Home Messages:  Undiagnosed AAA carries a high risk of rupture and subsequent mortality. Early detection and intervention can be life-saving. This case emphasizes the importance of increased awareness and regular screening for AAA  especially amongst high-risk individuals. Stringent control of cardiovascular risk factors  family history  and smoking cessation also play a crucial role in preventing the development and progression of AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 60-Year-Old Male   Introduction:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male presenting with significant lower abdominal and back pain. Previous health history includes hypertension  high cholesterol and a 30-year history of smoking.  Case Presentation:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden pain in the lower abdominal region and lower back. The patient described the pain as a 10/10 on severity scale  extending from back to his abdomen. Further noting periodic episodes of faintness and feeling of an abnormal heartbeat or heart pounding. There was no documented history of injury or trauma to the area.   Physical assessment revealed a palpable and pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Blood pressure was observed to be 180/100 mm Hg  a high level consistent with the patient’s known hypertension. The patient had a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and was obviously distressed. Further investigation revealed a marfanoid habitus  hinting potential for genetic connective tissue disorders.  Investigation:  Initial suspicion of aortic aneurysm was confirmed via computed tomography angiography (CTA) which highlighted an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of approximately 9 cm. Additionally  CTA showed no signs of rupture or an active leak  but the size and symptomatic presentation suggested a higher likelihood of rupture within the next few months if left untreated. Routine Blood tests revealed anemia and elevated leukocytes  indicating possible slow ongoing bleed and an immune response.   Management and Outcome:  The patient was promptly scheduled for a surgical operation and underwent successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Postoperative care included blood pressure and heart rate monitoring  pain control and wound care. The patient was also prescribed a statin to manage his cholesterol and an anti-hypertensive medication for his blood pressure  in addition to advice regarding smoking cessation.  One-month follow up found the patient recovering well  with relief from the abdominal pain  stable vital signs  and significant lifestyle changes like quitting smoking.  Discussion:  The present case underscores the importance of considering an AAA in older patients presenting with abdominal or back pain  hypertension  high cholesterol  and a smoking history. Successful outcome was facilitated by a timely diagnosis and surgery  coupled with ongoing medication management and lifestyle modifications.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-old Male with a History of Smoking and Hypertension  Case Report:  Patient Description:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a height of 180cm and weight 86kg (BMI – 26.5). He has been a smoker for over 40 years and was previously diagnosed with hypertension but has inconsistent compliance to taking his antihypertensive medications. The patient lives a sedentary lifestyle and has a family history of cardiac diseases. He is a retired engineer and is currently living with his wife.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient was brought to the hospital by his wife when he began experiencing sudden  severe  and continuous abdominal pain climbing up to his back. He also complained of dizziness and shortness of breath.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  he appeared pale and sweaty with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. His blood pressure was initially 160/90 mmHg and later dropped to 90/50mmHg. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsating mass and tenderness in the epigastric region.   Diagnostic Assessment:  The diagnosis was confirmed by an emergent abdominal ultrasound which revealed a 6.5 cm infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm with evidence suggesting impending rupture. His laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count and D-dimer levels  indicating an inflammatory process and coagulation activation respectively.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Due to suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  the patient was immediately taken to the operating room where a midline laparotomy was performed. The presence of intraabdominal blood confirmed the rupture and a synthetic graft was successfully placed to replace the aneurysmal aorta.   Postoperative Course:  Postoperatively  the patient was managed in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for close monitoring. His recovery was uneventful and he was discharged on the 14th postoperative day with prescriptions for antihypertensive medications and cholesterol-lowering drugs.   Follow-Up:  At the follow-up visit 6 weeks after discharge  the patient showed no signs of complications. He was strongly advised to quit smoking  to adhere to his medications regularly  and to undergo lifestyle modifications to control his blood pressure and weight. Regular check-ups with ultrasound scans every six months to monitor the graft were also scheduled.
