Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and prompt surgical intervention in the management of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. It also highlights the significance of effective patient counselling and implementing preventive measures to avoid complications associated with high-risk personal habits and poorly managed chronic conditions.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information A 66-year-old Caucasian male patient  retired mechanic  presented to the outpatient office with complaints of an unusual pulsating sensation in his abdomen for the past several weeks.  Medical History The patient has a recorded history of hypertension diagnosed 15 years prior and hyperlipidemia diagnosed 6 years prior — both conditions are managed with medications (amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia). Apart from these  there is no history of any other chronic illness.  He was a smoker for approximately 40 years (30 cigarettes per day) but quit about two years ago. His family history is also significant with his father passing away at the age of 70 due to a ruptured AAA.  Clinical Findings On physical examination  an abdominal mass was palpable midline below the xiphoid process that was pulsatile with strong expansile character. The mass was non-tender  and Bowel sounds were normal.   Diagnostic Assessment The patient was immediately sent for ultrasonography followed by CT angiogram due to high suspicion of an AAA based on history and physical examination. The CT angiogram confirmed the diagnosis and revealed an infrarenal AAA measuring 5.5 cm in diameter.   Therapeutic Interventions Given the size of the aneurysm  its rapid growth  and the patient's history and risk factors  surgical intervention was recommended. After discussing the options  the patient agreed and was scheduled for an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure.   Follow up and Outcomes The surgery was successful without any complications. Postoperative imaging showed successful exclusion of the AAA. The patient was discharged with instructions to take his prescribed medications and the importance of adhering to regular follow-up care including  routine imaging to monitor the aneurysm and general cardiovascular risk factor management.   Relevant Information This case highlights the importance of conducting thorough physical examinations and the significance of early detection of AAA. Given their asymptomatic nature  it's imperative that physicians recognize the potential signs of AAA  particularly in patients with multiple risk factors like our patient.   This case also underscores the importance of family history as an influential risk factor for the development of AAA. It allows healthcare providers to individualize preventative strategies  potentially preventing serious consequences.

Patient Case Report  Introduction  This case report discusses the management of a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a diagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Patient Information  The patient is a retired auto mechanic. His past medical history includes hypertension and a 20-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes per day  from which he quit 7 years ago. His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease; his father passed away at 62 following a myocardial infarction. He is currently on antihypertensive medication  specifically Beta-adrenergic blocking agents  and he follows a balanced diet. He has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings   The patient initially reported to the clinic with complaints of nonspecific lower abdominal and lower back discomfort that he had been experiencing for the past 3 weeks. He initially dismissed these discomforts as normal signs of aging. However  when the pain became intense and constant over time  he decided to seek medical attention.  Diagnostic Assessment   Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the patient's abdomen. Furthermore  an abdominal ultrasound was conducted which revealed a 5.8 cm fusiform aneurysm in the infrarenal portion of the abdominal aorta  consistent with an AAA. No echolucent area was found suggestive of free rupturing. There were no clinical indications of renal or visceral ischemia.  Therapeutic Intervention  Based on the size of the aneurysm and the patient's overall health status  surgical management was decided upon. An open surgical repair was performed which involved clamping the aorta  opening the aneurysm  and suturing in a synthetic graft to replace the diseased portion of the aorta. The surgery was successful and without complications.   Follow-up and Outcomes  Postoperatively  the patient had an uneventful course and was discharged on the 10th day after surgery. The patient was advised to stop smoking entirely and to adhere to the prescribed medication regimen to control his blood pressure. Regular follow-up every six months was recommended to monitor the graft and the patient's overall vascular health.  Patient Perspective  The patient expressed gratitude for the detection and treatment of the aneurysm  stating that he did not realize the seriousness of the condition until it was explained to him by the medical team. He emphasized his commitment to the postoperative care plan in hopes of preventing further vascular complications.  Informed Consent  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.  Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of early detection and management of AAA  particularly in patients with a history of hypertension and smoking  as these are known risk factors. The case already presented as a large aneurysm  which could have been life-threatening if not promptly treated. Regular physical examination and screening in at-risk populations can potentially lead to early detection and better outcomes for AAA patients.

Title: Case Report: An Incidence of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient   Introduction: This case report explores a rare scenario in which an abdominal aortic aneurysm was incidentally discovered in a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of prior health complications.  Patient Presentation: The patient  Mr. A  was presented at the clinic complaining about persistent lower back pain  which had gradually become severe over three weeks. He also complained about episodic abdominal discomfort. Prior to this  the patient had no apparent signs of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Medical History: Mr. A is a former smoker and has a long history of hypertension  which has been managed with regular medication. He also has Type II diabetes for the past 15 years and peripheral artery disease (PAD). Mr. A had no history of cardiovascular disease but his father had cirrhosis of the liver and died of aneurysm rupture at 70.   Examination and Tests: On examination  his vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg. On palpation  there was a pulsating mass in the mid-abdominal region  which raised suspicion for an AAA. His lab results revealed slightly elevated blood sugar levels and otherwise normal CBC  lipid profile  renal and liver function tests. An ensuing ultrasound and abdominal Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) confirmed a presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal AAA.  Management: Patient was promptly referred to vascular surgery for potential endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) to avoid the risk of rupture. After counseling about the benefits and risks of the procedure  the patient agreed to have EVAR.   Outcomes and Follow-up: The intervention was successful and the patient reported a dramatic decrease in lower back pain and abdominal discomfort. He was discharged after five days. Follow-up after four weeks showed a stable state of the aneurysm (4.9cm). The patient was advised a healthy lifestyle  regular exercise  tobacco-alcohol cessation  medication adherence  and to have regular check-ups.  Discussion: This case illustrates the importance of considering a diagnosis of AAA for older patients presenting with unexplained lower back or abdominal pain. Patient's advanced age  smoking history  hypertension  PAD  and family history of AAA contributed to the high index of suspicion. Early diagnosis and prompt management were crucial to prevent fatal complications.  Conclusion: Although AAA is often asymptomatic until rupture  careful examination  knowledge of risk factors  and a high index of suspicion  can lead to early diagnosis and successful management. Health professionals should also emphasize the importance of lifestyle modifications in controlling the risk factors associated with the disease.

Patient Details: Name: Anonymous Age: 68 years Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Problem: The patient was referred to the Emergency Department because of persistent abdominal and back pain for a last couple of weeks. The pain was noticed to be intense especially after having meals. He also reported loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  which is well-managed through anti-hypertensive medication. He has a 30-year history of smoking  about one pack per day  although he quit 5 years ago. In one of the previous routine check-ups 3 years ago  the patient was identified with early signs of atherosclerosis. He also has hyperlipidemia which is managed with statins. There is no history of any surgery. His father died due to a heart attack at the age of 58.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  a prominent pulsating mass was noticed in the abdomen. The physical examination showed his blood pressure to be 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate 78/min  respiratory rate 18/min  and body temperature 37.2 °C. A cardiovascular exam revealed no other abnormalities. All other systemic examinations were found to be normal.  Investigations: Abdominal ultrasonography was ordered which revealed a large aneurysm in the abdominal aorta. This result prompted the prescription of a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan. This confirmed the abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  measuring approximately 6.5cm in diameter. There was no sign of rupture or leakage  but the size suggested that the risk was high.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical history  physical examination  and investigations  the patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment: Given the size of the aneurysm  surgical repair was indicated. The patient was treated with an endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) procedure successfully. His systolic blood pressure was gradually brought down under 130 mmHg over a couple of days to reduce the pressure on the aorta.  Patient Education & Follow-Up: The patient was educated about the relationship of abdominal aortic aneurysm with hypertension  lifestyle  and diet. A follow-up was scheduled for two weeks later for wound check and to manage hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has also been referred for a smoking cessation program. Long term  he will have regular follow-ups to monitor for any potential complications related to the EVAR and the aneurysm.  In conclusion  this patient’s condition was successfully managed but he would require long-term follow-up due to the nature of his medical conditions and potential complications related to his AAA and EVAR.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 67-Year-Old Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of significant and persistent abdominal pain for the past week. The patient is a non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer  maintains a normal body mass index (BMI)  and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He resides with his spouse in an urban setting and is a retired military officer. His educational level is postgraduate.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reports central abdominal pain  which he describes as constant  with a heavy  throbbing intensity that does not relieve with rest. He also mentions a sensation of fullness and pressure in the abdominal area.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are currently well managed with medication (Rampiril 5mg daily for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia). His surgical history includes a cholecystectomy performed twenty years ago. The patient reports no known allergies. His father had a history of an aortic aneurysm and passed away at 72. The patient's mother is alive and well with hypertension being her only known medical problem.  Clinical Findings: During physical examination  an expansile mass was palpable in the mid-to-lower abdomen. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 140/90 mmHg  heart rate was normal at 72 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute  temperature was 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation was 97% while inhaling room air.  Diagnostic Assessment: An abdominal ultrasound was performed  demonstrating an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm of 5.6cm  confirming the suspected diagnosis. Full blood count  U&E  coagulation  and liver function tests returned within normal range. Lipid profile was abnormal with elevated total cholesterol  LDL  and triglycerides. Echocardiography was done to evaluate cardiac function  showing normal left ventricular ejection fraction with no valve disease.  Therapeutic Intervention: Given the size of his aneurysm  the patient was given an urgent referral to vascular surgery. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was planned.  Follow Up: The patient was scheduled for a follow up two weeks post-operation. He was advised to continue his medications for blood pressure and cholesterol  maintain a low-fat diet  regular exercise  and regular follow-up visits to monitor aneurysm size.  Conclusion: This patient's abdominal aortic aneurysm was likely influenced by his personal history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  as well as his family history of aneurysm disease. This case underlines the importance of closely monitoring patients with risk factors for timely intervention before the aneurysm ruptures  thereby reducing the risk of mortality.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old male  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency room with a complaint of sudden  intense lower abdominal and back pain. The pain was described as a severe tearing pain  persistent  and not relieved with any position change or over-the-counter medications. The patient also reported a mild nausea and light-headedness. The patient has a smoking history of thirty years and moderate alcohol intake. He is retired and lives alone.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  and has been taking antihypertensive medications. He also has hyperlipidemia  managed on statins. The patient has also been diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to his long history of smoking. No known allergies were reported. There was no previous history of any abdominal surgeries  but he had an appendectomy at the age of 25. The patient had been non-compliant with his annual check-ups and had no recent diagnostic studies.  Physical Examination and Diagnostic Assessment:  Upon presentation  the patient's blood pressure was 170/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 120/min  respiratory rate was 22/min  and the temperature was 98.6 F. The physical examination revealed a markedly tender and pulsating abdominal mass. An abdominal ultrasound revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 7.6 cm in greatest diameter. An emergent computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the ruptured AAA with evidence of hematoma in the retroperitoneal space.   Management and Outcome: The patient was stabilized with intravenous fluids and pain management. He underwent emergent open surgical repair of the ruptured AAA with a Dacron tube graft. Post-operatively  he was transferred to the intensive care unit for close monitoring of vital signs and neurological status. His postoperative course was uneventful  although marked by several episodes of hypertension  adequately managed with medication adjustments. The patient was discharged home on post-operative day 10 with prescriptions for antihypertensive and statin therapy  appropriate follow-up appointments  and instructions to cease smoking and limit alcohol consumption.    Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of regular examinations in high-risk individuals such as smokers with hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The timely diagnosis and intervention for abdominal aortic aneurysm are critical in preventing life-threatening consequences of rupture. Medical practitioners must contrive to provide preventative education and vigilant follow-up care for individuals at risk.

Patient Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with increased body mass index (BMI) of 29.7 kg/m2 indicative of overweight stature. He is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history but reports quitting approximately 10 years ago. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban area.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented at the emergency department with a two-day history of sudden onset  severe pain in the lower back and lower abdomen. The pain was constant  non-radiating  and did not alleviate with rest. He had no associated chest pain  dyspnea  palpitations  or lower limb weakness. He also reported mild dizziness but denied any history of syncope or presyncope  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  which has been well controlled with a combination therapy of an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and thiazide diuretic  and moderate hyperlipidemia controlled with statin therapy. He also has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from his smoking years but has managed with inhaler therapy without significant exacerbations.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination showed a distended abdomen with a palpable pulsatile mass but without bruit over the area. The patient had normal blood pressure during his initial evaluation  and his pulse was regular. Abdominal ultrasound confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.7 cm in its maximal diameter.  Diagnosis and Intervention: The patient was immediately referred for emergent vascular surgery evaluation due to the size and symptomatic nature of his aneurysm. His angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors were held until surgical consultation to prevent any possible hypotensive events. The patient underwent a successful endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) procedure without complications.  Follow-up and Outcome: Post-surgery  the patient remained stable with no signs of endoleak on post-operative imaging. He was discharged home with follow-up vascular clinic appointments. He was advised on maintaining a low-fat diet to manage his hyperlipidemia and regular aerobic exercise to maintain his blood pressure. Smoking cessation was reinforced  along with the need for an annual ultrasound to monitor the graft.  Conclusion: While this patient's abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was incidentally found secondary to his presentation for lower back pain  it underlines the significance of considering AAA in patients with pertinent risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  older age demographic  male gender  and a history of vascular disease. It also reinforces the importance of appropriate and timely intervention in the treatment of large or symptomatic AAAs to prevent rupture and associated high mortality rate.

Patient Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male. He weighs approximately 82 kg and is 185cm tall. Occupation is a retired automobile engineer. Currently lives with his wife and leads a quiet and normally healthy life. He is a former smoker of 35 years having quit 10 years prior to presentation. He consumes alcohol moderately and has no history of substance abuse. The patient's family history reveals that his father died of stroke at the age of 76 and his mother suffered from diabetes but had no cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History: The patient does not have a history of any chronic illnesses such as diabetes  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia. Also  he has never undergone surgery before. His last known complete routine check-up done 2 years ago revealed no abnormalities.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient came into the hospital complaining of abdominal and lower back pain that has lasted for three days. The pain was described as moderate  dull  and intermittent. He also reported having managed a few episodes of nausea over the duration of his pain with no episodes of vomiting or diarrhea. He denied noticing any blood in the stool or dark tarry feces. Additionally  there was no report of weight loss  night sweats  loss of appetite  fever or changes in urinary output.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  there was evidence of a pulsatile mass in the middle and upper part of the abdomen. No signs of lower limb ischemia were found. Blood pressure measurement yielded a reading of 135/80 mmHg in his left arm and 132/78 mmHg in his right arm. Serum creatinine was 0.9mg/dL  BUN 15mg/dL  total cholesterol 195mg/dL  LDL 120mg/dL  HDL 55mg/dL and triglyceride 110mg/dL. Other leucocytes  platelets and electrolytes were all normal.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Based on the assessment of the symptoms and physical examination findings  a high suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made. Further evaluation was ordered using computed tomographic angiography (CTA). This confirmed the initial diagnostic suspicion  revealing a fusiform aneurysm measuring 5.3cm in the infrarenal section of the abdominal aorta.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: The size and symptomatic presentation of the aneurysm rendered it a surgical case. Therefore  the patient is planned for an elective infrarenal aortic aneurysm repair. The surgical team was consulted and consent for surgery was obtained from the patient and his wife. The patient will be followed up after surgical and post-surgical intervention.  Follow Up and Outcomes: The patient will have a post-operative visit with the surgeon. Follow-up appointments are also scheduled for 3  6  and 12 months to check the status of the repair and o check for any potential risk of reoccurrence.  Patient Perspectives: The patient and his wife expressed worry about the emergent nature of the presentation and the need for surgery. However  they were reassured that early detection and timely intervention provide the best prognosis for AAA. They were also educated about the importance of a follow-up visit after surgery.    Informed Consent: Written and verbal consent to document and share this case (ensuring patient anonymity) has been taken from the patient and his wife.   This case underlines the importance of comprehensive physical examination in older patients presenting with non-specific abdominal pain. AAA remains a challenging clinical diagnosis and high index of suspicion is necessary for early detection and intervention. This cases also emphasizes the importance of follow up visits in prognosticating the disease course.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. Anthony Brown is a 70-years-old Caucasian male  a retired marine engineer residing in Chicago  Illinois. He has presented with complains of sudden intense abdominal pain for two days. The patient is married  with a 40-year history of smoking.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and elevated cholesterol levels. He has been under antihypertensive treatment (Lisinopril 20mg daily)  oral hypoglycemic (Metformin 500mg BID)  and a statin (Atorvastatin 20mg daily) for the past 15 years. The patient reported having undergone an appendectomy when he was 28 with no other surgical history. He drinks alcohol socially and smoked about one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years  although he ceased smoking five years ago.  Present Complaint and Investigation: On physical examination  the patient presented with hypertension (BP= 160/90 mmHg) and tachycardia (HR= 110 bpm). He complained of a sharp  sudden lower abdominal and back pain which was not relieved with ordinary analgesics. His abdomen was tender with a noticed pulsating mass. Given the suspected diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  he was immediately sent for an abdominal ultrasound which revealed a 7cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment: Due to the size of the aneurysm and symptoms  emergent surgical intervention was planned. He underwent a successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Post-operative follow-up was uneventful. He was given instructions for strict blood pressure control  compliance with medication  smoking cessation counseling was reinforced and he was prescribed analgesic for pain control.   Follow Up and Outcome: Mr. Brown was scheduled for regular follow-up every 6 months for the first year and then shifted to annual follow-ups with abdominal ultrasounds to monitor for any leaks or enlargements of the graft. The patient was also scheduled for regular consultations with cardiology and endocrinology for management of his hypertension  elevated cholesterol  and diabetes.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of recognizing the symptoms of AAA in a higher-risk patient with a history of long-term smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  which allowed for appropriate and timely surgical intervention with a positive outcome.  The timely referral for ultrasound investigation gave us a solid diagnosis  which further led to prompt surgical intervention. Regular follow-ups will ensure any potential complications are intercepted and managed promptly. It also highlights the need for strict blood pressure control  compliance with medication  smoking cessation  and regular check-ups in the management of AAA.

Patient Information  Mr. X is a 67-year-old male of Caucasian descent presented to the emergency department with severe  sharp  and sudden onset abdominal pain in the center that radiates to his back. He has a history of high blood pressure  tobacco consumption (around 40 pack-years)  and moderate alcohol drinking habits. The patient lives alone and is engaged in light physical labor work post-retirement. He doesn't have any known allergies but is on medication for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus under control for the past five years.  Clinical Findings  On physical examination  the patient appeared pale and diaphoretic but was in no apparent distress. He was conscious  oriented with a pulse rate of 100 beats/minute  blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile midline mass of about 5 cm in diameter with epigastric tenderness but no signs of discoloration or erythema.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment  Laboratory tests including complete blood count  kidney function  liver function  and electrolytes were within normal limits except higher levels of white blood cells suggesting possible infection. The duplex ultrasound helped to locate the aneurysm and establish its size  revealing a large infrarenal aortic aneurysm of 7.9 cm in diameter with signs of rupture. Contrast CT angiography further confirmed these findings and indicated the need for immediate surgery given the size and the presence of pain  which may indicate impending rupture.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment  An emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure was performed  which involved placing a stent graft within the aneurysm to provide a permanent alternative conduit for blood flow  excluding the aneurysmal sac from blood pressure  thereby preventing rupture. The surgery was successful with no signs of endoleak or graft infection.  Follow-up and Current status  The patient was discharged after a week in a stable condition with advice to completely quit smoking and limit alcohol consumption  and monitoring his condition through regular follow-up visits. Encouraged to consistently monitor his blood pressure and take his diabetic and hypertension medications regularly. He was also educated about the signs of aneurysm complications like sudden severe pain  fainting  rapid heartbeat  or dizziness  and to immediately seek medical care if any such symptoms arise. On his six-month follow-up appointment  he has reported no complications  his hygiene and dietary adjustments were appreciable  and follow-up imaging showed no signs of an aneurysm.  Conclusion  The case illustrates the importance of considering abdominal aortic aneurysm in older patients presenting with a pulsatile midline mass and risk factors such as smoking and hypertension. Early diagnosis and intervention can save lives especially in the case of an asymptomatic or rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further  it emphasizes the need for post-discharge health lifestyle education in these patients.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and longstanding cigarette smoking. He has been a heavy smoker for approximately 50 years  with a pack of cigarettes per day. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban area.   Chief Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal pain  described as a tearing sensation radiating to his lower back. The pain was constant  coming suddenly without any precipitating factors.  Past Medical History:  Aside from hypertension and hyperlipidemia  the patient also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is controlled with metformin. He was diagnosed with these conditions approximately ten years ago. He also shared that he had appendectomy when he was 25 years old  however  no other surgeries were reported.  Family History:  His father died at age 58 from a myocardial infarction and his mother had a stroke at age 81.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient was awake  alert  and oriented but in clear distress due to pain. His vitals reported were pulse 98 beats per minute  blood pressure 168/92 mm Hg  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  and temperature 37.2 degrees Celsius. Abdominal palpation revealed a pulsatile mass  and auscultation reported a bruit over the mass.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Considering the patient's clinical history and symptoms  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was highly suspected. A Computed Tomography angiogram (CTA) was immediately performed  which confirmed the diagnosis of a 6.5 cm infrarenal AAA.   Treatment Plan:  In light of the patient’s large  symptomatic AAA  an urgent vascular surgical consult was made. The decision was made to proceed with an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  upon the consent of the patient and his wife.   Follow-up:  Post-EVAR  the patient's recovery was uneventful. He was encouraged to quit smoking and adhere to his medications controlling hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Regular outpatient follow-ups were arranged to monitor his condition.   Discussion:  This case reminds the medical community of the importance of maintaining a strong clinical suspicion for AAA in older  male patients with significant cardiovascular risk factors who present with acute onset abdominal or back pain. Early recognition and treatment are critical given the high morbidity and mortality rates associated with ruptured AAAs.  Contributors:  All members of the multi-disciplinary medical team involved in the case contributed to the clinical data and reviewing the final case report.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information  The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian male  hailing from a rural area in Colorado. He is a retired construction worker  living with his daughter since his wife passed away seven years ago. He has a history of heavy smoking upto 40 pack years  but quit smoking 10 years ago.  History of Present Illness  The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden severe pain in his lower back that had begun about 12 hours prior. The pain did not radiate but was constant and worsened upon movement. He also reported symptoms of light-headedness and nausea  but denied chest pain  shortness of breath  loss of consciousness  or bowel and bladder complaints.  Past Medical History  The patient’s past medical history includes hypertension that was diagnosed around 20 years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 15 years ago. He has been diligent about his medications and regular check-ups concerning these conditions. Additionally  he has a history of dyslipidemia and peripheral artery disease. No previous surgeries are noted in his medical record.  Physical Examination  On examination  his blood pressure was found to be low (90/60 mmHg)  heart rate slightly elevated (95 beats per minute)  and all other vital signs were within normal ranges. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region with tenderness upon palpation.  Diagnostic Assessment  Considering the history and physical examination  a preliminary assessment of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made  and urgent abdominal ultrasound followed by a CT angiogram were performed. These confirmed the presence of a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with evidence of impending rupture.   Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was swiftly shifted to the operating room for an emergency open surgical repair of the AAA. A Dacron graft was used to repair the damaged aorta. His unstable hemodynamics throughout the procedure were managed by the Anesthesiology team.  Follow Up and Outcomes   The patient’s post-operative period was uneventful and he made a steady recovery. He was discharged 10 days later with advice on lifestyle modifications  a renewed emphasis on his hypertension  diabetes  and lipid control  and was scheduled to follow up after 30 days for a repeat ultrasound to assess graft patency. On his subsequent visits  the graft was found to be patent and the patient remained clinically stable.  Informed consent: Patient’s written and informed consent has been obtained for the publication of this case report.   Patient Perspective: The patient was deeply appreciative of the comprehensive care he received. He reported a significant improvement in his quality of life and expressed gratitude towards the medical teams involved in his treatment.

Patient Case Report: Case No. 001-AA  Patient Profile: - Name: Not disclosed (as per patient confidentiality policy); herein referred to as ""Patient X"" - Gender: Male - Age: 65 Years - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired engineer   Medical History: Patient X has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both being managed with medication for the past decade. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  quitting approximately 15 years ago. There is a recorded family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction in his 60s and his oldest brother undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery in his 70s.  Presenting Symptoms: Patient X initially presented to the clinic with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain  lower back pain  and unintentional weight loss over the past three months. He reported a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. There was no nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel movements.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a notable pulsating abdominal mass was palpated. The patient’s blood pressure was relatively stable at 140/88 mmHg and heart rate of 75 beats per minute.  Diagnostics: A subsequent ultrasound study confirmed a 7.8 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). There was no apparent sign of rupture or dissection. Cardiac function was also evaluated via ECG and echocardiogram with no significant abnormalities noted.  Treatment and Progress: After discussions with the patient regarding the risks and benefits  Patient X elected to undergo an elective open repair of his AAA. The surgery was successful and the patient was monitored postoperatively in the intensive care unit for a day. He recovered well and was discharged home on the third post-operative day with appropriate follow-up care instructions.  The patient has since reported to the clinic for regular follow-up and has shown signs of good recovery while maintaining his usual medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His latest ultrasound follow-ups have verified the successful repair of the aneurysm with no sign of recurrence or complication.  In conclusion  due to the large size of his AAA and symptoms  Patient X underwent successful surgical intervention which has likely decreased his risk of future aneurysm-related complications such as rupture. It is an indication of the importance of early detection and proactive management of abdominal aortic aneurysms particularly in high-risk patients.

Title: Emergent Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-Year-Old Non-Smoking Male with a History of Hypertension  Case Report:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who presented with severe  persistent abdominal pain. He has no history of smoking or diabetes but has chronic hypertension since age 50. He does not have any familial history of cardiovascular diseases  but his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He denied substance use  over-the-counter medication use  or having any allergies. The patient works as a school teacher and is sedentary with minimal physical activities.  The initial evaluation revealed a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg while the patient's regular medication Lisinopril was ineffective in controlling the systolic blood pressure below 140 mmHg. No significant weight loss  fever  or illicit drug use was noted.  Physical examination identified a pulsatile abdominal mass in the periumbilical region which was suspicious of an aneurysm. The patient appeared to be distressed from the continuous systemic pain. Other system examinations were unremarkable.  Laboratory tests showed mild leukocytosis  but his kidney function  liver enzymes  and electrolytes were all within normal limits. Lipid profile results showed borderline-high LDL levels.  A CT angiogram of the abdomen revealed a fusiform aneurysm located in the infra-renal area of the abdominal aorta with a maximum diameter of 6.5 cm  extending to both iliac arteries. The Aortic aneurysm was seen to be partially thrombosed and was accompanied by signs of rupture. No other visceral or peripheral vascular diseases were identified.  Given the size and clinical suspicion of impending rupture mirrored in patient's excruciating pain  vascular surgery was consulted  and an emergent open repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm was advised and performed. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate or post-operative complications.  This case underscores the importance of regular follow-ups  diligent monitoring of medication effects  and high suspicion for AAA in hypertensive patients and those with family histories of AAA. The patient's severe uncontrollable hypertension could have been a clue towards an undiagnosed AAA. The case reflects the practice of high clinical suspicion in patients with high-risk factors  which could potentially lead to early diagnosis and management  thereby decreasing mortality and morbidity associated with ruptured AAA.  Keywords: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Hypertension  Non-smoking  Elderly Male  Case Report.

Case Report  Patient Information  A 67-year-old Caucasian male residing in suburban Miami  Florida presented with consistent abdominal discomfort and lower back pain over a period of three weeks. The patient works as a professor in a local university  is a 30-year smoking pack-year  drinks light-to-moderate alcohol  and has a BMI of 27.8 classified as overweight. The patient also reported intermittent episodes of pulse sensation in the abdomen. The family history suggested that the father passed away at the age of 72 due to an unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Past Medical History  The patient has a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus controlled by lifestyle modifications and oral medication. His other medical history included hyperlipidemia treated with statin therapy. The patient also mentioned a history of hypertension for the past 13 years well-regulated on Lisinopril. There is no history of surgeries  no known allergies to drugs  and no noted blood dyscrasias.   Clinical Presentation  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was felt in the abdomen with slight tenderness. No signs of peritonitis were evident. Cardiovascular examination reveals a blood pressure of 140/80mmHg with normal rhythmic heart sounds. Respiratory and neurological examinations were unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment  A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) angiogram was ordered based on the clinical findings which revealed an infrarenal AAA  the largest diameter was approximately 5.2cm. There was no evidence of rupture or any signs of an impending rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention  Based on the evidence of a sizable aneurysm  the patient was referred to a vascular surgeon. Given the associated risk factors  the patient was counseled regarding the surgical procedures for AAA repair  namely open surgical repair (OSR) and endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). After presenting more information and risks associated with each procedure  the patient decided upon EVAR.    Follow-up and Outcomes  The patient responded well to the procedure with no perioperative complications. He was discharged three days post-operation with instructions on wound care  gradual increase in activities  symptoms to watch for  and a follow-up plan. He was also advised on lifestyle modification for risk factors control  primarily for smoking cessation and weight management. Regular follow-ups at 1 month  6 months  and annually were planned to monitor the patient's recovery and screen for any potential complications such as endoleak  aneurysm expansion or rupture.  Clinical Lesson Learned  This case underlines the importance of maintaining a high degree of suspicion for AAA in patients with relevant risk factors including smoking history  age  hypertension  and family history of AAA. Early identification and timely referral for surgical intervention can prevent life-threatening complications. Moreover  it emphasizes the pivotal role of primary healthcare providers in counseling  aiding decision-making for surgical intervention  and providing follow-up care.

Patient Description:  Mr. G.S. is a 65-year-old Caucasian male living in California. He is a former industrial worker who retired 15 years ago and has an extensive smoking history  having smoked a pack of cigarettes every day for the past 40 years. He lives with his wife in a suburb and does routine health check-ups. Mr. G.S. reports a family history of heart disease with both his father and grandfather passing away due to myocardial infarction.  Past Medical History:  He has been managing well-controlled Type II diabetes with Metformin for the last ten years. Additionally  he has a history of hypertension  which he controls with Lisinopril. His cholesterol levels have been relatively high  and he has been on Atorvastatin for the past five years.  Presenting Problem:  Mr. G.S. came to the emergency department with a sudden onset severe abdominal pain that began approximately five hours before presenting  describing it as a tearing sensation. He also reported that the pain seemed to radiate to his lower back.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the periumbilical area  indicating a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). His blood pressure was found to be 150/90 mm Hg  and his heart rate was 98 bpm. He appeared anxious and reported feeling faint.   Diagnostic Assessment:  An emergency abdominal ultrasound revealed a 7.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis and showed a large transverse aneurysm on the left side of the aorta with evidence of a leak  creating an urgency for surgical intervention.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Due to the large size of the aneurysm and the symptoms presented  an immediate endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was performed without complications. He was kept under intensive care postoperatively and closely monitored to ensure no additional leakage or complications from the surgery.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  Post-operative recovery went smoothly  with his abdominal pain significantly subsiding. Regular follow-up and monitoring of the aneurysm with repeated imaging confirmed success in preventing aneurysm rupture. Mr. G.S. was discharged on postoperative day 6 with close outpatient follow-up scheduled.  Lifestyle changes have been strongly advised  especially to quit smoking.  Learning Points:  Early diagnosis and intervention in the case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm can significantly reduce the risk of rupture and subsequent mortality. Risk factors such as smoking  high cholesterol  hypertension  and a family history of heart disease contributed to the condition and re-educating the patient on lifestyle management can drastically improve prognosis.

Title: Large Asymptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Patient: A Case Report  Demographics: The patient is an 86-year-old Caucasian male residing in the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. He is a retired manual labor worker  a widower living alone  and is currently assisted by a home nurse for his ADLs (Activity of Daily Living).   Presenting Complaints: The patient was initially presented for an annual general health check-up without any specific complaints. Clinical examination was generally unremarkable. Blood pressure was normal regime at 120/80 mmHg  temperature was 98.7⁰F  with a regular pulse rate and rhythm.  Previous Medical History: The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both well-controlled with medication. Furthermore  he is a former smoker  having quit smoking 15 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and has no known allergies.   Investigations and Findings: Routine blood test and urinalysis results were within normal limits. However  during an abdominal ultrasound performed due to an unrelated possible gallbladder disease  a large aneurysmal dilation of the abdominal aorta was incidentally discovered. Computed tomography (CT) confirmed the findings  revealing a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Considerations of Risk Factors: Given his medical history  age  and previous smoking habits  the patient can be considered as a high-risk patient for an aneurysmal rupture.   Management and Follow-up: Discussions regarding surgical interventions were had due to the size of the aneurysm. Aortic aneurysm repair surgery was deemed a valid option  however  due to the age and frailty of the patient  endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was the elected strategy. The patient was to be monitored closely for any signs of aneurysm expansion or rupture.  Outcome: The patient underwent endovascular aortic repair without immediate complications  and has since been on continuous follow up schedules. He was recommended to maintain his antihypertensive and anti-diabetic regimen and to abstain from smoking and alcohol.  This case emphasizes the importance of regular health check-ups in the geriatric population  especially those with a history of smoking and hypertension  for early diagnosis and management of asymptomatic large abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Male with History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia   INTRODUCTION: A case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in a 70-year old Caucasian male  presenting with lower back pain  is discussed here. The patient's medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  conditions largely identified as risk factors for AAA.  CASE PRESENTATION: A 70-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a primary complaint of severe lower back pain radiating to the abdomen for the past 48 hours. The patient also reported recent unexplained weight loss and a decrease in appetite.   His past medical history includes hypertension  well controlled with Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. He showed no previous record of major surgical procedures or any allergies. He does not consume alcohol and has no family history of aneurysms or heart diseases.   On physical examination  he appeared mildly distressed with a blood pressure of 166/98 mm Hg  heart rate of 102 beats per minute  and respiratory rate at 19 breaths per minute. The patient had a pulsatile abdominal mass approximately 5cm in diameter. His skin color appeared normal  and he had no visible skin lesions or injuries. His neurological examination was within normal limits with no signs of central or peripheral neurological deficits. Laboratory tests including complete blood count  renal function tests  and electrolyte panel were within normal limits.   Radiographic Assessment with an abdominal ultrasound showed a 5.3 cm infrarenal AAA with no signs of rupture. No other abnormalities were noted during the ultrasound assessment.   DISCUSSION: The combination of the patient's history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking habit  age  and the physical examination finding of a pulsatile abdominal mass led to the suspicion and subsequent diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm following an ultrasound scan.   The patient's high-risk features such as the size of aneurysm and severe symptoms led to the decision to undertake immediate surgical intervention. The patient underwent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR)  which was successful with no complications. He was then started on a beta-blocker therapy to control his blood pressure and reduce the risk of possible aortic rupture in the future.  He was advised to continue his current medications  quit smoking  adopt a healthy diet and engage in regular exercise. The patient was also scheduled for a regular follow-up appointment for monitoring and further management of his health condition.  CONCLUSION: This case enlightens the significance of recognizing risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and habitual smoking in the early detection and management of AAA. Timely detection of AAA and immediate surgical intervention can potentially save life. It also emphasizes the importance of lifestyle changes  regular monitoring and follow-up in the management of AAA.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Male  Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden and severe lower back pain on the left side  radiating to the groin  which started some hours ago. The patient described the pain intensity as 9/10. He reported no history of trauma or injury. He mentioned occasional dull abdominal pain in the past few months  which he had attributed to constipation and aging.   Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history of hypertension  for which he was taking antihypertensive medicines regularly with good compliance. His hypertension had been under control for the past ten years. He also had mild hyperlipidemia for which he was taking statins. His surgical history included an appendectomy about 30 years ago. He was not diabetic  and his family history was unremarkable  except for his father who died of a heart attack at the age of 75.   He was a non-smoker and drank alcohol occasionally. He had retired with no significant occupational exposure to any harmful substances. His body mass index (BMI) was 28  indicating that he was slightly overweight.   Clinical Findings: Upon examination  mild distention of the abdomen was observed. Upon palpation of the abdomen  a pulsatile mass was felt. Slight bruit was heard over the mass using a stethoscope. Blood pressure readings were consistently raised (160/85 mmHg) on both arms. The rest of the initial physical examinations are generally unremarkable.   Diagnosis:  The initial suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made on the basis of the above findings and the patient's age  gender  and history of hypertension. An urgent Abdominal ultrasound scan was done that revealed an AAA of approximately 5.7cm in diameter  confirming the diagnosis.  Treatment:  Considering his age  the size of the aneurysm  and potential rupture risk  the patient was emergently prepared for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The patient and his family were informed about the risks  benefits  and alternatives  and they consented for the intervention.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The procedure was successful with no observable complications. The patient was monitored in the hospital for several days post-operation  and his pain was adequately managed. He was discharged in a stable condition and advised to have regular follow-ups. At approximately three months' follow-up  a repeat ultrasound showed no signs of aneurysm expansion or leakage  indicating a good prognosis.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering AAA in older males with a history of hypertension presenting with severe back or abdominal pain. Early detection and prompt intervention can prevent possible catastrophic consequences.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired postal worker  living with his wife in a rural area. He is a non-smoker and has a body mass index (BMI) of 26. He consumes alcohol occasionally. Family history reveals his father succumbed to heart disease.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient reported a growing sense of discomfort in the mid-abdominal region  particularly in proximity to his umbilicus  for approximately eight days. Additionally  he also complained of minor difficulty in walking and intermittent lower back pain.  Prior Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with regular medications (Lisinopril 20 mg QD and Rosuvastatin 20 mg QD respectively). There is no documented history of diabetes  stroke  or any heart-related problems. Previous laboratory tests revealed an average blood pressure of 130/75 mmHg and a lipid panel in normal range due to regular statin therapy.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a pulsating mass in the periumbilical area. No signs of hemorrhage  scars  or rashes were observed on the abdomen. He has no hernia or abdominal distension. His cardiovascular examination was unremarkable apart from a slight abdominal bruit over the mass.  Auxiliary Examinations: An urgent CT-scan revealed an infra-renal Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) measuring about 4.7 cm in diameter. No signs of leakage or rupture were identified. As part of the pre-operative assessment  chest radiography and ECG were performed and found normal.  Diagnosis: The CT scan and physical examination confirmed the diagnosis of infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Treatment and Outcome: Given the size of the abdominal aneurysm and to prevent rupture  a decision was made for surgical intervention. Endovascular Aortic Repair (EVAR) of the abdominal aortic aneurysm was performed successfully and the patient responded well to the procedure. An uneventful recovery followed and blood pressure remained stable. The patient was discharged with advice for lifestyle modification and adherence to anti-hypertensive and statin therapy. He was scheduled for regular follow-up to monitor the success of the procedure and progression of his atherosclerotic disease.   Patient Education: A strong emphasis was made on the importance of regular clinic check-ups  maintaining a healthy diet  regular exercise  and good medication compliance to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia conditions to prevent any additional cardiovascular complications. He was also educated about the risk of recurrent aneurysms or endoleaks.   In conclusion  this case was significant in highlighting the common but potentially catastrophic condition of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. This patient's presentation was crucially aided by the awareness of his symptoms  medical history  and risk factors. Early detection and prompt intervention potentially saved this patient from life-threatening outcomes related to a potential aneurysm rupture.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. N  a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and moderate smoking (30 pack-years)  presented to the emergency department with acute onset mid-abdominal and low back pain. He reports living alone with basic access to healthcare services. His family medical history includes significant incidence of cardiovascular diseases  with his father succumbing to myocardial infarction and brother diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease.  Medical History:   Mr. N has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and has been on Losartan 50 mg once daily for the last six years. He is known to have dyslipidemia  managed conservatively through diet. He is not a known case of diabetes or any other chronic disease. Prior to this incident  his overall health has been stable with regular checkups indicating controlled blood pressure under medication. However  the patient admitted to intermittent compliance in medication-taking  missed clinic appointments  in addition to a 30 pack-year smoking history.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. N describes an acute onset of severe  throbbing pain in the mid-abdominal region radiating to his lower back  including a feeling of ""fullness"" in his stomach. He denied bowel or bladder changes or constitutional symptoms such as weight loss or fever. He reports no relief upon changing positions or lying down.   Physical Examination:  Physical examination revealed a moderately built and nourished male in evident discomfort. His vital signs were all within normal range. He had a palpable  pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. The rest of his physical examination  including cardiovascular  respiratory  and neurological exams  were unremarkable.  Imaging Results:  Given his symptoms and examination  an urgent CT angiogram of the abdomen and pelvis was ordered. It revealed a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  with no apparent sign of rupture but demonstrating an impending risk.  Treatment and Outcome:  After immediate consultation with the vascular surgery team  Mr. N was successfully managed with emergent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and he was successfully discharged on post-operative day three with advice for strict blood pressure control  smoking cessation  and regular follow-ups with the vascular surgery and primary care teams.  Conclusion:  This case exemplifies the importance of comprehensive clinical evaluation  including family history  in diagnosing AAA. In addition  it emphasizes the crucial role of patient education in managing comorbid conditions like hypertension which significantly contribute to the risk of developing AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male With Hypertension and Atherosclerosis: A Case Report  Case:  Mr. R is a 77-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset abdominal pain that radiated to his back. The pain was ranked 8/10 in intensity  was not alleviated by resting or positional changes  and was accompanied by a feeling of faintness. His past medical history included hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and atherosclerosis  with a ten-year history of smoking (quit 15 years ago). There was no known family history of heart or vascular diseases.  Clinical Examination:  The patient's pulse was rapid and weak  with a palpable abdominal mass noted on physical examination. The patient's blood pressure was relatively low at 90/60 mmHg  and there were signs of peripheral hypoperfusion. The abdomen was tender  particularly in the central and lower region.  Investigations:  Ultrasound imaging of the abdomen revealed a large aneurysm in the abdominal aorta  measuring approximately 8.1 cm in diameter. Subsequent CT angiography confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no apparent rupture  but there were signs of impending rupture due to the size and rapid expansion. Blood tests revealed an elevated white blood cell count  indicative of a possible inflammation or infection.  Treatment and Outcome:  Considering the patient's age  co-morbidities and the size of the aneurysm  an emergency endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) was performed successfully. His pain decreased significantly post-procedure  and his hemodynamic status remained stable. The patient was transferred to ICU for critical care monitoring during the immediate postoperative period.  At the 1-month follow-up  the patient reported no pain and there was no evidence of endoleak on follow-up ultrasound. His blood pressure was better controlled with medications  and he was advised on lifestyle modifications  including diet  exercise  and regular follow-ups to monitor his vascular status.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of considering an abdominal aortic aneurysm in the differential diagnosis when an elderly patient presents with unexplained severe abdominal pain  especially in conjunction with a history of vascular diseases and other risk factors such as smoking. Early diagnosis through non-invasive imaging modalities like ultrasound and CT angiography  followed by timely management can prevent catastrophic outcomes in such patients.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  Mr. M  a 76-year-old Caucasian male  presented at the walk-in clinic with complaints of intermittent  non-radiating abdominal pain for the past two weeks. The pain was described as a dull ache located in the mid-abdominal region  occasionally radiating to the lower back. The patient also reported a noticeable pulsating sensation in the abdomen. Other symptoms included a slight loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss of approximately 5 kgs over two months. He denied the presence of nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  blood in stool  dysuria  fever  or recent trauma.  Mr. M is a retired engineer living with his wife. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history but quit ten years ago. His alcohol intake is moderate. His diet is relatively balanced  and he admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Past Medical History: Mr. M has a past medical history significant for hypertension  managed effectively with Losartan 50mg daily for the last ten years. He was also diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus five years ago  controlled by Metformin 500mg twice daily. He has no known allergies.   Family History: His father died of a stroke at 80  and his mother passed at 75 due to heart failure. One of his three brothers had a myocardial infarction at 68.  Physical Examination: Vitals at the time of presentation were: Blood Pressure - 145/90 mmHg  Heart Rate - 85 beats/min  Respiratory Rate - 15 breaths/min  Oxygen Saturation - 97% on room air  Temperature - 98ºF. Height - 5'9""  Weight - 74kgs  BMI - 24.8kg/m2. The patient appears well built and nourished.  Abdominal examination revealed a palpable aortic pulsation in the epigastric region  superior to the umbilicus. There were no overlying skin changes  visible pulsations  or bruits. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations & Treatment: A bedside ultrasound and subsequent CT Angiography confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm. Due to the size and symptoms  a referral to vascular surgery was made. The surgeon opted for an elective open aneurysm repair  given the patient's otherwise good health status  with careful consideration of the potential risks and benefits. Mr. M and his family were informed about the surgery  recovery  and potential complications  to which they consented. Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and Mr. M was discharged on the ninth postoperative day.   The patient is currently on follow-ups  maintaining good health  and is advised to continue his antihypertensive medication and control his blood sugar levels. He is also recommended to have regular vascular consults to monitor possible complications. He was advised to continue regular exercise and adopt a healthy diet to manage his risk factors better.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from Mr. M for the publication of this case report.

Patient Information  Mr. Troy  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department at around 9:45 PM with symptoms of severe lower back pain and shortness of breath. Besides  he also reported a pulsating sensation in his abdomen and was mildly feverish. His ethnic origin is of Irish-American descent and he lives with his wife in a suburban region. His primary language is English.   Past Medical History  As per available medical records  Mr. Troy has a history of hypertension and he is a former smoker (40 years pack history) having quit around 10 years back. Further in the past  there were incidental findings of a small (3.5 cm) infrarenal abdominal aorta aneurysm  that was being monitored conservatively. His family history indicates that his late father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm  that was successfully surgically repaired. The patient had been prescribed medications for controlling blood pressure  including a beta-blocker and an ACE-inhibitor. His hypertension was typically well-controlled on these medications  although he admitted that he had been non-compliant in taking the medications over the last week.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  he appeared to be in significant discomfort. His blood pressure was 190/110 mm Hg  and his heart rate was faster at 110 beats per minute. His body mass index was 27  falling in the overweight range. There was evidence of a pulsatile mass in his abdomen  and there was tenderness localized to the mid and lower abdomen.  Diagnostic Assessment  A contrast CT scan confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. The size of the aneurysm had enlarged significantly to 8 cm. Unfortunately  evidence of a contained rupture with retroperitoneal hematoma was also observed.   Therapeutic Intervention  Emergent surgical repair was planned and informed consent for open repair versus endovascular aneurysm repair was obtained. The patient elected to undergo an endovascular procedure  guided by his age and the possibility of quicker recovery time.   Patient Follow-up  Postoperatively  the patient was closely monitored in the Intensive Care Unit for blood pressure control  potential renal damage  and lower extremity ischemia. No such complications were encountered. By Day 3  he reported significant improvement in his symptoms and his vital signs were also much-improved. To prevent further cardiovascular complications  the patient was counseled on the importance of compliance with medications  maintaining low sodium diet and moderate aerobic exercise. On follow-up visits at 1 month  3 months  and 6 months  the patient remained symptom-free and the size of the aneurysm remained stable.   In conclusion  this case emphasized the importance of adherence to prescribed medications in hypertensive patients with abdominal aortic aneurysm and that a high index of suspicion needs to be maintained in patients with a history presenting with acute abdominal or back pain.

Patient Identifier: Case-001-AA Demographics: 68-year-old Caucasian male Medical History: A known hypertensive on medication for the past 10 years. Has a history of smoking (30 pack years) but quit 5 years ago. Reported a family history of cardiovascular diseases.   PRESENTING COMPLAINT:  The patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal and back pain which he described as tearing in nature since morning. The pain was not relieved with over-the-counter pain medications. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or loss of consciousness.  CLINICAL FINDINGS:  On physical examination  the patient appeared in acute distress related to pain. Vital signs showed blood pressure of 180/100mmHg  pulse rate 110/min  temperature 98.5 degrees Fahrenheit  and respiratory rate of 22/min. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen.   No signs of limb ischemia or neurologic deficit were noted. Rectal examination was normal. Laboratory tests revealed normal kidney function and complete blood count. Electrocardiogram showed no signs of myocardial infarction or arrhythmia.  INVESTIGATION AND MANAGEMENT:  Given the clinical suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  the patient underwent an urgent contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen  which confirmed a 7.5cm infrarenal AAA with evidence of impending rupture.  Emergency surgical consultation was obtained  and the patient was urgently transferred to the operating room for an open surgical repair. A Dacron tube graft was placed without complications. Postoperative course was uneventful and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 7 after confirming graft patency via duplex ultrasonography.  DISCUSSION:  This case represents a classic presentation of an impending rupture of abdominal aortic aneurysm in a patient with a background of hypertension and smoking. AAA is often asymptomatic until rupture or threatened rupture occurs. In such instances  open surgical repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) are the primary treatment options. The patient's clinical presentation and CT findings dictated the urgency of surgical intervention.   KEY LEARNINGS:  Emergency physicians should maintain a high index of suspicion for AAA in older patients presenting with abdominal or back pain  especially with known risk factors like hypertension  smoking  and male sex. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention can be life-saving.   It highlights the importance of screening programs for AAA in high-risk populations to aid early diagnosis and intervention before disastrous consequences like rupture occur. Such programs have demonstrated a significant reduction in AAA-related mortality rates over the last decade.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Presentation: Mr. K  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset abdominal and back pain. He is 5'7"" in height  weight 82kg  a retired mechanical engineer currently living on his own. He is a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol moderately.  Patient Medical History:  Mr. K has a medical history of hypertension  managed for the past ten years with Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia managed with Simvastatin. He also had a transient ischemic attack five years ago. He had been adherent to his medications and regular follow-ups. Both his parents had cardiovascular diseases and passed away due to related complications. His mother had an unspecified aneurysm  and father had ischemic heart disease. Mr. K had no known allergies or surgical history.  Current Medications: - Lisinopril 10mg once daily  - Simvastatin 20mg once daily  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. K complained of a sharp  severe  and persistent abdominal pain that started abruptly while he was gardening. He also reported back pain that radiated towards his groin.  Clinical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  heart rate was 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. His abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile and tender mass in the periumbilical area.  Investigations: Emergency computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirmed the diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with a diameter of 6.5 cm  extending down to the common iliac arteries. His full blood count  liver function test  and renal function test were within normal limits  except for elevated levels of white blood cells (14 x 109/L).  Treatment Initiated: Mr. K was taken immediately for emergency open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. The surgery was successful  and he made a steady post-operative recovery. As a secondary prevention strategy  he was put on Clopidogrel.  Follow-Up: Post-surgery  he was discharged with a follow-up appointment with a consultant vascular surgeon. He was counseled concerning the warning symptoms of aneurysm rupture  the importance of regular follow-up visits  and maintaining a low-salt  low-fat diet to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Summary: Mr. K  a 75-year-old man with a clinical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents an interesting case of AAA with imminent rupture. Prompt diagnosis and treatment prevented a potentially life-threatening event and underlines the critical role of emergency medical care in managing acute conditions. It also highlights the importance of family history in vascular diseases  raising the need for routine AAA screening in high-risk individuals.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  Mr. Jones  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe lower back pain which grew progressively worse over the past week. He denies any history of trauma or injury to his back  complaining of pain localized in his mid-lower back and abdomen  described as ""gnawing"" in nature  severe in intensity  with no radiation  slightly alleviated by bending forward and significantly aggravated by lying flat on his back. He also reported episodes of light-headedness but no syncope.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a significant past medical history involving hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been a tobacco smoker for the past 50 years  consuming an average of 20 cigarettes per day. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father suffering from a myocardial infarction at 65-years-old. He has no history of surgery or any other major medical complaints. The patient confirmed he had been taking medications regularly for hyperlipidemia  Atorvastatin 20mg daily  and for hypertension  Amlodipine 10mg daily.  Clinical Findings and Diagnostic Assessment:   Physical examination revealed that the patient was in obvious distress due to pain  but vital signs were stable. No palpable abdominal mass was noted. Peripheral pulses were palpable and symmetrical. A vascular ultrasound later confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  with the diameter of the aorta measuring 5.5 cm at the widest point. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Therapeutic Intervention:   Following diagnosis  the patient was properly educated about the surgical and non-surgical management timings  risks  and benefits. After considering his lifestyle  age  and the size of the aneurysm  he was scheduled for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). He subsequently underwent the procedure which was successful without any complications and was discharged on post-operative day 3.   Follow-up and Outcomes:   The patient was advised to stop smoking and control his diet to reduce cholesterol level. He was also advised to continue his medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia with follow-up appointments scheduled for monitoring. During the subsequent follow-ups  two weeks and then 1  3  6  9  and 12 months post-surgery  the patient was found to be clinically stable  with significant pain relief and no further complications. CT angiogram at six months showed no evidence of endoleak or aneurysm expansion.  Takeaway/Teaching Points:   The case well illustrates the importance of considering the differential diagnosis of AAA in older patients with the relevant risk factors presenting with unexplained and severe lower back or abdominal pain. Further  the successful outcome of the intervention emphasizes the importance of prompt diagnosis and appropriate management.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient was presented to the clinic being concerned about his escalating back pain and a slight feeling of abdominal swells. He is a retired engineer  residing in a suburb in Philadelphia. He has an extensive 30-year history of cigarette smoking and alcohol consumption. He is a widower who lives alone  he is a non-vegetarian and he doesn't indulge in any physical activity or exercises. He has no known allergies.  Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for 15 years for which he is currently taking medication including beta-blockers and statins. In addition  he also has a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin and diet control. His family history reveals that his father died from a heart attack and his elder brother from a stroke. He has been prescribed a low-salt and low-fat diet combined with regular physical activity  but compliance has been sketchy. He has not had any prior surgical interventions or hospitalizations. No history of respiratory  renal or liver diseases.  Presenting Concerns: The patient presented with a 3-week history of constant back pain and recent onset of abdominal discomfort which he initially attributed to gastritis. He also reported a mild loss of appetite but no weight loss. He denied any bowel changes  chest pain  shortness of breath  lower limb edema or recent infections.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  a palpable pulsatile mass was felt in the area of the upper abdomen. No other abnormalities were noted in other abdominal  respiratory  neurological or cardiovascular examinations. The patient's blood pressure was 155/85 mmHg and heart rate was 78 bpm.  Clinical Findings/Diagnosis: Further diagnostic procedures included ultrasonography which revealed a 5.2 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) without any signs of rupture or dissection. CT angiography confirmed the presence of a large infrarenal AAA.  Therapeutic Intervention: The intervention decided for the patient was an elective surgical repair of the AAA. To adequately manage his risk factors before the procedure  the patient's antihypertensive treatment was adjusted. The patient was successfully treated with an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) under the vascular surgery service.  Outcome: The postoperative recovery was uneventful. His blood pressure was adequately controlled and he showed signs of recovery from the initial symptoms. At the 2-month post-op checkup  a repeat scan showed no aneurysm and the graft was well-apposed. The patient has been urged to stop smoking  restrict alcohol intake  remain compliant with medications and adopt a healthier lifestyle including diet and physical activities.  Patient's consent was obtained for writing this case report. This study was conducted in accordance with the ethical standards of the institution.  Discussion: This case underlines the importance of considering abdominal aortic aneurysm in older male patients especially with a history of smoking and cardiovascular diseases presenting with a combination of back pain and abdominal discomfort.
