Early diagnosis and intervention can prevent life-threatening complications of AAA.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Ethnic Male  Demographics:  The patient is a 72-year-old Hispanic male with an extensive past medical history  including hypertension  type-two diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is a retired construction worker and non-practicing alcoholic. His father passed due to complications from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  suggesting a potential family predisposition.  History:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe lower back pain that had been persistent for the last three days. He described the pain as sharp and constant  rating it as an eight on the pain scale. He reported dizziness  nausea  and general discomfort but denied any episodes of loss of consciousness  bleeding  or bowel disorders. The patient was otherwise in his usual state of health until the onset of the recent discomfort.  Assessment and Diagnosis:  On physical examination  the patient was alert and oriented but showcased significant discomfort. His vitals showed a blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg  a pulse of 90 beats per min  and a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per min. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region  and he exhibited tenderness on palpation. Bowel sounds were normal with no signs of peritonitis. Peripheral pulses were palpable and equal bilaterally.  Radiology performed a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan. The study revealed a large abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.8 cm in maximum diameter  beginning just below the renal arteries and ending just above the aortic bifurcation  confirming the suspected diagnosis.  The patient was also subjected to a complete blood count  renal function test  coagulation profile  and lipid profile  which were mostly within normal ranges  except the lipid profile  showing higher than normal levels. Given his symptomatic presentation and the large size of the aneurysm detected  the patient's case was considered for urgent surgical repair  and the vascular surgery team was consulted for emergency intervention.  Surgical Management:  The patient underwent endovascular abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. Postoperatively  he recovered well with close monitoring in the cardiovascular intensive care unit. The patient was discharged to an inpatient rehabilitation center on postoperative day seven.  In conclusion  this case underlines the clinical importance of timely diagnosis and treatment of abdominal aortic aneurysms given the patient's significant risk factors and symptomatic presentation. Despite his complex past medical history  successful surgical repair was performed  highlighting that emergency intervention can be life-saving in these acutely presenting patient scenarios.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 60-Year-Old Male   Patient Information: A 60-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presented with complaints of severe low back pain radiating towards the lower abdomen. He is a resident of the local area and resides with his wife. He had a 35-year history of smoking (quit 1 year ago) and is an occasional drinker. He has never been diagnosed with diabetes or hypertension  but his father suffered from cardiovascular disease.  Clinical Findings: The patient’s blood pressure was 145/95 mmHg  heart rate was 90 beats per minute  respiration rate was 16 breaths per minute  and body temperature was 36.7°C. Physical examination revealed that the patient was in discomfort due to pain  and deep palpation revealed a prominent pulsating mass in the central abdomen.  Diagnostic Assessment: The patient's blood tests and ECG findings were within normal limits. However  ultrasonography (US) revealed a dilated infrarenal aorta with an anterior-posterior diameter of 7.2cm and apparent signs of aortic wall weakness. A further CT scan was performed to confirm the diagnosis  which showed a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with no sign of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention: The AAA measured in this patient was a significant risk for rupture and required immediate attention. Due to the patient's stable condition  elective open surgical repair was undertaken instead of endovascular repair. An abdominal approach was made  and the AAA was successfully replaced with a synthetic graft. No complications were registered during the procedure. The patient was then transferred to the intensive care unit for observation.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient's recovery was uneventful. He was discharged 12 days post-operation with instructions for regular check-ups. Follow-up CT scans at 3 and 6 months post-operatively showed no graft-related complications or recurrence of AAA. The patient remains asymptomatic and is currently under regular outpatient vascular surveillance.  Patient Perspective: The patient reported fear and anxiety upon hearing his diagnosis. After a thorough explanation of the condition  its implications  and the proposed surgical treatment  the patient gave his informed consent. He started abdominal exercises as part of his physical rehabilitation program and was grateful for the high-quality care he received.   Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the treatment procedures and publication of the case details.   Teaching Points: Early recognition and surgical treatment of abdominal aortic aneurysms can dramatically reduce morbidity and mortality. It is essential for clinicians to note that severe abdominal or lower back pain in a patient with a significant smoking history might be indicative of AAA. Observation of the patient’s condition post-operation is critical to monitor the recovery route and catch any potential complications early.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Geriatric Patient with Significant Cardiovascular History  Introduction: Mr. Johnson  a 79-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe and sudden onset mid-abdominal and lower back pain. On inspection  a pulsatile abdominal mass could be palpated. Given the patient's history of cardiovascular disease  tobacco use  and hypertension  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was suspected.  Demographics: Patient Information: Mr. Johnson is a retired engineer living with his wife in suburban NY. He smoked for 40 years; however  he quit 10 years ago. His body mass index (BMI) is 27  indicating overweight.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has been treated for a range of chronic illnesses over the past two decades  including ischemic heart disease  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His medications include metformin for diabetes  aspirin and lisinopril for heart disease  and tiotropium bromide for COPD. Mr. Johnson underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery almost 12 years ago and maintains check-ups with his cardiologist annually.  Current Presentation: His sudden onset of severe mid-abdominal pain was not associated with food intake  positioned differently  or radiated elsewhere. No symptoms of diarrhea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habits were reported  although he admitted to having lower back pain. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass and moderate tenderness in the mid-abdominal region. Due to the suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm  an urgent abdominal ultrasound was conducted.  Investigations and Diagnosis: The ultrasound confirmed an infrarenal AAA with a diameter of 5.6 cm. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/92 mmHg. Complete blood count  liver function  and kidney function tests were within normal limits  but blood glucose level was slightly increased.  Management and Follow-Up: Given the size of the aneurysm  the patient was admitted for immediate surgical repair. The patient underwent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and was placed on intravenous antibiotic prophylaxis. Post-operative recovery was uneventful  with noticeable relief of pain. The patient was discharged on day 5 post-operation. Scheduled follow-ups were arranged to monitor recovery and aneurysm exclusion from the bloodstream.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering AAA in older patients with significant cardiovascular history presenting with acute abdominal or back pain. Early diagnosis and treatment are paramount in preventing catastrophic AAA rupture. It also underscores the need for frequent monitoring in patients with recognized risk factors for AAA  such as smoking history  hypertension  and coronary artery disease—characteristics that were present in this case.  Disclaimer: This case report is an educational example and does not contain real-life patient data.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old African American male  with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia.  Case Report: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of an acute onset of severe abdominal and back pain that has persisted for three hours. He is a known hypertensive on medication and a diagnosed diabetic for ten years on oral hypoglycemic agents. He has a twenty-year history of smoking one pack per day. He has been experiencing milder aches in his abdominal and lower back region intermittently over the past few weeks.  On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable in the periumbilical area. His blood pressure was recorded as 165/100 mmHg and his heart rate was 106 beats/minute. Immediate laboratory investigations including complete blood count  recorded high white blood count suggesting an ongoing systemic inflammation.   An urgent CT scan of the abdomen was done which confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  measuring about 7.6 cm in diameter  indicating progression from a possible pre-existing aneurysm considering his past intermittent abdominal discomfort. However  the scan didn't show any evidence of rupture  though the significant size of the aneurysm made it a great concern.  In consultation with vascular surgery  a decision was made to immediately operate for surgical repair given the symptomatic nature and large size of the aneurysm. He underwent a successful open aortic aneurysm repair. Biopsy of the removed aneurysmal wall revealed atherosclerotic changes  consistent with his risk profile of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a long history of smoking.  Post-operative period was uneventful with successful pain management and progressive ambulation. The patient was counseled regarding strict blood pressure control  glycemic control  smoking cessation  and dyslipidemia management to prevent the formation of new aneurysms. He was discharged to a rehabilitation facility on post-operative day 7  with plans for close follow-up in vascular surgery clinics.  Discussion: This case underlines the importance of maintaining vigilant monitoring and control over cardiovascular risk factors as well as conducting regular screenings for AAA in high-risk individuals. The patient’s longstanding hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  smoking history  and age over 65 years  placed him in a demographic group considered at-risk for AAA. Timely detection and intervention undoubtedly saved this patient from having a catastrophic outcome. Regular screenings and lifestyle modifications should be emphasized to at-risk individuals to prevent the formation of AAA.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year Old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 68-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden-onset severe abdominal and lower back pain persisting over 3 hours. The patient has been residing in Phoenix  Arizona  working as a retired school teacher  and lives with his wife. He doesn't have any children. The patient has a history of smoking a pack a day for the past 40 years and reported occasional consumption of alcohol. He is not on any routine medications apart from low dose aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease. Previously  he had no known allergies to food or drugs.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic and was grimacing in pain. His blood pressure was 95/60mmHg  heart rate was 120 beats/minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths/minute  temperature was 98.4°F  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air.  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient was also noted to have a slight motor weakness in both lower extremities with normal sensation and absent peripheral pulses. There was no history of trauma or injury.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Laboratory tests revealed a moderate leukocytosis and mild renal insufficiency (creatinine = 1.5mg/dl). Liver function tests were within normal limits. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a 6cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with signs of rupture and a small amount of retroperitoneal hematoma.  Therapeutic Intervention:  He underwent immediate open repair of the ruptured AAA with prosthetic graft placement. He required multiple units of blood during operation due to continuous blood loss.   Follow-up and Outcome:  Post-operative course was complicated by prolonged intubation due to underlying moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  and he required mechanical ventilation for three days. His renal function deteriorated further  probably due to perioperative hypotension  but it improved with conservative management and hydration. The patient resumed a regular diet on the 6th postoperative day and was transferred from the Intensive Care Unit to the surgical ward.  The patient was discharged home after 14 days of hospital stay  with advice to stop smoking  regulate his diet  avoid heavy physical work and be on regular follow-up with his primary care physician and vascular surgeon. He was also prescribed regular low-dose aspirin  a statin and an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor to prevent any possible future complications.  In conclusion  high index of suspicion  early diagnosis and immediate surgical intervention are essential in the management of a ruptured AAA. Primary prevention  through risk factor modification plays a significant role in the management of AAA. Also  early referral to a vascular surgeon for elective repair  when indicated  can significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Case Report  Patient Identification: Mr. Richard Johnston  a 60-year-old African-American male.  Presenting Complaints: The patient came in complaining of persistent  throbbing abdominal pain for the last month  that has gradually increased in intensity. It was also noticed that he felt an unusual pulsating mass in his abdomen while lying down.  Past Medical History: The patient is a known hypertensive and has been on antihypertensive medication for the last 8 years. His blood pressure has been reasonably controlled. He was a heavy smoker but quit 10 years ago. He has no history of diabetes or any high cholesterol level.  Socio-Economic Data: He is a retired engineer and lives with his wife and two daughters. His father died due to heart disease at the age of 62  while his mother is alive and in sound health.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable in the region of his belly button. The patient's blood pressure was slightly elevated but regulated with medication.  Investigations & Diagnosis: An abdominal ultrasound was advised  and it showed an abdominal aortic aneurysm of around 5.6 cm in diameter. Subsequently  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was performed  which also confirmed the diagnosis of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm without any sign of rupture.  Treatment: Since the aneurysm was large  the patient was advised for surgery. Endovascular repair was performed  and the patient tolerated the procedure well.   Follow-Up: The patient was followed-up two weeks postsurgery in which a repeat CTA showed successful placement of the endograft without any complication. He was counseled on maintaining a heart-healthy  low sodium diet  regular exercise  and medication adherence to control his hypertension. Regular six-monthly follow-ups were scheduled to monitor the endograft and to detect any late complications. He is expected to have regular check-ups to monitor his blood pressure.  Conclusion: Abdominal aortic aneurysm  especially above 5.5 cm  has a high risk of rupture. Timely detection and endovascular repair in this patient helped prevent potential life-threatening complications. The management of comorbid conditions  including hypertension  is vital in these patients. This case underscores the importance of regular medical follow-ups  especially in patients with a history of smoking and hypertension  to detect aortic aneurysms early and prevent serious consequences.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a primary complaint of severe  constant  and sharp pain in his lower back and abdomen that started suddenly a few hours earlier. He describes the pain as ""ripping"" and ""tearing"". His medical history includes a 20-year record of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a known 4.5cm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) diagnosed by a routine ultrasound two years ago. The patient had been on an annual surveillance program due to his not meeting the surgical intervention criteria at that time.   Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious  pale  clammy  and diaphoretic with a slight tinge of jaundice. His vital signs showed a blood pressure reading of 100/60 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  and a temperature reading of 98.5°F. Abdominal examination demonstrated a pulsatile abdominal mass with tenderness. No bruits or renal artery sounds were known.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An immediate ultrasound confirmed the presence of the known abdominal aortic aneurysm which has now rapidly grown to a maximum diameter of 8 cm  indicating an imminent risk of rupture. A complete blood count revealed a declining hemoglobin level of 8.9 g/dL from a baseline of 14 g/dL  and a hematocrit level of 27%  indicative of ongoing internal bleeding. The patient’s serum creatinine level was also elevated at 1.9 mg/dL  suggesting reduced renal perfusion. Coagulation profile  liver function tests  and electrolyte panels were within normal limits.  Therapeutic Interventions:  The on-call vascular surgery team was immediately alerted  and the patient was prepared for emergent endovascular abdominal aortic aneurysm repair (EVAR). A preoperative multidetector computed tomographic angiogram displayed the suitability for EVAR with good proximal neck  non-angulated aorta  and non-calcified iliac access vessels. Subsequently  he had successful endovascular repair without complications.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  In the postoperative period  the patient made excellent recovery. He was hemodynamically stable with an improved hemoglobin level to 11.6 g/dL. A repeat ultrasound showed a complete resolution of the aneurysm with no evidence of endoleak. At his follow-up appointment one month post-discharge  he reported no complaints  had stopped smoking and had his hypertension under control. A follow-up computed tomography angiography (CTA) at three months revealed no evidence of endoleak  and the endograft patency was well maintained.  Patient's Perspective:  The patient reported satisfaction with the care received  highlighting that the swift actions taken by the healthcare personnel potentially saved his life. He also appreciated the counselling received concerning his smoking habit and its link to his condition  resulting in his decisive action to quit smoking.  Informed Consent:  The patient provided informed consent for his case to be published.   Takeaway points:  This case emphasizes the importance of the periodic follow-up of patients with known abdominal aortic aneurysm  particularly those with risk factors such as smoking. It also highlights the effectiveness of EVAR as a safe and effective method to treat acutely expanded AAA. It further points out the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and early surgical referral in the management of complicated AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially fatal condition due to the risk of rupture  leading to massive internal bleeding. We present the case of a 68-year-old man who was incidentally found to have AAA during a routine physical examination.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: Mr. H  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented for his annual physical check-up. He lives in Boston  Massachusetts  and is a retired engineer. He has a 20-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  reasonably managed with medication  diet and exercise. Both his father and grandfather had a history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having died of AAA rupture at the age of 70.  Clinical Findings: The patient did not complain of any abdominal or back pain  weight loss  or change in bowel habits. His vital signs were stable with blood pressure readings within the acceptable range for his chronic hypertension. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the midline of the abdomen.   Diagnostic Assessment: An abdominal ultrasound was conducted  which revealed a 5.5 cm infrarenal AAA. A Computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the findings and indicated no signs of imminent rupture. Lab studies  including kidney function and complete blood count  were within normal limits  except for slightly elevated HbA1c and lipid levels.  Therapeutic Intervention: Given the patient's age  aneurysm size  and family history  the vascular surgery team was consulted. They recommended surgical intervention over watchful waiting. The patient underwent an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure  which was successful without complications.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The postoperative course was uneventful. The patient fully recovered and was discharged home on postoperative day 5. He was asymptomatic at his 1-month  3-month  and 6-month follow-up visits  showing good graft placement and patency on subsequent imaging.   Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief at having addressed this potentially fatal issue proactively. He is committed to maintaining control of his hypertension and diabetes and acknowledges the importance of regular check-ups.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of routine physical examination even in asymptomatic patients and a high degree of suspicion for AAA among individuals with risk factors such as advanced age  male gender  hypertension  history of smoking  and a family history of AAA. Early diagnosis followed by timely intervention can prevent devastating complications related to AAA.  The patient's informed consent was obtained for the case details to be published.

Case Report: 74-Year Old Male with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile  The patient is a 74-year old African American male residing in Denver  Colorado. He is retired from his occupation as a long-distance truck driver. His lifestyle is largely sedentary  with incidences of habitual alcohol consumption and smoking for a span of 35 years.  Medical History  The patient has a past medical history complicated by type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  managed with a combination of Metformin and diet restrictions. The patient also has a 15-year history of hypertension  controlled with Losartan and lifestyle modifications. He was first diagnosed with hyperlipidaemia 8 years ago and has since been on low-dose Atorvastatin. Additionally  he suffered a mild ischemic stroke two years ago with minor residual left-sided weakness  but has made a significant recovery with physical therapy.  He has no known drug allergies but has a family history of heart disease  with his father having died due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 69  and his elder brother died from an aortic dissection at the age of 70. The patient has a history of intermittent episodes of mild to moderate lower back and abdominal pain over the last six months.  Current Clinical Picture and Diagnosis  The patient recently attended the emergency department complaining of increasingly severe  sharp  and tearing abdominal pain radiating to his back. An emergency contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan revealed a 6.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with signs of an impending rupture. The patient was then diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Treatment and Progress  An urgent surgical consultation was made based on CT findings. Given the patient’s fitness and the imminent risk of rupture  he was offered an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure. Successful EVAR was performed without complications  and he was discharged home in a stable condition after six days postoperative hospital stay.   At the 3-month follow-up  the patient reported a notable improvement in his abdominal and back pain levels. CT scan showed no signs of an endoleak and revealed a stable post-EVAR aortic diameter. The patient was advised on smoking cessation  the importance of maintaining blood pressure and diabetes under control  and a healthier lifestyle involving a balanced diet and regular physical activity. Regular six-monthly follow-up was advised for the first year  then annually.  In conclusion  this case pinpoints the importance of routine medical follow-ups  stressing lifestyle modification in patients with risk factors for AAA  and the need for early intervention in the presence of AAA symptoms. An increased clinical suspicion in older patients presenting with abdominal and/or back pain  who have a history of hypertension  smoking  or familial predisposition may aid in early diagnosis and better prognosis of AAA.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Male Patient  Patient Information:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented with uncharacteristic abdominal discomfort for a period of two weeks. He was also experiencing back pain and had lost his appetite. He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he has been receiving treatment for the past 15 years. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  with a 20-pack year smoking history. His BMI is slightly over normal at 26  which makes him overweight  but not obese.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass but no other abnormalities. His pain was not severe but was consistent. His blood pressure was controlled within the normal limits and he was afebrile.  Diagnostic Assessment: An abdominal ultrasound was performed  which showed a 6 cm aneurysm in the infrarenal aorta. Further  a computerized topographic (CT) angiogram confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no evidence of rupture.   Therapeutic Intervention: Considering his age  medical history  the size of the aneurysm  and the symptoms he presented  the decision was made to pursue surgical intervention. The patient was counseled regarding the risk and benefits of an elective open surgical repair versus endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). A unanimous decision for EVAR was made due to its less invasive nature and lower morbidity and mortality.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient tolerated the procedure well with no complication. He was discharged after 5 days with advice to maintain a healthy lifestyle  take medications on schedule  and undergo regular follow-ups.  Lessons Learned: This case emphasizes the importance of early detection of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) in patients  especially those who are at high risk due to factors such as age  smoking  and hypertension. It is critical to regularly monitor HPB patients for AAA as ruptures can be life-threatening while the disease itself can be asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic in its early stages. The decision for intervention should consider factors including patient age  comorbidity  aneurysm size  and symptoms.

---  Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Introduction: This case report discusses the diagnosis  management  and follow-up of a large and symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in a 72-year-old male patient  presenting unique challenges due to several comorbidities.   Case Presentation:  Demographic Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  residing in rural Colorado. His occupation is retired  previously working as a construction worker. He is a former smoker  with a history of 35 pack-years  and reports moderate alcohol use.   Past Medical History:  The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and drug-eluting stent placement 5 years prior. Medications include aspirin  metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with a 4-hour history of sudden  intense  non-radiating pain in his lower back and abdomen.   Clinical findings: Physical examination revealed a tender  pulsatile abdominal mass. Vital signs included a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse 100 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) exam performed in the ED revealed a large AAA.   Diagnosis: A computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed a 7.5 cm infrarenal AAA with signs of rupture into the retroperitoneal space.   Treatment strategy: The patient was urgently transferred to the operating suite for open AAA repair. Surgery included resection of the aneurysm and replacement with a Dacron graft. The intraoperative course was complicated by significant hemorrhage requiring multiple transfusions.   Outcome and Follow-Up: The postoperative period was uneventful  and the patient was discharged on the 7th postoperative day with close follow-up arranged. Outpatient follow-up at three months and one year demonstrated no evidence of graft complication or postoperative infection  and the patient reported satisfactory pain relief and resolution of symptoms.  Conclusion: This case report highlights the unpredictable nature of AAA  the necessity of timely diagnosis and intervention  and the importance of managing comorbidities in elderly patients.   ---

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Male Patient: A Case Report   Introduction:  This case report discusses a 68-year-old Caucasian male with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This patient was evaluated and successfully treated at our medical facility.   Case presentation:  Mr. X is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a 2-week history of non-radiating  throbbing abdominal pain and lower back discomfort. He is a retired mining engineer with a 40-year history of smoking  two packs of cigarettes a day. His medical history revealed controlled hypertension for the last ten years and dyslipidemia. He had no known allergies and no family history of AAA. His routine surgical history included appendectomy at age 15 and a hernia operation about 20 years ago. He did not report any incidents of loss of consciousness  shortness of breath  or chest pain.  Physical examination and diagnostic evaluation:  During the physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was noticed  along with moderate abdominal tenderness. His initial blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  pulse was 85 bpm  respiration was 18 breaths per minute  and his temperature was 98.6 F. A comprehensive metabolic panel and complete blood count were ordered; results were within normal limits. An urgent  non-contrast computerized tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed  revealing a 5.5 cm infrarenal AAA. No signs of rupture or leak were found.  Management and outcome:  In consideration of the patient's symptoms and size of the aneurysm  surgical intervention was decided upon. The patient was scheduled for an open AAA repair. The procedure was successful without complications and the patient had an uneventful postoperative course. Following the surgery  he was given advice on lifestyle changes  specifically smoking cessation. He was also prescribed statins and antihypertensives to control his hypertension and dyslipidemia. The patient was subsequently discharged on postoperative day 7.  Follow-up:  He was seen in outpatient follow-up 1 month post discharge  where he reported feeling well and cessation of smoking. Follow-up imaging studies demonstrated that the graft site was intact with no evidence of endoleak. He remains on anti-hypertensive and statin therapy and is scheduled for regular follow-up visits and routine imaging.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early detection  appropriate surgical intervention  management of risk factors  and the necessity of patient education in the management of AAA. Given our patient's age  smoking history  and hypertension  it is crucial that he remains under regular monitoring to prevent potential AAA-related complications.

Patient Information:   An 83-year-old Caucasian male patient presented to the emergency department with chronic but progressively worsening lower abdominal and back pain  which had been present for the last six months but had intensified in the last few days. The pain was described as dull but continuous  radiating to his lower back and not related to movement or physical exertion. The patient also reported an unexplained weight loss of about 12 pounds over the past 2 months  but denied having a fever  vomiting  change in bowel habits  or urinary symptoms.   Medical History:   Patient had a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he was taking medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). There were no known allergies to any medication. He also had been a smoker for about 40 years but had stopped approximately 10 years ago. The patient denied alcohol or substance abuse and lifespan was spent mostly sedentary with little to no exercise. There was a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father dying of a heart attack in his sixties.   Clinical Findings:  Vitals upon arrival were: Blood pressure: 145/90 mmHg  Pulse: 80 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation was 96% in room air.  Physical examination disclosed a pulsatile and tender mass in the midline of the lower abdominal area. There were no signs of any peripheral vascular disease.  Timeline:   In the Emergency department  the initial clinical suspicion was of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An abdominal ultrasound was performed immediately  which showed an aneurysmal abdominal aorta measuring about 5.5 cm in diameter. A subsequent CT angiogram confirmed the initial diagnosis and showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no sign of rupture but a high risk of future rupture due to the diameter.   Therapeutic intervention:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous fluids and pain management. Given the size of the aneurysm and risk of rupture  the interventional radiology and vascular surgery teams were alerted for a possible endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) procedure.   Follow-up and outcomes:  Patient underwent a successful EVAR procedure with no immediate complications. During the post-op and a week's hospital stay  the patient's vitals and lab parameters remained stable. He was discharged on the eighth day with prescriptions of antihypertensives  statins  and pain relievers with close outpatient follow-up scheduled.   Conclusion:  Prompt evaluation and intervention avoided a potential life-threatening rupture in an elderly patient presenting with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. This case underlines the importance of maintaining a high clinical suspicion for AAA when evaluating chronic abdominal or back pain in elderly patients with cardiovascular risk factors. Regular follow-ups and adherence to prescribed medical treatment are crucial in preventing possible complications such as rupture in these patients.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Patient Description:  Mr. A is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who visited the emergency department complaining of severe and sudden onset abdominal pain. The patient rated his pain as 10 on a scale of 0 to 10. The pain was described as constant  sharp  radiating to the back and with no relieving factors. Mr. A is a retired engineer  resides with his wife  and has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He rarely drinks alcohol and denies use of recreational drugs. He has been leading an active lifestyle with regular exercise.  Past Medical  Surgical and Family History:  Mr. A's medical history includes hypertension  diagnosed at the age of 50 and controlled with medication (Losartan 50 mg daily). He underwent appendectomy at age 30 with no noted complications. He also had an episode of kidney stones at age 55  managed conservatively  and is under routine follow-up for prostate enlargement although there's no evidence of cancer. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father died from myocardial infarction at 67.  Physical Examination:  On examination  Mr. A was pale and appeared in distress. Vital signs showed blood pressure 90/60 mmHg  pulse rate 110 beats/min  respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  and temperature 37.2 °C. Abdominal inspection revealed visible peristalsis with tenderness and a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area. No abnormal findings were detected in the other systems.  Diagnosis and Management:  Due to the severe pain  hypotension  and findings on physical examination  a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was suspected. An urgent CT angiography confirmed a large infrarenal AAA measuring 8 cm with evidence of leak. The patient was resuscitated with intravenous fluids and immediately referred for emergency surgical intervention. His condition postoperatively was stable.  Conclusion:  While Mr. A was fortunate to receive immediate medical intervention  this case underscores the importance of awareness of AAA  especially in older males with a history of smoking and hypertension. Mr. A had typical clinical symptoms of ruptured AAA  which has a high mortality rate if not treated promptly. This case reinforces the necessity of regular AAA screening in high-risk groups to prevent fatal outcomes.    Keywords: Abdominal aortic aneurysm  rupture  case report  emergency surgery  screening.

Title: Evolving Management of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: Case Report  Patient Presentation: A 78-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of acute onset abdominal pain that had been persisting for 24 hours. The pain was described as severe and constant  originating in the central abdomen and radiating to the back. He also reported a sensation of abdominal fullness. No other significant symptoms were reported  including change in bowel habits  vomiting  or urogenital symptoms.  Demographics: The patient is a retired miner  living with his wife in a suburban area  and is an active smoker consuming around 15-20 cigarettes/day for the past 50 years. He is also a chronic alcoholic  consuming around 200-250gm of alcohol per week. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia under control with medication (Lisinopril and Atrovastatin respectively). His surgical history includes right knee arthroplasty approximately 10 years prior. He had been compliant with his medications with regular follow-up appointments with his primary care physician. There were no known cases of similar illness in his family.  Clinical Finding: On physical examination  the patient appeared in distress but vitally stable. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass slightly above the umbilicus that was tender to palpation. Bowel sounds were noted to be sluggish but present in all quadrants.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Blood labs were relatively within normal limits with a mild elevation in white blood cells. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated a large  infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring approximately 8cm in diameter with early signs of rupture.     Based on the clinical presentation and imaging  a diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made.  Management: The patient was immediately referred to the vascular surgical team and was taken to the operating room for an emergent open repair of the ruptured AAA. The surgery was successful with no intraoperative complications. He was transferred to the ICU postoperatively for close monitoring and management.  Conclusion: The patient's postoperative course was complicated by acute kidney injury possibly secondary to intraoperative hypotension. However  after supportive management in the intesive care unit  his renal parameters improved and he was able to be discharged in a week. This case emphasizes the potential presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm and the importance of early detection and successful surgical intervention.

Patient Information  Name: Pseudonym: Petrov A.V. Age: 65  Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Current residence: Moscow  Russia Occupational History: Retired computer engineer  Clinical Presentation  The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe  tearing abdominal and back pain. He complained of abdominal fullness and shortness of breath. His vitals on presentation were a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air.   Medical History  The patient has a known history of hypertension for over 10 years. He is also a 20-pack-year smoker. There is no history of diabetes mellitus  chest pain  peripheral vascular disease  or any other significant family history related to cardiovascular diseases. His only surgical history includes a hernia repair in 2002.  Examination and Investigations  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. Lab reports showed a slight increase in white blood cells and a normal renal function. A Computed tomography (CT) angiogram of the abdomen and pelvis was performed  which confirmed the presence of a 7.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with signs of impending rupture.   Hospital Course and Outcome  Emergency vascular surgery was recommended  considering the size of the aneurysm and the presentation symptoms. The patient underwent successful open AAA repair. The surgery was uneventful with no complications. The post-operative period was also smooth  with the patient showing improvement in symptoms. He was commenced on antiplatelets (as per standard postoperative management for vascular surgery)  beta-blockers (for hypertension management)  and counselled for smoking cessation. He was discharged after a week and was doing well at a month review in the outpatient department.   Discussion  This patient's presentation was typical for a rapidly expanding or ruptured AAA  considering his complaint of sudden  severe pain and the finding of a large  pulsatile abdominal mass on physical examination. His hypertension and history of smoking are significant risk factors. It was fortunate that despite the emergency nature and the size of the aneurysm  the surgical outcome was favorable. This case emphasizes the importance of prompt diagnosis and management of AAA  particularly among high-risk individuals.   The patient was informed about the necessity of further regular medical supervision. A recommendation was also made to examine his first-degree relatives  considering the genetic predisposition to aneurysmal disease.

Case Report: A 78-Year-Old Male Presenting with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information  A 78-year-old Caucasian male  a retired schoolteacher  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe and sudden onset abdominal and lower back pain. The patient lives in an urban habitat in New Jersey  is a former smoker  and quit around five years back after 40 years of smoking 1 pack/day. His alcohol use is occasional  and he follows a regular diet. He is widowed  lives alone  and is fairly active  performing his daily routine chores without difficulty. He is a known case of hypertension and atherosclerosis with a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) approximately 3 years back.  Clinical Findings  On presentation  the patient was hypertensive with a blood pressure reading of 170/90 mmHg. His HR was 112 bpm  and respiratory rate is 20 breaths/min. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass around the umbilical region consistent with an AAA diagnosis  along with marked tenderness on palpation. His body mass index was calculated to be within the normal range.  Diagnosis  The patient's severe pain profile  hypertension  and initial examination findings alerted the team towards a probable AAA diagnosis. Subsequent to a detailed history intake and preliminary physical examination  an emergency abdominal USG was arranged  which demonstrated a large infrarenal AAA measuring 7cm in diameter. Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) was planned to identify further vascular complications but was deferred owing to patients' renal insufficiency.  Therapeutic Intervention  An emergency endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) surgery was suggested considering the size of the aneurysm  age  and comorbidities of the patient. After a detailed discussion about the benefits  risks  and potential complications of the procedure  informed consent was taken from the patient and his family. The EVAR procedure was completed successfully without any intraoperative complications.  Follow-up and Outcome  The patient's postoperative period was uneventful  and pain was gradually subsided over the next few days. He was discharged on day 5 after appropriate wound care education and advice about lifestyle modifications.   He was followed up in the outpatient clinic after 2 weeks  wherein he denied any discomfort  and surgical wound healing appeared satisfactory. His BP was regulated around 140/80 mm Hg with amlodipine. Serial abdominal USGs during follow-ups at 1 month  3 months  6 months  and a year following the surgery reflected no endoleak or aneurysmal growth.  A multidisciplinary team including a cardiologist  a nephrologist  and a physiotherapist actively participated in providing the patient a coordinated care plan. Along with an optimized pharmacotherapy regimen  lifestyle modifications such as smoking cessation  maintaining a healthy diet  regular exercise  and avoidance of heavy lifting were reinforced during each follow-up visit.  This case illustrates the fact that rapid and appropriate diagnosis followed by suitable surgical intervention and postoperative care can effectively manage patients having abdominal aortic aneurysm  even in those with significant comorbidities. Furthermore  it highlights the importance of regular follow-up care and continued reinforcement of healthy behaviors in older adults.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 75-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report illustrates a patient diagnosed with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Patient Information:  The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  originating from France  and cigarette smoker with a pack per day for 30 years (but ceased smoking at the age of 65). He has been retired for ten years after a long career as a carpenter. His BMI is 28 and lives with his wife in a quiet countryside.  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of acute onset of severe  constant  and sharp back pain localized in the lower area  with intensity gradually increasing within 2 hours.  Past Medical History:  He has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years  maintained on lisinopril and metformin  respectively. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and takes atorvastatin regularly. The patient has undergone surgery for an inguinal hernia repair about ten years ago. There is no family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient lives a sedentary lifestyle and consumes alcohol moderately.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient had an irregular pulse of 100 beats per minute  blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  and a temperature of 37.2°C. The patient appeared to be pale and sweating. Examination of the abdomen revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen  and the pain was reproducible on palpation.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the patient's advanced age  history of hypertension  and the pulsatile abdominal mass  an AAA was suspected. Urgent abdominal ultrasound confirmed an AAA with a maximum diameter of 8.0 cm  suggesting a potential ruptured AAA. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) was immediately performed  which confirmed a ruptured infrarenal AAA with a moderate amount of retroperitoneal hematoma.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient underwent an urgent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR)  which was successful with no intraoperative complications. Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and the patient had regular follow-ups in the vascular clinic.  Follow-up and Outcome:  One month after surgery  the patient's pain had completely resolved. A follow-up ultrasound showed no endoleak  and the aneurysm sac had decreased in size. The patient was advised to have regular check-ups every 6 months to monitor the aneurysm and ensure there is no leak.  Conclusion:  The timely diagnosis and intervention in a ruptured AAA can save lives  especially in high-risk patients with multiple comorbidities. This case reinforces the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for AAA in elderly patients presenting with unexplained acute back or abdominal pain. Regular follow-ups and imaging tests are necessary in the post-operative period to ensure successful outcomes.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old Female Patient: An Urgent Surgical Intervention  Patient Description:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. She worked as a school teacher for 30 years before retirement. The patient lives alone and reports occasional alcohol consumption  limited to social occasions. Her familial history reveals her father died from aortic aneurysm at the age of 78.   Presenting Problem:  The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe  sudden onset of abdominal pain that radiated to her back. She reported the pain to be a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10  with 10 being the most severe. She had no associated fever  shortness of breath  nausea  or vomiting.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass accompanied by tenderness  hypotension  and signs of early hypovolemic shock. The patient’s temperature was normal  but her heart rate was elevated at 110 beats per minute. Her blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg  which was significantly lower than her baseline readings from previous clinical visits.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent abdominal ultrasonography identified an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 8cm in diameter  indicative of a ruptured AAA. The patient's complete blood count revealed moderate anemia and kidney function tests showed elevated creatinine levels suggesting impaired renal function  likely due to decreased perfusion secondary to hypotension.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the patient's hemodynamic instability and the size of the aneurysm  emergency open surgical repair was performed. The patient received intravenous fluids  anemia was corrected with blood transfusion and she was taken directly to the operating room under the care of a vascular surgeon. The aneurysmal wall was replaced with a prosthetic graft.  Outcome:  Postoperatively  the patient was monitored within the intensive care unit. After an eventful post-operative period  marked by transient decline in renal function and pulmonary edema  the patient’s conditions stabilized. The renal impairment resolved  and her anemia gradually improved. She was discharged after 15 days of hospital stay and was scheduled to attend follow-up visits and rehabilitation.  Patient Follow-up:  At a 6-month follow-up visit  the patient was stable  with an improved functional status. Her hypertension and hyperlipidemia were well-controlled and follow-up imaging showed satisfactory positioning of the graft with no evidence of leak or new aneurysm formation.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of immediate recognition of a potential ruptured AAA considering the high mortality associated with delayed management. It also emphasizes the need for public awareness about the risks of smoking and hypertension on developing AAA  especially in individuals with positive familial history.

Patient Profile:  An 82-year-old Caucasian male patient  living in a suburban locality with a history of 40 years of smoking. He is a retired mechanical engineer  burdened with significant past medical history  comprising Type II diabetes  hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia.   Presenting Symptom: The patient presented in the emergency room with sudden onset severe lower back pain radiating to the groin and legs. He reported no injury or inciting incidents related to the sudden pain  besides his habitual morning jog.  Physical Examination: Upon initial physical examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic and pale. His vital signs reflected a blood pressure level of 150/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 112 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  and a temperature of 98.6°F (37°C).  A distended and pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated about 3 cm in diameter  indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The mass showed expansive characteristics and tenderness.   Laboratory Tests: His laboratory results highlighted raised white blood cell count and c-reactive protein  hinting towards possible inflammation or infection. His serum Creatinine level was 1.2 mg/dL and Blood Glucose 160 mg/dL. Urinalysis  complete blood count  liver function tests  and other metabolic panels were within normal range. ECG reflected sinus tachycardia.  Imaging: An urgent Abdominal Ultrasound was performed confirming the presence of AAA of about 5.5 cm. Contrast-enhanced Computed Tomography (CT) scan indicated the AAA was lined with thrombus and was infrarenal.   Treatment: The patient was managed under emergency conditions to stabilize his condition  including intravenous fluids for hydration  opioids for pain management  and close monitoring of his blood pressure. Due to the high risk of rupture  a consented decision was made regarding an emergency Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR) operation.  Outcome: The endovascular stent-graft procedure was successfully performed without complications. The patient was hemodynamically stable following surgery and kept under intensive care unit observation for monitoring. Postoperative CT scan was done 2 days later showing successful exclusion of the aneurysm.  Follow-Up: The patient is scheduled for regular follow-ups  including periodic CT scans to monitor any potential graft-related problems. He was also referred to cessation smoking programs and received dietary and lifestyle counseling to manage his comorbid conditions such as diabetes and hypertension.   This case signifies the importance of urgent diagnosis and immediate surgery of symptomatic AAA. It also emphasizes the need for secondary prevention measures in an elderly patient burdened with multiple risk factors.
