Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-year-old Male - A Case Report  Patient Demographics: Mr. X  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  residing in an urban area  was presented with sudden abdominal and back pain. His BMI at presentation was 27.1 kg/m^2  which indicates moderate overweight. He is a retired engineer  married with two children  and a non-smoker. He consumes alcohol occasionally.   Past Medical History: Mr. X had a history of chronic hypertension for a period of 15 years but was inconsistent about his medication. He also had a vague  sporadic complaint of a pulsating feeling in his abdomen for the past few months. His family history was significant for cardiovascular diseases  including his father who died due to a heart attack and a brother who suffered from a stroke.   Presenting Concerns: The patient complained of severe  sudden onset abdominal pain radiating to his back and lower torso. The pain was non-radiating and unresponsive to over-the-counter analgesics. He also reported feeling a bit light-headed and experiencing mild shortness of breath. His abdomen was tender on palpation; however  no specific localized tenderness was identified.   Differential Diagnosis: Upon initial presentation  the differential diagnoses considered included acute pancreatitis  diverticulitis  peptic ulcer disease  and a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Investigations: On further evaluation and diagnosis using a computed tomography (CT) scan  a large  ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was identified  measuring approximately 7.8 cm in diameter. His hemoglobin level was 12.7 g/dL significantly low from his baseline of 14.9 g/dL. His blood pressure readings were 134/88 mmHg  indicating his chronic hypertension was not controlled.   Management and Outcome: The patient was emergently transferred to the operating room for an open surgical repair. A Dacron tube graft was used to replace the aneurysmal aorta. Despite experiencing post-operative complications including acute kidney injury and pulmonary edema  the patient survived. He was discharged on post-operative day 10 with a prescription for antihypertensive medication and advised on lifestyle modifications for controlling hypertension.   Patient’s Progress: On follow-up visits  the patient was counseled continuously on the necessity of regular check-ups  consistent antihypertensive medication  managing his diet  and moderate exercising. His hypertension was better controlled  and he exhibited a promising recovery from surgery.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of considering AAA in the differential for older individuals with sudden onset of abdominal and lower back pain  especially with a history of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases in the family. Timely detection and intervention can be life-saving  but post-operative complications may arise  requiring ongoing patient management.

Title: Expanding Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Patient Information:  The patient  Mr. F  is a 73-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  initially diagnosed five years ago on routine investigations. He is a retired engineer and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker of 30 pack-years and has quit smoking for the last ten years. His past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Presenting Concerns:  Mr. F presented to the outpatient vascular clinic for a regular follow-up visit for his AAA. He reported the recent onset of nonspecific  intermittent back pain over the past month. Pain was not associated with eating or exercise  and he reported no changes in bowel or bladder habits.   Clinical findings and Diagnostic Assessment:  On examination  Mr. F appeared comfortable with normal vitals. His abdomen was soft  non-tender  and a pulsatile mass was palpable in the peri-umbilical region  which was unchanged from previous examinations. Blood work  including renal function and glucose  displayed no significant abnormalities  with HbA1c controlled at 7.4%.  A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT was performed promptly  revealing an enlargement of his AAA from an earlier diameter of 4.5 cm to a diameter of 5.7 cm. No evidence was detected of rupture or leak.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the AAA’s growth rate and the patient’s symptoms  despite the potential risks associated with his age  comorbidities  and the procedure itself  the interdisciplinary team decided to proceed with an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The procedure was carried out successfully  without any intraoperative complications. A Stent graft was introduced and placed accurately via the femoral arteries  excluding the aneurysm from the circulation.  Follow-up and Outcome:  Mr. F was discharged home after a few days of monitoring  under strict orders to avoid strenuous activity or lifting heavy weights. Follow-up duplex ultrasonography confirmed a successful procedure with no endoleak and graft patency. His back pain improved  and he reported overall improved wellbeing at the 1 and 6-month postoperative visits.   Patient Perspective:  Mr. F expressed appreciation for the thorough follow-up and swift intervention that ""saved his life"". He commits to regular follow-up and maintaining a healthier lifestyle  including diet and exercise modifications.   This case emphasizes the importance of regular surveillance of patients with known AAA and making surgical decisions based on individual patient symptoms and aneurysm profiles. Even for elderly patients with multiple comorbidities  well-planned  prompt surgical intervention can yield successful outcomes.  Learning points/Discussion:  Patients known with AAA require regular follow-up; a sudden increase in size or onset of symptoms necessitates consideration for surgical intervention. An individualized approach to considering surgery for AAA patients must take into account the patient's entire health profile and symptomatology.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. J is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  currently residing in New York. He is a heavy smoker with a history of 40-pack years. He also has a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension.  Chief Complaint: Mr. J presented to the emergency department complaining of severe abdominal and lower back pain for the past six hours. The pain was described as constant  sharp  unbearable  and not relieved with over-the-counter analgesics.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He has had no previous surgical interventions. There is no known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  Mr. J was noted to be in severe distress due to pain. A pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable during the physical examination. The blood pressure was 174/92 mmHg  heart rate was 108 bpm and the temperature was 37.4°C. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: The initial laboratory evaluation was unexceptional. Abdominal ultra-sonography followed by confirmatory CT angiography revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 8cm in diameter  indicating imminent risk of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention: The findings were emergently discussed with the patient and informed consent was obtained for interventional surgery. An open surgical repair was carried via an infrarenal aortic graft replacement due to the location and size of the aneurysm. In the course of post-operative care  antihypertensive and analgesic medication were administered.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient's post-operative recovery was unremarkable. He was discharged after six days in the hospital. At his six-week follow-up  the patient reported no abdominal or back pain and his blood pressure was adequately controlled.   In Summary:  This case demonstrates the classic presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with severe abdominal and back pain with a pulsatile abdominal mass in an elderly male patient with a history of heavy smoking and uncontrolled hypertension. The patient was successfully managed with open surgical repair.   Lessons Learned:  Patients with risk factors such as older age  smoking  hypertension  and male sex should be evaluated for abdominal aortic aneurysms  particularly in the setting of abdominal or back pain. Early detection and management of abdominal aortic aneurysms can prevent catastrophic consequences of rupture.   Prevention methods  such as controlling blood pressure  quitting smoking  and managing blood cholesterol and glucose level  are essential in patients diagnosed with or at risk of AAA. Regular follow-ups and imaging studies are important for monitoring the aneurysm size.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old Male Patient: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by an abnormal enlargement of the abdominal aorta. This report describes a case of a ruptured AAA in a senior patient with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Case presentation:  The patient  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain radiating to his back. He had a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco smoking for the past 30 years (up to 20 cigarettes per day). He had no genetic disposition nor previous surgery history. He does not consume alcohol and had no known allergies.   Clinically  he was in obvious distress and diaphoretic. His vitals included a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the mid-abdominal area.  The patient was immediately managed with intravenous fluids  and analgesics and a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) abdomen was arranged  which confirmed the presence of a large  approximately 9.1 cm  ruptured AAA with evidence of retroperitoneal hematoma.   Due to the rapid deterioration in the patient's hemodynamic state  surgical consultation was obtained promptly  and an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was performed  which was successful.   Postoperatively  the patient was observed in the intensive care unit (ICU)  where he received blood transfusion  platelet transfusion  antihypertensive  analgesic and anticoagulant therapy. His recovery was uneventful  with gradual improvement in his blood pressure and decrease in his pain intensity. After two weeks of hospitalization and continued improvement  he was discharged with close outpatient follow-up arrangements.  Discussion and Conclusion:  This case illustrates the significant implications of prompt recognition and management of an AAA  particularly in patients with risk factors such as old age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a history of smoking. Though a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain is not exclusive to AAA  the presence of risk factors and a palpable abdominal mass should raise suspicion  prompting necessary diagnostic investigations. Emergency surgery  in this case  endovascular repair  can be lifesaving in preserving the patient's life.

Patient Profile: Mr. Norman Foster  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Mr. Foster made a visit to the emergency room complaining of persistent lower back and abdominal pain. The onset of pain was sudden and increased in severity over a short period of time.  Past Medical History: Mr. Foster has a known history of hypertension  for which he has been taking beta-blockers  as prescribed. However  his blood pressure has been mostly uncontrolled. He also reports a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit five years before the current visit. There is no history of diabetes mellitus  high cholesterol  or any significant family history of cardiovascular disease. Regular follow-ups have shown a slightly raised creatinine level indicative of renal dysfunction. No previous surgeries or hospital admissions were reported apart from routine health check-ups.  Social History: A retired accountant  Mr. F lives with his wife and son. He denied any alcohol abuse or use of psychoactive substances beyond smoking until five years ago.  Examination: On examination  he appeared to be slightly pale and in distress due to pain. His vitals were stable  however  with a blood pressure of 140/90. The abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile  expansile mass in the midline of the abdomen.  Investigations: Results from contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 6.5cm in its maximum diameter. An initial blood panel showed borderline anemia without any indications of infection or renal dysfunction.  Treatment: Mr. Foster was immediately admitted to the vascular surgery service for preoperative care. The patient and his family were diligently informed about the surgery and possible risks. The following day  Mr. Foster underwent successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).  Postoperative Care: The postoperative period was uneventful and the patient was sent home five days later. He is advised to have regular follow-ups with the vascular surgery and internal medicine team for constant monitoring of general wellbeing and the efficiency of the graft.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of regular follow-ups for patients with hypertension and a history of smoking in the timely diagnosis and management of abdominal aortic aneurysm. It also brings to focus the effectiveness of endovascular surgery in managing large infrarenal AAAs.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a High-Risk Elderly Male  Patient Information The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired construction worker  lives with his 70-year-old wife  and has two adult children living nearby. The patient is an ex-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol use.  Past Medical History The patient has a confirmed medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for which he has been under regular treatment for the past 15 years. He has also shown mild signs of early-stage chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and age-related arthritis in the past few years.  Complaint and Current Presentation The patient presented himself in the Emergency Department with sudden-onset  severe pain in the lower abdominal and lumbar area that radiated to his scrotum and thighs. He described the pain as constant and tearing. He also reported feelings of faintness and rapid heartbeats.  Diagnostic Assessment Physical examination showed the patient had a tender  pulsatile mass in the abdomen and was hypotensive. Laboratory tests confirmed a decreased level of hemoglobin  suggesting possible internal bleeding. An urgent abdominal ultrasound revealed a 9 cm aneurysm in the infra-renal part of the aorta with signs of rupture. A CT angiogram further confirmed these findings of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Therapeutic Intervention The patient was rushed in for an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) due to his high risk for an open surgical repair. A stent-graft was placed at the site of the aneurysm to prevent further rupture  under general anesthesia. The procedure went smoothly without any immediate complications.  Follow-Up and Outcome  After the surgery  the patient was closely monitored in the ICU for his vitals  and adequate analgesics were given to manage the postoperative pain. He made a slow but steady recovery and was discharged after 10 days. He was advised for regular follow-up every six months with ultrasound imaging to monitor the stent graft.  Teaching Points Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention. The management of AAA depends largely on the size of the aneurysm and the general health of the patient (as observed in this case  where the patient was considered a high-risk candidate for open surgery due to his age  COPD  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia). Regular follow-up postoperation is critical for such patients to monitor the patency of the stent-graft and possible endoleaks.

Title: A Case Report of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Male   Patient Information: Our patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history. He is a retired mechanic who lives with his wife and denies drug use or alcohol consumption. He has no family history of aneurysms or sudden cardiac death.  Clinical Findings: The patient was referred to the vascular clinic for evaluation of a pulsatile abdominal mass discovered during a routine physical examination. The patient denied any abdominal pain  changes in bowel habits  or loss of weight. On physical examination  the patient had a noticeable pulsatile mass approximately 4cm in diameter in the periumbilical region. There were no signs of peripheral vascular disease.  Timeline of Current Episode: The patient was not aware of his abdominal mass until it was discovered during his routine physical exam three weeks ago. He reported no symptoms priorly or since the time of discovery.  Diagnostic Assessment: The initial diagnosis was made clinically  based on the physical examination. An ultrasound of the abdomen was performed  and it confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a maximum diameter of 5.3 cm. A Computerized tomography angiography (CTA) of the abdomen and pelvis was subsequently performed to provide a detailed blueprint of the aneurysm and surrounding anatomy.   Therapeutic Intervention: Given that the aneurysm was >5 cm  surgical repair was planned. After shared decision-making with the patient  it was decided to undergo an Endovascular Aortic Repair (EVAR) procedure. The procedure was conducted without any immediate complications and he was kept under observation for a few days.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient had a swift recovery and was discharged a few days later. He was followed up at 1  3  6  and 12 months post-surgery and surveillance imaging showed no endoleaks  thus confirming a successful procedure. The patient had a good post-surgery course with no documented complications  and his most recent follow-up visit at 12 months post surgery showed the aneurysm remained stable without any evidence of expansion or leak.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief from the successful procedure and was adherent to the recommended follow-up surveillance  acknowledging the importance of early detection and appropriate intervention for such life-threatening conditions.  Informed consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.  This report further emphasizes the importance of meticulous physical examination and the crucial role it plays in the early detection of abdominal aortic aneurysms  allowing for appropriate intervention and thus preventing catastrophic consequences.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 52-year-old Male  Patient Profile:  Mr. X is a 52-year-old Caucasian male who presented himself at the emergency department complaining of severe abdominal pain that had been persistent for the last 48 hours. He is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history. His medical history underscores hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.  Medical History:  The patient is known to have had hypertension for the last 15 years which has been controlled with antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril). Six years ago  he was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia and has since been on statin (atorvastatin) therapy to manage cholesterol levels.  Family History:  Mr. X has a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 57. His older brother underwent a surgical intervention for an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 57.  Current Presentation and Examination:  The patient reported an intense and constant pain in his abdominal region that seemed to radiate to his lower back. The pain was described as sharp in nature. He also reported feeling lightheaded. His initial BP was 160/90 mmHg with a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute.  Clinical examination revealed an irregularly pulsatile abdominal mass  slightly tender to touch. His systemic review was comparatively unremarkable  with the exception of reported mild dyspnea.  Investigations:  An urgent ultrasound examination of his abdomen was carried out indicating a fusiform abdominal aorta measuring 7.0 cm in diameter confirming an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   A computer tomography angiogram (CTA) was subsequently performed  which further confirmed the ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosis. Blood tests indicated mild anemia  possibly due to chronic blood loss  and normal kidney function tests.  Treatment and Outcome:  Due to the clinical presentation  patient's medical and familial history  an emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was recommended. The patient was promptly limited to nil per os (NPO) and IV hydration was started. The patient underwent successful EVAR without any complications. His postoperative recovery was relatively uneventful.  Currently  Mr. X is monitored closely  with regular ultrasound surveillance recommended every 6 months. He was advised to quit smoking and was referred to a smoking cessation clinic. His blood pressure and cholesterol-lowering medications were also optimized for better control.  Summary:  This case report illustrates the significance of recognizing the symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  especially in high-risk patients who have significant smoking history  hypertension  and a family history of aortic diseases.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  The patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian male  retired  and living in a rural area. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago after an approximate 35-year history of more than a pack a day. He regularly consumes alcohol  reportedly a pint of whiskey every two days. His diet is high in red meat  and he follows a sedentary lifestyle. He reports a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died from a myocardial infarction in his late 70s.   Current health complaints and History of Present Illness:  The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain radiating to his back for the past 3 hours. He reported having mild and intermittent episodes of similar  but much less severe  lower abdominal pain for the past month.   Past Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with mild hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He suffered a bout of pneumonia 2 years ago but had a full recovery. He has no history of surgeries and there is no noted allergy in his medical records.   Clinical Findings:  At presentation  the patient was restless. His blood pressure was 190/100 mmHg  pulse was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute with clear lung field  and his temperature was 99°F. His abdomen was soft and mildly tender in the periumbilical region. Blood tests showed an elevated white blood cell count of 15 000 cells/mm³  and an increased serum creatinine level of 2 mg/dL.  Imaging Studies:  A CT (Computed Tomography) angiogram of the abdomen and pelvis was performed which revealed a 6.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm extending to the bifurcation with signs of impending rupture but no active contrast extravasation.   Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's symptoms  physical assessments  and the CT angiogram results  a diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm was made.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately transferred for emergency open laparotomy and repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm. Post-surgery  he was monitored in the intensive care unit. He was administered broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent infection and given analgesics for pain management. The postoperative period was uneventful  and he was discharged home after ten days with instructions to adhere to his prescribed medications  change his lifestyle  switch to a healthier diet  quit alcohol  and regularly follow up with his healthcare provider.  This case report emphasizes the potential of high-risk patients to develop abdominal aortic aneurysms and that early detection and prompt  decisive management could be lifesaving.

Title: Case Report on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an 84-Year-old Male Patient  Patient Profile: Name: (Anonymous) Age: 84 Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Summary:  The patient presented to the hospital complaining of a sudden onset of severe lower back pain. He described the pain as sharp and persistent  pain score 8/10. He has a known history of hypertension  coronary artery disease  and smoking  but no known allergies or prior surgical history. The patient is currently on medication for his hypertension and has a BMI of 28  classified as overweight.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the patient appeared in severe distress due to intense discomfort. His blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  he exhibited a tachycardic heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and his respiratory rate was slightly elevated at 20 breaths per minute. His temperature was 98.8°F. Palpation of the abdomen revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area  causing considerable discomfort.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Due to the presented symptoms and findings during the physical examination  an urgent abdominal ultrasound was requested. The ultrasound demonstrated a 6.2 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. An emergent computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the presence of the abdominal aortic aneurysm  which was 6.2 cm at its widest diameter  and also revealed signs of impending rupture with an increase in the retroperitoneal fat stranding.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was emergently transferred to the vascular surgery department and underwent an open surgical repair for the aneurysm with a Dacron graft. The surgery was successful and without complications. The patient's post-operative course was uneventful. He was discharged after 7 days of hospital stay with advice on smoking cessation and appropriate medication for control of his blood pressure. Subsequent follow-ups showed the graft in place with no sign of leakage or recurrence of the aneurysm.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of high vigilance for abdominal aortic aneurysm in elderly male patients with a history of cardiovascular disease and smoking. The early recognition  diagnosis  and prompt surgical intervention were vital elements that led to the successful management of the patient's life-threatening condition.  Conclusion:  Regular screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm as part of cardiovascular disease management might help identify such cases early in high-risk groups - males  over 65  smoking history  and hypertension  leading to better prognosis and potentially lower morbidity and mortality rates.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report   Patient Information:  An 80-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department (ED) of our hospital facility. The patient revealed he lives on his own in a metropolitan area and used to work as an engineer. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago  and drinks socially with history of moderate alcohol use in his adult life. He has no history of drug use.  Chief Complaint:  The patient reported sudden  severe abdominal and lower back pain for the past several hours. The pain  rated an 8 on a scale of 10  was described as a tearing sensation  encompassing his entire abdominal region and extending to the lower back.  History of Past Illness:  The patient has a known history of hypertension (HTN) and hyperlipidemia  controlled with antihypertensive and statin therapy  respectively. His other chronic conditions included type II diabetes mellitus and gout. He underwent an appendectomy in his mid-20s and has no known allergies.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appeared in severe discomfort. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats/min  respiratory rate 20 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Abdominal examination displayed a tender  pulsatile abdominal mass. No other abnormalities were noted.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The findings from the physical examination raised a high suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This suspicion was confirmed with an emergent CT angiography showing a 7.8 cm infrarenal AAA with signs of rupture. Laboratory results included normal Complete Blood Count (CBC)  Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP)  and slightly elevated Troponin level.  Therapeutic Interventions:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  the surgical team was consulted immediately and the patient was taken to the operating room for an emergent open surgical repair of the AAA. The surgery was successful  and the patient was monitored in an intensive care unit (ICU) post-operatively.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  His postoperative course was uncomplicated  and the patient was subsequently moved to a step-down unit. He was discharged home to self-care on postoperative day seven  with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician and the surgical team. At his six-month follow-up visit  the patient's condition was stable  with resolution of his abdominal pain  and he was asymptomatic.  Patient Perspective:  ""I'm fortunate to have received swift treatment once the severity of my situation was known. The reality of my diagnosis was shocking  but I am thankful for the medical intervention and follow-up care that I received.""  Informed Consent:  The patient provided informed consent for the case report to be published.  Conclusion:  This case brings to light the importance of a rapid diagnostic assessment and intervention in elderly patients presenting with abdominal pain of unclear origin. Given that abdominal aortic aneurysms are often asymptomatic until rupture  a high degree of clinical suspicion and the appropriate imaging are important in achieving a timely diagnosis and intervention  particularly in patients with identified risk factors.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Male  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year history of smoking.  Presenting Problem:  The patient visited the health care clinic with complaints of occasional mild abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. No instances of severe  sharp  or sudden pain were reported. The patient also mentioned a feeling of fullness in the abdomen  but no change in appetite or unexplained weight loss.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass could be palpated in the periumbilical area. No signs of external inflammation  extensive bruising or audible bruits were noted. Blood pressure was slightly elevated 140/90 mmHg consistent with his hypertensive history. Routine lab tests revealed normal kidney and liver functions.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An abdominal ultrasound was conducted on the patient revealing an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring approximately 5.6 cm in diameter  located below the renal arteries. The wall of the aorta was noted as thin  consistent with aneurysmal changes. No evidence of rupture or dissection was reported.  Therapeutic Intervention:  As the patient had a large AAA and was symptomatic  he was admitted immediately for urgent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) surgery. The operation was successful  and follow-up post-surgical radiograph and ultrasound confirm the appropriate placement and functioning of the graft.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  Postoperative period was uneventful without any complications. The patient had maintained lower blood pressure levels  and cessation of smoking was strongly encouraged. The patient was recommended for regular follow-up comprehensive examinations which should include abdominal ultrasound every 6 months to monitor the status of the grafted site.  Conclusion:  The case emphasizes the need for high suspicion toward abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients at risk  especially older males with a history of tobacco use and hypertension. Regular diagnostic screening and prompt treatment for AAA are very crucial and can be lifesaving. This case also indicates the crucial importance of patient education about lifestyle modifications  particularly smoking cessation which remains a major modifiable risk factor for AAA.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Male: Pathophysiology  Diagnosis  and Management  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the hospital with sudden  severe abdominal pain. He is a lifelong resident of Houston  Texas  USA  and a retired chemical engineer. He is a nonsmoker and drinks moderate alcohol only socially. His family history includes hypertension (both parents) and coronary artery disease (father).  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed for the past ten years with appropriate medical therapies. He had a colonoscopy at age 50  which was normal. He is non-compliant with preventative health visits for annual physical exams. His last visit to the primary care physician was eighteen months prior to this current presentation.  Presenting Complaints: The patient complained of sudden onset  severe pain in his abdomen that radiated to his back. He described it as the worst pain he had ever experienced and rated it as 10 on a scale of 10. There was associated nausea but no vomiting  fever  or chills.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a hypotensive (88/58 mmHg) and tachycardic (125 bpm) elderly male in severe distress. Abdominal examination disclosed a pulsatile abdominal mass with severe tenderness including guarding and rebound.  Diagnostic Assessment: A swift diagnosis of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (rAAA) was suspected based on the classical triad - hypotension  pulsatile abdominal mass  and severe abdominal pain. The clinician urgently requisitioned an abdominal CT scan which confirmed the diagnosis of rAAA.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient promptly underwent emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). His postoperative period was monitored in ICU  where he received input from cardiologists and endocrinologists for his other chronic health issues.  Follow-up and Outcomes: His postoperative phase was noteworthy for fever on day 2  managed by broad-spectrum antibiotics until cultures returned negative. He was discharged home on postoperative day 8 with a stable condition after full recovery from the acute episode.  Patient Perspective: The patient was appreciative of the urgency and coordinated care provided and committed to maintaining regular health check visits.  Learning Points: 1. rAAA is a medical urgency and high index of suspicion is needed for diagnosis. 2. Multidisciplinary team approach is essential for managing such complex patients. 3. Regular patient follow-up in outpatient clinics is crucial for early diagnosis and intervention to prevent such life-threatening events.  References:  This case report is a hypothetical patient and does not refer to any single actual patient treated. Any resemblance is purely coincidental.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information  The case concerns a 67-year-old Caucasian male  a retired teacher  presenting with a two-week history of moderate  intermittent abdominal discomfort and lower back pain. There is no change in bowel or bladder function  no fever  or weight loss. The patient lives with his wife  has a 30-year history of smoking (20-25 cigarettes per day) but quit two years ago  exercises regularly  and consumes alcohol occasionally. Previous medical interventions include a hernia repair operation 15 years ago  and he is on medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years.  Clinical Findings  On physical examination  no significant cutaneous manifestation was found. His vitals were stable with a blood pressure reading of 150/90mm Hg and heart rate of 80 beats per minute. Routine respiratory and cardiovascular examination was unremarkable. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable  pulsatile mass in the epigastrium. There was no evidence of peripheral vascular disease.   Diagnostic Assessment   Laboratory tests including complete blood count  kidney function tests  and coagulation profile were within the normal range. Fasting lipid profile showed elevated LDL cholesterol levels. An Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen was advised  which indicated signs of a 5.5-cm aneurysmal dilatation in the infra-renal part of the abdominal aorta with no evidence of rupture or thrombus. Diagnostic evaluation by contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) confirmed the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  5.5cm in diameter. The CT scan also revealed that the aneurysm was not causing any compression on adjacent structures.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for consultation regarding management of the AAA. After considering the patient's overall health and the size of the aneurysm  it was decided to perform an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The procedure was successfully performed with stent-graft placement  and the patient was discharged on post-procedure day five with advice on regular follow-ups.   Follow-up and Outcome  On the first follow-up visit  four weeks after surgery  the patient reported a significant reduction in abdominal discomfort. An ultrasound was performed  demonstrating the patent stent-graft with no signs of endoleak or aneurysm expansion. The patient was further advised to continue antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications and to return for follow-ups in six months or earlier if symptoms manifest.   Patient Perspective   The patient was satisfied with his care. He expressed relief from resolution of his discomfort and fear of aneurysm rupture. He committed to follow-up appointments and maintenance of a healthy lifestyle.  Informed Consent  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an 80-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  I. Introduction  This clinical case involves an 80-year-old Caucasian male with a confirmed diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the tertiary care clinic.  II. Patient Information  The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian male  residing in rural Arkansas  with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both under pharmacological treatment. The patient has been previously diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and has a 50-pack year history of smoking  though he stopped ten years ago. He lives alone  has never been married  and has no children. The patient's mother died from an aneurysm at the age of 79 and his father died from prostate cancer in his mid-70s.   III. Clinical Findings  The patient presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of generalized abdominal pain that had been waxing and waning for the last few days. On physical examination  he had a tender  pulsatile abdominal mass. There was no apparent pain on percussion. Vital signs were stable except for mildly elevated blood pressure (155/85 mmHg). Laboratory findings  including complete blood count  kidney function  and liver function  were within normal limits.  IV. Timeline  The patient first noticed the pain four days prior to presentation when it was subtle and sporadic. The pain intensity gradually increased  prompting him to seek medical advice. The multi-disciplinary team was engaged immediately after presentation for ongoing management.  V. Diagnostic Assessment  An abdominal ultrasound confirmed a 5.6 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. An aortogram provided an enhanced visualization of the aneurysm  yielding similar measurements. No impending signs of rupture were noted. The patient's aneurysm was classified as infrarenal.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention  Considering the patient's age and size of the aneurysm  the vascular surgery team recommended an elective open surgical repair (OSR) of the aneurysm. The procedure was explained to the patient  including potential risks and complications  to which he provided informed consent.  VII. Follow-Up and Outcomes   The patient underwent a successful OSR without intraoperative complications. His postoperative recovery was uneventful  and after a week  he was discharged with close outpatient follow-up appointments. An ultrasound scan  performed six weeks post-surgery  revealed no residual or recurrent aneurysm. The patient was advised to maintain regular follow-ups and adhere to his hypertensive and hyperlipidemia medication regimen.  VIII. Patient Perspective  The patient verbally expressed relief subsequent to his recovery and stated his satisfaction with the care he received.  IX. Learning Points  This case underscores the importance of prompt recognition and management of AAA in high-risk patients  considering their age  gender  history of smoking  genetics  and hypertension. This early intervention is critical to prevent potential fatal complications such as rupture.   Furthermore  it emphasizes the role of regular screening programs in high-risk patient populations  such as males over 65 with a history of smoking or family history of AAA  to facilitate early detection and management.

Title: An Atypical Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction: A 68-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department with sudden and severe back pain  centered towards his lower back region. The initial differential diagnosis was based around musculoskeletal pain as he has a past medical history of arthritis and degenerative disc disease. Subsequently  his abdominal examination revealed an unanticipated finding that steered toward the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Patient Information: Mr. M  a retired construction foreman  was brought to the emergency department by his wife. He is 5'10"" in height and weighs around 210 lbs. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history before stopping 5 years ago. He has hypertension  controlled with antihypertensive medication (amlodipine)  arthritis  degenerative disc disease  and a history of coronary artery disease without any prior cardiac surgery requirement.  Clinical Findings:  The patient described his pain as ""a tearing sensation"" that began suddenly whilst bending to lift a heavy object. He denied having any abdominal pain  chest pain  nausea  vomiting or any loss of consciousness. On physical examination  the patient appeared to be in distress  with a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  and respirations at 22 per minute. His abdomen was soft but showed a pulsatile mass in the peri-umbilical region.   Diagnostic Assessment: The patient’s hematological and biochemical parameters were within the normal range. Given the unexpected abdominal examination findings  an urgent CT scan was completed  which revealed a 7.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was emergently consulted to the vascular surgical team and was subsequently taken to the operating room for an open surgical repair of his AAA. An aorto-bi-iliac graft was successfully placed.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient’s postoperative period was uneventful. Pain subsided and he was transferred to a regular ward on day 3 of recovery. He was discharged home on day 7 after tolerating normal diet and independent ambulation. At his one month follow-up appointment  the patient was free of any abdominal or back pain  and a duplex ultrasound demonstrated the graft to be patent.   Patient Perspective: Mr. M reported that he had no knowledge of AAA prior to his surgical intervention. He was grateful for the timely diagnosis and management  attributing his recovery to the early detection of the disease  even though the presentation was misleading.  Conclusion: Although this case initially pointed toward musculoskeletal pain  the inclusion of an AAA in the differential diagnosis demonstrates the importance of a comprehensive medical examination. It underlines the significance of considering an AAA among the elderly population  even in the absence of the classic symptomatic triad: abdominal pain  hypotension  and a pulsatile mass.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Complaints: Intermittent episodes of severe abdominal and back pain during the past month.  Past Medical History: The patient had hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years  under medication with atorvastatin and amlodipine. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since his early 20s but quit five years ago following his primary care physician's advice to control his blood pressure and lipid levels. He is also a social drinker and does not use any illegal substances. His other past medical history includes appendectomy 20 years prior and pneumonia three years ago. He has no known allergies.   Family Medical History: His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his mother had a stroke at the age of 80 but survived  he also has one older brother who was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. No known family history of any connective tissue diseases or aneurysms.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination demonstrated a pulsatile abdominal mass upon palpation. No bruits could be heard over the mass. Legs were symmetrically normal with no noticeable difference in pulses. No signs of acute limb ischemia or embolic phenomena were present.   Diagnostic Assessment: An abdominal ultrasound was obtained which showed a dilated aorta measuring approximately 6.5 cm in diameter. Immediate computed tomographic angiography was done and confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  with a maximum diameter of 6.8 cm without signs of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention: Given the size of the AAA and the risk of rupture  the patient was referred urgently to vascular surgery. An endovascular stent graft was placed to seal the aneurysm site  and the procedure was completed without complications. The patient was monitored in the ICU for several days before being transferred to the medical ward.   Follow up: The patient was given follow-up appointments for clinical check-ups and radiological evaluation of the stent placement and aneurysm. Alongside  he was advised to continue lifestyle modifications  maintain control of blood pressure  ensure statin intake and avoid heavy lifting or straining. He was advised to notice and report the signs of possible complications such as shortness of breath  chest  abdominal  or back pain.   Conclusion: AAA is a severe  and life-threatening condition often presented with a pulsatile abdominal mass  and prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent fatal outcomes. High-risk individuals like elderly male  smokers  hypertensive  and hyperlipidemic should receive regular screenings to detect an AAA early in its course.

Title: Emergency Management of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient – A case report.  Introduction:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) refers to the enlargement of the abdominal aorta  often posing a significant risk of rupture  leading to life-threatening hemorrhage. It is most commonly seen in elderly men with a history of smoking or hypertension. This case report presents an elderly male patient presenting to the emergency department (ED) with abdominal pain and diagnosed with an AAA.  Patient Information:  Mr. X  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  was brought to the ED with complaints of acute onset  severe abdominal and lower back pain. The patient is a former smoker with a 30 year smoking history but quit approximately ten years ago. He has an established history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral vascular disease. His medications include daily aspirin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril.  Clinical Findings:  Upon presentation  the patient was anxious and pale with a mildly distended abdomen. His vitals were: blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  pulse rate 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate 22/minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was felt in the mid-abdominal region  suggestive of an aneurysmal enlargement of the abdominal aorta. Laboratory findings showed an elevated white cell count and D-dimer level.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the abdomen revealed a 7.5 cm infrarenal AAA with signs of impending rupture. No immediate signs of active bleeding were evident.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the imminent threat of rupture  the patient was hastily prepped for surgery. He underwent an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) which successfully excluded the aneurysm from systemic circulation. The procedure was uneventful  and the patient was stabilized post-operatively.  Follow-up and Outcome:  Post-operatively  the patient was monitored in the intensive care unit (ICU). He was discharged on the 10th postoperative day in stable condition. He has since been followed up in the vascular surgery outpatient's department  with no sign of reperfusion or endoleak evident on follow-up imaging. He is managed on antihypertensives  statins  and regular follow-up to monitor his condition.  Discussion:  In this case  the patient's history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia were contributing factors to the AAA. AAAs often remain asymptomatic until rupture  making timely diagnosis and management crucial. A high index of suspicion along with swift diagnosis and intervention can be life-saving.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the need for heightened vigilance in at-risk individuals presenting with abdominal and lower back pain. Earlier diagnosis could prevent rupture of an AAA  reducing mortality and morbidity in this patient population.

Case Report: Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the outpatient department of our hospital. He was brought by his daughter who mentioned that he had been complaining of severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that started two days ago. He was experiencing persistent lower back pain  coupled with intermittent episodes of lightheadedness.  Medical History:  The patient is a former smoker and quit smoking 20 years ago after a 30-year smoking history. He is known to have hypertension for the past 15 years and has been on antihypertensive medication. He has a history of dyslipidemia for over ten years. He has no known drug allergies. Family history revealed that the patient's father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 70.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient had a blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg and a heart rate of 78 beats per minute. His abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midabdominal region  which was tender on palpation. There was no evidence of a pulsatile mass in the inguinal region or any bruit over the abdominal aorta.  Diagnostic Assessment and Intervention:  A computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No sign of rupture was evident. Lab results including complete blood count  kidney and liver function were within normal limits. Considering his age  medical history  and the size of the aneurysm  he was promptly referred for an Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR).  The patient underwent successful EVAR without any complication and was monitored in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for 48 hours post-surgery. The patient reported relief from the abdominal pain and was hemodynamically stable.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  A hospital-based follow-up was scheduled within two weeks following discharge and then at three-month intervals to monitor the progress. Regular ultrasound screenings were advised to examine any potential endoleak from the procedure. The patient was counseled about the risks and benefits of statin therapy for dyslipidaemia  considering his history  and appropriate antihypertensive medication adjustments were made. The patient was also advised of the need for regular exercise and a balanced low-salt  low-cholesterol diet to maintain overall cardiovascular health.    This case highlights the importance of timely intervention in patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms factors  considering their age and other risk factors  to prevent serious complications associated with rupture.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in 73-Year-Old Male  Patient Profile: Mr. X is a 73-year-old Caucasian male  a retired mechanical engineer  who resides with his wife. He exhibits no history of allergies. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit twenty years ago. His alcohol consumption is minimal  with only occasional wine consumption with meals. He follows a balanced diet and his BMI is within normal parameters.  Medical History: The patient possesses a notable medical history of hypertension controlled by ACE inhibitors  and a familial history of cardiovascular disease; his father died due to myocardial infarction at age 56. There is no manifest history of peripheral vascular or other cardiovascular disease. The patient was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus approximately ten years prior and has maintained good glycemic control through diet and oral hypoglycemic agents.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. X presented to his general physician with primary complaints of abdominal pain symptoms and lower back discomfort  particularly after meals which had been increasing in intensity over the few last weeks.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. There was no evidence of renal insufficiency or peripheral vascular disease.   Further Management: Considering his age  smoking history  hypertension  and observed abdominal mass in a routine physical examination  the general practitioner suspected an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and arranged for an urgent ultrasound.  Outcome of Investigations: The ultrasonography showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm in diameter  confirming the suspicions. No signs of rupture or peripheral embolization were found. An entire aortoiliac CT angiography was requested to better delineate the aneurysm and for pre-operative planning purpose.   Treatment and Condition after Intervention: Seeing the size of AAA and symptoms  Mr X was referred for urgent vascular surgical intervention. He successfully underwent an endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) and post-operative recovery was unremarkable apart from a minor wound infection which was managed conservatively with antibiotics. Mr. X expressed relief of his abdominal and back discomfort post-operatively.  Follow-up: The patient is scheduled for follow-up visits with imaging at three  six  and twelve months intervals and annually thereafter to monitor for aneurysm-related complications.   In conclusion  this case report reiterates the importance of considering AAA in the differential diagnosis of abdominal pain or discomfort  particularly in males of advanced age with a history of smoking and hypertension.

Patient Presentation   Introduction: Mr. A is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presented with abdominal and lower back pain that had lasted the entire weekend. His pain level was described as a 6/10  dull in nature and non-radiating. Upon clinical examination  a pulsating mass near the navel was noticed. He also claimed that he had been feeling ""quite tired"" for several weeks prior to this episode.   Clinical History:  Mr. A is a smoker  consuming approximately one pack of cigarettes per day for the last 50 years. He has a history of hypertension under control with lisinopril  and he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia ten years ago  being managed by statin therapy. His BMI score of 31 classifies him as obese. He also mentioned that he has been experiencing difficulty with micturition.   Family History:  Mr. A's father had a history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and passed away from a ruptured AAA at the age of 78 years. His mother died of heart disease at the age of 75. He has two elder brothers who are hypertensive and one of them had a myocardial infarction.   Physical Examination: On presentation  he is alert and oriented  not in acute distress. His BP is 150/90 mmHg  HR 85 bpm  and his BMI is 31. Physical examination noted a pulsatile mass in his abdomen.  Investigations: The point-of-care ultrasound showed an aorta of approximately 5 cm in diameter. A confirmatory CT angiogram displayed an infrarenal AAA of 5.2 cm diameter with no signs of rupture.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical history  physical examinations  and investigations  the patient was diagnosed with abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management:  He was referred to a Vascular Surgeon for further assessment and management. He was also educated on the risks of rupture of the aneurysm and the imperative need to quit smoking to reduce his cardiovascular risk factors.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of early detection and treatment of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  especially in patients with a high-risk profile such as advanced age  long-term smoking  obesity  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and positive family history.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 68-year-old male known as Mr. Adam Williams. He is a retired school teacher and resides with his wife in their suburban home. He identifies as Caucasian  hails from Irish descent  and served briefly in the army during his younger years. His chief complaint is a progressively worsening  constant  throbbing pain in his mid-to-lower abdomen and lower back that's been making him very uncomfortable for the past three weeks.  Medical History:  Mr. Williams was diagnosed as hypertensive about 10 years ago  and he has been controlling his blood pressure with regular medication (Lisinopril). Five years ago  he was diagnosed with moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  a consequence of his 30-year smoking history. He quit smoking immediately after his COPD diagnosis. He also suffers from hyperlipidemia but has diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus in good control with metformin. He has no known allergies to medications.  Family History:  There is a significant familial predisposition to cardiovascular diseases. Mr Williams' father died of a heart attack at 72  while his mother had a stroke at the age of 76. His only sibling  a brother  has had coronary artery bypass surgery at 65. There is no family history of aneurysms.  Clinical Examination and Diagnosis:  On examination  a pulsating mass was noted in the mid-abdominal area. Upon suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  an abdominal ultrasound was ordered  which confirmed a 5.5 cm AAA (abdominal aortic aneurysm). He also underwent a chest X-ray and echocardiogram due to his severe COPD  which revealed moderate left ventricular hypertrophy  but no other significant anomalies.   Given the size of the aneurysm and taking into consideration the patient's overall health and family history were taken into account  he was referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation. His shortness of breath and palpitation during mild activity have made the cardiothoracic teams suggest that he may need elective surgical repair of the aneurysm.  In conclusion  Mr Williams  a 68-year-old ex-smoker with a history of hypertension  COPD  and hyperlipidemia  presents with an MRI-confirmed abdominal aortic aneurysm of 5.5 cm. The aneurysm's size  coupled with his other risk factors  suggests a high risk of rupture  requiring further surgical evaluation.  For future medical management  he was advised to maintain strict control of his blood pressure and to assess lipid status to prevent complications of his aneurysm and lessen the risk of other cardiovascular diseases. He was also recommended to have follow-up assessments every six months to monitor his condition.

Case Presentation  Demographics: Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired factory worker. He is a non-smoker and has a moderate alcohol history.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with a complaint of severe  unrelenting pain in the middle of his abdomen and back  which began suddenly while lifting a heavy box.  Medical History: The patient has history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years  managed under medication. He has been treated in the past for peripheral arterial disease. He has no known allergies and indicates he is up to date with his vaccinations. He does not have any history of surgeries. He admits non-compliance with both diet and medications  with frequent lapses.  Family History: The patient has a strong family history of cardiac disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 55  and his mother having high blood pressure. His brother was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at age 64 but declined surgery.  Physical Examination: The patient appears to be in severe pain  pale  and slightly diaphoretic. He's afebrile with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 110/min  and respiratory rate of 20/min. On physical examination  the abdomen is soft  and pulsatile mass is palpable in the mid and upper part of the abdomen. No other significant findings were noted.  Investigations: Lab tests revealed normal renal function  but elevated white blood cell count suggesting possible infection. An urgent CT-Angiogram revealed a 7cm abdominal aortic aneurysm with evidence of rupture.  Diagnosis: Based on history  physical examination  and imaging  the patient was diagnosed with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment and Plan: The patient was admitted to Intensive Care Unit and emergent surgical consultation was sought. Due to the patient's age and the risks associated with open surgery  both patient and surgical team decided on endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) as the treatment modality. He was scheduled for emergent intervention. The patient was also counselled regarding the importance of medication compliance and a heart-healthy diet.

Patient Profile:   The patient  Mr. Smith  is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who resides in Charleston  South Carolina. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases as both his father and uncle died of heart attacks in their late 60s. He has been a smoker for 40+ years and has a history of high blood pressure  though he has not been consistent with his medication regimen. Professionally  he is a retired engineer who lives with his 65-year-old wife in a suburban neighborhood.  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe and persistent abdominal pain and lower back pain  which had begun that morning. He describes the pain as a constant and sharp sensation.  Clinical Findings:   Upon physical examination  a pulsating mass was palpable in his lower abdomen  and he had a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg. Basic blood profiles showed elevated white blood cell counts of 13 000 cells/mm^3. His cholesterol and serum creatinine levels were also higher than the normal range.  Imaging:   A triplex ultrasonography was immediately ordered upon suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  which confirmed a 6cm infrarenal AAA. The aneurysm appeared to be leaking  which was likely causing his severe pain.   Diagnosis:   The presence of a large pulsating abdominal mass  characteristic pain  and ultrasonography findings confirmed the diagnosis of a rapidly expanding or possibly leaking abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment Plan:  Given the size of the aneurysm and his pain  he was immediately evaluated for surgical repair. Emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was performed to prevent rupture  the risk of which was increased due to the size and expansion of the aneurysm.  Aftercare:  Post-surgery  Mr. Smith will require a closely monitored recovery period  including regular check-ups to assess the successful integration of the graft and ensure there is no leak. Lifestyle modifications were also affirmed  including a well-rounded diet  regular exercise  smoking cessation  and moderating alcohol intake  to control his blood pressure and cholesterol levels. It is essential to provide him with regular monitoring and medication control for his hypertension management.  He is also advised to communicate the hereditary nature of cardiovascular diseases to his children so that they can proactively monitor their heart health. Given how late Mr. Smith's AAA was detected  his children would benefit from occasional ultrasound screenings for AAA  which can be life-saving for those with a family history of cardiovascular disease.

Patient Identification and Background: Mr. Edward Green  a 67-year-old Caucasian male who resides in Brooklyn  New York has been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient is retired and lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver.   Presenting Issue:  Mr. Green initially presented with complaints of steady middle abdominal pain and occasional lower back pain which he had been experiencing for about two weeks. No incidents of fainting  light-headedness  rapid heart rate or weakness on one side of the body were recorded and the patient does not have a history of palpitations or shortness of breath.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  the patient appeared visibly discomforted with the abdominal pain. His pulse was stable but the physician was able to palpate an expansive aortic pulsation in the abdomen about 6cm in width. There were no symptoms of rupture like extreme pain  hypotension  or loss of consciousness.   Medical History: Mr. Green was previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which he has been managing with diet  medication  and regular exercise. He underwent an appendectomy when he was young but other than that  no significant surgical history. He has regularly used alcohol and tobacco for 40 years but quit smoking five years ago.   Family History: Mr. Green’s father died of a ruptured AAA at the age of 70. His mother died from a stroke at the age of 75. There is no other significant family history of heart disease  aneurysms  or genetic disorders.   Diagnostic Evaluation: For further evaluation  a Contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan was performed which confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal AAA.   Management Plan: Given the size of the aneurysm and the associated risk of rupture  the vascular surgery team was consulted and an elective open surgical repair of the aneurysm was recommended. Mr. Green was counseled about the risks and benefits of the surgery and the importance of regular follow-ups thereafter.  Discussion: Abdominal aortic aneurysm's risk factors are notably the patient’s advanced age  genetic predisposition  and a history of hypertension  smoking  and hyperlipidemia  as in this case. Early detection and surgical intervention are crucial in preventing potentially life-threatening ruptures.   Conclusion: This case presentation clearly demonstrates classical manifestations of undiagnosed AAA  emphasizing the importance of timely investigation and intervention  especially in high-risk patients with specifics in their medical and family history.

Patient Presentation: J.D.  a seventy-two-year-old male of African American descent  has presented to the emergency department complaining of severe abdominal pain  radiating to his low back and groin. He also reported feeling light-headed with a transient loss of consciousness an hour prior to admission. His vital signs on arrival were blood pressure 90/50 mmHg  heart rate 84 bpm  respiratory rate 16 bpm  and temperature 98.6°F. He is a retired lawyer  widowed  with two adult children  and lives alone. He does not smoke or consume alcohol but struggled with obesity for many years.   Past Medical History: His past medical history includes type II diabetes diagnosed fifteen years ago  which he manages with Metformin and lifestyle modification. He also has been diagnosed with hypertension for eight years for which he takes Lisinopril  but he admits to not always adhering to the medication regimen. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with high cholesterol and coronary artery disease for which he had undergone angioplasty. He currently takes Atorvastatin for cholesterol control.   Family History: His father died from a heart attack at the age of 70  and his mother passed away due to stroke disease in her late 60s. He also reported that his brother underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm several years back.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination showed moderate-severe tenderness in the middle and lower abdomen. His abdomen is not distended  but a pulsatile mass was palpable on deep palpation in the periumbilical region. Blood work indicated a moderately elevated white blood cell count  suggestive of systemic infection. An urgent CT scan showed a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (8cm in diameter) with evidence of impending rupture.  Diagnosis:  The diagnosis of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm was made based on his clinical history  physical examination and radiography findings.  Plan: Immediate surgical consultation is called for  and the patient is prepared for emergent endovascular aneurysm repair. The patient was also counseled about the seriousness of his condition  the nature of the surgical procedure  and potential risks involved. Antihypertensive treatment will be re-evaluated after surgery to ensure better blood pressure control. It's also recommended for his children to undergo screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm due to the familial link.    Teaching: Abdominal aortic aneurysms are more common in males  smokers  and have a strong genetic component. A family history of aortic aneurysm significantly increases the risk. High blood pressure adds to the threat by causing wear and tear of the aorta  hence the importance of adhering to antihypertensive treatment. Screening and early detection can save lives.  Prognosis: Prognosis depends on successful surgical intervention  and the ability to manage associated comorbidities including hypertension  dyslipidemia  and diabetes. Early detection before rupture significantly improves outcomes. With successful surgery and good post-operative care  the survival rate can be as high as 95%.

Patient Identification:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  who was an active smoker from age 18 to 65 (around 47 pack-years) but quit five years ago. Visible signs of underweight are present. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has been reticent to commit to regular physical activities.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient complained of vague abdominal pain that has been persisting for the last few weeks. The pain is associated with episodes of nausea and occasional vomiting. He denies any chest pain  weight loss  loss of appetite  or recent onset constipation.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with Hypertension 15 years ago  which is well-controlled with medication. He also has a history of dyslipidemia for the past 10 years and has been on statin therapy. There is no past history of any major surgery or blood transfusion.   Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 76 and his mother died of lung cancer at the age of 70. He has two siblings; an elder brother diagnosed with an abdominal aneurysm and an elder sister with no significant known diseases.   Physical Examination: On examination  the patient was afebrile. Blood pressure was 135/85 mmHg and heart rate 76 bpm. On palpation  there was a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Other findings were within normal limits.  Investigations:  Complete blood count and kidney function test were normal. Lipid profile showed raised LDL levels. An abdominal ultrasound was done which showed a bulging area in the lower part of the aorta that measures more than 3 centimeters  suggestive an aortic aneurysm.  Diagnosis:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.  Management Plan:  Considering the patient’s age  clinical signs  and risks associated with surgical repair  a conservative management strategy was initiated. Statins were continued. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle to lower blood pressure and reduce the risk of rupture. Regular follow-ups were advised to monitor the size of the aneurysm. In case of rapid enlargement or symptomatic  surgical intervention might be considered in the future.   It was recommended that the patient's immediate relatives get screened for an abdominal aortic aneurysm considering the family history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Patient Education: The patient was informed about the need for close monitoring of his condition  the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle modifications  and adhering to follow-up regimens. He was also advised to immediately seek medical help if he experiences sudden severe pain in his abdomen or back  clammy or sweaty skin  or other symptoms of a ruptured aortic aneurysm.   In conclusion: This case presents the unique challenges of managing aortic aneurysm in elderly patients with other comorbidities and emphasizes the importance of a holistic approach in treatment decisions. Passage to close relatives about monitoring is also of the essence to allow early detection and intervention if necessary.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. John  who resides in Downtown  Manhattan. He is a retired engineer and lives with his wife. He is a non-smoker and maintains a moderate level of physical activity. He doesn't report any regular intake of alcohol or illicit substances. Born and raised in a rural setting  moved to the city for work but adopted a balanced lifestyle.   Presenting Problem:  Mr. John presented with intermittent  abdominal discomfort over the past few weeks  which he dismissed initially  attributing it to indigestion. Lately  however  the discomfort intensifies when he walks more than two blocks.   Past Medical History: Mr. John had a noteworthy medical history of mild hypertension diagnosed about 10 years ago  for which he is under medication (Enalapril 10 mg  once daily). No reports of any chronic diseases such as diabetes  COPD  or any pre-existing cardiac conditions. He did have a noted history of high cholesterol diagnosed around 7 years ago  treated with atorvastatin (20mg  once daily).   Family History: His father passed away at the age of 60 due to a stroke. His mother died due to Alzheimer's disease. There's no reported family history of any aneurysms  cardiac conditions  or familial genetic disorders.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in his abdomen  a bruit was audible upon auscultation. Otherwise  his cardiovascular  respiratory  neurological  and musculoskeletal examinations were unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment: Given his presenting symptoms and medical history  an suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was formed. This suspicion was confirmed through an ultrasound which showed an 5.5 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm.   Plan: Given the size of the aneurysm  surgery stands as the likely next step as watchful waiting carries significant risk. Vascular surgery consultation is imperative to discuss the options for open surgical repair vs endovascular aneurysm repair. The patient has been briefed on the need for lifestyle changes and the risk factors to control  like blood pressure and cholesterol levels  ensuring regular health check-ups.  Teaching: Mr. John and his wife are educated about the nature of his condition  symptoms to watch out for like severe abdominal or back pain (known as the herald symptoms of AAA rupture)  and the importance of strict blood pressure control and cholesterol management to prevent further complications. They were also made aware of the surgical procedures and post-surgical care.   This presentation summarises the clinical case of Mr. John and his recently diagnosed condition  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Collins  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presented with sudden  severe abdominal and lower back pain. He has been a regular patient at our facility for a few years now  diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well-managed with medications. He follows a reasonably healthy lifestyle  with habits such as moderate alcohol use  non-smoking  and maintaining a balanced diet. He also keeps under regular surveillance for his medical issues. Commendably  he has a relatively active lifestyle for his age  engaging in regular moderate physical activities.  His family history is significant with his late father succumbing to abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in his late 70s and mother dying due to heart disease. His elder brother also died due to myocardial infarction  suggesting this family's prevalent cardiovascular issues.  During his arrival at the facility  he manifested persistent but steady vital signs: BP 140/90 mmHG  Pulse- 87 bpm  Respiration Rate- 18 breaths per min  Temperature- 98.6 degrees. Further inspection confirmed tenderness in his central and lower abdominal region and lumbar. The auscultation supported a bruit over the abdominal aorta.  Following this physical examination  an urgent CT scan was ordered. The subsequent imaging report revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm of 6.3 cm  consistent with the preliminary diagnosis.   The patient's high familial history of cardiovascular disease  age  and hyperlipidemia puts him at significant risk of developing AAA. Given the patient's acute severe abdominal pain and the ultrasound report's findings  the aneurysm's size makes it prone to rupture  which can be a life-threatening state.   An interdisciplinary approach with vascular surgeons  anesthesiologists  and nursing staff is mandatory in this case to plan  prepare  and execute the urgent surgical intervention for AAA repair. The patient  upon stabilization  has been scheduled for an emergency open surgical repair of the aneurysm. He is currently receiving pain management and under close monitoring to control his blood pressure and other vitals until the surgery.  Conclusion:  Mr. Collins is a clear case of AAA risk due to his age  male gender  hereditary factors  and history of hypertension. Urgent surgical intervention could save his life. His case emphasizes the importance of regular screening and early diagnosis in susceptible populations. Post his recovery  it will be essential to emphasize good health practices  focusing primarily on diet  physical activity  and chronic disease control to prevent potential reoccurrence or development of associated complications.
