Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. X Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Mechanical Engineer Location: New York City  New York  Presenting Concern:  Mr. X presented with complaints of a dull pain that he felt in his lower back and abdomen for a period of two weeks. He reported the pain to be constant  with occasional episodes of intensification. He denied experiencing any notable weight loss  appetite changes  nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel or bladder activity.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years and is being managed with an ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril). He also has a history of high cholesterol levels which are under control with statins (Atorvastatin). He quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-year history and currently drinks alcohol socially. He has no known food or drug allergies.  Family History:  Mr. X's father died at the age of 72 due to a 'ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm'. His mother is alive and well at the age of 89. He has a younger brother diagnosed with diabetes.  Examination and Imaging:  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Lab tests showed normal renal function and liver function  with slightly elevated cholesterol levels. A CT abdominal scan was performed which confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.4 cm in diameter.  Diagnosis:  Mr. X was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm likely linked to a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a family history of the same condition.   Plan:  Due to the size of the aneurysm and the potential risk of rupture  surgical intervention is suggested. He was planned for an open surgical repair (OSR) of the aneurysm. He will have to be admitted to the hospital for the necessary preoperative workup and investigations. Post-operative care will be focused on pain management  close monitoring of his vital signs  and early mobilisation to prevent complications. He will be counseled for lifestyle modifications to manage his blood pressure and cholesterol levels as part of the long term management.  Discussion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a potentially life-threatening condition where early diagnosis is the key to successful management. In this case  the patient's past medical history and family history were indicative of the condition and diagnostic imaging confirmed the diagnosis.  In terms of prognosis  surgical repair generally has a high success rate. Post-operatively Mr. X will need regular follow-ups  and he will need to stick to a strict regimen to control hypertension and cholesterol which are known risk factors for recurrent AAA.   This case emphasizes the need for considering abdominal aortic aneurysm in older males with a history of smoking  hypertension  and the presence of similar conditions in the family. Prompt diagnosis and aggressive management of risk factors can significantly improve outcomes in these patients.

Patient Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA):  Patient Profile:  Mr. Jones is a 69-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of a low-grade persistent abdominal and back pain focused around the navel.  Medical History:  Mr. Jones has been hypertensive for over 20 years and was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes mellitus five years ago. Smoking history reveals a 40 pack/year habit  for which he quit ten years ago. He also had hyperlipidemia diagnosed ten years ago.   Demographics:  Mr. Jones lives in New York City with his wife and works as a retired school principal. He is a veteran and served in the Navy twenty years ago. Mr. Jones drinks socially  but has no illicit drug use or alcohol dependency.  Family History:  His father died at 70 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Maternal history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. No family history of connective tissue disorders.  Physical Examination: The patient appeared in no acute distress. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area. The abdomen was soft with no signs of peritoneal irritation. Cardiovascular examination revealed bradycardia. No signs of peripheral vascular disease on examination.  Investigations: Blood results showed that renal and liver functions were within normal ranges. Triglycerides and total cholesterol levels were slightly elevated and Hemoglobin A1c was slightly elevated indicating poorly controlled diabetes. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infra-renal Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. No signs of rupture or dissection.   Plan:  The patient was informed about his diagnosis and the risks of the disease - namely rupture leading to life-threatening bleeding. The size of his aneurysm necessitates surgical intervention. Mr. Jones was suggested to have an Endovascular Aortic Repair (EVAR) which is less invasive and has less recovery time. He was referred to a vascular surgeon. His hypertension and diabetes need to be better controlled - adjustments were made to his medication. Mr. Jones was recommended to quit drinking and advised to eat a healthy diet  lower in fat and sodium  and to exercise regularly.  Overall  the risks of the operation will be explained to him and informed consent taken. Mr. Jones will need close follow-up  typically with CT Angiograms  to check for any complications such as leaks or graft migration. His primary care physician will also be involved in the long-term yearly surveillance with abdominal imaging.  Summary: This case demonstrates the importance of early detection and intervention in high-risk patients with a family history of AAA. This approach may significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with ruptured AAA.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired military officer  presented to the clinic with complaints of moderate to severe abdominal pain that had persisted for two weeks. His pain was centralized in the middle and lower area of the abdomen. He also reported a feeling of fullness and bloating. Mr. Doe is a non-smoker. He has no history of illicit drug use  but consumes alcohol moderately.    Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  and he maintains it with prescribed medication. He is also being treated for hyperlipidemia. He underwent a cholecystectomy approximately 10 years ago. Besides this  Mr. Doe’s medical history revealed he was overweight with a BMI of 28. However  he does not have diabetes  liver  lung  or heart disease.   Family History: Mr. Doe’s father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his mother had an ischemic stroke at the age of 78. There was no reported history of aortic disease or connective tissue disorders within the family.  Physical Examination & Diagnostic Assessment: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the patient's abdomen. His blood pressure was 140/80 mm Hg and heart rate was 92 bpm. Laboratory results show a slightly elevated LDL cholesterol level. A computed tomography (CT) angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The aneurysm was 5.5 cm in diameter  starting below the renal arteries  and was consistent with the patient's presenting symptoms.  Plan: Due to the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture  Mr. Doe was recommended to undergo an open surgical repair. Risk factors were also discussed  and Mr. Doe was encouraged to maintain a healthy weight  regular exercise regime  and continue his blood pressure and cholesterol medications. Following the surgery  Mr. Doe will be monitored regularly for possible complications and effectiveness of treatment.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering an abdominal aortic aneurysm in a patient presenting with abdominal pain and hypertension. Swift diagnosis and appropriate treatment strategies are key to minimizing the potential complications associated with this condition.

Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. A  is a 70-years-old Caucasian male who has recently been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is retired and lives with his wife in Ohio. The patient is a former smoker and had a 40-pack year history before quitting 15 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and has been maintaining a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement.  Presenting Problem:  Mr. A came to the hospital with complaints of constant abdominal pain  concentrated in his lower back region. He reported the pain to be 'throbbing' in nature with increased intensity over the last couple of weeks. He also reported feeling fatigued and having mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension which is maintained on antihypertensive medication. He also has a background of hypercholesterolemia  controlled with statins. In addition  Mr. A previously experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago  for which he has been on aspirin. He had a myocardial infarction ten years back  which was followed by successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). He has no known allergies.  Family History: Mr. A's father suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his 60s and passed away in his 70s due to aortic rupture. His elder brother was diagnosed with AAA and operated on at the age of 65. His mother and two sisters are alive with no cardiac or vascular diseases. He has two grown-up sons with no known medical issues.  Physical Examination: Standing 1.80m tall and weighing 82 kg  his BMI is solidly situated in the overweight range. His blood pressure is elevated at 150/90 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination revealed a vascular bruit  and the rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: A CT angiogram confirmed the presence of a saccular abdominal aortic aneurysm with a size of 5.5cm.  Patient Management and Plan: Based on the size of the aneurysm  the patient's age  and family history  the decision has been made to proceed with a endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) in order to prevent potentially fatal rupture or dissection. The patient's hypertension and hypercholesterolemia will also need stricter control to avoid further harm to the vascular system.  In summary  Mr. A is a 70 year old male with significant cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a family history of AAA. Coupled with his current diagnosis of an AAA of significant size  timely intervention and strict control of his risk factors are essential.

Patient Information:  - Age: 74-years-old - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: African American - Occupation: Retired  Presenting Concern: Mrs. X presented to the emergency department due to a sudden and severe onset of lower back pain  rated as 8 out of 10. The pain was described as persistent and non-radiating.  Medical and Surgical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which are under control through medication for the past 15 years. Moreover  she had an appendectomy at 20 and a total hysterectomy at 50 due to fibroids. She denies any history of chronic diseases like diabetes or heart disease.   Social History: She is a widow who lives alone but often visited by her children. She has a 30-pack year smoking history but quit 15 years ago. She reports occasional alcohol use but denies use of illicit drugs. She has limited physical activity due to osteoarthritis.   Family History: Her mother died from a stroke in her late 80s  and her father died of a heart attack in his early 70s. She also mentions two older brothers; one suffering from heart disease and the other from diabetes.  Diagnosis: Upon physical  a pulsating mass was noted in the abdominal area. Abdominal ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.5cm in diameter. Blood pressure and heart rate were mildly elevated  potentially due to pain and anxiety. Other routine blood work including CBC  liver function tests  renal function tests  and coagulation profile were all within normal limits.  Management: Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  surgical intervention was deemed necessary. The surgical team was able to successfully perform an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  and the patient was transferred to the ICU post-procedure for close monitoring.  Education and Counselling: The patient was counselled upon discharge on lifestyle modifications  including the importance of regular exercise  a healthy diet  and routine follow-up scans every 6 months to monitor the progress of the aneurysm. As the patient has a substantial family history of cardiovascular disease  she was encouraged to inform her close relatives about her AAA as they may be at increased risk.  This case highlights the significant role of risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  atherosclerosis  and familial predisposition in the development of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. It is crucial to pursue early detection strategies  especially in patients with significant risk factors to reduce related morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation:   Patient Identification: Mr. A  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  has presented with a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Presenting Symptoms: The patient reported a sudden onset of severe pain in his lower back and abdomen that did not subside  along with nausea  rapid heartbeat  and dizziness when standing.   Past Medical History: Mr. A has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he has been taking medications. His long-standing smoking habit (30-pack years) and sedentary lifestyle have likely contributed to his current situation. He has no known allergies. Mr. A was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease and early-stage COPD 3 years ago.   Family History: Both his parents had cardiovascular-related issues. His father passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 72 and his mother had a stroke at 75 but survived.  Social History: Mr. A is retired and mostly spends his time indoors due to his COPD. He is a widower with two adult children who live out of town. He quit smoking two years ago and consumes alcohol moderately about twice a week.   Physical Examination: On physical examination  a visible and palpable pulsating mass was noted in his abdomen just above the umbilicus  consistent with the size noted on ultrasound (5.6 cm in diameter). The patient's vitals were as follows: blood pressure: 170/85 mmHg  Heart Rate: 95 bpm  Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths/minute.   Diagnostic Assessment: The aneurysm was initially discovered during a routine abdominal ultrasound  after which an abdominal CT scan was conducted for confirmation and better visualization of the aneurysm. The AAA of 5.6 cm in diameter was identified starting just below the renal arteries and ending just before the iliac arteries.  Treatment: Given the size and symptoms of the aneurysm  the possibility of rupture is high  necessitating immediate surgical intervention. He was admitted to the vascular surgery unit for an urgent EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) procedure. The patient also received instructions on lifestyle modifications  especially diet control  weight management  and regular exercise post-recovery  to manage his chronic conditions and prevent the recurrence of AAA.  Prognosis: Following successful surgical intervention  strict blood pressure control  and lifestyle modifications  the patient's prognosis could be significantly improved. Regular follow-up is necessary to monitor and manage his AAA and other comorbidities.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the hospital presenting a pulsating abdominal mass  abdominal pain  and constant back pain. His symptoms have been developing over the course of the past few months. He reports a family history significant for cardiovascular disease. His father had a coronary artery disease and died at age 75 from a myocardial infarction  and an older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) diagnosed at his 60s.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson quit smoking 10 years ago  but he was a two-pack-a-day smoker for over 40 years. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril. He has a past medical history of ""borderline"" diabetes and has mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  but he is not on any medications for either. He also underwent gallbladder surgery two decades ago.   Presenting Issue:  Physical examination revealed a non-tender  pulsatile mass in the middle and upper part of his abdomen. It measured approximately 4 cm in diameter. No bruit was heard over it. His blood pressure reading was 160/90 in his right arm and his pulse was 70 bpm. An abdominal ultrasound was performed which showed an aneurysm measuring 5.3 cm in diameter in the infra-renal aorta. No thrombus or calcification of the aneurysm was observed  which suggested a high risk for rupture.  Treatment and Prognosis:  Given the size of the aneurysm and Mr. Johnson's symptoms  the interventional radiology took place. He underwent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) which involves placing a stent graft within the aneurysm to provide a new path for blood flow.   Post-operatively  Mr. Johnson is being closely monitored for any possible complications. The patient was started on a beta-blocker to control and maintain his blood pressure levels and reduce the stress exerted on the aneurysm site. He's also prescribed a statin to manage his cholesterol levels  which further decreases the chance of future aneurysm development.  Outlook:  With successful surgery and proper post-operative care  the prognosis is generally good for patients like Mr. Johnson. However  he needs to closely follow-up with his cardiologist for routine monitoring of the placed graft for possible leaks  enlargement or re-opening of the aneurysm  or any other complications. Also  lifestyle modification like balancing diet  exercising  maintaining a healthy weight  checking cholesterol levels  and managing BP is advised to prevent further cardiovascular issues.  In conclusion  Mr. Johnson's past smoking habits  hypertension  age and family history played a significant role in the development of his AAA. His case notes the importance of early detection  presentation  and intervention of aneurysms  particularly in high-risk patients.

Patient Identification: Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the ED with severe abdominal pain.   Medical History: The patient has a history of long-term cigarette smoking (averaging 2 packs daily for 50 years)  hypertension  and high cholesterol levels  currently controlled by medication. He admits to having a sedentary lifestyle due to recent retirement and confesses to a lifelong diet rich in fats and low in fiber. Despite his hypertension and high cholesterol  he claims compliance with medication but admits to irregular follow-ups. He hasn’t had an operation before and has no known drug allergies. His immunisations are up to date.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith complained of sudden onset of severe and constant lower back and abdominal pain  describing it as “tearing.” The pain began while eating breakfast in the morning  approximately three hours before arrival to the emergency room (ER). No known triggers or mitigating factors were identified.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient had a blood pressure of 145/90 mm Hg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and temperature of 37.5 degrees Celsius. His breathing showed no difficulty  but he was observed to have some abdominal distension and tenderness. He was also noted to have a pulsating mass in the middle and upper part of his abdomen.   Family History: Mr. Smith’s father died of a heart attack at 72  and his mother died from a stroke at 65. He has a younger sibling diagnosed with ischaemic heart disease.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Based on the combination of his symptoms  physical examination findings  and risk factors  he was suspected with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). A subsequent fast bedside ultrasound confirmed the suspicion revealing an abdominal aortic diameter of approximately 7 cm with evidence of free fluid in the abdomen. The diagnosis was therefore a ruptured AAA.   Discussion: Mr. Smith’s case directly corresponds with the understanding that the primary risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysms are age over 60  Caucasian race  male sex  history of smoking  and family history of AAA. His case particularly highlights the significant role of cigarette smoking in the development of an AAA. Besides  his history of hypertension contributes to the weakening of the arterial wall  causing them to dilate over time. The presentation of a pulsatile abdominal mass also seals the diagnosis of AAA.  Management Plan: Following the diagnosis  Mr. Smith was urgently referred to vascular surgery for emergency operative repair of the ruptured AAA. Furthermore  counseling regarding the importance of lifestyle modification  specifically smoking cessation  was provided. If successful  the patient will be scheduled for regular follow-ups to monitor his recovery.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Male  Patient Profile: Mr. William  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented with a complaint of intermittent abdominal and lower back pain.  Demographics: Mr. William lives in an urban area and retired two years ago as an office clerk. He lives alone after his wife passed away five years ago. He is a chronic smoker and has been smoking one pack of cigarettes every day for the last 35 years. He consumes alcohol moderately and has a BMI of 28.  Family History: He lost his father to cardiac arrest at the age of 70  and his mother died of a stroke at 75. His older brother underwent surgery for aortic aneurysm at the age of 62.  Past Medical History: Mr. William has a history of hypertension  diagnosed seven years ago  and manages it with daily medication. He was also treated and managed for high cholesterol five years back. He has no known allergies to food or medication.  Current Presentation: Following the symptoms  relevant clinical investigations were performed  showing an enlarged aorta of about 5.5 cm  confirming the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Surprisingly  no signs of rupture was noted. His blood pressure was recorded as 165/90 mm Hg  and pain intensity was 5 on the pain scale.  Laboratory Findings: Blood and urine showed normal metabolic function. Lipid profile revealed high cholesterol and triglyceride levels.  Management: Considering the aneurysm's size  family history  and the presence of risk factors (hypertension  smoking  and high cholesterol)  a surgical approach by means of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) has been decided as the most appropriate treatment. Mr. William will also need to make substantial lifestyle modifications  such as smoking cessation and maintaining a low-fat diet for cholesterol control and blood pressure management.  Follow-Up: Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor hypertension and aneurysm post-surgery  ensuring normal metabolic function and assessing lifestyle modifications. The patient will be referred to a dietitian for dietary plans and to a counselor for smoking cessation assistance.  Given his age  past medical history  and the size of the aneurysm  Mr. William's is considered a high-risk case. This case emphasizes the relevance of early detection and the critical role of lifestyle changes in managing such conditions. Moreover  it also accentuates the importance of family history in spotting individuals at risk.

Patient Information:   Mr. John  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented at our outpatient clinic with a complaint of intermittent abdominal and back pain residing mostly around his lower abdomen and lower back area  which has been ongoing for over four months. The pain does not radiate but increases with physical effort. He has no known allergies but has a 45-year history of heavy smoking  consuming about a pack a day  and quit smoking two years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and has a sedentary lifestyle. He served in the military for 20 years.  Medical History:  His past medical history includes hypertension  for which he has been taking medication (Lisinopril) for the past 10 years. He is also on low-dose aspirin for generalized heart disease prevention. He experiences occasional heartburn and takes over the counter antacids. He also suffers from chronic lower back pain and takes Tylenol as needed. He has no known history of surgeries  transplants  or allergies.  Family History:   Within his family history  his father passed away at the age of 76 from a stroke  and his mother died at the age of 69 from breast cancer. He has one older brother who is living and has been diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease. There are no known genetic diseases in his family.  Recent Investigation:  Upon physical examination  an abdominal mass was palpable  especially when the patient was lying on his back. Initial blood tests were normal except for slightly raised cholesterol levels (250 mg/dL). An abdominal ultrasound revealed the presence of what appeared to be an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of 5.5 cm  which was confirmed by the subsequent CT (computed tomography) angiography.  Management and Prognosis:  The patient was counselled about the risk of rupture due to the large size of the aneurysm and was advised for immediate surgical intervention. Medically  his hypertension was well managed. However  he was instructed to follow a low cholesterol diet due to his slightly higher cholesterol levels.  Informed consent was taken for elective open surgical repair (OSR)  and the surgery was conducted successfully. The patient had uneventful recovery post-operation and is currently being followed up in the outpatient clinic with routine ultrasound examinations every 6 months to ensure no further complications arise.  Given the patient’s history of tobacco use  he was advised to participate in a smoking cessation program to improve overall health and reduce risk factors related to vascular disease. With these measures in place  the patient's prognosis is cautiously optimistic  but he will need to continue regular check-ups to monitor his health.   This case has been presented with the patient's informed consent for educational purposes only. All identifying information has been changed to protect patient's identity.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information:  Mr. J  a male  aged 67 years old  is a Caucasian who resides in Maryland  USA. He has been a lifetime non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. Mr. J is a retired mechanic and lives with his wife. His income is now fixed  derived mainly from his pension plan.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. J presented himself to the hospital complaining of unrelenting abdominal pain and lower back pain for six days. The pain increased gradually over a period and has been associated with mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J was diagnosed with hypertension ten years ago and has been on anti-hypertensive medication since then. He also has controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for approximately seven years. His last HbA1c count  tested three months ago  was 6.8%. He has history of occasional episodes of dyslipidemia and also had a cholecystectomy due to gall stone disease about a decade ago.   Family Medical History:  Mr. J's father died at the age of 73 from a stroke  and his mother died in her late 70s from ovarian cancer. He has two siblings; his older brother is living with cardiovascular disease  and his younger sister is clinically well.  Presenting Illness:  On physical examination  his vitals were stable but he appeared in distress due to pain. His abdomen was soft but tender at the mid-abdominal area with a detectable pulsating mass. Laboratory tests showed increased white blood cell count. A subsequent CT scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) 5.4 cm in diameter  beginning just below the renal arteries and extending just above the aortic bifurcation.  Next Step:  Since the AAA was larger than 5 cm and symptomatic  the patient was scheduled for an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) after his admission into the hospital. During the pre-anesthetic evaluation  he was reported fit for surgery.  Summary:  This is a case of a 67-year-old male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and dyslipidemia  which could have resulted in his current presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Regular screening and timely intervention may have possibly averted the condition escalating to this level. His family history of cardiovascular disease might have also played a role in his present condition  emphasizing the importance of genetic predisposition in AAA.

Patient Case Presentation  Demographics: Mr. J is a 67-year-old Caucasian man  an ex-smoker who lives alone  and was a truck driver prior to his retirement. He continues to drink alcohol occasionally and retired 2 years ago. He has been independent with his activities of daily living.  Medical History: Mr. J is known to have high blood pressure  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus which are managed with medication. Most recently  he has reported abdominal pain and back pain which is mild to moderate in intensity for the past 2 months. His GP referred him for an abdominal ultrasound for suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm due to his risk factors including smoking history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and age. Upon his most recent appointment  the ultrasound confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm which is approximately 5.6 cm in diameter.  Family History: Mr. J's father died at 62 from a sudden heart attack and he reportedly also had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has two siblings; one brother who has high blood pressure and a sister who is relatively well with no major medical conditions reported.  Current Medication: • Metoprolol for hypertension • Simvastatin for Hyperlipidemia  • Metformin for Diabetes Mellitus type 2  Assessment: Mr. J is experiencing pain  most probably due to the expanding aneurysm. The fact that it is now over 5 cm in diameter signifies a higher risk for rupture and hence an emergency situation. This condition is potentially life-threatening and he needs surgery as soon as possible. In addition  his risk factors may not be fully controlled  which further increases his risk of aneurysm growth and rupture.  Plan of Care: The primary course of action would be endovascular repair of his abdominal aortic aneurysm. Prior to this  a full medical workup  including cardiac checks (given his hypertension and family history of sudden cardiac death)  will be conducted to ensure he is capable of undergoing the procedure. His medication regimen will be revisited post-surgery and further lifestyle modifications such as dietary changes and exercise will get initiated to help manage his current conditions and prevent further medical complications. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor progress and check for any post-surgery complications.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Details:   Mr. Lopez  a 68-year-old Hispanic male  comes for a routine physical examination. He has a known history of hypertension  diagnosed five years ago  and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been under medication.  Demographics:   He retired from a career as a truck driver two years ago  is married  and has four adult children. Mr. Lopez is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago after 30 years of pack-a-day smoking. He drinks alcohol occasionally  mostly on social events. He claims to have an average diet and rare exercise due to chronic lower back pain.  Family History:   His father died of a heart attack at the age of 72  and his mother passed away at 76 due to colon cancer. His eldest brother has been treated for coronary artery disease  and a younger sister has type 2 diabetes.   Present Illness:  During his routine checkup  his primary care physician noticed a pulsatile mass upon palpating Mr. Lopez's abdomen. The physician referred him for an abdominal ultrasound  which revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.2 centimeters in diameter.  Physical Examination:  The patient appeared well and in no apparent distress on initial visual inspection. He had an overall BMI of 28. His vitals recorded a blood pressure of 142/85 mmHg  a heart rate of 82 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 per minute  and temperature of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit.  Diagnostic Evaluation:  Following his diagnosis of an AAA  Mr. Lopez was referred to a cardiovascular surgeon. A CT angiogram confirmed the presence of the 5.2cm infrarenal AAA  with no sign of rupture or dissection. His complete blood count  lipid panel  and renal and liver function tests were within normal limits  considering his age.  Current Therapy:  Mr. Lopez has been maintained on Lisinopril 20mg once daily for his hypertension and Atorvastatin 40mg once daily for his hyperlipidemia. No changes have been made to these medications following his AAA diagnosis.  Conclusion:  Given his sizeable aneurysm and family history of cardiovascular disease  Mr. Lopez is at risk for rupture  presenting a critical health situation. Appropriate steps regarding surveillance and potential repair  including endovascular repair or open surgical repair  will be discussed with him by the cardiovascular surgeon.  Future visits will monitor Mr. Lopez's AAA progression and evaluate the efficacy of the chosen treatment plan. Adjustments will be made to his hypertension and hyperlipidemia treatment as needed  and he will also be counseled on adopting a healthier lifestyle  including better dietary habits and regular  suitable exercise to further reduce his cardiovascular risk.

Patient Information:   Mr. James Thompson  a 68-year-old African-American male  presents with a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Thompson visited the hospital for a routine health check-up. He mentioned occasional lower back pain and feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen.  Patient's Past Medical History:   Mr. Thompson has a sustained history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he is taking antihypertensive medication and statins. He is a smoker  averaging about 10 cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. He has no known drug allergies. He has been admitted to the hospital previously for angina  for which he underwent angiography but no stents were placed.   Family History:  Mr. Thompson's father died from an aortic aneurysm  and his elder brother had an AAA repair several years ago. His mother had diabetes but lived to her late 80s.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the peri-umbilical area  and his blood pressure was slightly elevated at 150/85 mmHg.   Diagnostic Findings:  An abdominal ultrasound was carried out  which confirmed the diagnosis of AAA with the aneurysm measuring 5.5cm in diameter.  Discussion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysms are usually asymptomatic until rupture  at which point the mortality is high. Risk factors for AAA include age over 65  male gender  smoking  and family history  all of which apply to Mr. Thompson. Given the size of Mr. Thompson's AAA (5.5 cm)  the risk of rupture is high.  Plan:  Mr. Thompson's significant medical history increases his surgical risk  but his AAA's size necessitates surgical involvement. Therefore  the plan includes referral to a vascular surgeon for evaluation for either open surgery or endovascular repair. It will also be vital for him to fully understand the importance of ongoing follow-up  lifestyle modifications like smoking cessation  maintaining a healthy diet  routine exercises  good blood pressure control  and taking medication as prescribed.  Education:  Educate Mr. Thompson on the necessity for surgical intervention  risks  and expected outcomes. He should understand the necessity for lifestyle changes  particularly quitting smoking  which is a significant risk factor for AAA expansion and rupture.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mrs. Smith  a 75-year-old Caucasian female  presents with a recent diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  History of Present Illness: The patient was asymptomatic  and the AAA was incidentally found during an abdominal ultrasound for chronic gallstone disease. She complains of occasional abdominal discomfort and back pain that she attributed to her age and arthritis.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Smith has a significant history of hypertension effectively managed with medication for the past 15 years. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia and a 30-pack year smoking history  although she quit smoking ten years ago. The patient has chronic gallstone disease but has declined surgical intervention as the symptoms are currently manageable. She is also diagnosed with osteoarthritis in her hips and has had a left hip replacement surgery 5 years ago.  Family History: She has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with her father dying of a myocardial infarction at age 64 and her younger brother undergoing an aortic aneurysm repair in his early 70s.  Personal/Social History: She is a retired school teacher  a widow with 2 children who are both alive and well. She quit smoking ten years ago. She doesn't drink alcohol and has never used illicit drugs. She lives alone but is in close contact with her children who live nearby.  Physical Examination: The patient vitals show Blood pressure: 135/89 mmHg  Pulse rate: 80 BMP  Respiration rate: 16 breaths per minute  Temperature: 98.6°F  Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air  Weight: 160 pounds  Height: 5'5"". Physical examination of the abdomen revealed a pulsatile mass.  Diagnostic Imaging: Ultrasound showed a 5.4 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No signs of rupture were noted.   Plan: Considering her age  the size of the aneurysm  her family history  and personal history of hypertension and smoking  Mrs. Smith is at a higher risk for rupture. We will discuss surgical intervention options with her  including endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and open surgical repair.   Her hypertension needs closer monitoring to ensure it is under the best possible control. She will remain under surveillance with repeated scans every 6 months to monitor the aneurysm size and risk of rupture if she decides on non-operative management.  She needs to be counseled on the importance of lifestyle modifications  including a low-sodium  low-saturated-fat diet  maintaining physical activity as tolerated  and continued abstinence from smoking. We will also involve a cardiac specialist for a comprehensive cardiovascular risk assessment given her family and personal history. This comprehensive plan takes into account the complex nature of Mrs. Smith's case and prioritizes her quality of life and overall health.

Patient Presentation:  The patient being identified is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who was admitted to the emergency room with a complaint of continuous and severe pain in his abdominal region. The pain was severe  sudden  and was radiating to the back. The patient was also suffering from a mild fever and reporting nausea.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  ischemic heart disease  and hyperlipidemia. He had been prescribed antihypertensive medication  statins  and blood thinners by his primary care physician. He also has a history of smoking (2 packs/day for 30 years) but quit in his late 50s.  Family History:  The family history of the patient reveals that his father died in his late 60s due to a thoracic aortic aneurysm rupture. His older brother was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 68 but received surgical intervention. No history of similar symptoms in his two children; a son aged 45  and a daughter aged 43.  Social History:  The patient lives with his wife at their home and is substantially independent. He’s a retired air force officer. He quit smoking around 20 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally  moderate in quantity  more on social occasions.   Clinical Examination:  On clinical examination  a pulsating mass was felt in the abdomen. The patient was hemodynamically stable. Preliminary ultrasound showed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a diameter of around 7 cm.   Laboratory Investigations:  Apart from elevated triglyceride levels (220mg/dL)  and LDL (150mg/dL)  other blood parameters: CBC  LFTs  Renal Function Test were found within the reference range. The patient’s ECG showed non-specific ST and T wave changes. Chest radiography was unremarkable.  Management:  Due to the large size of the aneurysm and symptomatology  the patient was scheduled for emergency surgery. His surgery was successful  and he is being closely monitored for any further complications. The prognosis is currently cautiously positive.  Summary:  This case presentation reveals the critical importance of prompt intervention in the setting of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient’s significant risk factors were likely contributing factors  including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history  and a history of smoking. This patient's case should prompt us to screen other potential candidates promptly to prevent a possibly fatal aneurysm rupture.

Patient Information:   A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index (BMI) of 30 was brought to our hospital by his wife due to a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain which he rates at 8 out of 10. The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension treated with amlodipine  hyperlipidemia controlled with atorvastatin  and a 35-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes every day (he quit 6 years ago). He has no history of cardiovascular disease  diabetes  or other chronic diseases.   History of Present Illness:  The patient stated the pain was sudden  did not radiate  and was unrelated to his eating habits or physical activity. Associated symptoms included light-headedness and cold sweats  and his wife noticed paleness. No history of hematemesis  melena  diarrhea  or constipation.  Family History:  In his family history  his father died in his early 60s due to a heart attack  and his maternal uncle had surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm in his late 60s. His sister and mother have hypertension  and his eldest son has an unknown heart condition.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient had a BP of 160/90 mm Hg  a heart rate of 105 beats/min  a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  and a temperature of 98.6 F. Abdominal examination showed a pulsatile mass. No signs of peripheral vascular disease were noticed.   Lab reports:  Lab data showed a slightly higher white blood cell count and kidney function tests were within normal limits.   Imaging and Diagnosis:   The abdominal ultrasound revealed a 6.5cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. A contrast-enhanced CT scan confirmed these findings  showing a large abdominal aortic aneurysm without signs of rupture but with signs of imminent risk.  Management Plan:   The urgent nature of the patient's condition led him to be rushed into emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  which is a type of less invasive surgery procedure that reduces the risk of complications and allows for faster recovery.   Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of noting the medical and family history of a patient  especially one who is male  of an advanced age  and with a history of smoking and hypertension  as these are known risk factors for developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. A high index of suspicion and immediate validation of diagnosis prevents fatal outcomes in patients presenting with these risk factors and symptoms.   The patient will need to be counselled about the importance of regular medical follow-ups  lifestyle modifications and medication adherence to manage his hypertension  and regular monitoring of his aneurysm post-intervention.

Patient Information: The patient  Mr. A  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male residing in Middleton  Wisconsin  U.S. He is a retired electrician and lives with his wife of 48 years  with regular visits from their children and grandchildren. He has a past medical history of hypertension  for which he has been taking medication for the past 15 years. He has never smoked but has a history of casual drinking. He underwent a hernia repair surgery 6 years ago. The patient has been generally healthy  with an average weight considered normal for his height and age.  Presenting Problem: Over the last month  Mr. A has been experiencing gradually worsening abdominal and lower back pain. The pain sometimes radiates down his back into his legs  worse after meals or after physical exertion. No associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness is reported. There were no significant changes in bowel and urinary habits.  Family History: There is significant family history with his father dying of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 73  and his paternal uncle suffering from a similar condition. His mother died of breast cancer in her late 60s. He has one older brother who has diabetes and hypertension. His two children are healthy.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was felt in the abdomen. His blood pressure was found to be 140/90 mmHg. Routine blood tests were within normal limits. An abdominal ultrasound was performed  which showed a 5.5 cm dilatation within the abdominal aorta suggestive of AAA.  Diagnosis:  Based on the history  physical examination  and findings in ultrasound  the patient was diagnosed with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.  Treatment & Management: Given his age and the size of the aneurysm Mr. A was considered for elective surgery to repair the aneurysm and prevent potential rupture. His hypertension needs to be better controlled before the surgery. His primary care physician and a vascular surgeon were consulted to discuss the potential risks and benefits  and to chalk out an effective management strategy. In the interim  he was advised to avoid strenuous activities and heavy lifting.  Patient Education: The patient was informed about the diagnosis. The need for surgery and the risks involved  including the potential for rupture and life-threatening hemorrhage were explained. The importance of regular monitoring and imaging of the aneurysm was emphasized. Mr. A was advised about the beneficial effects of a low-salt diet for hypertension control. Alcohol moderation  regular exercise  and medication compliance were advised.  Follow-up:  A one-week follow-up was scheduled to review the blood pressure control and talk about the possible date for surgery. The patient was also instructed to report immediately if symptoms worsen or if symptoms such as sudden severe abdominal or back pain  cold/hot and numb legs or sudden onset of nausea and vomiting appear  as these could indicate a rupture of the aneurysm.

Patient Description  Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the clinic after experiencing severe abdominal pain that has been escalating over the last few weeks. The patient is also experiencing accompanying lower back pain  an unusual pulsating sensation around the navel area  and noticeable weight loss. Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker. His BMI is 27  showing slight overweight. He is a former smoker having quit 10 years ago after a 30-year smoking history. He drinks moderately and has a diet characterized by red meat  dairy products  and high-sodium foods.  Past Medical History  Mr. Smith has a history of high cholesterol  hypertension  and arteriosclerosis. For these chronic conditions  he has been managing them using antihypertensive drugs and statins. He has no known drug allergies. He has no previous surgical history. Briefly  his hypertension and high cholesterol have been inadequately controlled  which might have contributed to the development and progression of his current condition.  Family History  In his family  there is a history of heart diseases. His father died from a heart attack at the age of 72  and his elder brother was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. No known family members have had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Clinical Assessment  Upon physical examination  Mr. Smith appeared relatively well and engaged but looked a bit fatigued. The abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass above the umbilicus  characteristic of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Diagnosis and Treatment  An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis indicating a 5.5 cm AAA. Mr. Smith was immediately referred to the vascular surgeon to discuss treatment options due to the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture. Options presented to him included regular monitoring  medications or surgery  with surgery being the most viable due to the size of his aneurysm.   The patient is presently scheduled for endovascular surgical repair  which is less invasive and has a quicker recovery time compared to open surgical repair. The risks and benefits of the surgery were discussed with Mr. Smith. He was advised to continue his antihypertensive medication and make meaningful dietary adjustments.  Given the inherent risk of AAA rupture  we scheduled a follow-up with his primary care physician to review his medication management and provide recommendations for healthier lifestyle changes. His family was advised on the possible genetic predisposition to cardiovascular diseases and was recommended to have regular check-ups  with an emphasis on vascular health.

Patient Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Lawrence A. Sex: Male Age: 72 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired police officer Location: New York  Presenting Problem:  Mr. A. presents with complaints of persistent dull pain in the middle and lower part of his abdomen along with back pain. These symptoms have been on and off for roughly a month  and more recently  have become persistent and more pronounced.  Past Medical History:  Mr. A. has a known diagnosis of moderate hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively). He is also a 20-pack-year former smoker  having quit smoking 15 years ago. The patient also dealt with obesity in the past but lost considerable weight through diet and lifestyle modifications. He has not had any other surgical intervention in his life.  Family History:  Mr. A.'s father passed away from an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 76. His mother had a history of coronary artery disease and passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 81. He has two siblings  a 68-year-old brother with type 2 diabetes and a 70-year-old sister who is currently healthy.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was noted in the abdomen. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed signs of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a diameter of 5.0 cm. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate regular at 75 bpm  respiratory rate 18 per minute  oxygen saturation 96% room air  and temperature 98.6 Fahrenheit. Blood examinations showed elevated levels of total cholesterol and low-density lipoproteins.  Diagnosis: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  possibly an unruptured one. Given the size of the aneurysm and the persistent abdominal and back pain reported by Mr. A  along with his family history of aortic aneurysm  immediate medical attention is warranted.   Treatment/Plan: Mr. A eligible for surgical intervention due to the diameter of his aneurysm  and the fact it's symptomatic also suggests a potentially higher risk of rupture. A consultation with a vascular surgeon is necessary to discuss endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or open aneurysm repair  which is considered based on the patient's overall health and aneurysm’s characteristics. Additionally  stricter control of his blood pressure is required  thus Lisinopril may need dose adjustment or a combination with other medication. Regular follow-ups are also needed to monitor overall health  lipid profile  and aneurysm's status if the patient opts for surveillance. Modifications to Atorvastatin may also be considered.   This case clearly shows the importance of proper management of risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and lifestyle choices in preventing the development and progression of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Subject: Mr. Ivanov — Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Mr. Ivanov  a 68-year-old Russian male  was admitted to the emergency department for severe abdominal and back pain  which he described as a tearing sensation. He is a retired professor and lives with his wife. He has two adult children and five grandchildren.   Demographics and Family History: Mr. Ivanov is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic but has a history of hypertension and profitable obesity with a body mass index of 33.2. His father died of a stroke at 73  and his mother passed away at 81 from congestive heart failure. His older brother experienced a myocardial infarction at 67.  Past Medical History: Mr. Ivanov has been living with type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  managed primarily with metformin and lifestyle modifications. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia  for which he takes atorvastatin. He’s had stage I hypertension for 5 years  treated with lisinopril. There is no known drug allergy.  Presentation: In the emergency department  his blood pressure was 180/95 mmHg  and his pulse rate was 105 beats per minute. His lipid panel revealed high LDL cholesterol levels. A physical examination identified a pulsatile mass in the abdomen.   Diagnostics: An abdominal CT scan confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7.5 cm. No signs of rupture were noted  but the size and symptoms suggested risk.  Treatment and Progress: Mr. Ivanov underwent an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair. His postoperative course was uneventful  and his blood pressure and blood glucose levels were monitored closely. He discharged home with instructions for close follow-up and continuation of his antihypertensive and diabetes medications. Lifestyle changes were aggressively promoted.   Given his family history of cardiovascular diseases  cholesterol levels  and personal history of hypertension and diabetes  Mr. Ivanov is at high risk of cardiovascular complications. His case will require regular follow-up visits and continued management of his risk factors  along with the monitoring of any potential aneurysm-related complications.   In summary  this case underscores the importance of early detection and management of risk factors related to abdominal aortic aneurysms in patients with multiple comorbidities.

Patient Details:  Mr. Jackson  a 75-year-old male  presented to the emergency department complaining of severe  constant abdominal pain. He describes the pain as the worst he has ever experienced and likened it to a tearing sensation felt mostly in the lower abdomen and posterior back area. Other symptoms include transient lightheadedness. He does not report any associated nausea  vomiting  or changes in his bowel habits.  Medical History:  Mr. Jackson has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively). He has a 45-pack year smoking history but quit smoking around ten years ago after a minor stroke. He also underwent an appendectomy at the age of 30. There is no history of diabetes  kidney disease  or any other systemic diseases.  Social History:  Retired mechanic  a widower  lives alone. Elder daughter checks in on him occasionally. Alcohol use limited to 1-2 glasses of wine during social gatherings.   Family History:  There is some revelation of vascular disease in his family. His father suffered and eventually died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 80  whereas his brother had a history of peripheral arterial disease.  Clinical Assessment and Diagnosis:  On physical examination  Mr. Jackson appeared pale and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was noted to be 150/90 mmHg with an irregular pulse at 112 beats per minute. An audible abdominal bruit was detected with a palpable pulsatile mass on deep palpation in the upper abdominal area.  Given his age  smoking history  family history  and clinical presentation  a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was suspected  and Mr.Jackson was immediately sent for an emergent abdominal ultrasound.  Findings showed a 6.2cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm with mural thrombus  confirming our suspicion of AAA. He was immediately scheduled for emergency surgery given his clinical presentation and the size of his AAA  which significantly increased his risk for rupture.   This case provides insight into the critical features of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  which include risk factors like age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  and family history. AAA often remain asymptomatic until rupture  but when symptoms do occur  they generally include severe pain  hypotension  and a pulsatile abdominal mass. Prompt diagnosis and intervention are key to patient survival in these cases.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 70 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired office worker   Presenting Complaints: The patient is experiencing abdominal pain  back pain and a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He reported that he started noticing the symptoms around two weeks ago  but it has been getting progressively worse.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with high blood pressure 10 years ago and has been managing it with lifestyle changes and medication. He also has a history of smoking but has stayed smoke-free since his hypertension diagnosis. He battled Type 2 diabetes 8 years ago and is currently on medication for the same. There's a history of hyperlipidemia for about 15 years  controlled with diet and medication. No previous complaints or diagnosis of cardiovascular or abdominal problems.  Family History: The patient’s father suffered from coronary artery disease leading to an early death at 65. His mother passed away at 78 due to complications from stroke. He has two siblings: a younger brother who is hypertensive and a sister who is a type 2 diabetic.  Social History: Mr. Doe is a widower for the past 3 years and lives alone  though he has a son who visits frequently. He does not consume alcohol and quit smoking 10 years ago.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the physician noticed a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. The patient is afebrile  with a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg. His pulse is 76 beats per minute.  Results of Investigations: After performing a computed tomography scan (CT scan) of the abdomen  the radiologist reported the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that measures approximately 5.6 cm in diameter. Both kidneys show regular outlines with no hydronephrosis or stones. Urinalysis is normal.  Diagnosis: The CT scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm of 5.6 cm.  Management Plan: Considering his age  the size of the aneurysm  and his overall health  Mr. Doe is a suitable candidate for a surgical repair of the aneurysm. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is recommended. The patient will also be prescribed medication to lower his blood pressure and cholesterol levels  alongside a strict healthy diet and exercise regime.  Given the size of the aneurysm  the patient is advised not to delay the procedure. The plan is discussed thoroughly with Mr. Doe  and he agrees to go ahead with the preoperative preparation  including cardiovascular examination.   Patient Education: The patient is educated about the risks and complications associated with both the condition and the procedure  the importance of proper medication  and maintaining a healthy lifestyle to manage his blood pressure and cholesterol levels. Regular follow-up sessions are recommended to monitor his condition post-surgery.   Follow Up: Upon discharge  a follow-up appointment will be scheduled two weeks post-surgery to evaluate recovery progress. Thereafter  regular follow-ups every six months are envisaged for continuous monitoring of his AAA and associated conditions. He is also advised to immediately seek medical attention if he experiences severe abdominal or back pain  or any changes in his symptoms.

Case Presentation:  Introduction:  Mr. Frank Thomson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presented with a several week history of intermittent lower back pain and abdominal discomfort. He is a retired engineer and lives with his wife in a suburban area. Mr. Thomson does not smoke but is a moderate drinker. His body mass index (BMI) is 27  indicating that he is mildly overweight.  Past Medical and Surgical History: Mr. Thomson has a documented history of hypertension for the last 15 years  currently managed with ACE inhibitors. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years ago and currently takes statins. He underwent an appendectomy in his early 20s. He has had no known allergies and no other major surgeries.  Presenting Complaints: He complained of occasional episodes of dizziness  lower back pain and vague abdominal discomfort for the past few weeks  which were not associated with food intake.  Diagnostic Assessment: During palpation  a pulsatile mass was detected in his abdomen. Due to his age and medical history  he was immediately referred for an abdominal ultrasound which revealed a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aorta aneurysm (AAA). There were no signs of rupture  dissection or thrombosis in any part of aortic aneurysm. His lipid profile showed LDL 130mg/dL  HDL 35mg/dL and total cholesterol 200mg/dL. Blood pressure readings ranged between 140/85 to 150/95 mmHg.  Family History: His father had a history of heart disease and passed away due to sudden cardiac arrest in his late 60s. His mother died in her early 80s following a prolonged period of frail health. Mr. Thomson has two daughters  both in good health.  Social History: As a retired engineer  he leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle with little physical activity. He consumes alcohol moderately and does not smoke. His diet is mixed but includes a high consumption of meat. He lives with his wife and has good emotional and social support.  Plan and Management: In view of his large AAA  Mr. Thomson was referred for open or endovascular surgical repair  considering the surgical risks and benefits  and his general health condition. He was counseled on his condition  potential risks  and optimal lifestyle modifications to manage his associated comorbidities. Options to incorporate more physical activity into his everyday routine  cessation of alcohol consumption  and modification of his dietary habits were discussed.   Summary: AAA is common among men over 65 years of age with a history of smoking and cardiovascular disease. Early diagnosis and management are crucial to avoid rupturing  which can be life-threatening. Lifestyle modifications  monitoring blood pressure and cholesterol levels  and limiting alcohol intake are essential factors for managing patients diagnosed with AAA. Appropriate surgical intervention has to be considered depending on the extent of the aneurysm and the comorbidities of the patient.

Subject: Brief Case Presentation: Patient Diagnosed with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  A 72-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  presented to our clinic with complaints of diffuse  mild abdominal pain and a pulsating abdominal mass noted upon examination. His discomfort had been building up gradually over several weeks. These signs combined with a strong family history of vascular conditions prompted us to conduct further diagnostic evaluations.  Past Medical History: Mr. X was previously diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker  having quit smoking 15 years ago following a 20-pack year history. He's been taking Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril for his hypertension  and Atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia.  Demographics: Mr. X lives with his wife in the suburbs. He's a retired engineer  a moderate alcohol drinker  with no known allergies. The patient is slightly obese  with a BMI of 30.5. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a diet rich in cholesterol and fat.   Family History: There is a strong family history of cardiovascular disease on the paternal side  with his father succumbing to myocardial infarction at age 65 and an elder sibling living with diagnosed peripheral artery disease.   Diagnostic and Laboratory Findings: An ultrasound of the abdomen revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.6 cm. Laboratory tests indicated stable lipid levels although they remain on the higher side despite lipid-lowering treatment. Hemoglobin A1c was 7.6%  indicating moderate glycemic control. EKG findings were normal.  Management and Plan: We're discussing referral for vascular surgery consultation given the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture. He was advised to continue his current antihypertensive and lipid-controlling regimen. Emphasis is being placed on improving his lifestyle and dietary choices to reduce obesity and improve vascular health. More vigilant surveillance has been advised due to his condition  familial tendencies  and risk factors.  The patient is willing to undertake the necessary lifestyle changes to improve his health and reduce the risk of the aneurysm rupturing. He will continue his hypertensive and diabetic medicines with regular follow-ups with his primary clinician. Considering his condition and risk factors  he has been recommended to undergo surgical consultation for a possible intervention to reduce the aneurysm risk.

Patient Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe living in New York City  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He is a retired mechanic and a veteran. His only immediate family is a son with no significant health issues.  Chief Complaint: Mr Doe came to the emergency department with a sharp  severe  non-radiating lower back and abdominal pain that began suddenly this morning. The pain was described as a pulsating sensation that started briefly after he finished his breakfast.  Past Medical History: Mr Doe's past relevant medical history includes long-standing hypertension  which has been relatively controlled with beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers. Hyperlipidemia (diagnosed a decade ago) is managed with statins. He is not diabetic  but he had a smoking history of 40 pack-years & quit smoking three years ago.  Family History: His father passed at 68 years old from heart disease  and his mother passed at 76 years old from old age. No family history of aortic aneurysms or any hereditary disease is reported.  Examination and Investigation: On physical examination  he was tachycardic  vital signs otherwise stable. His abdomen was tender  especially in the mid-abdominal region  and a pulsatile mass was palpable. A faint bruit could be heard on auscultation over the mass. The rest of the physical examination showed no abnormal findings.  His blood test showed normal complete blood count  renal function  and liver function. Lipid profile shows managed hyperlipidemia. CT scan revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6 cm in diameter.  Diagnosis and Plan: An emergent diagnosis of a large  symptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) was made. He was immediately referred for a surgical consult to discuss the possibility of emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). His case was further complicated by his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  but his current stable medical condition increases operability.  Estimated Outcomes and Prognosis: The patient  if managed promptly  stands a good chance at survival  although the risk of rupture is high given the size of the aneurysm and the associated symptoms. Post-recovery lifestyle modifications and medications (for hypertension and hyperlipidemia) will be necessary to prevent recurrence.

Patient Information: Our patient  Mr. John Smith  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male living in a suburban community. Mr. Smith  a former bank manager  is now retired and enjoys golfing and gardening. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is slightly over the average range at 26.8  suggesting he is slightly overweight. He has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He consumes alcohol socially.  Presenting Problem: Recently  Mr. Smith reported symptoms of severe sharp and persistent abdominal pain  along with lower back pain. He also complained of feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. There is an associated symptom of occasional dizziness but no vomiting  diarrhea  or fever.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and has been on antihypertensive medications for over a decade. He also has hyperlipidemia  for which he takes statins. He was diagnosed with cardiovascular disease five years ago but has since been adequately managed. He has no known history of allergies or other surgical procedures  with the exception of an inguinal hernia repair about 15 years ago.  Family History: His father died from a stroke at the age of 67  and his mother suffered from chronic kidney disease. His older brother died at the age of 65 due to myocardial infarction.   Recent Findings: Due to the ongoing pain  he was taken to the hospital. An emergent CT scan revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of about 5.5 cm. Preliminary laboratory results showed a mild elevation in his white blood cell counts indicative of possible infection or inflammation but otherwise normal.  Conclusion and Recommendations:  Mr. Smith was immediately taken up by the vascular surgery team because of the significant size of the aneurysm and decided to perform an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The procedure was successful  and his pain has notably subsided. He has been adviced to quit smoking. He was discharged with clean wound sites and educated about the signs and symptoms of complications such as increasing pain  swelling  redness  or drainage from the incision. He is scheduled for a follow-up to evaluate the effectiveness of the procedure. Furthermore  his family members have been advised to get regular check-ups considering the family history of cardiovascular disease and now AAA.

Patient Profile:  The patient under discussion is a 65-year-old Caucasian male known as Mr. A. The patient is retired and is currently living with his wife in a suburban locality. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  conditions he has been managing through regular medication for the past ten years. Mr. A is a former smoker  having quit cigarettes 20 years ago after predominantly heavy smoking in his early adulthood. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has recently lost weight due to decreased appetite and stress.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. A presented with a recent history of persistent abdominal discomfort associated with lower back pain. The discomfort is not acute but has been noted to be gradually worsening over the past month. He reports no incidences of hematuria  bowel changes  or episodes of syncope.   Medical Evaluation and Diagnoses: Physical examination illuminated a pulsatile abdominal mass  and subsequent Ultrasound imaging confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.6 cm in diameter. No signs of rupture or dissection were identified. Mr. A was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Family History: Mr. A’s father died of a heart attack at age 85  and his mother died of complications from pneumonia in her late '70s. He has one brother who was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease in his late 60s. There is no family history of any known connective tissue disorders.   Laboratory Tests:  Blood tests including full blood count  renal and liver function tests  and coagulation profile were within normal limits. Lipid profile shows elevated total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein levels.   Counseling and Treatment Plan: Mr. A was counseled extensively about the nature of his diagnosis and the high risk associated with the aneurysm's rupture. As the AAA is more extensive than 5.5 cm  immediate surgical intervention was recommended after assessing Mr. A’s overall fitness and considering the balance between potential benefits and risks. A follow-up appointment was planned with the vascular surgery team for further assessment and to delineate a strategy for endovascular repair.  Patient Education: The patient was educated about lifestyle modifications  including dietary changes to manage his lipid profile  importance of regular exercise  and the implications of his diagnosis. Mr. A was advised to avoid heavy lifting and straining and monitor any significant changes in his symptoms  including severe abdominal or back pain  which can be a sign of rupture needing immediate medical attention.   Outlook: With appropriate surgical management and lifestyle modifications  the prognosis can be reasonably positive for Mr. A. However  he will need regular follow-ups to monitor the condition of the aneurysm and response to the suggested interventions.  This clinical scenario stresses the significant role of primary care providers in recognizing AAA in its early stages  allowing timely intervention  and potentially improving fatal outcomes. It also underlines the pivotal role of a comprehensive approach  encompassing psycho-social support and lifestyle modification counseling in managing such patients.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named John. He is a retired construction worker who lives with his wife in urban NYC. John is a non-smoker but drank alcohol socially for around 20 years. He also did not engage in regular physical activity due to his strenuous job demands  contributing to his less than optimal health status.    Presenting Symptoms:  John presented to the emergency department with severe pain in the abdomen and both legs. He reported that the pain was sudden in onset and had been constant since. Upon investigation  he also was seen to be hypotensive and short of breath.   Medical History:  John has a known history of hypertension for the past 15 years  for which he takes daily medication. Additionally  he had been diagnosed with Type II diabetes five years ago and maintained average glucose control using oral hypoglycemics. There was also a record of hyperlipidemia about a year ago which has been managed by statin therapy.   Family History:  John's medical history seems to align with his family history  as both his father and paternal grandfather had hypertension and were diabetic. His father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 77 and passed away suddenly. His grandfather had also been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm but passed away before the intervention could take place.   Diagnosis:  Given his symptoms and the tenderness revealed in his physical examination in combination with his medical and family history  John was suspected of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An immediate abdominal ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis revealing an aortic aneurysm of 5.8 cm.   Management Plan:  The size of John's aneurysm and his symptomatology suggest he is at a high risk of rupture  necessitating immediate surgical intervention. Open surgical repair or endovascular aneurysm repair are both viable options depending on his overall health status and the surgeon's decision. Clinical guidelines recommend continued monitoring of his hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Lifestyle modifications  including diet control and regular physical activity  are of parallel importance to manage his cardiovascular risk factors.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of vigilance and immediate action in patients with risk factors presenting with symptoms suggestive of AAA since ruptured AAA's have high mortality.

Patient Presentation  The patient is an 84 year old Caucasian male who has been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  but quit smoking 15 years ago.   Presenting Issue  The patient was referred to the vascular surgery clinic by his primary care physician following an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm on an abdominal ultrasound done for investigating his chronic stomach pain. His aneurysm measures 5.5 cm  which happens to be over the threshold for surgical intervention.  History and Examination  His hypertension and hyperlipidemia are well controlled with long-standing (15+ years) medications - Lisinopril for his hypertension and Atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia. He has no history of diabetes or ischemic heart disease. His family history indicates a paternal uncle who had an aortic aneurysm. The patient also has intermittent claudication.   His physical examination is largely unremarkable except for a pulsatile mass detected in the epigastric region on palpation. The patient denies any recent weight loss  change in bowel habits  or gastrointestinal symptoms.  Imaging and Lab Findings  An abdominal CT scan confirmed the presence of an AAA  measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. His labs revealed a WBC count of 9 000/uL  hemoglobin of 14 g/dL  and platelet count of 250 000/uL. His kidney and liver functions were normal. He had an LDL cholesterol of 120 mg/dL and triglyceride level of 150 mg/dL.  Impression  The patient’s history  along with physical examination and imaging findings  confirm the diagnosis of AAA. His risk factors include advanced age  being male  history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a positive family history. His symptoms of chronic abdominal pain and intermittent claudication warrant a surgical consultation.  Plan  Considering his age and the size of the AAA  a referral to vascular surgery for discussion regarding endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) versus open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair would be appropriate. The patient also needs regular follow-ups and lifestyle modification advice with the initiative to maintain optimal control over his hypertension and cholesterol levels. We will also revisit the pharmacotherapeutic strategies to manage his chronic diseases to see if we can mitigate the risk further. He must also receive a thorough pre-operative risk assessment by his cardiologist considering his age and medical status.

Case Presentation Patient Information: Mr. J. Smith is a 69-year-old male veteran  residing in Manchester  NH.   Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith recently presented to the clinic complaining of persistent abdominal and lower back pain lasting for more than two weeks.    Historical Overview: The patient has a medical history of hypertension  for which he actively takes medication. Moreover  he is a former smoker  having quit five years ago after a history of 40 pack years.   Family History: There is a significant family history as his father died at the age of 65 due to complications after emergency surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
