Medical Examination and Diagnostic Testing: On clinical abdominal examination  it was noticed that his abdomen was mildly distended and a pulsatile mass was felt. No bruit was audible on auscultation. The patient's lower extremities showed no signs of ischemia  and pulses were palpable bilaterally.  An ultrasonogram showed a 5.6 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. The diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm was then confirmed via a CT scan  indicating an impending risk of rupture due to aneurysm exceeding 5 cm.  Treatment: Considering his age  size of the aneurysm  the risk of rupture  and patient's surgical risk as per his baseline morbidity factors  it was decided to perform an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).  A multidisciplinary team including a vascular surgeon  anesthesiologist  and interventional radiologist was formed to perform the EVAR.   Discussion: Informed consent for the surgery was obtained after explaining to Mr. Smith about the risks and benefits of the procedure. The procedure went on without any complications  and post-operative recovery was uneventful. He was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.  The patient is currently under regular follow-ups with his vascular surgeon to monitor for any complications related to the surgery and is prescribed medication for his hypertension to reduce stress on the aorta.   Mr. Smith’s case underscores the importance of considering AAA in differential diagnosis in older male patients with a history of smoking and family history of AAA presenting with abdominal and back pain.

Patient Identification: Mr. W  Demographics: 69-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe lower back pain.  Present Illness History: Mr. W reported sudden severe lower back pain that started 24 hours earlier. He reported it being a distinct  sharp and constant pain which escalated while moving  coughing  or taking deep breaths. No noticeable changes in the pattern of urination or bowel movement. He denies having nausea  vomits  or appetite loss.  Past Medical History: A 10-year history of hypertension and a 5-year history of non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. Otherwise  he lives a relatively healthy lifestyle; he does not smoke nor consumes alcohol. No history of any surgical procedures in the past.  Family History: His father died due to a heart attack at the age of 75  and his mother had a history of stroke and died at 80. His brother  currently 72  underwent surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 65.  Physical Examination: The patient appeared distressed due to pain. Vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and temperature of 36.6 degrees Celsius. Abdominal examination showed a palpable pulsating mass in the midline of the abdomen along with tenderness.  Investigations: Given his sudden severe pain  associated family history  and hypertension  Mr. W was immediately recommended for ultrasound which confirmed a 6.5 cm aneurysm in the abdominal aorta. Blood tests reported mild anemia and marginally elevated creatinine level.  Management: He was immediately referred for surgical consultation due to the large size of the aneurysm and sudden onset of severe pain indicating risk of imminent rupture. The vascular surgeon recommended an urgent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Following the procedure  the patient recovered well.  Follow-up: Mr. W will undergo regular ultrasound examinations to monitor the status of the aneurysm repair  and management of hypertension and diabetes with medication and lifestyle modifications will continue.  This case highlights the importance of early detection and intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysm  particularly in patients with family history and other risk factors  such as hypertension  to prevent fatal complications.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with an abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosed during a routine medical examination. The patient initially came in with regular complaints of mild abdominal discomfort and lower back pain. He is currently a retired engineer  residing in Illinois  USA  with his spouse. He's been a non-smoker for the last ten years. He consumes alcohol moderately.  Medical History:  On review of his past medical history  he has been treated for moderate hypertension for the last 15 years. No prior surgeries or hospitalizations have been reported. He admits non-compliance with prescribed antihypertensive medication. He is also noted to have Dyslipidemia. Nevertheless  he is not diabetic and does not suffer from any chronic kidney disease. His functional status had been independent prior to this diagnosis.  Physical Examination:  Vital signs are normal  and BMI is 29; indicating overweight phenotype. Examination of his vitals indicates a palpable  pulsating mass in the abdomen. Otherwise  the rest of the exam  including the cardiovascular and respiratory system  is normal.  Family History:  His father died at the age of 72 due to myocardial infarction and was diagnosed with an abdominal aneurysm in his late 60s. His mother is alive and well at 85  but she is treated for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has two siblings  both are alive and have a history of hypertension.  Imaging:  An abdominal ultrasound revealed a large infrarenal abdominal aorta measuring 6.5 cm in diameter  extending to the aortic bifurcation.  Management Plan:  Taking into account the size of this aneurysm and his family history  there are significant risks of rupture and internal bleeding  so consultation with a vascular surgeon was made for possible surgical intervention. Concurrently  the patient’s hypertension and hyperlipidemia were managed more aggressively to mitigate further complications. Smoking cessation and reduced alcohol intake were also emphasized in addition to dietary and lifestyle modifications.  Prognosis:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm poses a serious health risk to the patient and requires immediate management to reduce morbidity and mortality. Adherence to treatment plans and lifestyle modifications is essential for this patient’s prognosis. Continued monitoring and follow-up will also be necessary after the surgery.   Consents for the surgery have been obtained  and the patient was scheduled for an endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). The patient and his wife seemed grateful for the explanation and plan and were reassured about the continuity of care.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a history of intermittent  severe abdominal pain  and lower back pain. He also recently experienced unusual fullness after eating small meals  unexplained weight loss  and noticed a pulsating mass in his stomach.   Past Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both under management for the past ten years. Mr. Smith was a heavy smoker for many years but succeeded in quitting ten years ago. He has a moderate alcohol intake. He also has a history of peripheral artery disease and coronary artery disease  for which he underwent angioplasty three years ago.  Family History: He revealed a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including his father who died at the age of 72 from a heart attack  and a brother who underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 65.  Physical Examination: On the physical examination  a pulsatile  expansile  and tender mass was detected in the central and upper part of the abdomen. No significant lower limb ischemia or peripheral pulses were missed.  Investigations: Upon obtaining a complete blood count  liver function tests  kidney function tests  and coagulation profile  all parameters appeared within the normal range. Lipid profile showed elevated LDL levels. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a 5.4 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management and Follow-up: Given the size of the AAA and symptoms  he was referred to a vascular surgeon for further assessment and management. His current medications - which include antihypertensives and statins - were reviewed  with suggestions to optimize his blood pressure and lipid levels. Information about the significance of lifestyle changes was reinforced  including maintaining a balanced diet and consistent physical exercise. Long-term follow-up plans were constructed for regular surveillance of the aneurysm and ongoing management of his cardiovascular risk factors.  This case underpins the significance of early detection and management of abdominal aortic aneurysms  particularly among patients with known cardiovascular diseases or significant family histories. It serves as an important reminder that aneurysms may be asymptomatic until complications occur  emphasizing the role of vigilant monitoring and early intervention.

Case Presentation  Demographics: John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian man  retired  and has never smoked. He lives with his wife of 40 years in the suburbs. He is 6' tall  weighs 250lbs  and is thus classified as obese. He was referred by his GP to our vascular clinic due to a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a known history of controlled hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  treated with lisinopril. He also has mild hypercholesterolemia  treated with statins  and type 2 diabetes managed with metformin for the last 10 years. He had an appendectomy at age 20  and a knee replacement at 60 due to osteoarthritis. No known allergies to medications.  Family History: His father died of a heart attack at 72  and his mother is still alive at 90  with Alzheimer's. He has one older brother who died from ruptured AAA at age 70. No history of any other heritable diseases in the family.  Presentation: Mr. Doe claims to be asymptomatic  no abdominal or back pain  no frequent urination or other urinary changes. His last physical exam  including a digital rectal exam and urinalysis  was 6 months ago  all within normal limits. However  on today's physical examination  a pulsatile mass in the abdomen was palpable  and bruit could be heard upon auscultation.  Imaging: Ultrasound was performed  which showed an AAA of about 5.5 cm in maximum diameter. Follow-up CT angiography confirmed this  showing an infrarenal AAA  with no apparent signs of rupture.    Plan: The AAA size indicates a high risk for rupture  hence we will admit Mr. Doe for elective surgery to repair the aneurysm. Preoperative optimization  including glycemic control and ensuring adequate blood pressure control  will be done. AAA repair options will be discussed with Mr. Doe  including open repair and endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  considering his age and health condition.   Education: Mr. Doe and his wife will be educated about AAA and surgical options  including potential complications and lifestyle modifications post-surgery. Post-operative screening for other vascular aneurysms will also be explained given the family history.  A multidisciplinary team  including Cardiology  Endocrinology  and Anaesthesiology  will be involved in his care to ensure optimal management planning and postoperative recovery.   Follow-up: John will be followed up in the vascular clinic after surgery. Regular surveillance and lifestyle changes will be strongly recommended to reduce the risk of further vascular events.

Patient Profile: Mr. Robert Johnson; Gender: Male; Age: 65 years; Race: Caucasian; Occupation: Retired engineer; Marital status: Married  three children; Location: Oklahoma City  OK  USA.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient reported to the Emergency Department with complaints of severe  sharp  and constant abdominal pain radiating towards the back.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 10 years. He is a smoker  with 40 pack years of smoking history. He has also been suffering from hyperlipidemia which is being managed through medications for the past 8 years. He had an appendectomy at the age of 30. No history of diabetes or any other disease.  Family History: Both of his parents suffered from cardiovascular problems. His father died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother passed away due to stroke at 75. Two of his siblings also have a history of hypertension.  Clinical Findings: On examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the abdomen  slightly to the left of the midline. His blood cholesterol level was found to be elevated. Other laboratory results were from within normal limits.  Diagnostic tests and Progress: An abdominal ultrasound was recommended based on the initial examination  which showed a dilatation of the abdominal aorta exceeding 3cm in maximum diameter. A contrast-enhanced CT scan was performed afterward which confirmed the diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm.  Management and Prognosis: As the aneurysm was above the threshold size  the patient was recommended for immediate surgical intervention considering the risk of rupture along with him being symptomatic. He underwent successful open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. His recovery was uneventful. He was advised to quit smoking and was given medication to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. He was advised for regular follow-ups and to immediately report any kind of severe abdominal or back pain.  Education: The patient and his family were educated about the condition and the risk factors  importance of medication adherence  need for regular follow-ups  and adopting a healthy lifestyle.  This summarizes the case of Mr. Johnson with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His management is ongoing  and a concerted approach is required to minimize the risk of other cardiovascular events given his family history and past medical history.

Patient Profile: ---- Patient Initials: J.L. Gender: Male Age: 68 years old Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired truck driver Location: Rural North Carolina.  History of Present Illness: ---  The patient  Mr. J.L.  presented at the hospital after experiencing sudden and severe lower back pain for the last 24 hours. He reports the pain is constant and does not alleviate with rest or over-the-counter NSAIDs. The pain is described as a sharp pain radiating to the abdomen and lower extremities. He denies any trauma or injury and had been in his usual state of health before the onset of the pain. In addition  he has been feeling lightheadedness and fatigue for the past few days. He has not noticed any hematochezia  melena  or changes in bowel habits. There is no history of recent weight changes  fever  or chills.  Past Medical History: ---  J.L. has a significant past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40-pack-year smoking habit. He also has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2. His medications include insulin  metformin  lisinopril  and Lipitor. He quit smoking about ten years back  following a minor stroke (for which he is on a daily aspirin regimen).   Family History: ---  His father died of a heart attack at the age of 64  and his mother has hypertension and diabetes. He has two brothers  one of whom underwent surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm some years ago. There is  therefore  a strong family history of cardiovascular disease.  Physical Examination: ---  The examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation. His blood pressure and heart rate readings were 150/100 mmHg and 98 beats per minute  respectively. The examination of his cardiovascular  pulmonary  and remaining gastrointestinal systems was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment: ---  Based on the examination findings and the patient’s history  an abdominal ultrasound was ordered which confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  measuring 5.5 cm in diameter.   Plan: ---  Given the size of the aneurysm and the sudden onset of symptoms  surgical intervention is required promptly. The risk of rupture is high  and mortality rates are dramatically increased upon rupture. The patient is referred to a vascular surgeon for an elective open repair of the abdominal aorta.  Discussion: ---  This case emphasizes the importance of considering abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients with a pertinent history of cardiovascular disease  smoking  hypertension  and familial predisposition. While open surgical repair is a common approach  modern procedures like endovascular stent grafts could also be considered depending on the patient's overall health condition and surgical risk.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Stanley  a 68-year-old African-American male  was referred for evaluation due to an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) on a routine abdominal ultrasound. His chief complaint was intermittent  non-specific abdominal discomfort for the past few weeks  which he initially associated with gastric issues.  Past Medical History In his medical history  Mr. Stanley was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus eight and ten years ago  respectively. Other conditions he has been managing include mild osteoarthritis  for which he occasionally uses non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs  and well-controlled chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) secondary to a 40 pack-year smoking history  which he discontinued 5 years ago.  Family History Family history reveals both his father and a paternal uncle underwent surgery for AAAs. His mother had hypertension and died from a stroke at an age of 73. His two elder brothers are alive with diabetes and cardiac diseases.  Social History Mr. Stanley is a retired plumber  married with two children. He quit smoking five years ago  he rarely drinks alcohol  and he’s a member of a local walking group.  Physical Examination On examination  he appears his stated age and is in no acute distress. He is afebrile  with a blood pressure of 146/92 mmHg  heart rate of 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and BMI of 29. Palpation confirmed a pulsatile mass in his abdomen.  Investigations and Diagnosis Results from an abdominal CT scan revealed a 5.5-cm infrarenal AAA with no evident leak. His laboratory findings  including complete blood counts  kidney and liver function tests  were within normal range except for slightly elevated glucose and HbA1c levels  suggesting inadequately controlled diabetes.   Management  Given his diagnosis of a large AAA  family history  and risk factors (including advanced age  hypertension  history of smoking and COPD)  he has been referred for consideration of surgical intervention. His diabetes and hypertension management will also need to be reassessed to minimize perioperative and long-term risks. He was advised to continue his exercise habits but to avoid strenuous activities which might precipitate rupture until the AAA is managed.  Follow-up Mr. Stanley will be seen again in a week to discuss his surgical options after an anesthesia evaluation. He will also follow-up with his primary care physician concerning hypertension and diabetes control.   This case advocates for the importance of recognizing risk factors  family history  and early detection of AAA especially in patients who might otherwise attribute their symptoms to less serious conditions.

Case Presentation:   Patient Information: Mr. Conway  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with severe sharp abdominal pain. He is a retired car mechanic  currently living with his wife.   Medical History: Mr. Conway has a significant medical history of hypertension and Hyperlipidemia. He had been previously chronic on Norvasc 10mg for hypertension and Lipitor 40mg for hyperlipidemia. He smoked heavily during his early adulthood and quit two decades ago. He described his alcohol intake as occasional and did not admit to any illicit drug use.   Family History: His father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his oldest brother was successfully treated for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) six years ago.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  he was sweaty and anxious. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 150/95 mmHg  with a pulse rate of 90 bpm. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. Bowel sounds were normoactive and there was no guarding or rigidity of the abdominal muscles.  Investigations: An urgent abdominal ultrasound showed a maximum infrarenal aortic diameter of 8cm  compatible with AAA. On contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis  the aneurysm was confirmed  and signs of active leak were identified.  Vascular Surgery Consultation: Considering the patient’s significant smoking history  his obvious large AAA and his brother’s successfully treated AAA  vascular surgeons were consulted immediately.   Diagnosis: Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Plan: Mr. Conway will be admitted for emergency endovascular aortic repair. His wife will be informed. His old medications  Norvasc and Lipitor  will be continued. Pain management will be carried alongside. He will be advised to monitor BP at home and adhere to high-fiber  low-cholesterol diet and regular gentle exercises after recovery.  Prognosis and Course: Prognosis will depend on the successful repair of the aorta  potential complications  and his compliance with postoperative instructions and medications. If all goes well  he could have a good quality of life.   Follow up: Post-surgery  Mr. Conway would require close monitoring and routine follow-ups to check for potential complications and monitor his overall health status. Strict control and lifelong pharmacotherapy of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia is required  considering the significant risk these conditions pose on his cardiovascular system.

Case Summary:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male by the name of Robert Smith  who was referred to our Cardiology Department by his primary care physician for further evaluation of a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a past medical history of untreated hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history. He gave up smoking 5 years ago. He also has a history of occasional chest pain and shortness of breath upon exertion  which he attributes to his advanced age and previous smoking history. There are no known allergies. He is on Lisinopril for his hypertension and Statin for hyperlipidemia.  Family History: The patient’s father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 75. His younger brother  now 70  had an AAA repair 4 years ago. He reported no history of any vascular or heart diseases in his children.  Current Presentation:  The patient's AAA was incidentally discovered during a routine ultrasound of his kidney  which was ordered for his chronic kidney disease monitoring. The AAA measures approximately 4.5 cm in maximum diameter. The patient is asymptomatic  reporting no abdominal  back  or flank pain  and no recent episodes of syncope or near syncope.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient was found to be essentially stable. He is normotensive and afebrile. His abdomen is non-distended with normal bowel sounds and no noticeable pulsatile mass upon palpation.  As the AAA is approaching the intervention threshold size of 5.5 cm  a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the abdomen and pelvis is planned for better characterization of the aneurysm  and to evaluate his overall vascular health.  With the patient’s remarkable family history and personal history of significant risk factors for AAA  including advanced age  Caucasian race  history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  he is at a high risk of rupture. The intervention plan shall be discussed further considering his overall physical status and health. In addition  lifestyle modifications along with good control of his blood pressure and cholesterol level might be encouraged.  Future appointments and monitoring plans are in discussion  given the continuous evolution of the patient's condition. At the moment  close surveillance with a repeating ultrasound in 6 months  or earlier if he develops any symptoms suggestive of expansion or rupture of his AAA  would be prudent. If the AAA reaches the threshold size earlier or if the patient becomes symptomatic  the decision to proceed with intervention shall be made accordingly.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old African-American male residing in Houston  Texas. He is a retired mechanical engineer and has been living alone since his wife's death five years ago. He has two sons  both of whom are in different states  and he visits them alternatively.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been prescribed a beta-blocker (Metoprolol) and an ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril) for hypertension and a statin (Atorvastatin) for hyperlipidemia. He has been compliant with the medications. He has no history of diabetes mellitus  kidney disease  or thyroid disorders but has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since his early 20’s. He quit smoking three years ago when he first felt discomfort in his back.  Present Symptoms:  The patient came to the clinic complaining of constant low back pain that has been progressively worsening for the last six months. He also complained of occasional abdominal discomfort but denied any recent weight loss  loss of appetite  or changes in bowel movements.  Family History:  His mother died at the age of 78 due to complications following a stroke  and his father underwent a successful surgical aortic aneurysm repair at the age of 65 and died at 80 from an unrelated cause.  Diagnosis:  Upon physical exam  a pulsating mass was noticed in the abdomen  prompting an ultrasound that confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of 5.5 cm in diameter.  Case Details:  This is a case of AAA in a patient with risk factors of age over 65 years  history of smoking  hypertension  and a family history of AAA. The patient's size of aneurysm and symptomatic presentation puts him in a high-risk category. Guidelines recommend immediate consultation with a vascular surgeon for consideration of repair in patients with AAAs with a diameter of 5.5 cm or more  symptomatic AAAs  or rapidly enlarging AAAs. His case will be managed accordingly.  Plan:  The patient has been informed of the diagnosis and risks related to AAA. He is referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and to determine whether endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or open surgical repair would be more appropriate considering the patient's age and overall health condition.  Recommendation:  The patient will be advised to continue his medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia to mitigate the risk of rupture and to facilitate post-surgery recovery. Additionally  maintaining a balanced diet  light physical activity  and regular follow-ups will be recommended. If he requires surgery  pre-surgical assessment by a team of specialists will be arranged to ensure his readiness for the procedure  and post-surgical care will be planned accordingly.

Patient Initials: J.D Sex: Male Age: 65 years old Occupation: Retired mail carrier Ethnicity: Caucasian   Presenting Problem  J.D. arrived at the emergency room with a primary complaint of intermittent sharp and severe abdominal pain for the past two days  which was radiating to his back.  Medical History   J.D. was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and has been consuming anti-hypertensive medications since then. He was also diagnosed with borderline diabetes five years ago. However  he did not require medication for this and was instructed on lifestyle modifications. He is a chain smoker with a history of a 20 pack-year smoking habit. He also consumes alcohol moderately.  As far as his surgical background  he underwent an appendectomy in his youth but has no other significant surgeries and has no known allergies.  Family History   J.D. reported a family history significant for heart disease. His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 60  and his mother has chronic hypertension. His older brother died of stroke in his early 60s. J.D. also mentioned that a cousin was treated for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Clinical Findings  On examination  J.D. had a slightly elevated blood pressure (160/95 mmHg). There is palpable and pulsatile mass in his abdomen. His peripheral pulses were symmetrically present. Laboratory results showed a slightly elevated cholesterol level. An ultrasound of the abdomen was performed revealing an abdominal aortic aneurysm that measures approximately 5.3cm in diameter.   Conclusion and Plan  J.D. diagnosis was Marfan Syndrome  which is at high risk for aortic dissection or rupture  therefore the recommended plan was immediate surgical intervention. Post-surgery  J.D would likely be setup on a regimen to manage his risk factors  including lifestyle modifications (cessation of smoking  diet control for diabetes)  medications for hypertension and cholesterol  as well as regular follow-up for monitoring any further dilation of the aorta.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: Severe abdominal pain with occasional back pain.  Past Medical History: He has been diagnosed with hypertension and high cholesterol levels ten years ago. He was a smoker for 30 years but quit five years ago.  Family History: His father died of a stroke at the age of 76. There's a history of cardiovascular disease on his maternal side.  Examinations and Tests: Physical examinations revealed a slightly pulsating abdominal mass. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 6 cm in diameter. The computed tomography (CT) scan further confirmed the location  extension  and diameter of the aneurysm.  Current Medications: Currently  he is on medication for hypertension (amlodipine 5 mg daily) and hypercholesterolemia (simvastatin 40 mg daily).  Relevant Information: Given his history of long-term smoking  the patient is at an elevated risk for cardiovascular diseases. His age and the history of hypertension also make him vulnerable to conditions such as AAA.  Diagnosis: Based on imaging tests  Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment Plan: Prompt surgical repair of the aneurysm is planned considering its size (6cm) to prevent rupture. He will undergo an open surgical repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  depending on the surgical team's assessment. His blood pressure and cholesterol levels need to be optimally controlled before surgery.  Follow-up Plan: Mr. Doe will need periodic monitoring post-operation  with an ultrasound examination every 6-12 months to detect any graft complications or aneurysm recurrence. He will also continue his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medication  with regular blood pressure and cholesterol checks. His immediate family members  particularly male siblings and offspring  should also consider early screening for AAA due to the revealed family history.  Risks and Complications: AAA surgery carries risks  including heart attack  kidney damage  and infection. Post-surgery  Mr. Doe will need to maintain a heart-healthy lifestyle  which includes a nutritious diet  regular exercise  quitting alcohol  and routine follow-up.  Patient Education: Mr. Doe was informed about his condition  the need for surgery  and the importance of maintaining a heart-healthy lifestyle post-operation. The family was also advised about the increased risk in immediate relatives and the need for early AAA screening.  Informed Consent: The patient understood his diagnosis and the need for surgical intervention. He has given written consent for surgery  and possible risks and complications were explained to him.

Patient Presentation  Patient Initials: J.K.        Sex: Male Age: 67 Race: Caucasian   Presenting Problem  J.K. presented himself to the emergency department following the sudden onset of severe lower back and abdominal pain. The pain was described as both sharp and tearing  radiating to the back and persisting for over two hours.  Past Medical History  J.K. has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well controlled with medications. He also has a past history of tobacco use  having smoked for 30 years before quitting 10 years ago. There is no known diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  diabetes mellitus or any other significant maladies. He had a coronary artery disease diagnosed 5 years ago and he underwent percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA).   Family History  The patient's father died at age 70 due to myocardial infarction and his mother at age 72 due to stroke. He has one older brother who is still alive and well. There is no family history of cancer  but a significant family history of hypertension and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.  Social History  The patient is a retired engineer. He is presently married  and he and his wife have three adult children in good health. Although he stopped smoking a decade ago  J.K. has a history of heavy alcohol intake  but for the last five years  he does light-to-moderate drinking.  Objective Evaluation  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. The patient appeared sweaty and in distress due to pain. Blood pressure was found to be in the hypertensive range at 160/100 mmHg and heart rate was slightly elevated at 90 beats per minute.  Relevant Tests and Results  An urgent abdominal ultrasound was performed  revealing an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. CT angiogram confirmed the large infrarenal AAA without evidence of rupture  dissection or thrombosis.  Plan  Immediate surgical consultation was sought. The surgical team recommended an emergent open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair given the size of the aneurysm and the severe pain of the patient  suspecting an impending rupture. The patient was emergently taken to the operating room  where the aneurysm repair was successfully performed.  Outcome  J.K. made an excellent recovery and was discharged home after seven days. He has been referred to outpatient vascular clinic and physiotherapy. He was strongly advised to follow up regularly and adhere to his medications  especially antihypertensives  statins and antiplatelet agents. He was also provided with education regarding lifestyle modification including healthy diet  regular exercise and avoidance of alcohol abuse.   Informed written consent was taken from the patient for all the procedures. Compliance to medication regimen and lifestyle modification  as well as regular follow-ups  were stressed upon to prevent any possible future cardiovascular event.   Future Plans  Future plan includes yearly monitoring of another smaller aneurysm found in the common iliac artery during the CT angiogram  which will be managed conservatively unless it reaches a size of 3 cm or more. Given his family history  the patient was also advised to have his adult children screened for familial aneurysm syndromes.

Patient Information:  John  a 73-year-old Caucasian male presented with a two-day history of severe lower back pain which intensifies with movement. He is currently living alone in an urban setting.  Past Medical History: John has an existing diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which he has been managing with medication (Lisinopril 20mg and Atorvastatin 10mg  respectively) for the past 10 years. Additionally  John has a 40-year history of cigar smoking  though he quit approximately seven years ago.  Present Illness: He reports a recent unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the past month and indistinct  persistent gastric discomfort. He mentions that he has been frequently fatigued and experienced a couple of episodes of fainting in the recent past. Upon physical examination  a pulsating mass of about 3 cm in diameter was palpated in his abdomen.  Investigations:  Further evaluation through an abdominal ultrasound confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of 5.5 cm. A CT angiogram further revealed an infrarenal AAA with no evidence of rupture. Blood pressure upon admission was 180/90 mmHg  and all laboratory investigations  including complete blood count  renal function  and coagulation profile  were within normal range.  Family History: John mentions that his late father was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his late 60s  which was successfully managed through surgical intervention.   Management and Intervention:  John was immediately admitted hospital for monitoring. The case was discussed with the vascular surgeon who recommended an elective open surgical repair  taking into account the size of the aneurysm and John’s overall health status. In the meantime  medications were adjusted to better control his blood pressure. He was prescribed Amlodipine 5mg daily  considering his elevated blood pressure readings.   Conclusion:  John’s history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and past smoking habit  apart from his genetic predisposition due to the family history of AAA  contributed to the development of his condition. His case demonstrates the importance of regular health checks for early detection and proper management of cardiovascular conditions  particularly in individuals with multiple risk factors.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Robert Fox Age: 72 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Lawyer  Medical History: Robert Fox is a 72 years old Caucasian male who has presented with persistent abdominal pain and discomfort for the past one week. Past medical records reveal a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-year smoking history  although the patient quit smoking 10 years ago. There is no significant history of diabetes  asthma  tuberculosis  or hepatitis. He takes antihypertensive medication and statins.   Robert does not drink alcohol and leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle. His last regular physical examination was conducted six months ago when all laboratory findings were within normal range. Specific to the current symptoms  there is no associated fever  vomiting  melena  and changes in bowel habits.  Family History: Robert's paternal uncle had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that was surgically treated  and his mother died of stroke. There is a significant family history for cardiovascular disease with his father having a myocardial infarction at 68 years.  Clinical Evaluation:  On examination  Robert was afebrile with a blood pressure of 145/90. Notably  a pulsating mass was perceptible in the abdomen. The remainder of his physical examination was largely unremarkable.   Investigations: Given Robert’s age  symptoms and family history  an abdominal ultrasound was performed that indicated a 5.3 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. Vitals were stable throughout with no signs of impending rupture.   Conclusion: Robert has been scheduled for elective repair by open surgery given the size of his aneurysm and his general good health. He has been educated about the symptoms of rupture  which would require immediate hospitalization and emergency surgery. Post intervention  he will require close follow-up  and lifestyle modifications  particularly regarding his hypertension and hyperlipidemia have been stressed. He has also been recommended for a vascular surgery consult to assess the feasibility of endovascular repair.  With a calculated surgical risk  open repair or endovascular repair offers the best hope for a permanent cure and Robert appears to understand this. Known family history of AAA makes this already high-risk patient even more so  underscoring the importance of regular follow-up and health maintenance measures.

Patient Profile: The patient is a Caucasian male  aged 72 years  living in Newark  New Jersey. He is a retired mechanical engineer and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker  with a 20-pack year history  but quit about 15 years ago. He has a history of hypertension for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily)  and was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 10 years back. He drinks moderately. He does not have a history of substance abuse. He also reports an irregular diet  sometimes missing meals due to loss of appetite.   Family medical history: The patient’s father died from coronary artery disease at the age of 60  and his mother passed away due to complications from diabetes at the age of 72. There is no known history of aortic aneurysm in his family.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency room with complaints of abdominal and back pain  which he describes as a constant  intense pulsating sensation  located in the middle of his abdomen and radiating to his lower back. The patient rated the pain as an 8 on a scale of 10.  Medical Examination: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the patient’s abdomen. This  along with the history of hypertension  pointed towards a preliminary diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Investigations: A subsequent CT scan affirmed the diagnosis  revealing an AAA measuring 7.5 cm in diameter. This crucial size  combined with the patient's presenting symptoms  places the patient at a high risk for rupture - a life-threatening condition.  Management: The attending vascular surgeon recommended an urgent endovascular aortic aneurysm repair surgery  considering the size of the aneurysm and the patient's high rupture risk.   Post-Operative Care: Patient will be closely monitored in the hospital until stabilized  followed by regular follow-ups with the doctor for monitoring vital signs  possible complications  and the efficacy of the current treatment plan.  Conclusion: This case highlights the critical importance of early detection and intervention in a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm. Primary care providers should be aware of the importance of palpating the abdomen as part of routine physical examination for older male patients  especially those with a history of smoking and hypertension. Timely diagnosis and intervention can prevent the potentially fatal consequence of a ruptured aneurysm.   References: It is important to continually update professional knowledge regarding AAA  given the serious implications of this condition. The ""2014 AHA/ACC Guideline for the Management of Patients with Valvular Heart Disease"" provides detailed information on the management of this condition and is recommended as further reading.

Patient Case Presentation Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 75-year-old male  Caucasian  retired from the military and living with his wife. He is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. The patient has a family history of both hypertension and cardiovascular disease. His father died at the age of 68 from a heart attack while his mother passed away at the age of 72 due to stroke.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the clinic with a three-week history of generalized abdominal pain that is not associated with food intake. The pain is non-radiating  dull in nature  continuous  and graded as 5/10 in terms of intensity. No other gastrointestinal symptoms reported  like vomiting  altered bowel habits  or weight loss.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension for the past 20 years  for which he is under medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily). He also reported a past history of elevated cholesterol levels and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) but is not on home oxygen. He has not been previously diagnosed or treated for diabetes.  Physical Exam:  Upon examination  the patient appeared in mild distress due to pain. Vital signs were stable  except for an elevated blood pressure reading of 160/90 mmHg. On abdominal palpation  there was a pulsatile mass in the midline around the umbilicus.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  The patient underwent ultrasonography  which revealed a 5.6cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. A subsequent CT angiogram also confirmed the infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  consistent with the presented symptoms and physical exam. No rupture or leakage was evidenced.  Management Plan:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture  the patient was referred to Vascular Surgery for possible endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). Meanwhile  the patient's hypertension was escalated with an added medication (Amlodipine 5mg/daily).  Discussion:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) tends to be asymptomatic until it becomes large or ruptures. Risk factors include age >65  male gender  smoking  and a family history of AAA. Hypertension can be a risk factor as well. It's crucial to diagnose AAA early to prevent potential rupture and consequent high mortality. Management typically includes surgical intervention  alongside optimal control of associated cardiovascular risk factors. This patient's case is a classic example of the importance of early detection and multi-disciplinary involvement in management.

Patient Brief Case Presentation:   Patient details: Our patient Mr. John Doe is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  who presented with complaints of a dull  constant pain localizing in his lower back and abdominal regions. He is a retired civil engineer and lives with his wife in the city. He stated that the pain had been intermittently present over the last month but had been increasing in frequency and intensity over the past week.   Past medical history: Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 25-year history of cigarette smoking  but he quit smoking five years ago. Also  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  for which he is currently on metformin. No past surgical history was reported by the patient.  Family history:  Mr. Doe's father died of a stroke at the age of 75  while his mother lived up to the age of 80 without any significant medical issues. His older brother  aged 77  was recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm as well.   Findings: This prompted suspicion of the potential for a vascular disease  particularly an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This suspicion increased due to Mr. Doe's age  sex  history of hypertension  and smoking. He underwent an abdominal ultrasound which confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring around 4.6cm in diameter.  Treatment Plan: The multidisciplinary team will pursue close observation and management of risk factors  considering the AAA size. This will include continuous hypertension  cholesterol  and diabetes control. Mr. Doe is also advised to attend follow-up visits every 6 months to monitor the aneurysm  as rapid enlargement or symptoms may suggest the need for surgical intervention.  The case of Mr. Doe emphasizes the importance of considering AAA in the differential for non-specific abdominal or back pain  particularly in those patients with risk factors such as age over 65 years  male gender  history of smoking  and hypertension. Furthermore  it underscores the significance of familial tendency in the development of AAAs and the utility of ultrasonography in initial diagnosis and follow-up assessment.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named Jim  who resides in New York City. He is a retired construction worker and leads an overall sedentary lifestyle due to occasional joint pain. He has been a heavy smoker for the last 45 years and moderately consumes alcohol.  Medical History:  Jim has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he takes medication. He had been experiencing intermittent and vague abdominal pain for over a week  which was initially attributed to indigestion and managed with over-the-counter antacids. Three days ago  the abdominal discomfort became acute  initially functioning as a pulsating lower back pain  ultimately driving Jim to the emergency department.   In the past  Jim underwent an angioplasty at the age of sixty for coronary artery disease. Echocardiogram reports have shown a mildly reduced ejection fraction. His chart also shows a diagnosis of Stage-2 Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)  for which he undergoes routine blood work. He has been treated twice for pneumonia over the past six years.  Family History:  Jim's family history reveals that his father died due to a rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 68. His mother lived until 91 and passed away from a stroke. He has two older brothers; one is healthy  and the other diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type 2.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable that directed clinical suspicion towards AAA. His blood pressure was 165/90  and heart rate was 88 bpm. Laboratory examinations of Jim showed slightly elevated creatinine  suggestive of his underlying CKD and marginally raised troponin levels. His complete blood count  coagulation profile  and electrolyte levels were all within normal limits. Further  a contrast-enhanced CT scan confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm.  Diagnosis and Management:  Given the size of the AAA  Jim's history of smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  and family history of AAA  the risk of rupture is high. After discussions involving vascular surgery  interventional radiology  and the patient  a decision was made for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).  In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of considering AAA in the differential diagnosis in elderly patients presenting with unexplained and persistent abdominal or back pain  especially in the presence of risk factors such as hypertension  high cholesterol  smoking  and family history. Timely diagnosis and intervention are crucial to prevent fatal complications such as rupture.

Patient Information:  Joseph Brown  a 68-year-old Caucasian male originally from Texas  has been confirmed with a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm(AAA).  Medical History:   Mr. Brown is a retired accountant now living in Denver  Colorado. He has a past medical history including hypertension for the last 15 years; for which he has been on medication. He was diagnosed with Type-II diabetes approximately 10 years back and has been controlling it with a combination of medications and dietary changes. He also had a stroke three years ago but fully recovered without any significant neurologic deficit. His other past medical history includes occasional GERD and hyperlipidemia.  Family History:   Mr. Brown has a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his elder brother had been diagnosed with AAA at 70 years. There is also a family history of type-II diabetes including his only sister and nephew.  Social History:   Mr. Brown is a widower  living with his elder daughter and two grandchildren. He quit smoking after his stroke three years back and has been maintaining an active lifestyle ever since. He drinks alcohol only socially and moderately.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Brown came with complaints of moderate to severe persistent abdominal pain that occasionally radiates to his lower back. The pain has been growing worse over the last month. He also notes occasional nausea and feeling of fullness even after small meals. He has lost about 10 pounds unexpectedly in the last three months without making any major dietary changes.  Investigations and Findings:  On clinical examination  a pulsatile mass could be palpated in his abdomen with auscultation revealing a bruit. Hence  Abdominal Ultrasonography was done which confirmed the presence of an AAA  with a maximal diameter of 5.5 cm.  Case Discussion:  Mr. Brown's AAA is an incidental finding following his complaints of persistent abdominal and back pain. Although AAAs are often asymptomatic until rupture  abdominal and back pain have been found to precede AAA rupture. Considering his significant family history of AAA and cardiovascular diseases; and also his past medical history  especially of hypertension  there is a risk factor predisposing Mr. Brown to AAA. His AAA is now approaching the size (5.5cm) at which prophylactic surgery is considered; to avoid the risk of rupture.  Plan:  The patient should have a detailed discussion with vascular surgery about the benefits and risks of both endovascular stent grafting and open surgery repair. His blood pressure control should be optimized. The GP should be informed  and a referral to a dietician for better diabetic control through diet may be helpful. His family members may also benefit from screening  considering the hereditary predisposition to AAA.

Case Presentation  Patient Information:  Mr. X is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a height of 5'10"" and weight of 185 lbs  retired automotive worker  who lives independently at home with his wife. He was brought to the hospital by his son due to complaints of a sudden  severe and persistent pain in his lower back and abdominal region  which started a couple of days ago.  Medical History:  The patient is known to have an extensive medical history with hypertension as well as hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on Amlodipine and Simvastatin respectively for the past 16 years. He is also a reformed smoker  consuming one pack daily for 30 years  but finally managed to quit smoking almost eight years back. He does not have any known allergies. His vaccination history is up-to-date  and his immunization includes an influenza shot annually and pneumococcal vaccine every five years.   Family History: A history of cardiovascular diseases is evident in his family. His father had a myocardial infarction at 65 and passed away due to stroke at 70. His mother died of heart failure at 75. He has one elder brother who is diabetic and a younger sister who is healthy.  Examination and Lab Investigations: The patient appeared uncomfortable. His blood pressure was 170/90 mmHg  with a pulse of 85 bpm  regular. His respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 97% on room air and temperature of 37.3 degrees Celsius. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Detailed lab tests showed slightly raised D-dimer and C-reactive protein indicating inflammation  normal kidney function tests  but raised cholesterol levels. Also  an abdominal Ultrasonography and CT scan findings confirmed the presence of the abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Diagnosis: Given the patient's clinical picture and diagnostic tests  a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is made.  Treatment Plan: The aneurysm measures approximately 5.6cm in diameter  which represents a critical size in terms of rupture risk and has significant pain indicating instability. An immediate referral to vascular surgery for endovascular aortic repair was completed. Also  the patient’s current medications will be continued until further recommendation by the vascular surgeon.  Follow-up: The patient will be admitted under the surgical unit and monitored for postoperative recovery and progress. There will be routine follow-ups and clinical assessments to monitor for any complications after the surgery.  Conclusion: Despite Mr. X being a fairly fit individual for his age  with the controlled underlining condition  his previous smoking habit and the family history of cardiovascular disease lead to the development of AAA. Early diagnosis and intervention in Mr. X's case signifies the importance of regular monitoring in those with risk factors for AAA  even in the absence of symptoms  to prevent fatal complications.

Patient Presentation  Complete Demographics:   The patient is a 72-year-old Portuguese-American male  recently retired firefighter  residing in Charleston  South Carolina with his wife and two adult children. He presents as a non-smoker and a social-drinker.   Chief Complaint:   Patient reported experiencing persistent abdominal pain and lower back discomfort over the past few weeks. The pain occurs intermittently  typically after meals  and worsens upon physical exertion.  Relevant Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia controlled with Atorvastatin. He underwent appendectomy at the age of 25 and has had recurrent urinary tract infections over the past decade.  Family History:   His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 74. His older brother (75) has a diagnosed  but not yet surgically intervened  5 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. His mother passed away at the age of 86 from natural causes. The patient has two adult sons  both in good health.  Medical Examination and Test Results:   Vitals: BP 150/90 mmHg  HR 77/min  respiratory rate 18/min  SpO2 96% on room air  BMI 30 kg/m^2.  Physical Exam: Poorly localized pain in the lower abdomen and back on palpation. No pulsating mass palpable in the abdomen. Normal bowel sounds heard.   Investigations: Abdominal ultrasound revealed a 5.5 cm fusiform aneurysm in the infra-renal segment of the aorta. No immediate signs of rupture were noted. Further analysis by CT scan confirmed the diagnosis and showed that the aneurysm is saccular with moderately thickened aortic wall.  Impression/Diagnosis:   The patient's age  gender  complaint of abdominal and back pain  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history  and ultrasound + CT results all support the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Due to the size of the aneurysm (5.5cm)  the patient is at a high risk of rupture and requires immediate intervention.  Treatment and Management:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture  a timely open surgical repair (OSR) or endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) should be considered based on the thorough examination of the patient's overall health and surgical risks. The patient should also receive counselling on lifestyle changes such as improving diet and maintaining regular exercise to control hypertension and hyperlipidemia.   Prognosis:  Early identification and treatment significantly lower the risk of rupture  which carries a mortality rate of over 80%. With proper monitoring and recommended surgical intervention  the patient has a good chance of having a successful outcome.

Presentation:  The patient is a 74-year-old African American male who is recently diagnosed with a 5.4 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) detected by screening ultrasound taken due to the presence of risk factors.   Demographics: He is retired  nonsmoker  but used to smoke one pack per day for about 40 years until he quit 10 years ago. He enjoys moderate alcohol consumption and follows a low-cholesterol diet. Lives alone in an urban apartment. He is insured and has access to medical and surgical services.  Medical History: The patient has hypertension and Type-II diabetes and is taking antihypertensives and oral hypoglycemics. Has average glycemic control with a last HbA1c of 7.8  3 months ago. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years back and has been on low-dose aspirin since then. Cholesterol levels have been in the normal range with no history of strokes  claudication  or TIAs. Past surgical history includes a successful prostatectomy for BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia) 10 years ago.  Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67  mother lived up to 83 years with no major health issues. He has 2 siblings  one of them suffered from a ruptured AAA at the age of 72.   Current Condition: He remains asymptomatic with regards to the AAA  with only mild to moderate lower back pain occasionally  which he had attributed to his old age. He has average mobility and is able to perform activities of daily living independently.  Examination: On physical examination  he was found to be of average build with some evidence of peripheral vascular disease in the form of weak pedal pulses. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile and expansile mass in the infrarenal region. No other significant findings were present.  Discussion: Since the AAA is larger than 5 cm with a high-risk family history  the usual course of action would be to consider surgical repair to prevent rupture. However  his previous cardiac event and chronic conditions like diabetes might make him a high-risk surgical candidate  hence a thorough pre-operative evaluation including cardiac stress testing would be advised. A detailed discussion about his potential risks and benefits must be carried out with the patient.  Based on this information  it is imperative to decide the appropriate course of action which should be individualized to the patient's unique medical and social situation.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. Charles Hernandez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  presented in the clinic with a primary complaint of occasional discomfort and a dull  throbbing pain in the lower back and abdominal area.  Past Medical History: The patient has a recorded history of coronary artery disease  hypertension  and high cholesterol levels. He also sustained a minor stroke 5 years earlier but has made a successful recovery.  Current Medication: He is on aspirin  metoprolol  atorvastatin  and amlodipine for his heart condition and hypertension.  Family History: His father passed away due to an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 68  and his mother died of complications related to diabetes in her mid-70s. He has a brother diagnosed with angina.  Social History: The patient quit smoking ten years ago after a 30-year history of smoking. He drinks alcohol occasionally but has no history of illicit drug use. He is retired but stays physically active on a daily basis  performing light exercises and walking.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  Mr. Hernandez's blood pressure was slightly elevated  and a pulsating mass was palpable in the mid-abdominal region. A bruit was detected over the mass on auscultation.   Diagnostic Assessment: He was immediately subjected to an ultrasound scan  which revealed an enlarged abdominal aorta with a diameter of 5.5 cm  suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An ECG demonstrated normal sinus rhythm with no signs of ischemic changes.  Management: Emergency referral was made to Vascular Surgery following the initial diagnosis and assessment. The clinical decision was to perform an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) to prevent rupture of the aneurysm. Additionally  prescribed medications for his heart condition and hypertension were reviewed and adjusted to optimize his blood pressure and overall cardiovascular health before the operation.  Discussion: The AAA in patients like Mr. Hernandez can be asymptomatic and only detected via physical examination or incidentally during diagnostic imaging for other conditions. However  once it expands beyond 5 cm  the risk of rupture increases significantly  necessitating immediate surgical intervention. The prognosis after EVAR surgery is generally good with continued follow-up.    Future Consideration: The presence of AAA in Mr. Hernandez also warrants careful monitoring of close relatives considering the higher risk in first-degree relatives of patients with AAA.

Patient's Overview: This case involves Mr. A  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  with a recent diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He was referred to the clinic due to a discovery made during a routine abdominal ultrasound undertaken for unrelated renal issues. He is a retired engineer and lives with his wife. Their two daughters live nearby.  Medical History: Mr. A has an extensive medical history including controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Notably  he is a former smoker  having smoked a pack a day for approximately 30 years  but quit smoking 10 years ago. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use. Despite these current controlled conditions  he remains relatively mobile  performing daily tasks independently  with mild dyspnea upon exertion due to COPD.   Presenting Problem: He presents with asymptomatic AAA identified through ultrasound  which he underwent due to a history of nephrolithiasis. No abdominal pain  back pain  or recent changes in bowel or urinary habits noticed  which are cardinal symptoms of ruptured/symptomatic AAA.  Family History:  There is a concerning family history  as his father died suddenly due to (presumed) ruptured AAA at the age of 75. Moreover  his elder brother underwent successful elective surgical repair for AAA at the age of 73. No known history of connective tissue disorders in the family.  Examination/Diagnosis: A physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. Subsequent ultrasonography of the abdomen confirmed the presence of an AAA with a maximum diameter of 5.3 cm. No other visceral anomalies were detected. EKG showed no abnormalities.   Treatment Plan: As per the current guidelines  since the aneurysm is larger than 5.5 cm  the patient was informed about the need for surgical intervention to prevent the risk of rupture. After discussing the pros and cons  the patient consented for elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). A detailed surgical planning CT with contrast was arranged. His medications  including antihypertensives and oral antidiabetic agents  were reviewed and optimized.  Conclusion: This patient’s case portrays the significance of routine health checks and gives emphasis to the value of a detailed patient and family history. For patients such as Mr. A with established risk factors for AAA  including older age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  and family history of AAA  early detection and appropriate management is key to preventing fatal complications.   Note: In real-world practice  precise information regarding the patient's demographics  medical history  presenting symptoms  initial diagnosis  laboratory results  treatment and outcomes will be included in a case presentation.

Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile:   Mr. John Masters  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  lives in the suburbs of New Jersey  with his wife and is a retired engineer. He has been experiencing persistent abdominal pain and back discomfort for several weeks  which led him to seek medical advice.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Masters has a lengthy medical history that includes well-managed hypertension for the past 10 years  hyperlipidemia  and COPD due to 40 years of smoking. He has two former myocardial infarctions  the most recent one was five years ago. For these conditions  he routinely takes tab lisinopril  tab atorvastatin  tab metoprolol  and inhalational salbutamol. He quit smoking after his second MI.  Family History:  There's a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases: both his father and older brother died of heart attacks in their early 70s. His mother had stroke at the age of 80 and died at 84. Additionally  his maternal grandfather had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Presenting Complaints:  His main complaints are dull ache in his abdomen and lower back pain. The pain isn't associated with meals  posture  or physical activity. He reported unintentional weight loss but no fever  chills  or changes in bowel movements.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was felt. The patient also displayed mild hypertension with a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg.  Investigations:  Labs were largely unremarkable with normal renal function  CBC  liver function and electrolytes. Abdominal ultrasound confirmed a 5.5cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm.  Diagnosis:  Given the clinical examination and ultrasound findings  Mr. Masters was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Plan:  Elective surgical repair of his AAA is suggested due to its size and risk for rupture. Mr. Masters will need a pre-operative evaluation to ascertain his fitness for surgery. His hypertension should also be managed more aggressively. A cessation of smoking was previously achieved  a low fat diet to manage his hyperlipidemia and continue his medications has been recommended. Alongside medical treatment  the benefit of repair (open or endovascular) should be discussed and considered. Regular follow-ups for his other chronic conditions are needed.  Informed consent regarding the benefits  risks  and alternatives to surgery will be taken. Family support and engagement during this time would play a vital role in the management of Mr. Masters' condition. His case should be managed with a multidisciplinary approach involving the cardiologist  surgeon  anesthetist  and nursing staff.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 70-year-old male  Mr. J  Caucasian  retired military officer  living with his wife in the suburbs of New York. He is a non-smoker and maintains a moderate alcohol consumption. His BMI is 28  indicating overweight.  Presenting Complaints & Clinical Findings: Mr. J complained of severe lower back pain and abdominal discomfort persisting for the last two weeks. He had an occasional drop in blood pressure. He also mentioned feeling a pulsating sensation near his navel. The pain has not subsided despite initial treatments for low back pain.  Past Medical History: Reviewing his medical history  it reveals that Mr. J is diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years  controlled by medication. He also has borderline hyperlipidemia and had peripheral vascular disease about 10 years ago. He is not diabetic  but he has a history of heart disease and had undergone coronary artery bypass graft surgery approximately 6 years back.  Family History: Mr. J reported that his father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 75.  Investigations & Diagnosis: Given his symptoms and family history  the physician ordered an abdominal ultrasound. This revealed a 5.5 cm aneurysm in his abdominal aorta. Based on the screening results and clinical presentation  a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm was made.  Treatment & Follow-Up: Considering his age  size of aneurysm  and medical history  the multi-disciplinary team recommended surgical intervention—an elective Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR). He is currently under preoperative assessments to minimize the anesthetic risk. Simultaneously  he is counselled about the possible risk and benefits associated with the procedure. His blood pressure is being closely monitored with adjustments in medications as required. He will be followed up postoperatively in the vascular clinic every 6 months with ultrasound for surveillance of his EVAR.  This case highlights the importance of considering a diagnosis of AAA in older patients presenting with unexplained  persistent back or abdominal pain  especially with a family history of AAA or significant risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and timely intervention can prevent catastrophic outcomes like aortic rupture.

Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information Patient AB  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented with abrupt onset of severe lower back pain radiating to both lower extremities. He is a current smoker with a history of 30 pack-years and notable physical findings include a body mass index (BMI) of 29.8 kg/m(2)  a large pulsatile abdominal mass  and normal peripheral artery pulses.   Prior Medical History AB's past medical history includes hypertension  dyslipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. He is being managed on Lisinopril 20mg daily for his hypertension  Atorvastatin 20mg daily for his dyslipidemia  and Aspirin 81mg daily for his peripheral artery disease. His last check-up was six months ago and he has reported good compliance to his medications. Despite persistent advice  he has continued to smoke.  Family History The patient revealed his father died at the age of 65 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). There is no history of AAA on the maternal side of the family. However  his mother died of a heart attack at the age of 75 and his brother  aged 70  is currently being treated with antihypertensive drugs for high blood pressure.   Current Presentation Following assessment  an urgent Computed Tomographic Angiogram (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of AAA measuring 7.8 cm with the possibility of rupture. Due to increasing back pain and risk of AAA rupture  he was recommended for urgent surgical intervention. The patient has been advised to stop smoking  maintain a healthy diet  and keep up with drug treatment to control blood pressure and lipid levels.   Given his age  smoking history  and notable family history of AAA  the patient was at a high risk for developing AAA. Although the patient acknowledges the severity of his condition  he remains adamant on maintaining his current lifestyle habits and is doubtful about the proposed surgical intervention. Emphasis on the risks of his lifestyle choices and the projected positive outcomes of the prescribed surgical treatment is our ongoing challenge with patient AB.

Patient Information: The patient is Mr. Thomas  a 68-year-old Caucasian male who is retired. He lives with his spouse and maintains a fairly sedentary lifestyle since retirement. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  after a 30-year pack-a-day habit. His body mass index (BMI) is 27.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thomas has a past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has not had any previous surgeries or significant illnesses. Up to this point  Mr. Thomas has been managing his medical conditions with medication and regular check-ups. His medications include Lisinopril 10mg once daily and Atorvastatin 40mg once at night.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented with intermittent abdominal pain and lower back discomfort. The pain is described as sudden  severe  and constant  mostly in the abdominal area  radiating to the lower back. It lasts for several hours and isn't relieved by changes in position or other symptomatic measures.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  On examination  the clinician palpated a pulsatile abdominal mass  raising the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An ultrasound confirmed the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.5cm in diameter. The patient's blood pressure and heart rate were noted to be elevated during the episodes of pain; however  no other signs or symptoms of shock were present.  Family History:  Mr. Thomas's father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 70. His mother died of breast cancer at 65. He has one brother who also has an AAA diagnosis.  Management:  Due to the size of the aneurysm and family history  the decision was made to proceed with surgical intervention. The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for an endovascular repair (EVAR). He will also undergo a cardio-pulmonary assessment given the risk factors and the nature of the surgery.  Discussion: Mr. Thomas is at higher risk of having an AAA given his gender (male)  age  history of smoking  and the presence of other cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Furthermore  his positive family history and his age push the risk even further. His current symptoms of abdominal pain and the size of the aneurysm suggest an imminent risk of rupture  necessitating instruction for surgical evaluation. After surgery  Mr. Thomas needs to be monitored long-term with regular imaging surveillance to ascertain the stability of the aneurysm repair.

Patient Introduction: Mr. James Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden severe abdominal and back pain  which he described to be ripping and tearing in nature. Mr. Smith is a retired machine operator and lives with his wife in a suburban community.   Relevant Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension which is managed by lisinopril (5mg daily). He also has a distant smoking history of 20 years but quit about 25 years ago. He also has hyperlipidemia. Mr. Smith reported regular checkups with his primary care physician and allegedly was in stable condition until the development of the current symptoms.  Family History: The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his mother died of stroke at 70. Mr. Smith has one brother who is 62 and has recently been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). There's no known family history of connective tissue disorders.  Physical Examination: Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 185/101 mm Hg and pulse rate of 91 beats/minute. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. Lab results showed anemia and elevated inflammatory markers. Electrocardiogram was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Evaluation: An emergent CT scan was performed  confirming the presence of a 7.4 cm AAA with evidence of rupture. The patient was immediately referred to vascular surgery for further management.  Management and Outcome: Mr. Smith underwent an emergent open surgical repair (aortic grafting). Postoperative recovery was complicated by an acute kidney injury related to perioperative hypotension. However  with aggressive management  his renal function returned to baseline  and he was discharged home on postoperative day 8.  Discussion: In Mr. Smith's case  risk factors for AAA include his age  gender  history of hypertension  former smoker  as well as his brother’s diagnosis of AAA (which can indicate a possible genetic predisposition). Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention are crucial in the management of a ruptured AAA to avoid potentially fatal outcomes.   Healthcare providers must maintain a high index of suspicion for AAA in patients presenting with acute onset of abdominal or back pain  particularly in those with risk factors. A routine screening program could be beneficial for high-risk individuals considering the silent nature of the disease. Regular follow-ups with primary care physicians  and management of risk factors  are essential preventive strategies for these patients.

Patient Profile:   Mr. John S.  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired  with a BMI of 28  was referred by his family physician for further evaluation after detection of a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Patient’s Past Medical History:  Patient has a past medical history of high blood cholesterol  hypertension  and smoking for 40 years before quitting two years ago. He had an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) around a year ago  with no recurrence. No history of diabetes. Patient is currently on statin therapy for hypercholesterolemia and antihypertensive drugs.   Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. S. came into the clinic with symptoms of occasional vague abdominal discomfort and back pain. He denies any recent weight loss or loss of appetite. He reported having some difficulty in passing stools  thought to be constipation. No history of abdominal surgeries or traumas.  Family History:  His father passed away from a heart attack at age 75  and his mother died from a stroke at ages 82. He has a brother who had an operation for abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 70. There is no history of aneurysms  strokes  or diabetes in any of his four children  all above 30 years.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. His blood pressure was measured to be 145/90. No signs of peripheral vascular disease were noted. His blood cholesterol level was found to be slightly elevated despite statin therapy.  Diagnosis:  Upon suspicion  a transabdominal ultrasound was performed which confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring approximately 5 cm in the largest diameter.
