A subsequent contrast-enhanced CT scan confirmed an incidental unruptured atheromatous aneurysm in the abdominal region.  Treatment Plan:  Given Mr. S.'s age  smoking history  the size of his aneurysm  and family history of aortic aneurysm  surgical intervention is planned. The patient will undergo the endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure. His blood pressure and cholesterol levels will continue being managed medically. He receives information about risks and benefits concerning the procedure and gives his informed consent.  Outcome & Follow-up:  Follow-up will include regular physical check-ups and imaging surveillance post-EVAR every six months for the first two years  then annually thereafter  to ensure there are no complications or recurrence.   In conclusion  Mr. S.'s case highlights the importance of family history in the early detection and management of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Rodriguez  a 71-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal and lower back pain that had been worsening over a period of four hours. He described the pain as a tearing sensation radiating to his back. He also complained of nausea and shortness of breath. His vitals on admission were blood pressure: 140/90mmHg and a heart rate of 100 beats per minute.   Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50 pack-year smoking history. He has been on Amlodipine and Lipitor for the last 15 years. He underwent an appendectomy in his twenties and was in good health until a diagnosis of hypertension at the age of 50. There is a negative history of alcohol or drug abuse. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes a rash.  Family History:  Mr. Rodriguez's family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. Both his parents died of heart disease in their late sixties. His two older brothers have coronary artery disease  and one of them also has an abdominal aortic aneurysm. There is no known family history of connective tissue disorders or polycystic kidney disease.  Clinical Findings:  Clinical examination showed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. The patient looked uncomfortable. There were no signs of peritonitis. A computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 8cm  which was severely infrarenal and was threatening to rupture.   Impression and Plan:  Considering the patient's age  medical history  family history  and most importantly his present clinical picture  the diagnosis of a rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made. The increased size of the aneurysm  combined with his symptoms  suggested imminent rupture  which elevated the patient to surgical emergency.   The vascular surgery team was immediately consulted and the patient was prepared for an emergent open surgical repair  given his stable hemodynamic condition. He was counsellued about the urgency and risks of the procedure and provided informed consent. Post-operation  the patient will be closely monitored in ICU for any signs of complications  such as renal failure  bowel ischemia  and lower limb ischemia. After discharge  surveillance will be initiated for the monitoring of other potential aneurysms  given the family history. The patient will also be advised on lifestyle modifications  such as quitting smoking  along with the continuation of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia management.  This case underscores the importance of prompt diagnosis and intervention in elderly patients with a significant smoking history and family history of aneurysms  who present with symptoms suggestive of a rupturing AAA.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Marital Status: Married  Presenting Problem: Mr. Doe was referred to the vascular surgery clinic for evaluation of an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm  as reported by his primary care physician.  Medical History: Mr. Doe is a long-standing patient with a history of hypertension  smoking (30 pack/year)  peripheral artery disease  and hypercholesterolemia. He had a myocardial infarction twenty years ago  treated with a single bypass graft.  Present Condition: At the time of presentation  Mr. Doe reported feeling occasional  mild abdominal discomfort but no severe pain  back pain  tenderness  or other consistent symptoms associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  he had a palpable  pulsating mass in the mid- and upper abdomen.  Investigative Results:  An abdominal ultrasound revealed a 5.4 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No evidence of rupture or leaking was found.  Family History:  Mr. Doe’s father passed away at 70 due to a myocardial infarction. His mother deceased at 90 with no cardiovascular problems. He has two brothers; one diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his 60s.  Social History:  Mr. Doe is married with two grown-up children. He used to smoke 1 pack/day for 30 years and quit about ten years ago. He denies any alcohol or recreational drug use.  Treatment Plan:  Given the aneurysm's size and the patient's risk factors  the team recommended surgical intervention  in particular  endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The associated risks  potential benefits  and alternatives were extensively discussed with the patient and his family. They agreed with the proposed plan.  Prognosis: The prognosis for Mr. Doe following surgery is generally good  considering his past medical condition. However  regular monitoring to check aneurysm growth and leaks is recommended. He has agreed to participate in a smoking cessation program  which will substantially decrease his future peripheral and cardiovascular risks.   This case presentation illustrates the importance of early detection  evaluation  and timely intervention in managing abdominal aortic aneurysms effectively. It also emphasizes the importance of addressing lifestyle factors like smoking  known to potentiate aortic aneurysm progression.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department complaining of extreme pain localized in the lower back and abdominal area. He described the pain as a dull and deep-seated ache. The pain was sudden in onset and had been persistent for over an hour intermittently. His vital signs showed elevated blood pressure at 168/100 mmHg  heart rate of 88 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 97% on room air  and temperature was 98.2°F. He had no known allergies at the time of presentation.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years  managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin. The patient has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit smoking about ten years ago. He also has a history of obesity  with a BMI of 31. No history of any surgical intervention was reported.  Family History: His father died at 78 due to coronary artery disease  and his younger brother suffered a stroke at 60. Apart from cardiovascular complications  neither the immediate family members nor the extended family showed a history of diseases like cancers or infectious diseases.   Present Illness: Physical examination revealed a pulsating abdominal mass. However  no bruits were heard over the mass. The rest of the physical exam was unremarkable. Due to the nature of his symptoms and findings upon examination  an urgent contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan was ordered  which showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 7.5cm in diameter.   Investigation reports and findings: His blood panel showed borderline elevated LDL cholesterol levels  suggesting a moderately high cardiovascular risk. Normal kidney functions indicated no evidence of renal artery involvement. D-dimer level was slightly elevated  which typically happens with AAA. However  EKG  hematologic  and metabolic panels were normal.   Treatment and Prognosis: The patient was emergently prescribed iv morphine for pain management. Since he was hemodynamically stable  he was scheduled for an urgent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) over open surgical repair because of his age and hypertension.   The case was discussed with vascular surgery  and consent was taken for intervention. Patient was put on diltiazem to control his hypertension. His recovering prognosis post-surgery will need to be closely monitored considering his past medical history and large size aneurysm.   Summary: This case represents a classic presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in a patient with significant risk factors  including advanced age  male gender  history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a smoking history. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are key in preventing serious complications such as rupture and death. This case also underlines the importance of adopting a healthy lifestyle and regular screening in patients having multiple risk factors  for preventing aortic aneurysms.

Patient Identification: Mr. M.B.  67-year-old male  Chief Complaint: The patient has been experiencing persistent abdominal and lower back pain for the past week.  Presenting Illness: Patient presents with symptoms that suggest an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication. Patient also has borderline diabetes but has been managing it with diet and lifestyle changes.  Family History: Patient's father died at age 56 due to an AAA rupture  and his mother died from stroke at age 80. He has a younger brother living with diabetes and hypertension.  Social History: Patient is a retired engineer. He quit smoking 15 years ago after a 25-year pack-a-day habit. Also  he drinks alcohol socially.  Examination: The patient was alert and oriented. His vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 156/92 mmHg; pulse  78 bpm; and respirations  16 per minute. He had a distended abdomen with a pulsatile mass in the midline  and there was tenderness on deep palpation.  Investigation: Abdominal Ultrasonography revealed a 5.8 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. No rupture or leak was noted.  Diagnosis: Based on the history  clinical exam  and radiological evidence  the patient was diagnosed with an unruptured AAA.  Management Plan: The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for possible surgical intervention. He was also advised to maintain good control over his hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and borderline diabetes to reduce the risk of complications associated with AAA. He was counseled on the importance of frequent monitoring and adherence to his medication regimen.  Comments: AAA is a potentially life-threatening condition if ruptured  hence prompt diagnosis and management are crucial. It is more common in males and risk increases with a family history of AAA  old age  smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and other vascular diseases.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male from New York City  was referred for consultation and further evaluation after an incidental finding of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) during an ultrasound scan for an unrelated matter.   His demographics include retirement from a professional job  high socio-economic status  non-smoker  non-vegan  ethyl alcohol consumer twice in a week. He lives with his wife  does regular self-care  and participates in moderate physical activities. He is not under any form of caregiver support.   The patient’s past medical history reveals hypertension controlled with medication (lisinopril 20mg daily)  dyslipidemia managed with statins (rosuvastatin 20mg daily)  and Type II diabetes mellitus under control with metformin (500mg twice daily). He denies any known allergies to food  chemicals  or medicine. He has a surgical history of an uncomplicated appendectomy which occurred 15 years ago.  Further  the patient demonstrated a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases  with both his father and younger brother dying of myocardial infarction in their mid 70s. His mother died of stroke at the age of 78.   He denies having any complaints of pain  discomfort in his abdomen or lower back  or any episodes of fainting. He maintains regular bowel and urinary habits without any disturbances. He has not reported any loss of weight  loss of appetite  or fever. His vital signs are within normal limits  although blood pressure on his recent visits has been around 145/95 mmHg.   The patient's radiology report showed an AAA of approximately 4.6cm in diameter. The aneurysm located just above the aortic bifurcation with no significant increase in size over the last 3 months as per the comparison with previous images. No signs of rupture or impending rupture such as inflammation or hematoma were noted.   Inspecting the lipid panel  he demonstrated slightly elevated levels of total cholesterol and LDL with controlled triglycerides and HDL levels. His blood glucose level and HbA1c level were also under control  showing efficient management of his diabetes.  Moving forward  controlling his hypertension and maintaining regular follow-ups seem to be an immediate need. Given his familial history and lifestyle  he is at a high risk of AAA rupture. Therefore  an intervention plan should be proposed based on the threat-to-life and the potential benefits and consequences of the procedure. Constant monitoring of the AAA coupled with lifestyle changes will also be of primary importance in his case.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. D.T  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  visited his primary care physician for an annual check-up. His weight and BMI fall well within the normal range for his height. He is in a stable relationship  lives with his wife  and has two adult children. He is a retired mechanic and enjoys gardening and woodworking in his free time. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history  which he quit 10 years ago. He maintains a moderate consumption of alcohol  drinks occasionally on weekends.  Past Medical History/Pertinent History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and a sedentary lifestyle. He has been experiencing occasional back pain for a few years. Previously  he was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and had undergone percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement 5 years ago. Medication history includes an aspirin daily and moderate-intensity statin for hyperlipidemia.  Family History:  Both of D.T's parents passed away in their mid-80s. His father died due to heart disease and his mother due to natural causes. There is no known family history of aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Symptoms:  During his current visit  D.T complained of an unusual dull ache near the navel area. Initially  he deemed it indigestion but after it persisted  he became concerned. He also reports fatigue and unintentional weight loss.  Physical Examination:  On palpation  his abdomen is soft with a pulsatile  expansile aorta. No additional arterial bruits were noted.  Investigations:  Ultrasound examination revealed an infrarenal aortic aneurysm measuring 4.5 cm in diameter. Furthermore  the blood report showed slightly elevated liver enzymes.  Diagnosis:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Recommended Management:  This patient is scheduled for an outpatient computed tomography (CT) scan to further evaluate the aneurysm and surrounding vessels and organs. Meanwhile  aggressive blood pressure control would be ideal. The size of the aneurysm does not warrant surgery at present but does require close monitoring. Regular follow-ups for monitoring the progression of the aneurysm size are necessary. The decision for future treatment  whether endovascular or open surgical repair  will be taken as per the progression and development of the symptoms.  Education on the significance of regular follow-ups  reducing alcohol consumption  and encouraging a healthy lifestyle to modulate cardiovascular risk factors was provided. Also  the patient was advised to immediately report any sudden  severe pain in the back or abdomen.

Case Presentation  Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents himself in our healthcare facility. He is a retired Army officer and has a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died of a myocardial infarction at age 54 and his brother having undergone aortic aneurysm repair at age 49.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Doe presents with intermittent  dull abdominal pain that aggravates on physical activity and subsides on rest. The pain made him visits our clinic.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension diagnosed in his late forties and has been on medication (Lisinopril and Amlodipine) ever since. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia seven years ago and is currently on Atorvastatin. He is a non-smoker  consumes alcohol socially  and leads sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.   Physical examination:  On examination  a palpable pulsatile mass was found in his abdomen. The mass does not appear tender or have an increased temperature in comparison to the surrounding area. His blood pressure was 145/90 mm Hg and the pulse rate was 80 beats/min.  Investigations & Diagnosis:  Following these initial findings  an abdominal ultrasound was suggested which confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm of 5.4cm. A subsequent CT angiogram was performed to assess the anatomy of the aneurysm further  which supported the diagnosis.  Management & Conclusion:  Given the size of the aneurysm and history of hypertension  it was decided to offer Mr. Doe an elective open surgical repair. Patient and his family were informed about the situation  the need for surgery and potential risks & complications. A team approach involving vascular surgery  cardiovascular anaesthesiology and intensive care was discussed at length and implemented to provide optimal preoperative  intraoperative and postoperative care.  In summary  Mr. Doe  a 67 y/o male with a significant hypertension and hyperlipidemia history  is diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His management plan  which includes an elective open surgical repair  is kept patient-centered  considering his previous medical history  lifestyle  and family history.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the clinic with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and back pain that started half an hour ago. He rated the pain as a sharp  9/10 pain that spread from his mid-abdomen to his lower back. He described a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30 pack-year smoking history  which he quit ten years ago. He is currently on Atorvastatin for cholesterol and Losartan for his blood pressure. Mr. Smith has no known allergies.   He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other symptoms. He has never had a similar episode in the past. Family history revealed that his father died in his 60s from an aortic aneurysm. His siblings have a history of cardiovascular disease  particularly hypertension.  Possibly Relevant Results:  On examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 168/98 mm Hg  heart rate was 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  temperature was 37.2°C  and oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. Abdominal examination showed a pulsatile mass around the navel  tenderness precisely over the mass  but no signs of peritonitis.  After initial clinical assessment  an immediate abdominal ultrasound was performed. The ultrasound demonstrated a large  7 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with signs of a possible rupture. The patient was immediately transferred to the emergency department for further evaluation and management.  The patient condition was explained to him  including the risks of rupture  probable complications  need for emergent surgical intervention  and prognosis. The patient agreed and provided informed consent for emergency surgery.  Impression:  The patient was diagnosed with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  which is a serious  life-threatening condition. Considering his age  history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and positive family history  he was at a high risk for developing AAA. Despite controlling his hypertension and cholesterol levels in recent years  the patient couldn’t escape his genetic predisposition.  Plan:  Mr. Smith was transferred to the operating room for an emergency repair of his ruptured AAA. The procedure was successful  and Mr. Smith was moved to the intensive care unit for close monitoring postoperatively.  This case concludes that strict monitoring and aggressive control of risk factors  plus screening for AAA in high-risk patients (such as Mr. Smith) can be beneficial in early detection and better management outcomes.

Patient Information: Mr. John Baker  a 75-year-old African-American male was admitted to our hospital following complaints of persistent  severe abdominal and back pain. He is a retired teacher and lives with his wife in the city. He is a non-smoker and drinks wine socially.   Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels and has been on antihypertensive and statin therapy for the past ten years. Mr. Baker has managed the hypertension well  with regular follow-ups and medication adjustments as needed. He has not had any other major illnesses or surgeries in the past. No history of allergies to any medication was reported.  Family History: Upon questioning  he disclosed a family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father had an aortic aneurysm (the aneurysm ruptured) and died at the age of 70. He has two brothers  one of whom has hypertension and the other passed away due to myocardial infarction.  Presenting Complaints: He first experienced sudden severe pain near the navel a week ago  lasting for more than a few hours  along with back pain. Over the week  the pain gradually spread to the groin and buttocks. No exacerbating or relieving factors were identified. There was no evidence of associated symptoms such as fever  syncope  or weight loss. Signs of shock or rupture were absent. His pulse rate and blood pressure were in the normal range.   Physical Examination: On examination  he was in no critical condition  conscious  and oriented. An abdominal palpation revealed a tender  pulsating mass in the central portion of his abdomen. The peripheral pulses were equal in all the limbs.   Investigations: Due to the family history and clinical presentation  an abdominal ultrasound was ordered  revealing a 5.1 cm dilation of the abdominal aorta. Computed Tomography scan of abdomen and pelvis confirmed the presence of an infra-renal Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  confirming the suspicion.    Management and Outcome: Given his condition and the size of the aneurysm  operative intervention was warranted. Following interdisciplinary discussions  an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure was performed due to its minimally invasive nature and the patient's preference. He tolerated the operation well with complete resolution of symptoms post-operatively.  The plan is to monitor his condition closely under cardiology and vascular surgery care  focusing on lifestyle counseling and regular medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia control. He is also scheduled for six months' follow-up imaging tests to monitor the status of the aneurysm repair.  Teaching Points:  This case highlights the importance of detailed family histories when assessing cardiovascular risk  especially in patients with hypertensive and hyperlipidemia history. It also stresses early imaging and intervention in patients presenting with clinical suspicion of an aneurysm  given its potentially life-threatening complications if left undiagnosed or untreated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who is under observation for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He was diagnosed with the condition four weeks ago during a routine ultrasound scan  meant to monitor his chronic kidney disease stage 3.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension that has been controlled with medication for the past 15 years. He also has chronic kidney disease stage 3  which has been stable for the last couple of years. He ceased smoking 5 years ago but had a 35-year history of smoking one pack per day. He has moderate alcohol intake and follows a low-salt diet due to his kidney disease.  Current Medications:   Lisinopril for hypertension and Rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia. Due to worsening of kidney function over time  dosage adjustments are periodically made.  Family history:  There is a significant family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his brother recently diagnosed with AAA too.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith is asymptomatic  without any abdominal or back pain. The AAA was found incidentally during an ultrasound scan for his chronic kidney disease monitoring.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  Mr. Smith appeared well. Vital signs were normal  and the abdominal examination was unremarkable with no palpable mass. His cardiovascular examination was normal without any significant peripheral vascular disease signs. The AAA was confirmed using a subsequent CT angiogram  which showed a 5.4 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment Plan:  Given the size of the aneurysm  the dangers of rupture are real. Therefore  an elective open repair surgery is planned. Mr. Smith has been informed about the risks and benefits of the procedure. He is scheduled to meet the anesthetist and the preoperative assessment team next week. He also knows the necessity of complying strictly with his antihypertensive medication to control his blood pressure before the surgery.  This case brings out an incidental finding of a large AAA in a patient with significant smoking and cardiovascular risk factors  which affirms the need to maintain a high index of suspicion in individuals with such risk predispositions. The timing and type of surgical intervention  open repair in this case  reflect the size of the aneurysm and the patient's overall health status.

Patient Presentation  Demographics: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who works as a retired teacher  married  with three grown children.  Chief Complaint: He presented at the emergency room complaining of sudden onset lower back pain of severe intensity.  Past Medical History: His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 30 years of smoking history (quit smoking 10 years ago). He has no known allergies. He underwent hip replacement surgery five years ago without any complications. His current medications include amlodipine and rosuvastatin.  Social History: The patient lives with his wife and is quite physically active for his age. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.  Family History: The patient reported a positive family history for cardiovascular disease. His father had myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his maternal uncle died of a stroke in his 70s. No known genetic diseases run in his family.  Physical Exam: On physical examination  his vitals were within normal limits and he appeared in mild distress. His abdomen was noted to be soft with a palpable pulsatile mass in the mid-lower abdomen.   Diagnostic Tests: An urgent CT scan was done which revealed a large abdominal aortic aneurysm of approximately 7.5cm with no sign of rupture.  Assessment and Plan: The patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The size and the presence of severe back pain elicited a high concern for impending rupture. The patient was urgently referred to vascular surgery and consented for immediate surgical intervention for repair of the aneurysm.   During a follow-up visit  the patient recovered well from the surgery without any complications and was advised to continue in medication for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  obtain regular follow-up care with his cardiologist  and adopt lifestyle modifications including a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  and maintaining a healthy weight to reduce his risk of recurrent aneurysm and other cardiovascular problems.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates a classic presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  quick identification and referral for surgical intervention were crucial to prevent life-threatening rupture.

Case Presentation  Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67 years old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presents with steady  gnawing pain in his lower back and abdomen that has persisted for the last three days. The pain seems to intensify upon standing and sitting upright for long durations.  Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily for approximately 20 years but quit 15 years ago. He continues to consume alcohol socially and moderately. He also has mild obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30.   Episodes of faintishness along with back and abdominal pain have been increasing in frequency over the past three months. He had consulted a local physician who diagnosed him with sciatica due to his complaints of lower back pain radiating to the lower extremities.  Clinical Examination:  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the abdomen. His blood pressure was high at 160/90 mmHg and heart rate was 83 beats per minute. His lungs were clear to auscultation  cardiac examination revealed no abnormalities  and the remaining physical exam was unremarkable.   Investigations:  He was referred for an abdominal ultrasound which revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of 5.2 cm. Based on the subsequent CT scan  it was concluded that the aneurysm was infrarenal and non-ruptured  with no apparent involvement of the iliac arteries.  Family History:  Mr. Doe’s father had a history of stroke at an advanced age  and his mother died of a heart attack in her late sixties. His one older sibling also had an AAA  detected and repaired in his early 70s.  Diagnosis:   A diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made.  Management:  Considering the size of the aneurysm as well as his family history  Mr. Doe is planned for an elective surgical repair of the aneurysm. He is to continue antihypertensive medications  and he is referred to a dietitian for weight and cholesterol management. Further discussions on the details and risks of surgery are planned.  Patient Education:  Patient is educated on the necessity of following the prescribed medication regimen and maintaining a healthy lifestyle  including low-cholesterol diet and regular exercise. He is informed about the risk of rupture and the importance of coming in for follow-ups or seeking immediate medical attention if he experiences sudden intense abdominal or back pain.  Follow Up:  Regular follow-up visits are scheduled for check-ups and to monitor his progress post-operatively.

Patient Profile: The patient under review is a 74-year-old Caucasian male  weighing around 92 kg with a height of 5ft 11in. He is a non-smoker and a moderate alcohol consumer.  Presenting Problem: He was presented at the hospital complaining of constant  severe abdominal pain  which occasionally radiated to his back. He reported the pain had gradually increased over the last few days. He is not taking any regular type of medication.  Past Medical History: He has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both were controlled with medication. He quit smoking 10 years prior  but he was a heavy smoker (2 packs per day) for more than 30 years. He remained physically active before the current issue.  Family History: His father died from a myocardial infarction at a young age (56)  and his mother lived to be 85 but suffered from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. According to the patient  his maternal uncle had an 'aneurysm ' but he wasn't sure about the location or the outcome of the condition.  Clinical Examination: On physical examination  he appeared uncomfortable with a mildly distended abdomen. His vitals were within normal limits except for elevated BP (170/95 mmHg). On auscultating the abdomen  a bruit was heard over the upper abdomen.  Investigations: An abdominal ultrasound showed a 5.5 cm dilatation in the infrarenal abdominal aorta which was confirmed by a subsequent CT angiography. There was no indication of any renal issues  liver disease  or gastrointestinal concerns.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  based on his symptoms  physical examination  and radiographic reports.  Current Management: Given the sudden onset and the severity of pain coupled with the size of the aneurysm  an immediate surgical referral was made considering the high risk of rupture. He is scheduled for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).  Follow-up: Post-operative and post-discharge follow-up care will include regular blood pressure management  cholesterol checks  advice on a low-saturated-fat diet  and regular physical activity. The patient will also be counseled on the importance of stress management and avoiding alcohol.  This case illustrates the significance of early detection and timely management of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  especially in patients with a strong smoking history and high-risk factors such as hyperlipidemia and hypertension. This case further highlights the importance of careful patient history taking and thorough physical examination.

Patient Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson is a 69-year-old Caucasian male who resides in an urban setting with his wife. He is a retired carpenter and has a history of smoking 2 packs/day for the past 35 years. His BMI is 30.2  indicating obesity. He does not drink alcohol and does not participate in any regular physical activities.   Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden  constant  and severe abdominal and lower back pain that began approximately 4 hours prior to admission.   Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension for the past 15 years. He also has a moderate history of hyperlipidemia and has experienced intermittent claudication  but up until this point has been non-compliant with his exercise prescription and medication regimen  including antihypertensives and statins. He has no known allergies. He had a cholecystectomy at the age of 50 due to gallstones.   Family History: His father died at the age of 72 due to myocardial infarction. His mother lived to the age of 90 and died of natural causes. She had hypertension. He has one older brother who has an AAA and is scheduled for elective surgery.  Physical Examination: On examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in his abdomen. Blood pressure was 165/90 mm Hg  heart rate was 100 bpm  and he had a decreased breath sound on the left lower lung. His skin was cool and clammy and he appeared in distress due to pain.  Lab Results: Laboratory evaluation revealed a slightly elevated WBC count  indicating possible infection. His Hemoglobin and Hematocrit were within normal levels. His cholesterol level was high with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol level significantly high. His renal function was mildly impaired  indicated by increased serum creatinine.  Imaging: An emergency ultrasound confirmed a 6.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment: An urgent CT scan was ordered for further assessment and the patient was scheduled for immediate repair surgery considering the size and symptomatic nature of the aneurysm. His family was informed of the urgency and potential risks associated with the procedure. Consent was received for emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). After successful surgery  the patient was shifted to intensive care for close monitoring.  Conclusion: Mr. Johnson's heavy smoking history  obesity  advanced age  and familial predisposition likely contributed to his diagnosis. AAA cases like this underscore the importance of early detection through routine screenings  especially for those with risk factors  and the necessity of lifestyle modifications and adherence to prescribed therapies.

Patient Info: Mr. John Smith  Male  67  Caucasian  Presentation Mr. John Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  was referred to our medical center with a recent diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He presented complaints of vague and intermittent abdominal pain located in the middle and lower part of his abdomen  plus lower back discomfort for the last 6 weeks. On further enquiry  he reported the pain to be mild  non-radiating  non-provoked by meals  and not associated with any particular physical activity. He had no history of fever  nausea  vomiting  weight loss  change in bowel habits  or urinary symptoms.  Past Medical History Mr. Smith has an established diagnosis of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia managed through medications for the last 10 years. He used to smoke 1 pack per day for 30 years but quit approximately 15 years ago. He has a history of alcohol consumption  reporting an intake of about 2-3 drinks daily for the last 40 years. He has no history of illicit substance use.  Family History His father died at 72 from a heart attack  and his mother at 65 due to a stroke. He has one elder brother diagnosed with an AAA in his mid-70s who is alive and well following surgical intervention. This family history indicates a possible genetic predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.  Physiological Examination On physical examination  he was hemodynamically stable. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable pulsating mass in the middle of the abdomen  which was non-tender on palpation.  Investigations Laboratory examinations  including electrocardiogram and complete blood count  were normal. In view of his symptoms and physical examination  a CT scan was planned and revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring approximately 5.6 cm in diameter.  Management and Plan Mr. Smith was admitted for further evaluation and possible surgical intervention for his large AAA. Given his medical history  it is critical to initiate measures to control his blood pressure and cholesterol levels rigorously and monitor for any signs of aneurysm expansion or rupture. With the patient's informed consent  an open repair or endovascular technique intervention will be scheduled  depending on his overall evaluation.  Conclusion This case underscores the significance of vigilance in patients presenting ambiguous abdominal symptoms  particularly those with a personal or family history of AAA. Early detection and appropriate management of AAA can significantly reduce the risk of rupture and associated morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. A.J.  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of consistent abdominal and back pain. Mr. A.J retired from his job as a construction worker five years ago. He is a widower and a smoker  with a 40-pack-year smoking history.  Medical History: Mr. A.J. has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are under control with medication. He had surgery to remove his gallbladder 18 years ago and has no other surgical history. He has not reported any known allergies.  Family History: Mr. A.J. has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his 50s  and his mother died due to stroke at the age of 75.  Current issue: The patient complains of consistent abdominal pain for the past week. Further  he states that he has been occasionally experiencing back pain that radiates to his groin  with increasing severity. He denies experiencing nausea  vomiting  past incidences of fractures  or bowel and bladder changes. His appetite and weight have remained consistent.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient’s blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg in the right arm  heart rate is 80 beats per minute  and his respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute with an oxygen saturation level of 98% on room air. The abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. Auscultation identified a bruit over the same area.  Investigations: The patient underwent a CT scan  which confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.2cm in maximum diameter.  Diagnosis: The size of the disease and associated symptoms leads to the diagnosis of a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Plan: Mr. A.J. is at a high risk for rupture due to the size of the aneurysm and his symptoms. Therefore  he will be referred for an imminent surgical intervention  either an open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  based on a vascular surgeon's assessment.   Follow-Up: We need to emphasize the importance of regular follow-up post-surgery and lifestyle modifications  namely smoking cessation  diet modification  and appropriate exercise. Upon discharge  he will be required to take medications as prescribed and attend all follow-up appointments for monitoring and managing any potential complications.   The patient’s family members should also be informed about their increased risk of developing AAA  considering their familial relation to Mr. A.J.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. J  a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-pack year history of smoking  is presented. He is currently residing in Chicago  Illinois  with his wife. He had been feeling relatively well until three days ago  when he started complaining of uncharacteristic abdominal and lower back pain.  History of present illness:   Mr. J came to the emergency department (ED) complaining of a sudden onset of severe abdominal and lower back pain that started three days ago. The pain was constant  rated 9/10  and did not alleviate with rest or over-the-counter pain medications. There was no nausea  vomiting  fever  urinary or bowel changes. He also reported a recent loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss over the past month.   Past medical history:   He was previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 15 years ago  and he has been on treatment with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. Patient is also an ex-smoker with a 20-pack year history who quit 10 years ago.   Family History:   His father passed away at 82 due to complications following a myocardial infarction  and his mother is alive and well at 101 with no significant health issues. His older brother died at 62 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Physical examination:   On examination  the patient looked anxious but was alert and oriented. His blood pressure was 140/90 mm Hg  pulse – 80 beats per minute  temperature of 36.7oC (98.1oF)  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Abdominal exam revealed a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area associated with tenderness.  Pertinent Tests and Results:   A confirmatory abdominal Ultrasound reveals a 6cm abdominal aorta aneurysm. His complete blood count was within normal limits  as were his liver function tests. His renal function was mildly impaired  with a creatinine of 1.5 mg/dl (normal < 1.3mg/dl).   Impression and Plan:  Given these findings  the patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm  likely related to his long history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. Given the size of his aneurysm and associated symptoms  the patient was advised immediate surgical intervention to prevent rupture. We also discussed the need for better blood pressure control and the maintenance of a heart-healthy diet. The renal impairment might necessitate a lower Lisinopril dose; however  this will be reconsidered post-surgery. The patient was admitted to the surgery unit for monitoring and preparation for surgery.   Our plan is to repair the aneurysm endovascularly  followed by regular follow-ups for surveillance. Patient education and reassurance were also provided to Mr. J and his family. The risks associated with delayed intervention were explained carefully  and questions/concerns were addressed.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male was referred to our vascular clinic due to an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) during a computed tomography (CT) scan for a routine prostate cancer check. Mr. Doe is retired  lives with his wife and has two adult children. He is a former smoker  having quit a decade ago after a 30-year habit. He co-manages moderate hypertension and Type 2 diabetes with appropriate medication and lifestyle modifications. However  he admits difficulty adhering to a healthy diet and struggles with regular exercise due to age-associated mobility issues.  Doe's past medical history includes hypertension diagnosed 12 years ago  managed on angiotensin II receptor blockers and diuretics. His Type 2 diabetes was diagnosed 8 years ago  controlled by metformin and a bariatric diet. He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) 5 years ago. He is also on a statin for hyperlipidemia. There is no history of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  carotid artery disease  stroke or renal failure. He underwent surgical repair for an inguinal hernia in the distant past.  His family history is significant for cardiac and vascular diseases. His father died of a myocardial infarction at 70 and his mother survived a stroke at 85. One of his brothers had an aortic aneurysm surgically repaired at 72.  Presenting complaint and investigations:   He was entirely asymptomatic regarding the AAA. CT scan revealed an infrarenal AAA measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. Further physical exam and investigations showed a well-healed midline sternotomy scar and a surgical scar in the lower-right quadrant. Cardiovascular examination was normal with no abnormal arterial pulses.   Impressions:  Considering the patient’s past and family history  long-term smoking history  and asymptomatic presentation  an incidental diagnosis of AAA was made. Current guidelines suggest surgical intervention for AAAs measuring greater than 5.5 cm or rapidly expanding aneurysms. This patient's AAA meets the criteria for surgical intervention.   Treatment plan and follow-up:   Given the size of the AAA and patient's previous history  he is promptly referred to vascular surgery for further evaluation and likely endovascular repair. Pre-operative cardiology clearance will be needed considering his prior CABG. Regular follow-up post-repair to monitor the success of the procedure as well as management of his diabetes and hypertension is planned. Lifestyle modifications to correct his diet and increase physical activity within the capabilities of his age and mobility are also emphasized.

Case Presentation   Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. S. He is a retired engineer  living with his wife in the suburbs.  Chief Complaint: Mr. S has been experiencing constant  severe lower back pain for the past two weeks.  History of Present Illness: Mr. S’s pain has been non-radiating and without any positional alleviation. It ranges from 7-8 on a scale of 10. He reports no recent history of injury  strains  or heavy lifting. In the last few days  he has also started feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. Mr. S denies any changes in bowel or bladder function. He has occasional dizziness but denies any chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  or syncopal episodes.  Past Medical History: Mr. S has a history of hypertension and moderate hyperlipidemia. He was a smoker for about 50 years but quit 10 years ago. Mr. S also had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  and as a result  he is on aspirin  metoprolol  and atorvastatin.  Family History: Mr. S’s father died of a stroke in his early 70s  and his mother died from complications of diabetes mellitus at 85. His only sibling  a brother who is 72  had a recent diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Physical Examination: Mr. S’s Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile  expansile mass in the infraumbilical region which increased suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). His blood pressure on presentation was 160/90 mmHg. The rest of his systemic examination was unremarkable.    Diagnostic Assessment: Ultrasonography aorta revealed a saccular aneurysm in the infrarenal section of the abdominal aorta measuring 5.5 cm in maximal diameter. Enhanced CT Angiogram confirmed the above findings and ruled out any rupture or emergency situation. Lab investigations showed slightly elevated serum creatinine levels and normal Hb/HCT levels  indicating compensatory erythropoiesis. His lipid profile showed raised LDL levels.    Plan: Due to the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  surgical intervention is deemed appropriate. The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).  This case of Mr. S illustrates a typical case of large abdominal aortic aneurysm in a patient with relevant risk factors including advanced age  male gender  hypertension  a history of smoking  and family history of cardiovascular disease and AAA.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Doe  Demographics: Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  presents to the clinic with his wife. He is a resident of New York City  United States.  Reason for Visit:  Complaints of intermittent abdominal discomfort  notably in the lower abdomen that tends to increase after meals. History of slight shortness of breath while performing regular activities.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia that are currently under control with Losartan and Atorvastatin respectively. He is a former smoker  he quit 15 years ago after smoking for 30 years. He takes mild alcohol occasionally and he has no known drug allergies.   Family Medical History: His father suffered from heart disease and passed away in his late 70s. Mr. Doe's mother had a stroke in her 80s and the patient has two siblings who are alive and well. However  his maternal uncle had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Physical Examination: Mr Doe appears comfortable  rational and communicative. His vital signs reveal blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  a pulse of 80 bpm and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. His BMI is within the normal range. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass.  Investigations: A duplex ultrasound carried out at the clinic revealed a dilated aorta measuring 5.5 cm in transverse diameter. Blood tests results were within normal range  with the exception of slightly elevated cholesterol levels.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) based on clinical examination and ultrasonography findings.  Treatment: Considering his age  the size of the aneurysm  and potential for rupture  it was decided to refer Mr Doe for an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The medical team also reinforced the importance of medication adherence to maintain his hypertension and hyperlipidemia under control.  Follow-Up: A follow-up appointment was scheduled 1 month post-surgery and regularly thereafter. Additional imaging studies suggested in accordance with current guidelines.  Patient Education:  Detailed explanation about abdominal aortic aneurysm  its cause  complications like rupture and the need for surgical intervention were provided. The core measures to reduce the risk factors  including sustaining a heart-healthy diet  maintaining a regular exercise regime  and regular medications were emphasized.  (Please note  the case is fictional and created just for the purpose of the given task)

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 75-Year-Old Retired Male (Case Study)  I. Demographics The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  who resides in Austin  Texas. Our patient is a former smoker (20-pack year history  quit 15 years ago) and has a known history of moderate alcohol intake (10-14 drinks/week). He is married with three grown children and lives with his wife of 48 years.   II. Referring Complaint The patient presented with episodic lower back pain over the last three weeks which he initially dismissed for age-related aches. The pain became persistent and progressively intense  prompting him to visit the emergency department.  III. Past Medical History  Patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension (controlled on lisinopril)  and type 2 diabetes mellitus (controlled on metformin). He underwent surgery 5 years ago for a right knee replacement due to advanced osteoarthritis. History of annual physical examinations with age-appropriate screenings  including colonoscopies.  IV. Family History His father died due to a stroke at 82  and his mother passed away from complications of breast cancer at 78. Of his two brothers  one developed coronary artery disease in his sixties and had a bypass surgery  the other is healthy. No known family history of aneurysms.  V. Physical Examination  Vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass slightly above the umbilicus. There was no palpable tenderness  and the remainder of the abdominal examination was unremarkable. Peripheral pulses were present and symmetric.   VI. Diagnosis and Assessment Abdominal ultrasound was performed that showed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Abdominal CT angiography confirmed the AAA  which was fusiform with no signs of rupture or dissection.   VII. Management Plan Considering the patient's age  family history of cardiovascular disease  past smoking  hypertension  and the size of the aneurysm  we decided to proceed with endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The patient was adequately informed about the procedure  risks  and possible complications. Meanwhile  he was closely monitored for signs of rupture.  VIII. Outcomes and Follow-up Patient underwent a successful EVAR without complications. He was discharged after 4 days with prescriptions for a beta-blocker  a statin  and aspirin  and instructions to quit drinking. Scheduled follow-up appointments at 1 month  6 months  and then annually for ultrasound surveillance  physical examinations  and evaluation of his cardiovascular risk profile.  This brief case presentation shows an elderly patient with an asymptomatic AAA detected due to his low back pain  emphasizing the importance of considering AAA in differential diagnosis in similar clinical scenarios. The case also highlights the need for considered management decisions based on individual patient profiles.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presents at the emergency department with mid-abdominal pain radiating to his back. He describes the pain as severe  sudden  and constant  rating it as 10/10. The pain initiated while he was engaged in his daily chores at home with no history of trauma  injury  or heavy lifting. The patient reports that the pain was accompanied by episodes of dizziness and nausea  but no vomiting or change in bowel and urinary habits.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a medical history of hypertension for the last 15 years  managed with hydrochlorothiazide and beta-blockers. He also has a 30-pack-year smoking history  though he quit five years ago. Additionally  he suffers from stage III chronic kidney disease due to long-term hypertension and is closely followed by a nephrologist. He has no known drug allergies.   Family history:  Patient reports a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having suffered a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 80.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he appears distressed with a slight pallor. His vitals are BP: 145/90 mm Hg  Pulse: 110 bpm  Temp: 98.2°F  and Respiratory rate: 23 bpm. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the middle abdomen with moderate tenderness. His extremities are warm with palpable peripheral pulses. There is no sign of lower extremity edema.  Additional Workflow: An emergent ultrasound reveals a 6.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). CT angiography confirms these findings  demonstrating a saccular aneurysm with no sign of rupture or dissection.  Case Management:  Given his age  clinical presentation  and size of the aneurysm  planning was made for an emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Mr. Smith was immediately started on analgesics for pain and beta-blockers in preparation for surgery.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the typical symptoms of an increasing AAA  the risk factors including age  hypertension  smoking history  and the importance of early diagnosis and intervention. Regular follow-ups in primary care could have identified this potentially life-threatening condition earlier. Awareness and education about the dangers of smoking and importance of blood pressure control may have helped in the prevention and management of his condition.   Disclaimer: This is a hypothetical patient presentation and does not represent any real patient's information. Always consult your medical provider for any health concerns.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. L is a 67-year-old male retired teacher  Caucasian  married  and with a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He was referred to our hospital's cardiovascular department with intermittent abdominal pain associated with weight loss over the past few months. His pain was not related to meals  and no other symptoms were noted  such as vomiting or palpitations.  Past Medical History:   Mr. L has a documented history of hypertension for 15 years  managed with Lisinopril 10 mg daily. He's also known to have hyperlipidemia under control with statins (Atorvastatin 20 mg). He also had an episode of chest pain four years prior  investigation of which revealed no significant cardiac etiology. Further  he has no known history of diabetes  no reported food or drug allergies. Mr. L has a 10-pack-year history of smoking but quit nearly 12 years ago.  Family History:  His father died of a stroke at 78  mom died of breast cancer at 82  an elder brother died of a heart attack at 64  and a younger sister alive and currently 60-years old diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. No known hereditary conditions  but the cardiovascular disease seems prevalent in his family.  Examination and Investigation:  On examination  Mr. L maintained good general condition with a BMI of 27.8. Vitals recorded: BP 140/90  RR 16/min  HR 70 beats/min  SpO2 98% on room air. Abdomen palpation revealed a pulsating middle abdominal mass  while auscultation revealed a bruit. Other systemic examinations were within normal limits.  Urgent ultrasound was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a 5.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. The subsequent CT angiography confirmed the size and infrarenal location while assessing the anatomy for potential intervention.  Management:  Considering the measurements  infrarenal location  and family history of cardiovascular diseases  Mr. L was recommended for surgery as the aneurysm size puts him at risk for rupture. His case was discussed in the Vascular Multidisciplinary Team meeting  and elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was planned.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Mr. L underwent successful EVAR with no major complications  presented a favorable postoperative recovery  and was discharged 3 days after surgery. He is scheduled for follow-up appointments to monitor his recovery and the success of the procedure  comprising clinical examination & CT angiography.  This case underscores the importance of considering an abdominal aortic aneurysm in older patients who present with nonspecific abdominal pain  particularly those with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial in preventing catastrophic complications such as aneurysm rupture.

Patient ID: Mr. A  Age: 68  Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Married  Mr. A presented to the emergency department complaining of persistent lower back pain which had been worsening over the last three days. He also mentioned feeling a pulsating feeling in his abdomen. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated  prompting concern of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).   Medical History: Mr. A is a known hypertensive since 10 years and is currently on medication  Metoprolol. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and is on Atorvastatin. He was a smoker since his mid-20s but he quit in his 40s.   Family History: His father passed away at 73 due to an AAA rupture and his mother has a history of coronary artery disease. He has an older brother who has recently been diagnosed with an AAA  but is currently asymptomatic.  Diagnostic examination: A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring 5.6 cm. His blood tests all showed normal levels except for a slight elevation in his CRP levels  which suggests some degree of systemic inflammation. His chest X-ray was normal  and his EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with no sign of ischemia or any other previous infarction.   Management plan: Given the patient's history  size of the aneurysm  and symptoms  there is a high risk of rupture and it was deemed necessary to proceed with elective surgical repair. The case was referred to the vascular surgery team for evaluation and to discuss with the patient his options: an open repair or a less invasive endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).   In summary  the case presents a 68-year-old male with a significant family history of AAA and a personal history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been diagnosed with AAA and is referred to a vascular surgeon for further management. The patient and his family were counseled on the importance of regular follow-up  necessary lifestyle changes  including healthy diet  and regular physical activity. He was also urged to alert any close family members about his diagnosis due to the potential hereditary nature of this condition.   The patient's subsequent response to treatment and his progress are being closely monitored with the hope for a successful reduction in the risk of future severe complications  such as rupture  which can carry a high risk of mortality.

Patient Information:  - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 65 years old - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Chief Complaint:  The patient presents with a 2-week history of lower back and abdominal pain  which he describes as dull and constant  with occasional sharp spikes.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication (Lisinopril 10mg for hypertension and Atorvastatin 20mg for hyperlipidemia). He quit smoking 10 years ago but had a 30-year tobacco history prior to quitting. The patient also admits to moderate alcohol use.  Family History:  The patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father suffered a myocardial infarction at an early age (52 years old)  and his older brother underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 70.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  the patient is hemodynamically stable but appears to be in mild distress due to discomfort. Abdominal palpation revealed a pulsatile mass in the central area associated with tenderness.   Diagnostic Investigations:  An abdominal ultrasound was performed  which confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. A subsequent CT scan clearly delineated the aneurysm  its size  and relationship to the renal arteries.  Clinical Impressions:  Given the significant size of the aneurysm and symptoms  it is assessed as a high risk for rupture. The patient's family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  along with his own history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia increase the overall risk.   Management Plan:  Surgical consultation was sought to discuss a possible endovascular aortic repair  an appropriate intervention for this case  considering in light of the patient's overall clinical picture. Further  patient education regarding the immediate discontinuation of alcohol  maintaining a healthy diet  and regular surveillance is crucial.

Patient's Information: The patient is a 65-year-old  Caucasian male. He is retired  living with his wife in a suburban community. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  but previously smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He drinks alcohol occasionally and exercises regularly.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  which is being currently controlled with anti-hypertensive medications. He was previously diagnosed with high cholesterol as well but has since maintained a healthy diet and regular exercise  thereby managing it without medication. There is no known history of diabetes  cancer  or any other significant diseases.   Family History: As per family history  the patient's father died at age 70 due to heart disease. The patient's mother is presently adept at 95 with no cardiovascular issues but lives with Alzheimer's Disease. He has an older sister who was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 55  and a younger brother with diabetes.  Current Presentation: The patient was brought into the hospital with complaints of persistent  sharp pain in the middle of his abdomen and significant back pain. These symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few days. He also reported experiencing episodes of shortness of breath and fainting spells. The patient denied any chest pain  bowel irregularities  or changes in appetite or weight.   On physical examination  his vital signs were all within normal limits  but a palpable  pulsatile mass was found in his abdomen.   Investigations and Diagnosis: On suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  a Computed Tomography (CT) angiogram was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a large  5.5 cm infrarenal AAA. No signs of rupture were detected.   Management: Considering the size of the AAA and the patient's symptoms  the patient has been referred to a vascular surgeon for intervention. Based on the patient's overall health status  either an open surgical repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) will be considered. The patient was advised to remain in the hospital for monitoring until the surgery. He was also educated about the potential risks of aneurysm rupture.  This case underscores the importance of routine physical examinations and attentive history taking  especially in patients with a known history of cardiovascular disease or associated risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and age.   The patient and his family were explained about the diagnosis and the need for surgical intervention. They appeared to understand and agreed for the same. They were reassured of best possible care during his hospital stay.

Patient Presentation  Mr. John Doe is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented at the clinic due to persistent abdominal and back pain. He is a retired businessman  lives with his wife  and they have two grown-up children. Mr. Doe smokes half a packet a day for the past 45 years showing a significant smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially  reports no drug abuse  and puts his current health status at ""fair.""   Past Medical History  Mr. Doe was previously diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago which he manages with a daily medication routine. He also has early-stage emphysema due to his long-term smoking habit for which he uses a bronchodilator and has slightly elevated cholesterol levels. Additionally  he has successfully treated prostate cancer through radiotherapy now five years in remission.   Family History  His father passed away at 72 years from heart disease  while his mother passed away at 65 years due to stroke. His elder brother underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in his mid-sixties. Mr. Doe has two adult children in good health.  Presenting Complaint and Evaluation  Mr. Doe complained of sharp  intense pain in his abdomen and lower back ongoing for the past week that made him come to the clinic. Physical examinations revealed a pulsating mass in his abdomen along with hypertension. A subsequent ultrasound confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5cm. His blood work showed slightly elevated white blood cell count  but all else within normal limits.  Summary   Given the patient's age  gender  smoking history  hypertension  elevated cholesterol level  family history of AAA  and enlarged size of the aneurysm  he is at high risk for aneurysm rupture. He was subsequently referred to a cardiovascular surgeon for consultation on AAA repair options such as open repair or Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Smoking cessation and strict control of blood pressure were heavily emphasised to Mr. Doe. Furthermore  his close relatives (children) are also advised to undergo a screening ultrasound due to the familial tendency of AAA.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. Richard W Age: 65-year old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired salesman  Presenting complaint and history of presenting complaint: Mr. Richard W. presented to the ER with a chief complaint of severe pain located in his lower back  vomiting  lightheadedness  and shortness of breath. The patient describes the onset of pain as sudden  which started around 10 hours ago.  Past medical history: Mr. W. has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) controlled with beta-blockers  statins  and bronchodilators  respectively. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago.   Complete demographics: The patient is a retired salesman from Minnesota. He has lived alone since his wife passed away two years ago. His son visits frequently but lives out of state. Mr. W. is of Caucasian ethnicity.  Family history:  Mr. W. has a family history of cardiovascular disease: his father died at the age of 58 from a myocardial infarction  and his older brother  68  was recently diagnosed with a thoracic aortic aneurysm.   Social history:  He quit smoking ten years ago but had a substantial smoking history  consuming a pack per day for 30 years. He consumes alcohol occasionally. He exercises sporadically due to his COPD but maintains an active lifestyle  and his diet is relatively balanced.   Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure was 150/95mmHg  pulse rate was 110 bpm  and he exhibited diaphoresis. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass.   Investigations and Diagnosis: Urgent ultrasonography was performed which confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The AAA was measured to be 8cm in diameter  which is suggestive of potential aortic rupture.   Plan/ Treatment:  The patient was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon for emergency repair using an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) method to prevent rupture.  Summary: This case represents a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical and family history of cardiovascular disease  who presents with a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm at high risk of rupture. His past and family medical history  combined with symptoms  lifestyle factors  and physical examination  faciliatated a quick diagnosis and immediate action. This case underscores the critical importance of comprehensive patient history and emphasizes the lethal complications an AAA can present if not identified and treated effectively.

Patient Presentation: Our patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  a retired Navy officer  presenting with intermittent abdominal and back pain that has been persistent for a last few weeks. The pain  according to the patient  is not associated with meals and does not radiate to any specific location. He described it as a pulsating  sometimes sharp  abdominal pain  worse when he sits for extended periods.   Besides these  the patient does not have any other gastrointestinal or urinary complaints  weight loss  altered bowel habits or any alarming signs of anemia  jaundish or night-time awakening due to pain. He denies recent travels  and there is no history of trauma or injury.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and has been on medication since. He also has moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which he is on inhaler therapy. There is no history of any major surgical interventions apart from a hernia repair ten years ago. The patient admits to having smoked about 20 cigarettes daily for 50 years  and quit about two years back. He stopped alcohol consumption around the same time. He denies any other substance abuse.  Family History: His father had hypertension and suffered a stroke in his 70s. The patient’s mother had diabetes and was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of sixty. He has two brothers  both hypertensive. Both the patient's children are healthy with no significant health issues.  Assessment: On physical examination  the patient is conscious  alert and seems a bit anxious. His blood pressure is 142/90 mmHg and heart rate is 72 beats per minute. His BMI is 26. He has mild pitting edema in both ankles. On auscultation  lungs are clear. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile and tender mass in the periumbilical region. No evidence of peripheral vascular disease is seen.  Workup including CBC  kidney  liver function tests  coagulation profile and urinalysis are largely within normal limits. EKG does not show any ischemic changes. The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No signs of rupture or leakage were seen.  The patient’s condition is consistent with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  most likely due to atherosclerosis given his long history of smoking and the presence of other cardiovascular risk factors.   Plan: The patient will undergo an elective surgical operation for the aneurysm  due to the increasing size and the risk of rupture. Consultation with the cardiovascular team is priority for surgical evaluation and optimization of his COPD and blood pressure prior to surgery. Counseling for cessation of smoking will also be initiated  and the patient will be properly informed about his condition and the proposed treatment plan.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Patient's Name: Mr. Brown Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension controlled with medication 2. Ex-smoker (quit 10 years ago) 3. High cholesterol  4. Diabetes type 2 managed with diet and oral medication  Key Complaints: Mr. Brown presented to the clinic complaining of persistent back and abdominal pain for the past couple of weeks. He describes the pain as a dull ache in the lower back region that sometimes radiates to the sides. He says the pain is moderate in intensity and does not reduce with over-the-counter pain medications. Additionally  Mr. Brown mentions a weakness and feeling of heaviness in his legs.  He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or any alterations in bowel or urinary habits. He does not have a history of rectal bleeding or the presence of blood in urine. He also denies any recent traumatic events.  Given the age of the patient  his past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  diabetes  and tobacco use (although he did quit)  as well as his current chief complaints  it is essential to consider an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) as a differential diagnosis. An appropriate clinical evaluation and imaging studies should be arranged to confirm or rule out the condition.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Gender: Male Age: 83  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension - Patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years and is currently on antihypertensive medications. 2. Smoking History - Former smoker who quit 8 years ago after a history of smoking one pack a day for approximately 40 years. 3. Hyperlipidemia - Patient has been managing this condition with statins. 4. Family history of cardiovascular diseases - Father suffered from a myocardial infarction  brother died due to thoracic aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient came into the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe back pain that started a few hours ago. The patient describes it as a tearing sensation that radiates to the abdominal region. He also has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain over the past few weeks. The patient reported minor weight loss and decreased appetite but no changes in bowel or urinary habits. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower extremity weakness.  These demographics  complaints  and medical history are important because they present common risk factors and symptoms for abdominal aortic aneurysm. The advanced age  male gender  hypertension  smoking history  hyperlipidemia  and family history of cardiovascular diseases serve as risk factors. The back pain radiating to the abdomen  the chronic nature of abdominal pain  and associated symptoms such as loss of appetite and weight loss are key symptoms often observed in patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. This case provides an opportunity for medical students to learn about potential presentations  considerations  and procedures related to the diagnosis and management of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Allen Thompson   Age: 70 years old   Sex: Male   Occupation: Retired engineer   Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian   Language: English   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson is a retired engineer  who has never consumed alcohol or used illicit drugs but has a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years which he quit about 10 years ago. He has a documented history of— 1. Hypertension  well-controlled on medication  2. Hyperlipidemia  3. Type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  4. One episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years back.  Family History: His father died at 67 years due to a sudden  fatal rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His mother died due to old age with no significant health issues. He has one brother who was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Thompson presents to the clinic with recently evolving mild to moderate abdominal pain that he describes as dull and constant which increases after eating. He reports occasional lower back pain and having noticed a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  but initially dismissed as unrelated. No history of fever  cough  chest pain  or difficulty in breathing. He explains that he has unintentionally lost about 10 pounds over the last two months and his appetite has reduced significantly.  He reports history of irregular bowel movements for the last three weeks. No history of altered bowel habits  blood in stools  or black tar-like stools. No history of altered urination.   No history of recent trauma or surgical procedures. He has been feeling fatigued more than usual and didn’t think much of it until the abdominal discomfort became persistent. He’s reluctant and worried due to his father’s history of abdominal aortic aneurysm.
