Past Medical History: Mr. Jack has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and Hypertension for the last 15 years. He also has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago.  Family History: His father died due to an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Jack appears visibly distressed due to pain. He is obese with a Body Mass Index of 30. His pulse is 110 beats/minute  blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate is 20 breaths/min. On palpating his abdomen  a pulsating mass is felt in the umbilical region. His pulses in bilateral lower extremities are symmetrically normal.  Suspected Diagnosis: With the background of hypertension  history of excessive smoking  obesity  the sudden onset of abdominal and back pain along with the physical exam findings and family history  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is suspected. Immediate investigation and management are critical due to the high risk of life-threatening rupture.   Next steps: Urgent Abdominal Ultrasound and CT angiography for confirmation and assessment of AAA. If AAA is confirmed  the location and size of the aneurysm will determine the mode and urgency of treatment  with surgical intervention being a likely course of action considering the patient's symptoms.

Patient Information -------------------------------- Name: John Doe Age: 70 years  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired accountant  Medical History ----------------------- John has a significant medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 50-pack-year smoking history  having quit smoking 10 years ago. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease (his father died of a myocardial infarction at 72).  Presenting complaint --------------------------- John has arrived at the emergency department (ED) after becoming symptomatic at his home. He reports a sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal and lower back pain over the last few hours  which has significantly worsened over time. He describes it as the worst pain he has ever felt. The pain is continuous and not related to meals or physical activities. He also mentions a feeling of his 'heart beating in his belly’ over the past few weeks.   John reports feeling light-headed today and has experienced episodes of syncope. He denies chest pain  dyspnea  altered bowel habits  or urinary changes. His wife adds that he has been fatigued over the past week  and there has been unintentional weight loss of about 5 kilograms over the past month. John looks pale and diaphoretic during the examination.  This brief clinical scenario is suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  possibly with impending rupture  given John's age  significant risk factors  and the presence of subjective and objective signs. It's an effective way to introduce students to the symptoms  high-risk individuals  and emergency nature of AAA.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  - Age: 73 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Engineer  - Ethnicity: Caucasian   Chief Complaints:  The patient came in complaining of persistent abdominal pain for the past several days  specifying that the discomfort was notably located in the mid-abdominal region. Additionally  the patient reported feeling intermittent episodes of back pain.   HPI (History of Present Illness):  The pain has been consistently present for about five days and appears to be gradually amplifying. The patient described the pain as throbbing  persistent  and intense enough to disrupt his daily activities. The patient denied any recent physical injuries  abdominal trauma  or heavy lifting.  The patient has also noted a feeling of fullness in the abdomen and a noticeable  pulsating mass while in a sitting or lying position. The patient has not reported any concomitant symptoms such as weight loss  loss of appetite  change in bowel movements  or urination  or fever.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of high blood pressure  and high cholesterol levels and is currently under medication (Losartan 50mg daily for Hypertension and Atorvastatin 40mg for Hyperlipidemia). Further  the patient has been a moderate smoker for 50 years (1 pack per day) but quit 5 years ago. He also has a sedentary lifestyle and a familial history of cardiovascular diseases.  Surgical history reveals an appendectomy 30 years prior.  Conclusion:  The patient’s age  smoking history  high blood pressure  high cholesterol levels  family history  and the reported abnormally pulsating mass in the abdomen all contribute to the presumptive diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. However  further examination  such as an ultrasound or CT scan  would be needed to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Information: Mr. William Thompson  a 74-year-old African American retired teacher  is presently living in Chicago with his wife.   Past Medical History: He has a history of high-blood pressure for the last 20 years and is under medication. He is also a former smoker  having quit smoking 10 years ago but he smoked one pack per day for approximately 25 years. He has a past history of high cholesterol which is currently under control with medication. There is no significant family history of any cardiac or kidney disorders. He is not diabetic and does not have asthma.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson visited the clinic with the primary complaint of a continuous pulsating sensation in his lower abdomen which he noticed about two weeks ago. He also mentioned that he occasionally experiences mild abdominal and lower back pain  which he initially thought was due to his old age. He has noticed an unintentional weight loss over the past month and has reported feeling fatigued and dizzy recently. Additionally  he complained about occasional bouts of constipation. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.   Considering the above information  you have a strong suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in Mr. Thompson  and decide to investigate further. This case aims to guide students through the differential diagnosis and management of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Information: John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired army officer  residing in Austin  Texas.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reports experiencing intermittent abdominal pain of moderate intensity associated with episodes of lightheadedness for the past three weeks. The pain was originally diffuse but has localized to the lower abdomen over time. However  no associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  weight loss or changes in bowel habits are reported.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with medication  for the past ten years. He is also a former smoker  consuming a pack per day for 30 years  but successfully quit 5 years ago. There is no family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Past Surgical History: No previous surgeries.  Medications: Daily antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril 10 mg) and a statin (Atorvastatin 20 mg).  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Review of Systems: Negative except contributing to the presenting complaint.  Physical Examination: BP: 146/90 mmHg  HR: 95 bpm  regular  RR: 18/min  Temp: 98.6°F. Abdominal palpation revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid- and upper-abdominal region  no bruits were noted. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical.  Psychosocial History: Lives with his wife  denies any alcohol consumption and has been a non-smoker for the past 5 years.  This summary could be followed by a series of actions including preliminary differential diagnoses  lab investigations  imaging  further management and possible outcomes. The primary goal should be about teaching students of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  its risk factors  manifestations  diagnostic approaches and management.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department. He is a retired civil engineer who lives alone. Mr. Johnson is a long-term smoker (50 pack-years) and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a significant history of hypertension with marginal control  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  dyslipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - his father died of a myocardial infarction at an age younger than Mr. Johnson's present age  and a younger brother was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Johnson was brought to the emergency department due to sudden severe  tearing abdominal pain radiating to the back. Accompanied with this  he reports symptoms of syncope  general malaise  and intense sweating. He states the pain started about 2 hours prior to arrival and has been worsening in intensity. On further questioning  Mr. Johnson also mentioned that he had been experiencing a vague abdominal discomfort and low-back pain for several weeks  which he attributed to aging and his previous lower back problems.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  Mr. Johnson appears anxious  and pale. His blood pressure on presentation is 90/60 mmHg  heart rate is regular but rapid at 108 bpm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths/minute  and the oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass. His peripheral pulses are equally diminished.  Given Mr. Johnson's background  his family history  and his current presentation with severe abdominal and back pain along with hypotension  the clinical suspicion is towards the rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is quickly referred for a computed tomography (CT) scan to confirm the suspicion. Appropriate management should take place subsequently depending on the results and the patient's condition.

Patient Information:  Mr. Edward Hyde  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presented to the outpatient department.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Hyde has a history of 20 years of uncontrolled hypertension and a 50-pack year smoking history. He is known to have high cholesterol levels and peripheral vascular disease. No known allergies are reported. His surgical history includes a partial right hip replacement as a result of a work-site accident 12 years ago. Inherits no known familial diseases.   Present Complaints: Mr. Hyde came in reporting the presence of consistent  dull  abdominal pain for the past few weeks  which had worsened in the last three days. The pain is located in the center of his abdomen and radiates to his lower back. He describes a feeling of fullness in his abdomen. He also noted unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the last 2 months despite a good appetite. He reported no changes in bowel movements  no difficulty swallowing  and no nausea or vomiting. Mr. Hyde has also been feeling fatigued for the past month which he initially attributed to his age. He also reported occasional shortness of breath while climbing stairs. He has no known diabetes but reports a recent pattern of frequent urination.   The patient's history and presenting complaints suggest a potential diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The persistent  radiating abdominal pain  feeling of fullness  weight loss  and fatigue could indicate a possible rupture. His risk factors include advanced age  gender  long-term hypertension  history of smoking  high cholesterol levels  and peripheral vascular disease. Prompt diagnostic steps and further evaluation are crucial due to the life-threatening progression of a potentially ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Case Report:  Demographics:  Mr. Perkins  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  presents at the emergency room. He is a non-smoker with light alcohol use. He lives with his wife and enjoys gardening in his leisure time.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Perkins has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled on medication for 15 years. Family history includes his father who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 77.  Key Complaints:  The patient describes a sudden severe mid-abdominal pain that started two hours ago  which he rates as 9/10 on the pain scale. The pain is continuous  radiating to his back  and is not associated with a meal or change in position. He also mentions feeling unusually lightheaded and a severe  almost claustrophobic discomfort.  On examination  the patient is in significant distress  looks pale  and is diaphoretic. An abdominal examination reveals an expansile  pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area. His peripheral pulses are weak  and blood pressure is slightly on the lower side.   Given his age  risk factors  symptoms  family history  and physical examination findings  his clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate imaging  surgical consultation  and appropriate management would be crucial in his case; otherwise  rupture of the aneurysm could have disastrous consequences.

Patient Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Alberto Ferrari  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired automobile mechanic. He is a resident of Rome  Italy living with his wife. He is a non-smoker and an occasional drinker. He has been active throughout his life and currently enjoys gardening and walking his dog.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Ferrari was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia ten years ago  but both are well controlled with medication (Losartan and Atorvastatin). He had a brief episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 5 years back  post which he has been on an Aspirin regimen. His father had suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and passed away due to its rupture. Mr. Ferrari's body mass index (BMI) is within a reasonable range and he has no known drug allergies.  Main Reasons for Seeking Medical Help: Mr. Ferrari came to the hospital's emergency department with a main complaint of sudden severe abdominal pain which he describes as ""tearing"" in nature. The pain started approximately a couple hours ago and has progressively worsened  radiating to the lower back and discomfort in the legs. He also reports feelings of light-headedness and has vomited a couple of times since the pain began. He is worried due to his father’s medical history.  This case report sets the scene for an abdominal aortic aneurysm case. The following education course is intended for a detailed analysis and discussion about signs and symptoms  diagnostic methods  risk factors  and treatment options for AAA  with a particular emphasis on emergency management in case of a rupture.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presents to the office with his daughter.  Medical History: Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  40-pack-year smoking history but quit 9 years ago. He has undergone two skin cancer surgeries. Family history shows that his father died from a ruptured AAA at age 77.  Chief Complaint: Over the past three weeks  his daughter has noticed a slight decrease in her father's appetite and occasional complaints of a dull  localized  abdominal pain. Mr. Doe has also mentioned feeling a ""pulsing"" sensation in his stomach  which he self-attributed to being more aware of his heartbeat due to anxiety. He denies weight loss  melena  hematochezia  chest pain  or shortness of breath. He has had no changes in bowel movements and no urological symptoms.  Physical Exam: On examination  he is a well-appearing older man. Vital signs are stable: Blood pressure is 158/95 mmHg  heart rate is 78 bpm  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  body mass index is 26 kg/m2  and body temperature is 98.6 F (37.0 C). He has a non-tender  pulsatile mass palpated in the midline of the abdomen. Remaining examination  including cardiovascular and respiratory systems  is non-contributory.    This patient's history and physical examination  specifically the non-tender  pulsatile abdominal mass  put him at high suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Urgent abdominal ultrasound will be crucial to confirm this diagnosis and assess its severity. Later  a CT scan may be necessary for further evaluation and pre-surgical planning if aneurysm repair is indicated. If the diagnosis of AAA is confirmed  the patient's high blood pressure and lipid levels  alongside his history of smoking and familial predisposition  should be addressed as part of a holistic management plan.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and has been a smoker for the past 50 years. He had previously been diagnosed with a small abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) 3 years ago which has been monitored with yearly ultrasonography. His father also died of a ruptured AAA  indicating the presence of a familial risk.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith presents to the hospital emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal and back pain  along with a sensation of pulsating mass in his abdomen. According to him  the pain seemed to start suddenly  it radiated to his back and has been continuous for the last few hours. He denies any associated symptoms or trauma. He appeared pale  sweaty  and in noticeable discomfort.  Further important screening tests and management strategy will be discussed in due course during the diagnosis  treatment and management part of the case training.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith  an 70 years old Caucasian male   Past Medical History:   Patient has a significant history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and 40-pack year history of smoking. No history of diabetes  kidney failure  or any other comorbid chronic conditions. No prior history of surgeries.  Key Complaints:   Mr. Smith visits the clinic complaining of intermittent  nonspecific  abdominal and back pain which has been occurring for the past three weeks. Patient also describes an unexplained recent weight loss and feeling of fullness after eating small meals. He denies experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  dizziness  nausea  or vomiting. He also denies any changes in bowel habits or urinary symptoms.

Patient Information:   Mr. Jeffery Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  married with three children  currently residing in Chicago  Illinois.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years and has been a cigarette smoker for approximately 50 years  about a pack a day. His other past medical history includes hypercholesterolemia  mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases  especially his father who died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his early 70s.  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Smith is at the clinic for his routine appointments. He has been taking his hypertension and cholesterol medications regularly but has been experiencing occasional back pain and discomfort for the past few couple of weeks. He also mentions that he has been feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  which he noticed accidentally. However  he denies any history of weight loss  loss of appetite  or any other systemic symptoms.  For teaching purposes  the students should be guided to explore the patient's cardiovascular risk factors  clarify the details of his back pain and abdominal pulsations  discuss the relevance of his family history  and engage in routine examination to determine whether further work-up would be appropriate for potential abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further abdominal palpation in conjunction with appropriate imaging studies such as/like abdominal ultrasound can be deliberated. This case can also serve as an opportunity to discuss preventive measures such as smoking cessation.

Patient Information: Mr. Patrick Wilson  Male  68 years old  Caucasian  retired school teacher   Chief Complaint: Severe  sudden onset pain in the middle or lower part of the abdomen  unexplained weight loss  and an uncomfortable pulsating sensation in the abdomen.  Past Medical History: Tobacco use for 30 years (quit 5 years ago)  diagnosed with essential hypertension 8 years ago  and a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm. No documented allergies. He is currently on antihypertensive medication and a lipid-lowering drug.  Case Description: Mr. Wilson arrives at the Emergency department with his wife  complaining about sudden  severe pain in his mid to lower abdomen region. He describes the pain as 'tearing' and mentions that it began about 3 hours ago. He mentions that he has had mild discomfort in his abdomen previously  associated with a pulsating sensation. He has also noticed a substantial weight loss over the past month  without any changes in diet or exercise. Upon questioning  Mr. Wilson reveals his past medical history and his use of tobacco  although he quit it five years ago.   His vitals at present are: B.P - 168/92 mmHg  HR - 112  Temp - 98.6 °F  Respiration rate - 22  Oxygen saturation - 97%. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Initial Assessment: These symptoms and findings suggest an underlying abdominal aortic aneurysm. It is pertinent to conduct necessary diagnostic tests  such as an abdominal ultrasound or CT scan  to confirm the diagnosis. The history of hypertension and smoking further increases his risk of an aneurysm. The sudden  severe abdominal pain  coupled with the patient's history and examination findings  suggests a possible rupture  which  if not managed immediately  can be life-threatening.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  Mr. Jones  a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient complains of persistent abdominal pain and back pain that has lasted for approximately two weeks. He has noted that the pain becomes more intense after meals and occasionally feels a palpable abdominal mass.  Past Medical  Surgical  Social and Family History:  He has had a 20-year history of high blood pressure  for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide. He also has a history of smoking about 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years  although he quit smoking 10 years ago. He reports moderate alcohol consumption of one drink per day. He has no previous surgical history. His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 75.  Medication:  Hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension.  Physical Examination:   BP: 150/90  HR: 85 bpm  Temp: 98.6°F  RR: 16/min  BMI: 27  Abdominal exam reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient exhibits tenderness on palpation. Bowel sounds are present. No other abnormal physical findings.  Based on the initial examination and the patient's medical history  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was suspected. A CT scan should be ordered to confirm.   This student case is designed to highlight risk factors (age  male sex  smoking history  hypertension  family history)  classic symptoms (abdominal pain  back pain  palpable abdominal mass)  and steps to confirm the diagnosis for learning about AAA. An emphasis on early detection  careful monitoring and elective surgery before rupture is important in the subsequent management discussion.

Case Presentation:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  residing in Ontario  Canada.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith is a known hypertensive and smoker for the past 50 years. He also has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. There's no known allergy reported. He has high cholesterol levels and is currently under medication. His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at 72.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset severe abdominal pain radiating to his back for the past 12 hours. The pain  initially negligent  has progressively worsened over time. There is no history of trauma. He reports feeling pulses in his stomach  mild nausea  but no vomiting  changes in bowel or bladder habit or fevers. He has never experienced similar pain before. He does not report any loss of weight  changes in appetite  or any other systemic symptoms.   Emergency medical technicians reported that he looked pale and sweaty on arrival. His vital signs included BP 150/90 mmHg  pulse 85 bpm  temperature: 98.2°F  and respiration: 20 breaths per minute.   This case presentation is deliberately ambiguous at this stage to open discussion regarding differential diagnoses (including AAA  renal colic  myocardial infarction  pancreatitis  etc.). Further exploration  physical examination  and appropriate diagnostic tests will lead towards a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a BMI of 28  presents to the clinic. He's a retired construction worker  a widow living alone  and has two adult children. He's a former smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has been previously diagnosed with Hypertension (controlled with Amlodipine)  Hypercholesterolemia (taking Simvastatin)  and a history of mild obesity. His surgical history is significant for an appendectomy in his early 20s. He had a smoking history of 30 pack years but quit 10 years ago. His father died in his late 60’s of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).   Chief Complaints: Over the past two months  Mr. Doe has been experiencing mild to moderate  intermittent abdominal pain  localized in the center and slightly towards the left. The pain does not radiate  and there is no noticeable pattern with eating or bowel movements. He describes it as a dull ache and denies any associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or changes in bowel habit. He also reports that he has noticed an unusual pulsation feeling in his abdomen while he is lying down.   He does not have any symptoms of palpitations  chest pain  dyspnea  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  edema  claudication or syncope. However  he does report a recent weight loss of around 4 kilograms in the last 2 months but he attributes it to better dietary control. He denies any changes in appetite  fever  night sweats  urinary or mental symptoms.  He has no known allergies and his vaccinations are up-to-date. He visits his primary physician for regular check-ups.  On this basis of the case history  an investigation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) should be initiated  considering his age  sex  past medical history  and familial predisposition. The symptom of perceived pulsation may correspond with the aneurysm's growth.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: Mr. Richard Miller  a 67-year old African American male  retired construction worker  presents during a routine checkup.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of smoking two packs a day for 40 years but quit five years ago. He is known to have hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He also has hypercholesterolemia  managed with statins (Atorvastatin). Relevant family history includes his father who died suddenly at the age of 70 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Chief Complaint: Patient reports intermittent lower back pain over the past 4 months; he attributes it to his past line of work and age. He takes over-the-counter NSAIDs  which provides minimal relief. He also mentions occasional  vague abdominal discomfort. No history of fever  weight loss  other systemic complaints  or conditions that could cause increased pressure on the aorta  such as COPD.  During the current visit  the patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg (despite compliant with medication)  heart rate is 76 bpm  and all other vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals a mildly pulsatile abdominal mass. A bruit is heard on auscultation over the mass.  [Given the risk factors and clinical presentation  a suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is raised and the patient is referred for further diagnostic imaging.]  This educational case focuses on the importance of recognizing nonspecific symptoms such as back pain and vague abdominal discomfort in older individuals with risk factors (smoking  hypertension  and family history). Early detection is crucial in managing a potentially life-threatening abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Case: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: The patient is a 70-year-old African American male named Charles. He resides in an urban area and is a retired truck driver. Charles is single and lives alone with limited support from distant relatives.   Past Medical History:  Charles has a significant past medical history including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from a 30+ year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day (quit smoking 10 years ago)  hypertension that is generally well-controlled with medication  and obesity (Body Mass Index =30.3 kg/m2). Additionally  he has a family history of vascular pathology and his father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture when he was in his mid 70s.  Presenting Complaints:  Charles came to the clinic for his regular check-up but reported recent onset of vague and intermittent abdominal pain and lower back discomfort spanning over the past couple of months  which he initially attributed to arthritis. The pain appears unrelated to meals or physical activity.   Key Symptoms for Consideration: 1. Intermittent abdominal and lower back pain 2. Long history of hypertension 3. Chronic history of smoking 4. Family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm   To summarize  Charles represents a typical demographic who can potentially develop an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The medical students should identify his risk factors and symptoms  pointing out the importance of considering abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients with such demographic data and presenting complaints  and the necessity of effective clinical and diagnostic investigations.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 72 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanical engineer Residency: Urban Midwest  Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension which is well-controlled with medication. He is also moderately overweight with a BMI of 28. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking ten years ago. Over the last few months  he has been showing high cholesterol levels. There is no history of diabetes or any other cardiovascular diseases.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson has come to the hospital with complaints of persistent and intermittent abdominal pain for the past three weeks. The pain is located around the umbilical region and often radiates to the lower back  but does not seem eating-related. He has also been feeling an unusual pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He describes the intensity as moderate to severe.   Additionally  he reported recent unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite. Mr. Johnson denies any changes in bowel habits  urinary symptoms  or any symptoms relating to his chest.  The patient has been feeling increasingly fatigued and notes that the pain often intensifies during physical activity. Intriguingly  he mentioned that he also feels the abdominal pain when he's lying flat  which momentarily eases upon sitting up.   To note  there has been no trauma or injury to the abdominal region  nor does Mr. Johnson recall any similar previous episodes. His last routine physical examination was approximately 6 months ago with no alarming findings.  This case requires a high degree of suspicion for an underlying Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  given the patient's age  gender  smoking history  hypertension status  and symptomatic presentation. An urgent comprehensive examination is in order to confirm this diagnosis and initiate appropriate management.

Patient Information:   Mr. A  a 72-year-old Caucasian male from rural areas  retired army officer  is brought to the emergency department by his son with the chief complaint of sudden onset severe abdominal and lower back pain for the past 4 hours.   His past medical history is notable for long-term smoking over 30 years (currently smoked at least a half pack per day)  uncontrolled hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has no surgeries in the past. He is on antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medication as well as inhalers for his COPD but admits that he has not been compliant with his medications. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  his father died after suffering a cardiac arrest at the age of 60  and his older brother had a history of peripheral artery disease.  Present Complaint:  The pain is described as severe  10/10  and tearing in nature that started in his belly where he pointed to his belly button but has since moved to his lower back. The pain was sudden  didn’t radiate  and nothing makes it better or worse. He has also complained of generalized malaise  nausea  loss of appetite  and involuntary weight loss over the last month. There is no history of trauma  fever  chest pain  palpitations  cough  or urinary problems. He admits his abdomen has been growing larger in size over the last few months  but he thought it was related to his weight gain due to his decreased physical activity from COPD. There are no known drug allergies.   These symptoms raise suspicion for an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) given the sudden onset of severe abdominal and lower back pain  history of long-term smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol level  family history of cardiovascular disease  and the patient's age. The lack of trauma history and presence of generalized malaise  loss of appetite  and weight loss further increases the suspicion. Immediate medical attention and imaging studies are required at this point to confirm the presence of an AAA and assess its severity to manage it appropriately.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  an 80-year-old Caucasian male  presents himself to the Emergency Department. He is a retired army officer and currently a resident of the City of Jackson  Mississippi. The patient is married with three adult children and lives with his wife. He has been a non-smoker for the past 15 years after a 40-year history of smoking. He has a BMI of 27  denoting overweight.  Medical History:  The patient has a known history of Hypertension for the past 20 years  controlled with routine medications  namely Lisinopril and Amlodipine. He also has a history of Hyperlipidemia. There is no known history of any cardiac illnesses or endocrine disorders. There are no known allergies. The patient has had an appendectomy done 40 years ago. He is regularly followed up by his primary physician for the management of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and is generally compliant with medication.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Doe reported to the emergency department complaining of abrupt onset  severe  and constant abdominal pain for the past 6 hours. He describes it as a 'ripping' sensation that also radiates to his lower back. He also mentioned feeling lightheadedness but denies any loss of consciousness. He does not report any associated nausea  vomiting  change in bowel movements  or urinary symptoms. There have been no alterations in appetite or weight recently.   This brief case report sets the stage for the discussion and diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  considering the demographic data  medical history  and the presenting complaints of the patient. This case can be further expanded according to the educational needs  discussing the possibilities of differential diagnosis  additional required investigations  management plan and potential complications of the disease.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Mr. Robertson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired mechanic. He is a long-time smoker  with a history of a 40-pack-years smoking. He lives with his wife  is independent in his activities of daily living  and generally maintains good health. His father had a history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and died following a rupture at the age of 65.  Past Medical History: Mr. Robertson is previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia and is on medications including Amlodipine and Atorvastatin. His other past medical history includes appendectomy in his mid-20s and a broken arm in his late 60s. He has no known allergies. Mr. Robertson has refused annual ultrasound screening for AAA  despite having several risk factors.  Chief Complaints: He presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset  severe abdominal pain that started few hours ago. The pain is central and radiating to his back. He also reports feelings of faintness and anxiety. He denies having chest pain  palpitation or shortness of breath.  On examination  a pulsatile mass is noticed in the periumbilical area  which is tender on palpation. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and pulse is 110/min.  Given his history and symptoms  an emergency ultrasound is ordered suspecting a ruptured AAA. The ultrasound reveals a 7.1 cm AAA indicating an impending rupture. The patient is immediately taken to the operation theatre for surgical intervention.   This case would be a beneficial study for medical students to understand the risk factors  symptoms  and immediate intervention required in the case of AAA  especially in patients who refuse routine screenings despite being at high risk.

Patient Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics: - Name: John Doe - Age: 72-years-old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired factory worker - Pressent Address: Virginia  Past Medical History: - The patient has a history of hypertension for the past 15 years controlled with Lisinopril. - Patient has a 45 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. - Former history of high cholesterol  controlled by statins. - No known allergies - No past surgery or significant family history  Presenting Complaints: - The patient came in with a complaint of continuous  throbbing pain in his lower back and abdomen for 3 days.  - He characterizes the pain as a severe  pulsating sensation that came on suddenly and has gradually worsened over time. - The pain is 7/10 on the pain scale and radiates to his flank and groin. - He denies any changes in bowel or bladder habits  nausea  vomiting  fever  or weight loss.  - He also mentions that he feels a pulse in his belly.   This short profile of a patient living with an abdominal aortic aneurysm is designed to help medical students learn to handle the condition in a real-world scenario. The case highlights the common symptoms of the disorder  as well as factors  like smoking and hypertension that increase the risk of developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  The goal through this case is for students to understand how to diagnose and treat this potentially life-threatening condition promptly.

Case:  Demographics: Mr. Jackson  age 72  Caucasian male  retired construction worker  non-smoker  social drinker  BMI of 27  lives with wife  two children (now adults)  present a regular exercise regimen.  Past Medical History: Hypertension diagnosed at 60  hyperlipidemia diagnosed at 65  currently managed with medication. Both father and elder brother had a history of cardiovascular disease. No history of surgeries  allergies  or medications other than for hypertension and hyperlipidemia.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Jackson presents with complaints related to moderate to severe pain in the abdomen  particularly the middle and lower abdomen  which he describes as a ""pulsating sensation"". His appetite has been negatively affected over the past week  leading to weight loss. He also reports feeling fatigued and occasional lightheadedness. He mentioned that the pain seems to get severe after meals and decreases while lying down.   The patient's pain severity and the pulsating nature of the discomfort raises suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). AAA should be considered in all older adults with abdominal pain or back pain  particularly those with risk factors such as advanced age  male sex  smoking  and a history of cardiovascular disease. If AAA is suspected  refer for emergency care to prevent rupture.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Name: John Doe Age: 68 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired police officer  Medical History: John is an ex-smoker who quit 15 years ago after smoking a pack a day for 30 years. He has a known history of hypertension that is managed with a beta-blocker (Atenolol) and an ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril). He also has a history of high cholesterol which is controlled with a statin (Atorvastatin). John has a sedentary lifestyle and a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his older brother had a stroke at the age of 65.  Key Complaints: John came into the clinic for a routine medical check-up as he is experiencing some nonspecific complaints: He reports a feeling of fullness in his belly  vague abdominal discomfort  and occasional lower back pain for the past three months that haven't escalated but also haven't dissipated. These symptoms do not seem to relate to any specific trigger and haven't responded to over-the-counter pain killers. He also notes unintentional weight loss over the past 6 months. Vital signs are stable and he doesn’t display distress. He denies any sharp or radiating abdominal pain  pulsations in the abdomen  loss of consciousness  chest pain  nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  constipation  dysuria  or hematuria. The patient also denies any calf pain or discoloration of his extremities.  Conclusion: Based on his age  sex  and family history of cardiovascular disease along with risk factors like cigarette smoking  hypertension  hypercholesteremia  and his symptoms  John should be evaluated for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Physical examination to inspect the abdomen and palpate for an aneurysm should be conducted. Depending on the assessment  further ultrasound imaging might be required.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics: - Name: Anonymous - Age: 71-years-old  - Sex: Male  - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired accountant   Past Medical History:  - High Blood Pressure (uncontrolled - patient is non-compliant with medication) - Smoking: 1.5 packs/day for 45 years (quit 4 years ago) - Peripheral Vascular Disease  - No previous surgeries  - Family history of heart disease (Father died of myocardial infarction at 68  mother had stroke at age 70)  Key Complaints:  - Came in for a routine physical check-up - Occasional mild to moderate discomfort in the abdominal region over the last couple of weeks - Brief episodes of light-headedness and dizziness over the past week  - Reports occasional back pain  Note: Case aims to highlight that abdominal aortic aneurysms often have no obvious symptoms. This patient's symptoms are vague but could indicate an aneurysm if correlated with the right elements from the patient's history and physical examination. These symptoms can be caused by slow growth and steady pressure on the wall of the aorta. The history of smoking  high blood pressure  and peripheral vascular disease increase the patient's risk.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  John Doe  a 75-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of high blood pressure (hypertension) and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. The patient has been treated for 10 years with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor for his hypertension and a statin for hyperlipidemia.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Doe presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset  severe 'tearing' pain in his lower back and abdomen that has persisted for the past three hours. He has noted an increase in intensity over the time. He has not had any similar episodes before. He also reports light-headedness and a rapid heartbeat but denies chest pain  shortness of breath  lower limb weakness or loss of consciousness. He also denies having any fever  recent infections  or trauma.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appears anxious and distressed. His blood pressure is 160/80 mmHg in the right arm and 155/78 in the left  pulse rate is 110 bpm  and respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-epigastric area. The pain is reproduced on palpation of the mass. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Please note that this training case is designed to provide medical students with an understanding of abdominal aortic aneurysm - its risk factors  presentation  examination findings  and the urgent need for referral and treatment. The patient's detailed past medical history and current signs and symptoms should guide the student in developing a strong clinical suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Case Report:  Patient Presentation: Mr. Henry Thompson  a 72-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic for a routine check-up.  Demographics: Mr. Thompson is a retired school teacher who lives with his wife. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but has a 40-pack year history. He only drinks alcohol occasionally in social settings.  Past Medical history: His past medical history is significant for hypertension  well controlled with medication (Losartan 50 mg once daily)  and moderately high cholesterol treated with Atorvastatin 20 mg once daily. He also has a longstanding history of obesity. He has no known drug allergies. He has no family history of cardiovascular disease.  Key Complaints: Mr. Thompson denies any current chest pain  shortness of breath  or exertional fatigue. However  he complains of a mild  nagging pain in the lower back that has been unremitting for the past couple of months. It feels like a dull ache and doesn't improve with rest or over-the-counter analgesics. He reports no associated weight loss  bowel or bladder changes  or traumatic injury.  He had noted a weird pulsating sensation in his abdomen occasionally but thought nothing more of it. He states he didn't report these symptoms earlier as he attributed it to his age and weight. The concern from his wife prompted him to mention it at this routine visit.  Summary: This case presents a geriatric man with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  obesity and a significant smoking history. His main complaints are chronic lower back pain and a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He denies any cardiovascular  respiratory  or urinary symptoms. Given his risk factors  there is a possible suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This case would challenge learners to consider a AAA in the differential diagnosis  prompting appropriate evaluation and management.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 70 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanic  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension – diagnosed 10 years ago  on antihypertensive medication 2. Smoking – 40 pack years history but quit around 5 years ago 3. Dyslipidemia - diagnosed 5 years ago  on lipid-lowering agents 4. No history of allergic reactions 5. No previous surgical history  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal and lower back pain which he describes as tearing in nature. The pain  according to Mr. Doe  started a few hours ago  without any provocative event  and has progressively worsened. Mr. Doe also complains of feeling generally unwell and lightheaded. He denies any chest pain  loss of consciousness  or recent trauma. He has no complaint of fever  cough  urinary problem  changes in bowel habits or weight loss.  On further questioning  Mr. Doe reports that he has noticed a pulsating lump in his abdomen for the past few months but assumed it was just due to getting older and gaining weight. He denied any previous similar episodes of abdominal or back pain  radiating pain to the legs  or recent fever.  Family history is remarkable for cardiovascular diseases including an uncle who died of a ""heart rupture"" in his early seventies.   Key learning objectives for this case would be to recognize the signs and symptoms of abdominal aortic aneurysm including risk factors  diagnostic approaches  and immediate management of the condition. The importance of rapidly managing pain and hemodynamic stabilization should be emphasized  as well as the need for immediate surgical consultation.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Introduction: Mr. James Hopkins  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  presents to the Emergency Department.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years  which is fairly well controlled with medications (Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia).   Smoking History:  He was a pack-a-day smoker for 30 years  but he quit smoking 15 years ago.   Social History:  He lives alone and denies any alcohol or illicit substance use.   Key Complaints: Mr. Hopkins complains of sudden-onset  severe lower back pain  described as a tearing sensation  which began 2 hours prior to presentation. The pain is non-radiating and has been continuous and impairing his ability to move. He also reports feeling somewhat light-headed but denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. He has not noticed any visible changes to his abdomen  such as swelling or color change.   Family History: His father died in his early 70s due to an unknown heart condition.   This patient's presentation is classical for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The medical history  particularly the history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and significant smoking history  all contribute to the suspected AAA. Its acute onset and severity are indicative of a potentially rupturing AAA  which would be a medical emergency. This case could provide an excellent opportunity for students to learn about the clinical presentation  risk factors  diagnosis  and management of AAA. It is essential for them to recognize this condition promptly and accurately because it is potentially life-threatening.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Barker Age: 72 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Engineer Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled by medication (taking Lisinopril 20mg/daily) and hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin 40mg/daily. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 10 years ago. He also underwent angioplasty for coronary artery disease three years ago. Mr. Barker underwent a cholecystectomy in his 50's  but otherwise  there was no history of other serious diseases. No family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Barker presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset  severe abdominal pain that started approximately two hours ago. He describes the pain as non-radiating  constant  and located in the middle and lower abdomen. He has felt light-headed and has vomited once since the pain began. Further  he remarks a feeling of increased pulse near his belly button.   In this case  the student should focus on the patient's age  smoking history  and hypertension  which are significant risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain  an increased pulsatile feeling near the navel  and the hemodynamic instability might suggest a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The history of coronary artery disease hints towards generalized atherosclerosis which further adds to patient's risk of having an AAA.

Case Report - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Wilson is a 69-year-old white male  retired college professor. He is a smoker with a history in high-intensity academic-related work. He is divorced  lives alone  and is relatively physically inactive.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Wilson's past medical history includes hypertension  high cholesterol for which he takes statins  and he was a chronic smoker for almost 40 years having started in his early twenties. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus which is currently being managed with oral hypoglycaemic agents. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - his father died of a myocardial infarction in his late 50s  and his brother has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Wilson presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe  sharp abdominal pain that began roughly two hours prior to arrival. The pain is 10/10 in severity  constant  beginning around his navel  and ""tearing"" towards his lower back. He also noted a brief period of dizziness and cold sweating but denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. He characterizes his pain as the worst he has ever experienced.  On further enquiry  he also admits to recent unintended weight loss and early satiety over the past six months but did not seek medical attention because he attributed these symptoms to his age and stress.  This case report provides a comprehensive history of a patient with multiple risk factors for developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm including age  family history of cardiovascular diseases  smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  and diabetes. It also presents a typical presentation of a possibly ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm with sudden onset severe abdominal pain  subjective weight loss  and early satiety. This case will aid in introducing the medical students to the complexities of diagnosing and managing an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: Name: Patient XYZ Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension – Patient has been on anti-hypertensive medication since past 10 years.  2. Smoking - Patient has a history of smoking  about one pack per day for over 30 years until he quit 5 years ago. 3. Hypercholesterolemia – Diagnosis established at age 62  patient treated with statins. 4. Family history- Father died of heart attack at age 70; older brother currently undergoing treatment for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Presenting Complaints: Patient XYZ presents with: 1. Recurrent  severe  pounding pain in his lower back  which started a week ago. Describes it as a tearing pain that is constant and not influenced by position or movement.    2. Recent unintentional weight loss (~10 lbs. over last 6 months). 3. Occasionally  the patient also complains of abdominal and/or chest pain. 4. Patient mentions feeling of a pulsating mass in his abdomen.   No indications of bowel or bladder dysfunction or lower extremity ischemia.  This case should trigger consideration for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  especially with the red flag symptom - constant  severe back pain coupled with patient's history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a significant family history. Further testing with abdominal ultrasound and CT scan may be warranted to confirm diagnosis.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics  Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 72  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Smoking Status: Ex-smoker  quit 10 years prior. Occupation: Retired Bank manager Location: Urban dwelling  Past Medical History  1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 20 years ago  under control with Amlodipine 5mg daily. 2. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 15 years ago  statin-controlled. 3. Type II Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 10 years ago  under control with Metformin. 4. Personal history of aneurysm repair in a brother. 5. No previous surgical history. 6. Has not undergone any recent radiological investigations.  Key Complaints  1. The patient reports a continuous abdominal pain which is not severe but creates discomfort. The pain  (described as a pulsating feeling) is in the center and upper part of the abdomen.  2. The patient suffers from an occasional back pain that radiates to his lower back area.  3. Fatigue  probably secondary to the burden of chronic diseases and continuous discomfort.  4. Unexplained weight loss in the last three months.  5. Reports instances of feeling lightheaded  but has had no loss of consciousness.   This case should guide medical students to explore the disease of abdominal aortic aneurysm  its risk factors  presentation  associated symptoms  and familial incidents. It will help them understand the disease process  and develop diagnostic and management plans. Learning from such case will also educate them about the importance of swift intervention to avoid lethal consequences such as rupture of the abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Information: J.D. is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  hailing from the suburbs of Boston  Massachusetts.  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with hypertension eight years ago. - Became a regular smoker at age 20 and quit at age 64. - Periodic bouts of mild lower back pain for the past few years. - His father died due to aortic aneurysm at age 70  and his primary care provider has been monitoring him for signs of the same disease.  Key Complaints: - One week of persisting abdominal pain  slightly lower than the belly button  described as a deep  pulsating feeling. - The pain seems to intensify while lying down. - He has experienced intermittent episodes of sharp  severe  tearing pain in the middle of his abdomen and lower back. - There is a reported light-headedness and difficulty standing upright without support  indicating potential hypotensive episodes. - No accompanying complaints of fever  weight loss  loss of appetite  or change in bowel habits.  Possible other nonspecific or related complaints for an advanced stage or rupture may include clammy skin  rapid heart rate  nausea  vomiting  or shock.   Clinical Decision Making: The combination of age  sex  background  family history  smoking  hypertension  and the nature of pain suggests a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Physical examination may reveal an abdominal mass that pulses with the heartbeat. Diagnostic tests  e.g.  ultrasound  CT Scan  or MRI  and immediate surgical consultation will be required. The case thus can be used to teach students about AAA pathophysiology  risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnosis  and management.

Case Report  Patient Demographics Mr. Daniel Brown  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker presented to the emergency department of our hospital.  Past Medical History Mr. Brown has been diagnosed with Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia ten years ago  controlled by medication. He has a ten-year history of tobacco use but quit five years ago. He has no history of surgical interventions. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Key Complaints Mr. Brown presented with a sudden severe abdominal pain radiating to the back  associated with nausea. He reported the pain as tearing and constant. He denied chest pain  lower limb weakness  or any recent trauma.   This case should lead students to suspect an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). In this case  the patient's history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and family history of cardiovascular disease are significant risk factors. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain radiating to the back is definitive of AAA. Once students establish a differential diagnosis that includes AAA  they should be instructed to next steps including confirmatory diagnostic tests and emergency management of a potentially ruptured AAA.

Case Report - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. John Doe. He has a history of smoking about 1 pack per day since he was in his twenties. He is a retired construction worker  widower  and lives alone.  Past Medical History: He has a known past medical history of high blood pressure and Type 2 Diabetes  both of which are being managed with medication. He also has a history of peripheral artery disease  a condition prevalent in his family. He does not regularly exercise and has a diet high in fat and cholesterol. He has never had any surgeries or serious injuries in his past.  Key Complaints: Over the last six months  Mr. Doe has experienced intermittent and non-specific abdominal pain and lower back pain. He describes the pain as intense and pulsating  especially after eating. Recently  he has noticed a feeling of fullness in the stomach even though he hasn't eaten much. Occasionally  he's had episodes of nausea. The pain seems to decrease when he lies down or sits. He reports unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the past 4 months which he attributed to loss of appetite. He also reports some difficulty in walking  which he attributes to ""old age"".  Over the past week  the intensity of the pain has increased  prompting him to seek medical attention. He expressed a fear that these symptoms could be related to his heart  as his father died of a heart attack at the age of 70.   The intent of this case study is to help medical students apply their theoretical knowledge of cardiovascular diseases  namely abdominal aortic aneurysm. It encourages in-depth examination  review of patient's history and risk factors (such as hypertension  smoking  age  family history)  correct diagnosis through physical and laboratory tests  and appropriate management of the condition.

Patient Details:  Name: John Doe Age: 71 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosis confirmed 12 years ago  being managed by oral medication - Previous smoker for 45 years  quit 6 years ago - History of high cholesterol - No known allergies - No family history of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) - No previous surgeries  Key Complaints: - The patient presents with sudden severe  sharp  and persistent pain in the lower back and abdomen. - The pain started approximately four hours prior to patient's visit  according to the patient  it was not linked to any specific event or physical trauma. - Accompanying symptoms include fainting episodes  rapid pulse  sweating  and nausea. - Patient describes pain as 8 on the scale of 10  not relieved by rest or change of position. - No known allergies  Proposed Case: Mr. John Doe  a 71-year-old retired engineer with a past medical history significant for hypertension and high cholesterol  came to the emergency department complaining of sudden and severe abdominal and back pain persisting for four hours. Upon further questioning  Mr. Doe mentioned fainting  sweating  rapid pulse  and nausea during this period. The patient was a long-time smoker  but quit 6 years ago. He does not have a family history of AAA  and his discomfort is not relieved by rest or change of position. The history and presentation of symptoms suggest a potential diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Information:  Mr. James Collins  65-year-old Caucasian Male  retired engineer. Non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Collins has a long-standing history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  managed by antihypertensive medications (ACE inhibitors) and statins respectively. He was diagnosed with early-stage COPD 3 years ago. Family history reveals that his father died of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 68.   Key complaints:  Mr. Collins presents to the clinic with constant  severe pain in his lower back and abdominal region  dissimilar to anything he has previously experienced. He described the pain as deep  throbbing  and unrelieved by position change. He also mentions occasional lightheadedness over the past week but denies any experience of syncope  palpitations  or chest pain. On further inquiry  mild unexplained weight loss over the past month is identified.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he appears in acute pain. An abdominal exam discovered a pulsatile mass in his mid-abdominal region slightly left of midline. No signs of abdominal distension  guarding  or rebound tenderness were observed. His blood pressure reading is high  around 155/90 mmHg  and pulse rate is around 90 beats per minute  regular.   Investigations: His description of symptoms and clinical findings leads us to suspect an abdominal aortic aneurysm. An immediate abdominal ultrasound followed by a CT scan if an aneurysm is found is suggested. Blood tests including full blood count  kidney function tests  and coagulation profile are also proposed.   Plan:  If the aneurysm is confirmed and measures over 5.5 cm  or if Mr. Collins displays symptoms suggestive of impending rupture  immediate surgical intervention will be required. Parallelly  close monitoring of his hypertension would be paramount. Mr. Collins also needs to be counseled on lifestyle changes  especially dietary modifications and increased physical activity to manage his risks.  This case is valuable for students to understand the presentation  risk factors  assessment  and management of abdominal aortic aneurysms in the clinical setting. It also brings awareness of the importance of familial history in the context of aneurysms.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics:  Patient is a 68-year old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for about 40 years but quit 10 years ago  and has a moderate alcohol intake.  Key Complaints:  The patient presented to the clinic with a vague  uncomfortable feeling in his lower abdominal area. He reported occasional low back pain and unexplained weight loss. The patient has noticed that he feels the pain especially after meals  walking  and other physical activities. He also mentioned that the pain seems to decrease when laying flat.  The patient further notes that he is currently not taking his blood pressure medication due to financial issues  and the recently deployed blood pressure measurements suggest moderately high readings. Despite past attempts to manage his cholesterol through diet  he has struggled to maintain a low-fat diet.   Please Note:   Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) often doesn't show symptoms unless it's close to rupturing. However  the nature of the patient’s complaints—pain in the abdominal and lower back area  unexplained weight loss  and high-risk factors such as age  smoking history  and hypertension—may point towards AAA  which should be evaluated further. AAA’s should be suspected in older patients with risk factors and new onset  unexplained abdominal or lower back pain. Rapid diagnosis and referral to a vascular surgeon are crucial.   Remaining aware of risk factors and keeping AAA on the differential diagnosis list can aid early detection and prevent catastrophic outcomes. Surgical treatment for AAA is effective  but postoperative care can be challenging with patients often needing intensive care post-surgery.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: R.M. Gender: Male Age: 71 Occupation: Retired mechanical engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian  Smoking History: 40 pack-years  Past Medical History: R.M. has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) associated with his tobacco use. Confirmation of R.M.'s COPD diagnosis was made 7 years ago with spirometry. He manages his hypertension and hyperlipidemia with amlodipine and rosuvastatin  respectively. However  patient admits to non-adherence in medication usage. R.M has no history of any previous surgical procedure.   Key Complaints: R.M. presents with a several months' history of intermittent abdominal and back pain  which he initially attributed to 'old age' and 'stress'. He also complained of unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite over the same time frame. Over the past week  R.M. noticed the pain has become more severe  constituting a sharp  tearing sensation in his lower back and abdomen. Additionally  he now feels occasional pulsations in his abdomen and has grown more concerned. He has had no changes in bowel or bladder function.  Family History: R.M.'s father died from heart disease at 75 and his mother had a stroke in her 70's. His brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm that was operated on in his 60s.  Remarks: Given R.M.'s age  gender  smoking history  and family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  he's at an increased risk for developing such condition. His complaints of persistent  severe pain  along with the noticeable pulsations in his abdomen  are alarming symptoms that call for immediate ultrasound imaging to confirm or rule out an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Demographics: - Name: Mr. James Smith - Gender: Male - Age: 65 - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: - Hypertension - Smoking (40 pack-years) - Hyperlipidemia  - Family history of vascular aneurysms  Presenting Complaint:   Mr. James Smith presents to his primary care physician office complaining of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. It has been ongoing for the past few weeks. He mentions that it's not painful but just a dull  throbbing feeling in his stomach he refers to it as ""odd."" He also reports feeling a bit of uneasiness and shortness of breath after exertion (climbing stairs or walking a short distance)  which is unusual for him. Recently  he has noticed that he gets fatigued easily. He denies any blood in stools  weight loss  or loss of appetite but mentions he feels bloated sometimes.  The above case presents a possible scenario for abdominal aortic aneurysm. Target teaching points include understanding risk factors (such as the patient's history of smoking  hypertension  and familial occurrence)  recognizing the characteristic complaint of an abdominal pulsation  working with potential symptoms of abdominal fullness  shortness of breath  and fatigue. This case provides an opportunity to discuss abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosis  the role for ultrasound in screening  management strategies and the importance of regular follow-ups for at-risk patients.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics: Name - Mr. John Doe Age  - 65 years old Sex  - Male Race - Caucasian  Occupation - Retired teacher  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with Hypertension in 2002 and has been on medication since then. History of smoking: 1 pack/day for 40 years  quit in 2012. Father died from a probable abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at age 68. No history of surgeries. No history of any other cardiovascular or respiratory disease. Regular alcohol consumption: Moderate  1-2 units/day. No known allergies.  Key Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents to the Emergency department complaining of sudden  severe back pain that began a few hours ago. The pain is constant and is described as 'tearing' in nature. He also reports a mild stomach ache and feeling fullness near his navel area. He is feeling mildly dizzy and has broken out in cold sweats. No symptoms of chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or fainting. No history of trauma. No change in bowel or urinary habits.  On physical examination  a pulsating mass is palpable in the abdomen. Despite the severity of pain  no abdominal rigidity or rebound tenderness is noted  suggesting absence of peritonitis.  Note: This case is designed to trigger the high index of suspicion required for diagnosing an abdominal aortic aneurysm  considering the key complaint and risk factors present (age  male  smoking history  family history). Its objectives are to understand the pathophysiology of an AAA  appreciate the importance of early detection and intervention  and to familiarize the students  with the management and prognosis of AAA.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male of slightly overweight build. He is a retired naval officer  currently living with his wife  and is an active smoker for 50 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a known history of hypertension for ten years which he controls with daily metoprolol. His other significant medical history includes high cholesterol controlled with statins and a minor heart attack five years ago. Importantly  Mr. Doe also has a family history of cardiovascular disorders  as his father passed away at the age of 75 due to a massive heart attack and his elder brother  aged 72  was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) last year.  Key Complaints: The patient presented in the outpatient department reporting continuing episodes of severe abdominal pain  centered in his lower back  that comes and goes for the past two weeks but has progressively worsened. He describes it as a sharp  tearing sensation. He also mentioned episodes of lightheadedness but no palpitations  chest pain  or dyspnea. On further probing  he reported feeling a pulsating mass near his navel while lying down. Mr. Doe had no changes in bowel movements  urinary habits  or significant weight loss.  Given his family history  the fluctuating pattern of abdominal and back pain  and the presence of a pulsatile mass  these could all indicate the presence of AAA. Prompt evaluation with imaging  normally ultrasound or CT angiography  should be performed for definitive diagnosis and assessment of AAA.

Patient Information: Mr. Edward Black  Male  72 years old  Caucasian. Retired engineer  smoker for 50 years  social drinker. From New York City. No known drug allergies.    Past Medical History: Record shows a history of hypertension managed with lisinopril for 20 years and high cholesterol levels managed with atorvastatin for the last 15 years. Diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  managed with metformin. No history of surgeries or major illnesses. No record of similar problems in the family. Followed vaccination schedule and no travel history in the past year. Regularly visits his primary care physician every six months for check-ups.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Black presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset severe pain in the middle and lower part of his abdomen and lower back that started around two hours ago. The pain was sudden in onset and has progressively worsened. He described it as a tearing sensation. He also feels dizzy and sweaty  but denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations. He mentions having had episodes of sharp  intermittent  lower abdominal pain for the past 3 months  which he thought was indigestion and treated with over-the-counter antacids. No weight loss  change in appetite  nausea  vomiting  alterations in bowel or bladder habits  or any other associated symptoms.   Given the patient's age  history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and long-term smoking habit  along with his current symptoms  an abdominal aortic aneurysm could be the possible cause of his abdominal and back pain  warranting immediate attention and thorough investigation  such as a computed tomography (CT) scan. Additionally  other differential diagnoses that must be ruled out include renal colic  diverticulosis  and acute pancreatitis.  Through this case  medical students should recognize the importance of obtaining a thorough history and performing a detailed physical examination  which are crucial steps in diagnosing acute abdominal conditions like an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Students should also understand the importance of recognizing the risk factors and clinical presentations for an abdominal aortic aneurysm  which can be a life-threatening condition if not treated promptly.

Patient Information:   Gender: Male Age: 65 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Construction Worker  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol  for which he takes medication regularly. He is a former smoker  who quit 15 years ago after a 30-year  one pack/day habit. His father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 75.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presents to the outpatient department with a 3-day history of intermittent  dull abdominal pain. He reports the pain to be 6/10 on the pain scale  which seems to be concentrated in the central and lower abdomen and not associated with food intake. There is no radiation of the pain. He denies any back pain  change in bowel or urinary habits  but has noted vague discomfort in his lower abdomen. He has not noticed any pulsating masses in his abdomen. He has also experienced random episodes of lightheadedness and fatigue.  This case could lead on to teaching points on the risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). For instance  hypertension  high cholesterol  family history  smoking  and increased age  all of which the patient has. It should be explained that AAA often presents with nonspecific or no symptoms. However  symptomatic aneurysms might present with abdominal or back pain. An incidental finding of a pulsatile abdominal mass on examination or using diagnostic ultrasound imaging fortifies the potential AAA diagnosis.   The management of AAA depends on the size and rate of growth  and could include watchful waiting  medical management to slow the growth  or surgical intervention which can be minimally invasive (endovascular) or open surgery. Emphasis should be on the potential fatal complication of AAA rupture that underlines the importance of early identification and management of the condition.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   Mr. William Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired plumber and war veteran  presently living alone at his residence. He is an active smoker  currently on one pack a day for the last 50 years and is a social drinker.  Past Medical History:   He's hypertensive and has a history of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  had a stent placed 10 years ago. He's been compliant with medication for the last 10 years - Aspirin  Metoprolol  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. There are no allergies reported. He’s been attending regular follow-ups and his blood pressure and cholesterol levels have been at target levels. His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at age 78.  Key Complaints:   Mr. Smith visited the ER today with a sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain that radiates to his back and flank  and he also reports a light-headedness. On enquiry  he mentions getting similar  but less intense pain in the abdomen on and off for a few months which he attributed to indigestion or a hernia.  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpated in the abdomen. His BP is 145/90 mmHg and heart rate is 110 bpm. Initial investigations including an abdominal ultrasound are ordered to confirm the suspicion of AAA  with an immediate surgical consultation.
