This case presentation can stimulate discussions on screening for AAA  risk factors  signs and symptoms  diagnostic measures and management strategies including the surgical and endovascular approaches for AAA.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  73-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Intense  persistent abdominal pain.  Present Illness: The patient was brought to the emergency department complaining of persistent abdominal and back pain which he described as a deep  intense pain. He also reported a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  similar to a heartbeat.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago and hyperlipidemia 5 years ago. He is a former smoker  having stopped 15 years ago  but reported a smoking history of 30 years. No history of Diabetes Mellitus  COPD  or kidney disease. No history of surgeries or hospitalization.  Family History: The patient's father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 77. His mother passed away due to old age at 80. His older brother has Coronary Artery Disease.  Review of Systems: Upon examination  the patient was in obvious distress from pain. His blood pressure was elevated and he had an unusually fast heart rate. The abdomen was not distended  there was a palpable pulsating mass in the abdomen.  Summary: This case is designed to assist medical students in identifying and managing abdominal aortic aneurysm. The provided information is intended to guide students toward considering AAA in differential diagnosis when an elderly patient presents with abdominal or back pain  especially with a positive family history. Additionally  it aims to enforce the direct link between diseases like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking with AAA. It is crucial to understand that prompt diagnosis and intervention is essential to prevent complications like rupture and massive internal bleeding.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mark Thompson Age: 70-year-old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer Marital status: Married Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Known hypertensive for 10 years (medication adherent); treated with enalapril Smoker; 1 pack per day for 40 years Father passed away from a ruptured aortic aneurysm at the age of 75 years. No known allergies No previously documented surgical history  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson has been having intermittent  dull abdominal pain for the past 1-2 months. It was not severe enough to seek consultation initially  but recently the pain has shifted to the lower back and seems to have increased in intensity. He also mentioned feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He has not noticed any weight loss  changes in appetite  or bowel habits. He also denies any leg pain  weakness  or difficulty walking.  ED Visit: He presented to emergency today as he suddenly started feeling lightheaded with increased severity of the abdominal and back pain. On examination  a palpable pulsating mass in the center of his abdomen was noted and he was tachycardic. No lower extremity deficits were found.  These symptoms are suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  but further investigations are needed to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate the size and extent of the aneurysm.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Frederick Johnson  a Seventy-year-old African American male  retired high-school teacher  from Cleveland  Ohio.   Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a fifteen-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both conditions being managed with antihypertensives (Lisinopril) and statins (Atorvastatin)  respectively. He is a 40-pack year smoker but quit after diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) five years ago. He denies any history of heart disease  stroke  or diabetes. His family history reveals that his father died at the age of 78 due to an undiagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson reached out to his primary care physician complaining about intermittent  gnawing abdominal pain for the past couple of weeks  not associated with meals or physical activity. The pain radiates to his lower back. He also reported unintentional weight loss but denies experiencing any changes in bowel habits  fever  night sweats  or any other systemic symptoms. He has no known drug allergies or intolerances.   On examination  a pulsatile mass was felt in the center of his abdomen slightly below the sternum  coinciding with a palpable thrill.   This case is designed to help medical students understand the presentation  risk factors  and diagnostic approach of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. It also emphasizes the importance of a detailed medical history in identifying at-risk individuals.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  - The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired engineer  a widower  and lives alone. He is a non-smoker but admits to a history of moderate daily alcohol use.   Past Medical History:  - The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been prescribed medication for both hypertension (Amlodipine 5mg daily) and hyperlipidemia (Atorvastatin 20mg at night).  - He has known allergies to sulfa-based drugs. Past surgeries include an appendectomy at the age of 28 and a cholecystectomy at the age of 45. Family history is significant for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in his late father. - The patient has also mentioned persistent onset periodic back pain over the last two months for which he has been using over-the-counter NSAIDs with minimal relief.  Presenting Complaints:  - The patient visited the emergency department with a persistent  severe abdominal pain that started abruptly  described as previously ""never felt before"". The pain had an episodic pattern that started in the flank and radiated to the groin. The severity of the pain was graded as 8 out of 10 on a pain scale. Associated symptoms include mild nausea without vomiting and mild lightheadedness.   Observations:   - The patient was noted to be slightly diaphoretic  with a palpable pulsatile mass upon a light examination of the abdomen.  This case focuses on the classic presentation of a potentially life-threatening emergency - an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupturing. It is important to educate medical students regarding the immediate actions  necessary diagnostic tools  and present surgical or non-surgical options. This case aligns well with those aspects of AAA.

Case Summary:  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Johnson Gender: Male Age: 67 years Occupation: Retired mechanic Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been hypertensive for the past 10 years and is on regular medication (once daily 50mg Atenolol). He was a smoker for around 30 years but quit 5 years ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases - his father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 74. He is also overweight with a BMI of 29.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Johnson has been experiencing a pulsating feeling in his abdomen for the past few weeks and complains of occasional back pain. He also reports feeling generally unwell  with bouts of dizziness and nausea.  On Physical Examination: Abdomen is soft and non-tender. A palpable pulsating mass felt around the center of the abdomen. Examination of peripheral pulses is normal; no evident claudication or neurological deficits present. There is no history of recent trauma.  Case Analysis:  Given the patient’s history  clinical presentation  the age of the patient  and long-standing history of hypertension  smoking  and high BMI  an abdominal aortic aneurysm could be the possible medical condition. Further investigations like an abdominal ultrasound  MRI  or CT scan might be required to obtain more clarity on the diagnosis.  Objectives for the Training Case:  By utilizing this case report  medical students should be encouraged to connect their theoretical knowledge with practical situations. With this real-life scenario  students can observe the clinical manifestations and risk factors of abdominal aortic aneurysms  review their understanding of the disease process  and learn about important diagnostic procedures and treatments in managing such a condition. The objective will be to develop skills to efficiently diagnose  manage  and discuss potential complications of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
